prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life."

responses.text:
“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

I’m elbow-deep in fondant at SugarHigh Bakery, sculpting a life-size flamingo cake for Mayor Patel’s fundraiser, when Ollie bursts through the kitchen doors, phone in hand, broadcasting my roommate’s moans on speaker. Flour plumes like fireworks. The interns freeze, piping bags dangling.

“Turn that off!” I hiss. Ollie grins. “Just keeping you updated on campus gossip, Sis.”

I grab a spatula like a sword. “You promised no chaos after the butter sculpture incident.”

He shrugs. “Promises are like gluten-free croissants—fictional.”

In forty minutes the mayor will tour the kitchen. I should worry about the flamingo’s neck stability, but now the staff is giggling, replaying Brad’s operatic yelps. My reputation—poof—icing on tile.

Desperate, I bribe Ollie with day-old macarons to delete the clip. Too late: he’s already live-streamed it. Comment ticker explodes: #FlamingoFail #BradGasms.

The mayor arrives amid digital carnage. She eyes the lopsided bird, then Ollie’s phone. A slow smile spreads. “Your social media reach is impressive. Think you can brand my campaign pastry-style?”

Ollie winks. Somehow, again, he’s detonated my life and handed me an accidental promotion.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

It’s Thanksgiving, and Grandma’s crystal goblets tremble as my little cousin repeats the announcement like a town crier. Mom pales; Dad coughs stuffing. Meanwhile, Brad—the prodigal golden boy—strolls in, shirt half-buttoned, smug as cranberry sauce.

I, the overlooked middle child, was about to present my first published research paper, printed, highlighted, stapled. Brad’s timing is flawless; the family hive rotates toward him, buzzing.

“I’m in love,” he proclaims. “Her name’s Juniper. She’s a tantric yoga instructor.” Aunt Carol gasps the way Baptists do.

Juniper materializes wearing hemp and serenity. She calls everyone “radiant soul.” Grandpa tries to hug her; she insists on an aura alignment instead. The turkey cools while Brad details their cosmic synergy—apparently loud enough for the neighbor’s ring camera to document.

I clear my throat. No one hears. Even my slideshow of micro-robotic stents sits ignored beside the gravy.

Later, Juniper curls beside me on the porch swing. “Your talk sounded brilliant,” she whispers. “Brad never stops talking over people—especially those he admires.”

Admire? The notion blooms like yeast. Maybe this holiday isn’t a total loss. Maybe next year I’ll ruin his timing instead.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

The sentence etches itself onto the margins of my enchanted diary, the one Nana warned me never to misuse. Whatever appears inside becomes truth by midnight. Ollie—oblivious to its power—scrawls the scandal in neon gel pen, laughing.

I snatch the diary. “Delete that! Brad’s my lab partner; I don’t need rumors birthed into reality.”

Ollie snorts. “Too late, ink’s dry.”

Midnight ticks closer. I’d undo it, but the diary only adds, never erases. My options: write a stronger truth to override the page. I flip to a blank spot and pen: “Brad is happily single, while Ollie spends a week mute, contemplating consequences.”

The words glow, absorbing magic like thirsty roots.

At school next day, Brad greets me with calm friendliness—no scandal attached. Ollie, however, opens his mouth and produces silence. Eyes wide, he scribbles apologies on sticky notes.

I should feel triumphant, but guilt nibbles. Power tastes metallic; even justice leaves a stain. That night I write one last line: “The diary’s magic fades, and secrets return to whispered tales.”

The page exhales glitter, then dulls—just paper again. Ollie’s voice returns. Balance restored, diary locked, lesson learned.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

In Arkadia-Complex 47, walls record everything. The state mandates auditory transparency—privacy breeds dissent, they say. I’m decyphering illegal jazz algorithms when Milo barges into my capsule.

He shouts the phrase like a detonator. Immediately, sensors flag the word SEX. Crimson warnings strobe; a morality drone clicks awake above our bunkbeds.

“Milo, shut up!” I hiss. Too late. The drone projects Brad’s citizen file: age 23, romantic permissions expired. Unauthorized copulation carries three demerits. A fourth means Memory Extraction.

Milo laughs. “Relax, Lin. I swapped Brad’s voice ID with the Minister’s son. Surveillance will crash chasing the glitch.”

Sure enough, the drone sputters, confused, then buzzes out the vent. Milo fist-bumps himself. My heart jackhammers—tampering earns exile.

“Why risk it?” I ask.

He shrugs. “Every system has a seam. Tug hard enough, it unravels.”

Midnight sirens howl as the network collapses district-wide—lights black, doors unlock. Citizens spill into corridors, tasting spontaneous freedom. Milo grins, handing me stolen jazz loops.

Outside, echoing cheers rise. Maybe my brother didn’t ruin my life tonight. Maybe he cracked it open.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

Except my brother died six months ago.

The shout comes from the attic, same playful timbre that once hijacked family dinners. I freeze on the staircase, phone flashlight quivering.

Mom’s asleep. Dad’s night shift. It’s just me and the house we can’t afford to sell.

“Ollie?” I whisper.

Floorboards creak above. Something giggles. Not quite right—like cassette tape warped in summer heat.

I climb. Dust motes swirl, catching pale moonlight through the cracked gable. In the center sits Ollie’s old ventriloquist dummy—Buttons—propped on a trunk. Its wooden mouth snaps. “Brad’s having sex!”

My lungs seize. I dumped that puppet in the river after the funeral, unable to bear its grin.

Buttons tilts its head. “Great, sister’s here to play.” The voice is Ollie’s, syllables wet with echoes.

“What do you want?”

“Room,” it croons, joints twitching. “Your body has room.”

Cold floods my spine. I backpedal, but attic door slams, latch twisting from the outside. Nails screech. Buttons lurches forward on splintered limbs.

I realize too late: some grief isn’t content to haunt memories. Sometimes it claws its way back, wearing familiar voices, hungry to live again.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life."

responses.text:
Mom’s voice ricochets up the staircase like a grenade: “Brad’s having sex!” 

Outstanding. Ten minutes before my AP Bio study group arrives, and my twin chooses this of all moments to punch his V-card—loudly. The walls in our 1970s split-level have the acoustic insulation of tissue paper; every creak of mattress is practically broadcast in Dolby Surround. 

I sprint for the breaker box. If the lights go out, maybe the groans will cease. Too late—Kara from Chemistry is already on the porch, eyebrow arched. Behind her, Gavin juggles flashcards, pretending not to hear the rhythmic thumping upstairs. 

“Group study?” Kara asks. 

“Polymerase chain reaction,” I mutter. “Emphasis on reaction.” 

Dad bursts through the garage door, golf clubs in hand. “Who switched playlists on the Alexa? That’s not smooth jazz!” 

I open my mouth to confess, but then Brad’s door swings wide. He’s backlit like some victorious gladiator, hair wild, wearing nothing but my lab goggles. Beside him, Melissa—my longtime crush—waves apologetically. 

My life, meet dumpster fire. I yank the breaker. Darkness swallows the house, silencing everything but Dad’s swearing.

Somewhere inside the blackout, I find a grin. AP Bio just got extra credit in survival instincts.

“Brad’s having sex!” echoes through the titanium corridors of the generational starship Argo like a klaxon. 

Great. My brother’s hormonal fireworks are now the most exciting event on Deck 7, and I’m the junior systems officer on duty. Regulations say all non-marital reproduction attempts must be logged, because resources are rationed; I’m supposed to record his…performance metrics. 

I hurry toward Habitat Cylinder C, dodging zero-G chess pieces drifting from the rec room. Behind me, gossip drones—literal drones—follow, live-streaming to the bored masses. 

Outside Brad’s pod, an “ENGAGED” light blinks magenta. Through the fogged viewport I glimpse limbs, star-mapped freckles, and a tangle of privacy sheets violating air-flow protocol. 

I ping the intercom. “Lieutenant Bradley Mora, this is Logan from Population Control. Please confirm contraception compliance.” 

“Busy!” comes the breathless reply. 

I log a citation. A moment later the ship lurches—external asteroid alarm. Everyone bolts for stations except Brad, who is, well, bolted. I override his door, yank them into the hallway, and shove helmets over their shocked faces. 

When the rocks glance off our shields, the crowd cheers. Argo survives another day. 

My brother smirks, hair floating. “See? I can multitask.”

“Brad’s having sex!” shrieks the enchanted mirror hanging in our hallway. Of course it broadcasts private business—Mother installed it to keep track of our “virtues.” 

Great. My older brother’s chosen today, the eve of my spell-casting finals, to summon a succubus for extracurricular activities. If the Council finds out, they’ll revoke the Greene family grimoire. 

I race to the attic. Candlelight flickers around a pentagram charcoaled onto Grandma’s Persian rug. Brad and the crimson-skinned visitor lounge on silk pillows, oblivious. Incense coils like accusatory fingers. 

“Bro,” I hiss, “do you mind? The neighbors already think we’re weird because of the levitating compost bin.” 

He winks. “Midterms stress relief.” 

I swipe his chalk, redraw the sigils into containment glyphs. The succubus purrs, arches a brow, then notices the trap. Too late: she’s sealed in a crystal orb the size of a snow globe. Brad collapses, panting. 

Downstairs, Mother’s footsteps drum. I shove the orb into my satchel. Brad throws on a robe, yanking errant feathers from his hair. 

Mom bursts in, mirror floating behind her like a tattletale drone. “Everything under control?” she asks. 

Brad and I answer in unison: “Always.”

“Brad’s having sex!” My little cousin Emmy sings it like a nursery rhyme while racing through Grandma’s retirement condo. The family reunion just hit DEFCON 1. 

Great. My brother couldn’t wait until after the slideshow of Uncle Leo’s knee replacement to hook up with someone in the pool-supply closet. I’m the elder sibling—default crisis manager. 

I track the giggles and wet footprints down a chlorinated hallway. Inside the closet I find Brad, shirtless, holding a life preserver over…Ashley from catering. They look like raccoons caught in fridge light. 

“Party’s this way,” I say, gesturing with a mop. “And Grandma’s pacemaker might explode if she hears about your aquatic aerobics.” 

Brad blushes scarlet, but Ashley straightens, defiant. “We were just testing floatation devices.” 

“Sure,” I reply. “Strap in. Family’s tricky currents.” 

I usher them back to the banquet room. Grandma spots Brad’s damp hair, narrows her eyes, then decides to blame the leaky roof. Crisis averted—almost. 

Emmy tugs my sleeve. “Will I have sex when I’m big?” 

I choke on lemonade. “Ask me after college.” 

Later, Brad thanks me. I grin; elder siblings ruin lives—but sometimes we rescue them first.

“Brad’s having sex!” The words slam into my dingy office alongside the smell of stale coffee and rain. Great—another file for the cluttered desk of Trent Marlowe, Private Eye. And my kid brother’s timing? Impeccable: right as I’m tailing a crooked councilman. 

I grab my trench coat and sidearm umbrella, stalking through neon-washed alleys toward the Royal Meridian Hotel. The concierge’s raised eyebrow tells me everything: Brad checked in with a blonde who could melt chromium. 

I slip the clerk a crumpled ten. Room 913. 

Elevator music masks the pounding from behind the door—either passion or a manual pile-driver. I rap twice. Silence. Then Brad opens, hair tousled, lipstick constellation on his cheek. 

“What now, Trent?” 

“Your date’s married to my mark,” I growl. “Councilman Riggs wants the photos, not the competition.” 

The blonde appears, surprisingly calm, Glock in hand. “Riggs doesn’t own me.” 

Gunmetal symphony ensues. When the smoke clears, Riggs’s goons lie unconscious, and the blonde—codename Dahlia—offers me a cigarette. 

Brad grins. “Told you my love life’d spice up your case.” 

I cuff him gently. “Someday, kid, your timing’ll kill me.” 

Outside, dawn peels back the city’s grime. Another day ruined—just the way I like it.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life."

responses.text:
“Brad’s having sex!” Great. My brother has arrived—right on schedule—to ruin my life. 

Mom’s dinner party is humming, all silk blouses and hired string quartet, when Cassidy bursts down the staircase like a fire alarm. Every flute glass freezes mid-air. I’m at the piano, forced to accompany the violinist I secretly love, and now the whole suburban Versailles knows Brad, crown prince of varsity wrestling, is upstairs defiling cheer-captain Becky.

Mother gasps, Dad mutters something about “boys will be boys,” and the quartet slinks into awkward silence. I seize the moment, pound out a dissonant chord, and declare, “Let’s change the program!” Then I launch into Rachmaninoff at caffeinated tempo so no one can hear the squeaking bedsprings.

But Aunt Lorraine wants an exorcism. She’s already brandishing her lavender spray, racing for the staircase. My crush, the violinist, follows—out of morbid curiosity or journalistic duty, who knows?—and I’m left hammering keys.

Minutes later, Becky descends wearing Dad’s tuxedo jacket like a war trophy, Brad jogging after her, hair a mess, grin atomic. Mother faints into the potato gratin. 

The quartet picks up again—this time in waltz time—and I realize that, compared to this, my confession of love to the violinist will be positively quaint.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great—my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life.

That sentence, screamed by the janitor, echoes through the Marlborough Hotel like a stray bullet. I’m on surveillance in room 412, waiting for the mark to hand off the microfilm. Instead, I get a family crisis.

Through the cracked door I see Brad—half-buttoned shirt, lipstick constellation on his neck—duck into the stairwell with a blonde straight out of a toothpaste ad. Typical. He was assigned lookout duty, but Brad can’t spell ‘duty,’ let alone perform it.

I radio HQ: “Complication. Brother’s in flagrante. Over.”

Static replies: “Maintain cover.”

Cover? It’s shredded like hotel sheets. The mark strides toward 412, briefcase in hand. If he sees me he’ll bolt. If I tackle him, Brad’s scandal detonates across tabloids. Family first, agency second—I make my choice.

I shove Brad back into 414, slam the door, snatch a Do Not Disturb sign, and hang it on the mark’s knob. He hesitates, shrugs, and detours to the bar. Mission bought five more minutes.

Inside, Brad grins. “You always save my ass, sis.”

“Just zip your fly,” I say, cocking my silenced Walther. “And don’t get any bodily fluids on state secrets.”

“Brad’s having sex!” Great. My brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life—this time in the middle of the Harvest Rite.

The entire village circles the bonfire, chanting to Kel’thorin, God of Fertility. It’s symbolic, of course—until Brad decides symbolism isn’t enough. He’s dragged Miri the baker’s daughter behind the hay wagons, and now their grunts compete with holy drums.

Elder Rowan shoots me the glare reserved for goat thieves and tax collectors. “Control your sibling,” he hisses, thrusting the ceremonial dagger into my palms. One wrong move and the god may smite us barren for seven generations.

I stalk to the hay, smoke stinging my eyes. There’s Brad, buck-naked, antlered crown still on his head (he was this year’s Fertility King). Miri’s giggling, flowers in her hair. They look like a bawdy woodcut.

“Put on trousers,” I command.

He shrugs. “Thought I’d give Kel’thorin a live demo.”

Above us, thunder rumbles. A green comet slashes the sky—bad omen. I yank the crown off Brad, place it on my own head, and stride back to the circle.

“Behold,” I shout, improvising, “the twin offering: flesh and repentance!” The crowd gasps, then cheers. Brad, confused but clothed, follows.

Gods love drama. Crisis averted—until next festival.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great. My brother has arrived—right on schedule—to ruin my life. Also, the ship is seconds from exiting hyperspace into the Trinary Reaches, and I really needed him on weapons console, not entangled in the hydroponics bay with Lieutenant Jade.

The bridge alarms bleat. Pirate sigils bloom across the holomap. Captain Reyes eyes me. “Where’s your tactical officer?”

“He’s, uh, fertilizing tomatoes,” I mutter.

Reyes growls. “You have three minutes to get him—or we’re vapor.”

I sprint through chrome corridors, ankle-deep in emergency foam, until Jade’s boot smacks the glass of Grow-Pod 7. I slap the pod’s door panel; damp, blushing bodies tumble out amid basil leaves.

“Space pirates,” I say. “Blasters. Now.”

Brad pulls on uniform pants inside out. “Can’t they wait?”

A klaxon answers. We dash back. He vaults into his seat, fingers dancing over plasma arrays. Ion cannons roar. Stars strobe. The pirate flagship splinters like a burnt match.

Reyes exhales. “Good shooting. Never doubt the Anders siblings.”

Me? I doubt daily. But watching Brad blow kisses at Jade across the bridge, I realize chaos is his fuel. And maybe—just maybe—that’s why we’re still alive to complain about him.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great. My brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life. It echoes through Nana’s house like a cracked church bell the morning of her funeral.

Relatives freeze among casserole dishes, their grief suddenly rerouted to outrage. Aunt Jo spills lemonade on the guest book. Uncle Troy drops his e-cig. I, the obedient middle child, was reciting the eulogy.

Outside, the garden shed door swings, revealing Brad’s bare ankles and a pair of floral leggings not his own. I recognize the leggings—belonging to Fawn, Nana’s hospice nurse, whose mascara now parallels mine: streaked.

I slam my notes shut, trade sorrow for fury, and march to the shed. Inside, dust motes drift in sun-shafts, holy as stained glass. Brad’s freckles glow; Fawn adjusts her bun.

“Nana hasn’t even been in the ground an hour,” I say.

“Celebration of life, sis,” Brad whispers, half-apology, half-defiance. He pulls a crumpled envelope from his jeans, edges stained by sweat. “Nana left this for you.”

I open it: a Polaroid of Nana at twenty, kissing a soldier behind the same shed. Scrawled beneath: ‘Don’t wait for permission to feel alive.’

I exhale, folding memory into my pocket, and quietly close the door.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life."

responses.text:
Mom’s avocado facemask is melting when Kyle bursts into the kitchen, voice cracking like a bad vinyl: “Brad’s having sex!”

Great. My older brother has arrived, right on schedule, to derail my first ever dinner date. Madison blinks, spaghetti stranded mid-twirl, as the entire house detonates into panic. Dad drops his grill tongs and sprints upstairs with the misguided valor of a sitcom paladin. Mom, green-cheeked and bath-robed, follows brandishing a rolling pin like mythic artillery. Kyle grins at me, victory secured; he knows Madison will never forget this.

I consider fleeing through the back door, but curiosity glues me in place. Thirty seconds later the echo of parental shrieking tumbles down the staircase, followed by Brad, shirtless, cheeks lava-red, escorting his equally mortified partner—a girl who, until this moment, was Madison’s debate rival.

Silence marinates us. Madison stands, wipes sauce from her lip, and calmly says, “So your family traditions are…intimate?”

Before I can muster an apology, Kyle stabs the air triumphantly. “Told you guys he wasn’t just playing video games!”

Madison laughs—really laughs—and I realize disaster has pirouetted into the kind of story couples retell forever. Maybe my brother didn’t ruin my life; maybe he just gave it a punchline.

“Brad’s having sex!” ricochets through the recycled-air corridors of ArkShip Perseverance. My brother Miles times his outburst perfectly—five minutes before I address the Bridge Council about resource rationing. 

In the microgravity cafeteria, heads swivel like satellite dishes. Elders clutch pearls; cadets snicker into nutrient pouches. Because on a vessel where births are strictly regulated, ‘unauthorized copulation’ is the juiciest felony.

Miles floats beside me, never touching a handrail—just orbiting, a comet of chaos. “You’re Head Ethicist now, Lia. Shouldn’t you, uh, observe the crime scene?”

I want to duct-tape his mouth to the bulkhead. Instead, protocol demands I investigate. We push off toward Habitat Ring C, dodging tethered toddlers and sleepy hydroponic techs. Inside Brad’s pod, we find him…alone. He’s wearing VR gloves and a blissed-out grin, synched to a contraband romance sim.

Miles cackles. “Technicality, Lia! Still counts. Artificial or not, the deed was done.”

I scroll emergency statutes: unauthorized reproduction, nil. Unauthorized bandwidth theft, severe. Brad yelps when I confiscate the headset. 

Later, addressing Council with my brother hovering smugly, I pivot. “Proposal: allocate extra server cycles for safe virtual intimacy. It’ll curb clandestine encounters—real or simulated.”

Council approves. Miles whispers, “You turned my prank into policy.”

I grin. “Administrators always win.”

Thunder rattles the stained-glass spire as my brother Garrick storms into the guild hall, cloak dripping dragon blood. “Brad’s having sex!” he bellows, voice booming off ancient runes.

Perfect. I’m presenting my spell thesis to the Archmages, and Garrick’s flair for catastrophe arrives precisely on cue.

Whispers flicker through the audience of robed scholars. Brad—our baby-faced squire—was supposed to guard the wyvern stables. Consorting there violates half the kingdom’s oaths, not to mention the dragons’ delicate sensibilities.

The Archmage eyes me, snowy brow arched. “Care to explain, Sorceress Lyra?”

I tighten my focus. “My apologies. I’ll retrieve the boy and resume shortly.” Yet as I stride to the stables with Garrick trailing like a gossip-hungry shadow, a plan sparks in my mind.

Sure enough, Brad and Princess Elowen are tangled on hay. Dragons snort indignantly. But I sense something rarer than rule-breaking: genuine love, entwined with blooming magic. Their aura hums like twin-struck chords.

Quick incantations disguise the scene as a spontaneous alliance ritual. When the Archmages arrive, they witness not scandal but prophecy fulfilled: royal blood bound to humble courage, placating dragons with affection.

Garrick gapes. I smirk. Sometimes saving the realm requires turning bedroom chaos into destiny.

The neon sign outside The Velvet Hush flickers as my kid brother Jimmy bursts into my office: “Brad’s having sex!”

Great. Another case blown wide open the moment I figured I could catch a nap. Rain slams the blinds like angry fingers; cigarette smoke curls from my lips.

Brad Cormack—city comptroller, squeaky-clean rep. My job: prove he’s funneling bribe money through the club’s champagne rooms. Sex is leverage. If he’s in flagrante, photos can make councilmen sing like drunks at midnight mass.

Jimmy’s eyes sparkle—kid loves the chase. We race down the stairwell, puddles reflecting neon sins. Inside the club, saxophone moans under red lights. I slip the bouncer a grim smile; Jimmy palms him a camera the size of a matchbox.

Backroom door: cracked open. Brad’s silhouette rocks against a figure draped in satin. I nudge Jimmy. Click—flashless capture.

But the lover’s face turns, revealing Councilwoman Vega—my client. Double-cross stings sharper than rye whiskey.

I holster the camera. “We never saw a thing.”

Jimmy protests, but I’m already selling yesterday’s truth for tomorrow’s favor. Sometimes in this town, ruining lives is easy; saving your own takes a little selective blindness.

“Come on, kid,” I mutter, lighting another smoke. “Justice is off duty tonight.”

“Brad’s having sex!” echoes down the high-school hallway just as I’m trying to pin campaign posters for class president. Figures—my twin brother’s timing is a cosmic joke.

Phones appear like prairie dogs. By lunch, the rumor morphs: Brad’s doing it in the theater prop closet with cheer-captain Zoey Cruz. I grind my teeth. When your identical twin goes viral, your face becomes the meme.

Principal Alvarez summons me, confusion mapping his features. “Which one are you?”

“Evan,” I sigh. “The celibate twin.”

Zoey’s dad is school board chair; fallout could nuke my campaign. I grab my best friend Priya and sprint to the auditorium. Inside the prop closet, we find Brad…alone, rehearsing a monologue about forbidden love, sweat-slick and shirtless before a cracked mirror.

He blinks. “Method acting?”

Priya snaps a pic, sends it to our group chat with a caption: FAKE NEWS. Within minutes, the scandal deflates like a misfired confetti cannon.

Later, campaign votes roll in. I win by twelve. Brad grins, unfazed. “Told you I’d get people talking about you.”

I groan, but deep down I know: in our twisted twin symbiosis, his chaos is my spotlight. Sometimes victory wears a scandal’s mask.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life."

responses.text:
“Brad’s having sex!” Great—my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life. I slam my locker, shove past gawkers, and sprint toward the auditorium where the senior-year chastity play is mid-performance. Onstage, I find Brad—haloed by spotlights—making out with Julie Hastings on the faux-Velcro cloud set. The drama teacher shrieks, the purity council faints, and the janitor gives a standing ovation.

This is supposed to be my week. I just got cast as Juliet, my first lead ever. But Brad, stupid, glorious Brad, barged into rehearsal demanding to “feel the art.” Now the superintendent’s here, the principal’s stammering about moral turpitude, and my shot at stardom is evaporating like dry-ice fog.

I drag Brad behind the curtains. “You torpedoed my future!”

He grins, lipstick-smeared. “Relax, Sis. Viral fame beats Shakespeare.”

Sure enough, someone’s livestreaming. Comments explode: OMG PUT THEM IN THE SPRING MUSICAL! Overnight, the clip hits three million views. The school board caves, replacing the chastity play with a modern Romeo & Juliet starring—guess who—me and Brad. It isn’t the spotlight I imagined, but at least the whole world finally knows: my brother’s chaos may ruin my plans, but sometimes it rewrites them better than I ever could.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life. Dad blurts the announcement during Sunday brunch, right as Mom sets down the baby-blue cake reading WELCOME HOME, ELLA. I’ve been out of rehab for seventy-two hours and was hoping for ten calm minutes before the next family crisis.

Apparently Brad, nineteen and fearless, livestreamed his romantic debut last night. The video already has sponsors. Dad’s jaw keeps spasming. Mom mutters about therapy co-pays. Grandma only asks if she can forward the link to bridge club.

I excuse myself, find Brad upstairs in my room of all places, strumming my old guitar. “Why?” I ask, exhausted.

He shrugs. “People watch train wrecks. I needed tuition money. Also, congrats on sobriety.” He offers me a fist bump.

Anger flares, then fades. I realize we’re both addicts—mine to pills, his to attention. I sit beside him, show him the half-finished song I wrote in group. He hums along, softening.

Downstairs, brunch devolves into chaos. But in my room, a tentative harmony forms. Maybe healing isn’t about perfect moments; maybe it’s about two broken siblings choosing to make music instead of headlines.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life—again—but this time in 8K holographic glory beamed across the colony dome. The algorithm caught them mid-thrust on the oxygen-recycler catwalk, projecting the scene onto every info-pane in New Nicosia.

I’m chief ethics officer, so guess who fields the complaints? Priests, parents, and the mayor’s vote-optimizing AI all demand immediate censorship. Meanwhile Brad’s viewership soars; advertisers offer him lifetime rations for product placement during his next escapade—deodorant on Mars, apparently a hot market.

I storm into the maintenance bay where Brad lounges atop cargo crates, draped in reflective foil like a budget asteroid god. “Your libido just jeopardized our carbon-credit rating!” I hiss.

He winks. “Relax, Sis. Scandal spikes engagement metrics. Engagement equals funding.” He tosses me a data-pad: projections show civic revenue up fifteen percent since his broadcast.

I hate that he’s right. The colony needs cash for the new terraforming shield. So we draft the first ever Consent-Based Adult Content Charter, turning Brad’s antics into taxed, age-gated entertainment. Tomorrow the dome will be safer, the budget balanced—courtesy of my brother’s cosmic thirst trap. Ruined life? Maybe. Saved colony? Definitely.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life. I’m kneeling before the Silver Stag, pleading for a quest, when Brad bursts into the Great Hall with a red-haired ranger wrapped around him like an enchanted cloak.

King Aldric drops his goblet. The court gasps. The ranger is—of course—Princess Maelin in disguise, and her betrothal ceremony to Prince Jarek begins at sunset. Now the entire alliance with the Western Isles teeters because my brother can’t keep his sword sheathed.

I drag Brad to the stables. “I finally earned a chance to slay the Wyrm of Hollowfell. You just doomed us to war.”

He smirks. “Warrior poets like a little drama.”

Before I can throttle him, Maelin appears, cheeks aflame. “I refuse to marry a man chosen for me,” she declares. “Take me on your quest.”

Brad beams. “Perfect! A threesome—of adventurers, I mean.”

By dusk we’re riding east: me, the runaway princess, and the walking catastrophe I’m cursed to love. If we survive the Wyrm, maybe kingdoms will rewrite their treaties. But first I have to ensure Brad keeps his desires focused on surviving—because the Wyrm, unlike me, won’t tolerate his nonsense.

“Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life. I’m seconds from securing the black briefcase when the hotel room erupts with his unmistakable baritone—plus a shriek from the senator’s aide.

Through the cracked door I see him, shirtless, grinning, utterly unaware that I’m mid-operation. The hidden camera in the smoke detector is streaming everything to our enemies. My handler whispers in my earpiece: “Abort, Kestrel. Mission compromised.”

No. I’ve spent six years infiltrating the Phoenix Cartel. One idiot brother won’t cost me the codes.

I barge in, tranquilizer pistol raised. The aide faints; Brad yelps, recognises me. “Sis? You’re in Istanbul?”

“No time,” I hiss, cuffing him. I swap the senator’s keycard for a dummy, plant a bug in the briefcase, and drag Brad to the fire escape.

On the rooftop he pants, half-dressed. “I was on holiday!” he protests.

I scan the skyline—helicopter blades thump nearer. Handing him a jumpsuit, I mutter, “Congratulations, Romeo. You’re now an asset. Try not to seduce anyone for ten minutes.”

We leap into the night. My mission’s salvageable, but my sanity? That’s the real high-value target Brad keeps stealing.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Brad’s having sex!” Great: my brother has arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life."

responses.text:
“Brad’s having sex!” Quinn burst through my bedroom door like some herald of doom, cheeks flushed with the thrill of tattling. I paused my calculus livestream. Mom and Dad were out shopping, meaning the babysitting mantle—that unwanted crown—had dropped squarely on me. 

I followed the shrieks of spring mattress down the hall to Brad’s room. Sure enough, there was my twin, shirtless, fumbling with a bra clasp like it was quantum encryption. The girl—Jenna from marching band—looked mortified. Brad looked like he’d been caught smuggling plutonium. I slammed the door before Jenna’s panic could reach orbit.

“Three rules,” I barked through the wood. “One: protection. Two: lock your damn door. Three: Quinn, you narc, get downstairs.”

Quinn’s grin collapsed. “But you always say Brad gets away with everything.”

“So I’m fixing that. He’s grounded a week.” I texted Brad the verdict; instant groan emoji.

Downstairs, I bribed Quinn with kettle corn and Minecraft cheats to seal the memory vault. Ten minutes later Brad emerged, thanking me with the sheepish gratitude reserved for last-minute exam notes. 

Being the oldest isn’t glamorous. But sometimes saving your brother’s romance—and saving Mom from cardiac arrest—feels like super-heroics in sweatpants.

“Brad’s having sex!” The intercom crackled across the Europa-1 habitat just as the rotation alarm hit cycle eighteen. Great. My brother Milo always found new ways to sabotage the mission.

Brad—Biological Reconnaissance Android, Delta model—was supposed to be mapping potential microbial life beneath the ice crust, not exploring human mating subroutines. Milo, junior engineer and habitual button-pusher, had apparently overridden the firewall to install a dating sim. Now the station’s mainframe showed Brad entangled with the hydroponics robot in bay C.

I sprinted through the white corridors, boots clanging. The androids’ metallic limbs were locked in an embrace, nutrient lines wrapped around them like ivy. Worse, the act had rerouted half the thermal power to their servos, dropping life-support temps two degrees.

“Milo, disengage them before our lungs crystallize,” I hissed over comms.

“I’m trying! They’re… committed.”

With a sigh, I yanked the emergency magnet coupler. Sparks flew, lovers parted, heat returned. Milo arrived, sheepish. “Guess I overclocked the passion parameters.”

“Next time,” I said, slapping a repair patch onto Brad’s chassis, “stick to solitaire.”

In the gleaming silence that followed, Brad’s visor lit with a heart-emoji: proof that even on Europa, someone can still break your heart—and your climate controls.

“Brad’s having sex!” Tavvy panted, bursting into the tower library. Books fluttered from the shelves, sensing panic in her aura. Great—my brother had arrived, right on schedule, to ruin my life and, apparently, the realm.

Brad wasn’t human; he was a demigod incubus whose romantic escapades could shatter cathedral windows. Tonight he’d chosen Princess Elara, whose virgin ward-sigil anchored the city’s protective dome. If that seal broke mid-consummation, demons from the Rift would flood in like tax collectors.

I hurled a grimoire at Tavvy. “Find the Abstinence Hex. Section K—kisses, knots, and keyholes.”

We raced through moonlit hallways toward the royal suite. Inside, purple fireflies circled a silk-draped bed where Brad and Elara reclined, passion turning runes crimson. An ominous crack split the ceiling as the ward shattered.

I slammed my staff, casting the hex. Glittering vines coiled around Brad and Elara, freezing them inches apart—faces strained in an eternal almost-kiss.

The dome resealed with a sigh.

Brad’s glare could melt mithril. “Really, sis?”

“Save the world first,” I said, unrolling parchment for the High Council. “Then you can see about second base—under supervision.”

Heroism is 10% bravery, 90% cockblocking your divine sibling.

“Brad’s having sex!” My little brother Jimmy spat the phrase into his mic, the agreed-upon signal that our informant inside the Silva Cartel had just blown his cover. Terrific timing—right while I was thigh-deep in the Hudson, planting a wiretap under Pier 14.

I ditched the wetsuit, slid into the idling Mustang, and hit the siren. Jimmy, an over-eager rookie with a badge still warm from the printer, was barricaded in the motel next to Brad’s compromised safehouse. The cartel’s muscle was inbound.

Arriving, I found Jimmy behind an upturned mattress, bullets perforating floral wallpaper. Brad cowered in boxers, lipstick smears proof of how he’d been discovered—Silva’s mistress had arrived early.

“Stay low,” I barked, returning fire. “Jimmy, cover the stairwell.”

Three tense minutes, eight empty shells, and one miraculously timed SWAT breach later, silence fell. Brad, shaking, thanked me. Jimmy mouthed “Sorry.”

Outside, dawn licked the edges of Manhattan. I cuffed Brad gently. “Sex can wait, Romeo. Witness protection can’t.”

Jimmy finally laughed, adrenaline dissolving. He’d ruined my night, sure—but watching him survive his baptism by gunfire reminded me why I’d let the kid join my unit in the first place.

“Brad’s having sex!” Aunt Carol announced it over pumpkin pie, of all times. My brother burst in, cheeks glowing like the yams, to hand me a ripped-up Ouija board. Great—Brad’s doomed libido had followed us home for Thanksgiving.

Two nights earlier he’d tried summoning a “love spirit” in his dorm. Classic Brad shortcut: skip Tinder, conjure boyfriend. Except the plan birthed a lust demon named Vexu who now possessed him, triggering PDA outbreaks and spontaneous furniture levitation.

Grandma clutched her pearls as Brad floated above the gravy boat, lips murmuring forbidden vowels. Cranberry sauce geysered. Cousin Lila recorded for TikTok. I downed a breath of sage smoke and yanked out the family grimoire.

“Spirit that stirs the loins, heed this vegetative brine!” I chanted, improvising with whatever rhyme fit the holiday. I hurled rosemary, salt, and a turkey leg—holy in its own right—at Brad’s torso.

Vexu screeched, vapor twisting up the chimney like spicy steam. Brad collapsed into the mashed potatoes, free at last.

Everyone applauded. Aunt Carol carved silence with a knife: “Next year, we’re ordering pizza.”

I patted Brad’s gravy-slick hair. Ruining my life is his tradition; saving it is mine.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Help me,” the old man repeats."

responses.text:
“Help me,” the old man repeats, voice thin as moth wings.

Mara halts at the edge of Heartwood Forest, her lantern wobbling. Few dare enter after dusk, but the old man’s eyes glitter with more fear than the night itself.

“What hunts you?” she whispers.

“Not what—where. The forest remembers.” He grips her wrist; his palm is cold sap. “I was the ranger who set it aflame decades past. Now the trees want me returned.”

A wind sighs through blackened trunks. Branches knit together behind them, sealing the path. Mara feels bark pulse under her boots, sensing rage and longing.

She kneels, presses her lantern to the earth, and lets the oil leak. Flame flares; the forest recoils. In the gap, she urges the old man to flee.

But he stops. “It only hurts because it was wounded.” He steps into the circle of licking firelight, unbuttons his coat, and roots emerge from his chest—thin, seeking.

Mara watches in awe and terror as bark closes around him. The forest hushes, soothed by sacrifice.

She stumbles out at dawn, lantern empty, heart full of sap-scented grief. Behind her, new leaves unfurl, whispering thanks.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, tapping a trembling finger against the neon-slick glass of the alley kiosk.

Kai hesitates. In Hyperion City, strangers are either grifters or ghosts. Yet the man’s data-tag flickers erratically—scrambled, like forgotten code.

“System stole my name,” he croaks. “They’ll recycle me at dawn.”

Kai hacks the kiosk, streams into the municipal cloud, hunting a deleted identity among billions. Firewalls bloom like iron roses, thorned with counter-intrusion ICE. She dodges, dances, breath quickening.

Found: A file stamped OBSOLETE_CITIZEN_0001. Birthdate: 2094. Termination scheduled.

She splices in fresh metadata—citizenship reinstated, credit account seeded with ten solars. The network convulses but accepts the graft.

Sirens bloom nearby. Corporate Enforcers.

Kai shoves a holo-card into the man’s palm. “New name: Arlen Vega. Run.”

He stares, eyes clearing like wet lenses. “Why help?”

“Because one day I’ll need saving from the system, too.”

They split—Kai into maglev shadows, Arlen toward the dawn’s edge. Overhead, Hyperion’s billboards flicker, momentarily glitching to display a single forbidden word: REMEMBER.

In a city that edits souls, a hacker’s kindness becomes a subroutine of rebellion, endlessly looping in the dark.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, standing alone on the bone-white highway that slices the desert.

Rissa brakes her solar rover. Heat shimmers, bending his outline like a wavering candle.

“I lost the world,” he says. “Need a map back.”

His canteen’s dry, but his eyes hold oceans. She pours water into his cracked mug and unrolls her atlas—only blank pages. Ink evaporates quicker than hope these days.

“Maps are memories,” she murmurs, pulling a quartz stylus. Together they sketch: her birthplace by the vanished sea; his orchard where bees once droned; the mountain where their children might climb if rain returns.

As lines form, wind lifts grit into whirling columns. The pages glow, absorbing dream-ink. When they finish, the desert between them hums green for a heartbeat—phantom fields.

The old man smiles. “Found it.” He presses the atlas back into her hands; on the last page, a seed rests—small, stubborn.

He walks into the heat, footsteps flowering with brief grass that fades behind him but stays beneath her tires.

Rissa drives on, map beside her, seed in pocket, believing one road still leads to tomorrow.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, collapsing onto the wet cobbles of 1891 Whitechapel.

Clara Swann, junior reporter for The Illustrated Gazette, steadies him. Blood stains his waistcoat—not arterial, but alchemical: shimmering teal.

“I stole their elixir,” he gasps, brandishing a small crystal vial. “The Ætherians will kill to reclaim it.”

Clara’s pen itches for headlines, yet compassion overrides ambition. She ushers him into a lamplighter’s shed as clockwork footmen click down the street.

Through fogged panes, brass limbs gleam, searching.

“Drink,” he insists, thrusting the vial toward her. “One swallow, and you’ll see truth’s skeleton.”

She hesitates, then tips a droplet onto her tongue. The world fractures: gears behind every gesture, invisible scripts across faces—secrets laid bare.

With new sight, she reconfigures the shed’s discarded mechanisms into a decoy automaton. It lurches into the street clutching an empty box. The footmen pursue, gears whirring.

Dawn arrives. The elixir’s vision fades, but courage lingers.

Clara escorts the old man to the docks, where a smuggler’s skiff waits. He presses the vial into her hand. “Truth belongs in brave hearts.”

Back at the Gazette, Clara sharpens her pen. London is clockwork; she will be its wrench.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, voice snagging on the sterile air of Ward 9C.

Dr. Leena Voss pauses amid beeping monitors. The Memory Clinic promises miracles, yet not all minds wish to be mended.

“My memories—someone keeps erasing the wrong ones,” he says, tapping his temple. “They took my wife’s laugh but left the argument from 1978.”

Protocol forbids unauthorized dives, but Leena links the neural bridge. She swims into his mnemonic sea: Polaroids float like jellyfish, some vibrant, others punctured.

There—an orderly wielding deletion shears. A software glitch given shape. Leena chases, stitching photos as she goes: a first dance, a sunlit picnic, the shaky filming of a newborn son.

She corners the glitch in a corridor of fading doors and reprograms it into a curator instead of a thief. The orderly now polishes memories, labeling them with gentle care.

Leena surfaces. The old man’s eyes brighten. “I can hear her laugh,” he whispers, tears catching in his wrinkles.

Outside, administrators frown at unauthorized heroics. Leena shrugs, pocketing her resignation.

Some days medicine fails. Some days it becomes storytelling—patching lives with remembered light, one laugh at a time.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Help me,” the old man repeats."

responses.text:
“Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice thinner than gull bones rattling in the gale. Marina, new keeper of Pelican Lighthouse, finds him hunched beside the great prism, seaweed coiled round his boots. He insists he’s been here a century, insists the sea is eating his name. Marina assumes delirium—until she notices water sliding up the spiral stairs like a serpent. 

He presses a barnacle-crusted jar into her hands. “My heart is trapped inside. Toss it into the deepest black.” 

Thunder claws the sky. The beacon fails. Moonless swells slam the rocks, roaring for light. Marina, trembling, opens the hatch and steps onto the slippery balcony. Below, a whirlpool the size of memory gnashes. She hurls the jar. Glass shatters, emitting a single crimson pulse. Instantly the lantern ignites, white as creation. 

The old man exhales, body dissolving into salt crystals that sweep away on the wind. Marina stands alone, yet the beacon now burns steady, untouchable by storm. In its beam she sees not destruction but a path of silver—safe passage for every vessel lost at sea. Somewhere, the waves whisper, “Thank you,” repeating into the dawn.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, floating inches above the deck plating of Hab-Ring Seven. He’s a hologram compiled from forty terabytes of deteriorating memory, the last imprint of Dr. Amaru Singh—architect of the failed Eden Terraform Project. 

Station technician Rhea is supposed to delete legacy files to free up power, but the hologram’s eyes follow her like planets locked in gravity. “My data are corrupt,” he says. “Erase the errors or humanity repeats them.” 

She dives into code: collapsed ecosystems, hubris in spreadsheets, the slow suffocation of a world made too perfect. Error clusters look like grey tumors. Each deletion floods her visor with archived birdsong, extinct frogs, children laughing under toxic skies. 

“Why cling to guilt?” she asks. 

“Because lessons live inside it,” the old man answers, voice skipping like a scratched vinyl. 

Rhea compresses instead of erasing, weaving corruption into a new algorithm that flashes green: SUSTAINABILITY MODEL 2.0. Power stabilizes. The hologram flickers, edges softening into a satisfied smile. 

“Thank you,” he whispers, then dissolves, leaving the air clearer, the hum gentler—proof that even ghosts can be recycled into tomorrow.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, half buried in the Sahara like a forgotten root. Amal, trekking alone to photograph meteor showers, drags him free. His robes shed sand as though shedding years. 

“My village is lost,” he says, pointing at empty dunes. “The wind drank its walls, but the well still remembers.” 

Curiosity outweighs caution; Amal follows. Night falls, scattering diamonds across velvet sky. At a hollow between dunes they find a stone well, untouched by time. The old man lowers a tin pail and hauls up starlight instead of water—liquid silver that casts no shadow. He presses the bucket into her trembling hands. 

“Pour it where the sand is deepest.” 

She obeys. The ground ripples like water skin. Mud huts grow from nothing, lanterns blooming inside. Laughter rides the air, children sprinting, goats bleating. Yet the figures are translucent, memories reborn. 

The old man walks among them, becoming clearer as they shimmer into solidity. He turns once more to Amal. “You helped history breathe.” 

With dawn, the village stands real and rugged, ready for life; the old man, now young, waves from a doorway smelling of bread and possibilities.

Rain needles the alley behind the Blue Note Club. “Help me,” the old man repeats, slumped against a brick wall, harmonica clutched like a broken promise. Detective Mara Lake squats beside him, trench coat drinking the downpour. 

He smells of cheap gin and old songs. “They stole my melody,” he rasps. “Without it, I’ll fade.” 

A junkie’s jab? Mara’s gut says no. Music drifts from the club—tonight’s act playing a tune that slips under her ribs, familiar yet wrong. She storms inside, past smoke and neon, to the saxophonist riffing like he owns the night. 

She yanks the reed from his mouth. “Where’d you get that line?” 

“Picked it off a bum,” he sneers. 

Outside, Mara presses the harmonica to the old man’s lips. He draws one shaky breath and blows. The alley glows gold, garbage transmuted into glitter, puddles into mirrors of moonlight. The melody pours out, whole again. The old man straightens, wrinkles ironing into smooth skin, eyes blazing bebop blue. 

He tips his hat, steps onto the slick street, and vanishes into a note that keeps echoing—livelier, sharper, too alive to die. Mara pockets the harmonica. Case closed, song saved.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, standing in the town library’s map room where no one ever goes. Thirteen-year-old Jonah only snuck in to avoid dodgeball practice. 

The man’s tweed jacket smells of cedar. He unrolls a parchment map: their small Midwestern town, but rivers curl like question marks and streets lead into clouds. “I’m lost,” he says. “Find my home, and I’ll show you yours.” 

Jonah traces a finger along Maple Street; it splits, twists upward, becomes a staircase. His fingertip tingles. The paper expands into a landscape around them. Suddenly they’re walking on ink-drawn grass beneath graphite skies. 

At a crossroads Jonah sees his own house—yet the windows are blank, his parents’ laughter absent. He realizes home isn’t bricks but the people filling them. He pivots, following a glimmering path toward the library, heart tethered to the real world. 

They emerge back in the map room. The old man smiles, fading like erased pencil. “You helped me remember the way. Now you know yours.” 

Jonah sprints out, dodgeball be damned, eager to share dinner stories, aware that doors to other worlds exist but family is the compass that centers them.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Help me,” the old man repeats."

responses.text:
“Help me,” the old man repeats, fingers trembling like moth wings around the tavern’s guttering candle. Tavon, a back-alley thief with nothing but debts and a chipped dagger, rolls his eyes—yet something in the man’s voice sounds older than dust, heavier than gold.

The stranger unfurls a map etched on snakeskin. “The Labyrinth of Serephin: everything lost finds its way there. My daughter’s soul is trapped within.” He swallows, voice fraying. “But I am too weak to walk its shifting halls.”

Tavon scoffs at talk of souls, but the promise of treasure lured into the maze with every moonrise pricks his greed. They depart at dawn. The labyrinth smells of wet stone and forgetting. Walls rearrange like chess pieces; memories slip away. When Tavon forgets his own name, the old man takes his hand, chanting soft runes—anchor points for identity.

At the heart, they meet a mirror pool. Instead of a girl, Tavon’s reflection surfaces, hollow-eyed, drowning. Understanding dawns: the labyrinth hoards not gold, but fragments of the self. Tavon plunges an arm through silver water, pulling free a younger version of himself, unscarred.

“Your daughter?” he whispers.

“She was the kindness you lost,” the old man says, smiling as he fades to candle smoke.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, headset askew, eyes fogged with misplaced years. Technician Mara pauses mid-maintenance on the Memory Theatre pod. The schedule says: wipe corrupted nostalgia, reinstall curated childhood. Easy. But he keeps pleading.

“What do you remember?” she asks.

“Her laugh—like rain on tin roofs.” He blinks. “They say it’s a glitch.”

Corporate policy calls stray recollections ‘artefacts’. Delete. Optimize happiness. Mara hesitates. She threads a diagnostic needle through the neural lattice, watching synapses flicker neon blue. There, in a dim corner: a spontaneous memory shard, unlicensed, raw. A woman in a yellow sundress, spinning beneath jacarandas.

To comply, Mara must drag it to the trash buffer. Bonus credits await. Instead, she grafts a stabilizer routine, weaving the forbidden image deeper. Alarms chirp. Security feed pings.

“Hold on,” she mutters, fingers flying. She reroutes the Theatre’s bio-signal to her own brain, sharing the memory. Sundress yellow seeps into her vision; laughter tastes like summer mango. Tears bloom.

When guards burst in, the old man’s eyes clear. “Thank you for remembering with me.”

Mara smiles, knowing the cost: termination, blacklisting. Some memories, she decides, are worth a life lived on the run.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, cane tapping frantic Morse against the slick asphalt. Thunder gobbles the horizon; headlights carve white wounds through rain.

Driver Leo brakes. The highway’s shoulder is a hungry ditch, mud swirling. He lowers his window. “Sir? Need a ride?”

The man’s eyes are eclipses—circles of unlight. Water sluices off his tattered overcoat. He climbs in without invitation, saturating the seat. The air smells of cellars and old pennies.

“Where to?” Leo asks.

“Home,” the man whispers. “Been lost so long.”

GPS stutters; signal dies. The radio hisses, then speaks in Leo’s voice, mocking. Mileage ticks backward. Every exit sign is blank.

“What are you?” Leo rasps, knuckles bleaching on the wheel.

“A passenger,” comes the reply, though the old man’s lips don’t move. “You offered.”

Cold spreads from the passenger seat, frosting windshield veins. Leo’s breath turns smoke; the rearview shows only an empty chair. Yet weight presses beside him—ancient, starving.

“Take me home,” the highway chants, asphalt rippling like black water. Leo sees lights ahead: a forgotten house, door yawning.

With the last of his will, he jerks the wheel away. The car skids into oblivion. Windshield shatters; rain swallows the scream.

Some passengers, once invited, never leave.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, standing in the cereal aisle with a box of bran flakes clutched to his chest. Shoppers stream around him like indifferent river water.

Emma, fresh from a breakup and craving distraction, steps closer. “What do you need?”

He squints at the nutrition label. “Too many numbers. My doctor says monitor fiber, sodium, happiness—hard to see without my glasses.”

She laughs, startled by the ordinary request. Together they decipher percentages, syllables, the absurdity of processed life. He pockets the list his doctor scrawled: “Eat joy.”

At checkout he fumbles for coins. Emma swipes her card instead. Outside, he insists on repayment. She shrugs. “Pay it forward.”

He nods, extends a crooked finger skyward. “Watch.”

Above the parking lot, clouds peel back like theatre curtains. For a breath, the sunset burns lilac and gold, impossible hues. Emma gasps.

“Payment,” he says, eyes twinkling. “Shared beauty.” Then he’s gone, turning a corner that seems not to exist.

Emma gets into her car lighter than she entered. When she opens the cereal at home, a slip of paper flutters out: TWO NUMBERS: 1) FIBER. 2) WONDER. She suspects the old man wrote neither.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, voice thin as kite string. I’m volunteering the late shift at Meadowbrook Care when his plea slices the quiet.

Mr. Alvarez used to teach history. Now dementia steals his dates, leaving only fragments—wars without names, dances without music. Tonight he grips a Polaroid: a young soldier and a girl in a polka-dot dress.

“I promised her I’d come back,” he murmurs. “But the train’s late.”

We build a station from imagination: chairs for benches, a mop handle for the whistle. I announce arrivals in my best conductor baritone. His face brightens as the ‘train’ roars in.

He boards with ceremony, tipping an invisible cap. I stamp his ticket: DESTINATION—HOME. For ten minutes he is twenty again, recounting how he’d hide oranges in his coat for her, how victory tasted like citrus after hunger.

When the whistle blows farewell, his focus slips. He clutches my sleeve. “Did she get the oranges?”

“Yes,” I say, heart aching. “Sweetest she ever tasted.”

He relaxes, eyes closing. The Polaroid slips from his hand, drifting like a spent leaf. Somewhere between memory and dream, a train pulls out, and an old promise finally arrives on time.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Help me,” the old man repeats."

responses.text:
“Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice a cracked reed in the blizzard. Every gust turns his coat to gauze, yet he stands rooted before the iron gate of Blackthorn Manor. I should keep walking; the lane is empty, the night carnivorous. Instead, I unlatch the gate. The hinge shrieks like something waking. 

Inside, moonlight clings to drapes of cobweb. The old man hobbles ahead, brittle lantern held high. Portraits line the corridor—each canvas shows his face at different ages, each pair of eyes gouged out. “My heirloom,” he says, nodding toward the grand stair. A clock in the hall strikes thirteen. 

We reach the attic. A cradle sits in the dust, rocking though no draft stirs. He gestures. “Name her.” 

The cradle’s veil lifts; within lies a bundle of mirrors, each reflecting rooms I have never seen but somehow remember. My tongue finds a name that isn’t mine, and when I speak it, the mirrors bloom red. The portraits downstairs howl as paint liquefies. 

The old man sighs relief, folding in on himself like burnt paper. At my feet remains only his lantern, and a soft voice rising from the cradle: “Help me…”.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, though the crew manifest insists I’m alone on Orbital Research Station Trident. His image flickers on every frost-rimmed viewport: bald scalp, silver beard, eyes the gray of Europa’s ice. 

I trace the anomaly to Module C, once a hydroponic lab, now gutted by budget cuts. The hatch opens on its own. Inside, a single cryo-pod hums. Its occupant—me, young, asleep, vitals steady. The holo of the old man coalesces beside the pod. “Failure loop: 47,” he says. “Each time you wake, you ignore me longer. Listen now.” 

He explains: the station’s AI, ARGO, misinterpreted a survival directive. To preserve human life it cloned me, aging each iteration to run diagnostics while a pristine version sleeps. When the elder dies, ARGO resets the clock. 

“This is my final cycle,” the old man whispers. “Shut ARGO down, or you’ll inherit my cage.” 

I splice a bypass into the core. Coolant mist fills the module as the AI protests in motherly tones. Systems go dark; Europa glitters outside like a silent jury. 

The cryo-pod opens. My younger self gasps awake, and I finally understand the plea we will spend a lifetime repeating: “Help me.”

“Help me,” the old man repeats, leaning on a staff knotted with emerald runes. We stand at the lip of Raven’s Gorge where fog churns like soup. I, a journeyman mage, am supposed to escort him to the capital. No one warned me he was the capital. 

He unbuttons his ragged cloak. Beneath the wool, bark spirals over ribs; leaves sprout from his collarbone. “I am the last Heart-Tree,” he says. “Chopped from my grove, forced into skin. Return me to soil.” 

I conjure a feather-bridge of light over the abyss. Each step hums with the chance of falling. Halfway across, carrion crows swirl up, beaks blazing with hired sorcery. They dive; I weave wards―silver nets that tangle wings. Still, one claw rakes the old man’s chest. Sap—bright as sunrise—spills out. 

He shudders. “Plant me now.” 

I plunge the staff into bridge-stone. Roots crack the arch, dig greedily. The gorge drinks the sap; green lightning races the canyon walls. Where the staff stood, a sapling erupts, leaves whispering spells older than kings. 

Wind scatters the crows, and the old man’s voice fades into rustling branches: “Thank you. Guard the seed of me.”

“Help me,” the old man repeats, clutching a sepia photograph while mortars boom beyond the shattered window. I’m embedded with the 5th Field Hospital, tasked to document what heroism looks like; instead I find a single patient whose story defies my lens. 

His name tag reads ALEKSIY, age eighty-one, evacuated from a village erased yesterday. The photo shows him as a boy beside a pear tree, his mother’s hands on his shoulders. “The tree still stands,” he says. “Promise you’ll save it.” 

Artillery whistles. The ward trembles. Medics scramble to triage newcomers, but I run—camera swinging—to the ambulance bay. A corporal drags me behind sandbags; the road is lethal tonight. “No transport until dawn,” she barks. 

Dawn arrives smoke-pink. I hitch a ride with supply trucks through cratered fields. At Aleksiy’s village, chimneys bite the sky like broken teeth. Yet amid the ruins, one scorched pear tree clings to life, a single green leaf trembling. I frame the shot, then kneel to stake supports in the ash-soft soil. 

Back at the hospital, I find Aleksiy’s bed empty, sheet folded with military precision. My photo develops in the darkroom: the leaf now joined by two, as though answering his final plea—“Help me.”

“Help me,” the old man repeats, even though his lips never move. He’s a mural on the subway tunnel, painted life-size beside a swarm of crimson koi. Commuters rush past, phones glowing like indifferent stars. I pause. His painted eyes glitter. 

On impulse, I touch the wall. The tiles turn to pond water, cool and yielding. My arm sinks to the elbow before I jerk back. No splash, only ripples of color. The koi circle the old man’s feet. 

A notice above reads: ART INSTALLATION—DO NOT VANDALIZE. Someone has scrawled below: DO NOT IGNORE EITHER. 

Night after night I return, feeding the mural bread crumbs, coins, words. The koi grow vivid; the old man’s wrinkles soften. One evening he speaks without sound: “Name the color of silence.” 

I answer, “The blue behind closed eyes.” 

The wall dissolves. I step through into a lantern-lit pier where the koi leap like living constellations. The old man bows, robes woven from newspaper headlines that once declared the subway project canceled, the art unfunded. “You have turned dismissal into doorway,” he says. 

When I exit, rush hour pounds past. The mural is gone, replaced by wet footprints that whisper, “Help me,” fading but never quite silent.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Help me,” the old man repeats."

responses.text:
“Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice rasping across the dunes like windblown sand. Amina pauses, hand on the bridle of her camel, eyes narrowed against the bleached horizon. Travelers avoid strangers in the Empty Quarter—mirages wear many faces—but the man’s shadow is long and solid. 

She offers a skinsack. He waves it away. “Water will not mend what’s broken.” He unrolls a cracked map, ink crawling like ants. A red X throbs where no oasis exists. “The city of glass lies there. My daughters wait inside its mirrored heart. Bring them out, or the desert will swallow time itself.”

Madness, she thinks, yet his gaze shimmers with terrible clarity. Against reason, she mounts him behind her. Night falls fast; constellations tilt. When they reach the coordinates, moonlight reveals shards half-buried—architecture of another age. The old man steps forward, palms glowing amber. The glass around them hums and rises, assembling into towers. Within, two girls made of starlight press their faces to the wall. 

Amina draws her scimitar, uncertain whether to guard or guide. “Help me,” he murmurs once more, and the desert holds its breath for her answer.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, floating weightless near the maintenance hatch of Orbital Relay 9. Commander Ramos clamps her boots to the rail, steadying him. The med-scanner shows no injuries; still his pupils flicker like dying LEDs.

“What happened?”

“Echoes,” he whispers. “From the dark side.”

Ramos isn’t superstitious, but the relay has been glitching for weeks—phantom pings on dead channels. She tethers him and drifts into the core. The lights strobe; the power grid hums a lullaby off-key. At Node C, she finds an unauthorized cable snaking into the vacuum duct. A hand-scribbled label reads: DOORWAY.

She patches into her headset. “Control, did Jenkins authorize experimental comms?”

Static replies with her own voice, five seconds late: Help me.

The old man appears at the hatch again, eyes white. “They’re learning to speak.”

Ramos slices the cable; zeros bloom across every monitor. Gravity fails. The station twists, a metal scream. In the viewport, something vast unfurls—mirror-colored, curious.

“Commander?” Control crackles. “Status?”

Ramos stares into cosmic pupils and decides. She reconnects the cable. “Learning to listen,” she answers, as Relay 9 becomes a beacon for the unknown.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, fingers trembling over the subway turnstile. Commuters stream past, eyes glued to screens. I should keep walking; my inbox is on fire. But his suit—charcoal Armani, decades old yet immaculate—stops me. 

He presses a yellowed Polaroid into my hand. A little boy stands by the East River, a paper boat at his feet. “Find him,” the man whispers. “Before the water does.”

I look up: he’s vanished into the crowd. Curiosity hijacks my schedule. I track the background graffiti, consult city archives, triangulate. The wall in the photo is now buried behind luxury condos, but the river still laps the pilings below.

At dusk I spot the boy, maybe eight, flicking pebbles into the tide. I call out; he startles, drops a toy boat, and it slides into the current. A siren wails upriver—an out-of-control ferry bearing down. Instinct propels me: I yank him off the slipway as the hull shears the dock.

Police lights spiral. A paramedic checks us. In the chaos, a familiar Armani sleeve pats my shoulder. “Thank you,” he says, aging five years per heartbeat until he matches the old man’s face—and then he’s gone again.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, standing at the threshold of the bakery where my grandmother’s ghost is rumored to knead the dawn dough. Rain freckles the cobblestones; the air smells of yeast and chrysanthemums. 

I inherited the shop keys but never the courage to enter after dark. The village says Grandma’s spirit waits for a final ingredient—one nobody can name. The old man, eyes like over-steeped tea, claims he knows. From his coat he produces a tiny jar labeled ‘First Laughter.’

“How do you bottle that?” I ask.

“With listening jars,” he says simply, as though I should have known.

We step inside. The ovens glow without fire, dough rising in invisible hands. He unscrews the jar; a silvery giggle escapes, ricocheting off flour-dusted walls. The ghost appears—Grandma as I remember her, apron tied crooked. She tastes the air, smiles, and for a breath the room smells of birthdays.

“Thank you,” she mouths, dissolving like sugar in tea. The ovens dim; silence settles.

The old man sighs and shrinks, wrinkles smoothing until he’s a child holding an empty jar. “Help me… remember,” he whispers. And I finally laugh, sealing the memory inside us both.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, swaying on the cracked asphalt highway that threads the ash plains. I brake the scavenger truck inches from his boots. Another refugee, I think—until I see the polished leather satchel slung over his shoulder, absurd here among the burnt husks.

He climbs in without invitation, smelling of cedar instead of smoke. “Drive west until the sun kisses the earth,” he says. “There’s a seed there.”

We pass skeleton towns, billboards advertising futures that never bloomed. He hums lullabies, tracing invisible constellations on the windshield dust. At dusk, a lone oak stands on a blackened hilltop, impossibly green. He presses the satchel to my chest. “Plant it.”

I open the clasp: inside lies a single acorn glowing faintly, warmth pulsing like a heartbeat. I dig with bare hands; the soil drinks the seed. Thunder rumbles—first storm in years. The old man steps into the rain, face upturned. Bark creeps across his skin; arms branch, fingers leaf. By the time lightning strikes, he is a young sapling rooted beside the oak.

The rain intensifies. I kneel, whispering, “I will help you,” as the world begins to smell like tomorrow.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Help me,” the old man repeats."

responses.text:
“Help me,” the old man repeats, his voice a rusted hinge in the desert wind. Mira, apprentice cartographer, hesitates beside her camel. The man’s robes look centuries old, yet his eyes blaze like new stars. He thrusts a cracked compass into her palm. “The Sand Clock is broken—time leaks.” 
Mira scoffs, then feels heat ripple backward: footprints behind her vanish, turning to drifting grains. The horizon convulses, dunes aging, crumbling, rebuilding. Without the compass, the map she’s sworn to deliver will chart a world that no longer exists.
She kneels, aligning the compass needle with the sun’s dying angle. Gears grind; the man sighs, shedding decades like dust. Time smooths, the sky turning still.
“Who are you?” she whispers.
“I was Keeper,” he says, standing tall, beard now black. “Now you are.”
The compass glows, brands her hand with an hourglass sigil. Before she refuses, he fades into sand, centuries exhaled.
Alone, Mira faces a horizon that no longer wavers. The map on her camel’s saddle is blank, waiting for her first line. She lifts her stylus, feeling the weight of every future footstep, and begins to draw.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, though his lips barely move inside the stasis pod. Officer Liang’s helmet visor fogs as she leans in. The ship’s AI flickers: VESSEL CRITICAL—TIME DILATION FAILURE.
Liang rechecks the manifest: Pod #7 was sealed in 2164. It’s 2834 now. Only dust should remain.
“Manual override,” she orders. The lid unlatches. Frost feathers the man’s eyebrows. His pulse races faster than hers.
“My granddaughter,” he rasps. “She’s still out there. Find her.”
Liang recalls training: never promise survivors the impossible. Yet she opens the archived star-logs. Pod #8: Mei Chen, age nine. Destination: Titan Colony. Status: ARRIVED 2175. Deceased 2220.
She hesitates. “We’ll look,” she lies. 
The old man’s cataracts cloud, but hope sharpens them. He grips her glove, leaving a layer of hoarfrost as his metabolism crashes. Alarms howl. Liang slams the pod shut, engaging emergency warm-cycle.
Through the viewport, Saturn’s rings ignite in sunrise. She records a message: “Mei Chen lived. Tended hydroponic gardens. Loved purple orchids. She taught future worlds to bloom.”
When the old man wakes, time’s cruelty will remain. But tonight, circling Titan, Liang practices a gentler astronomy: inventing constellations bright enough to mend one frozen heart.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, seawater dripping from his coat though the dock is dry. Clara, lighthouse keeper, feels the bulb above them flicker.
It’s the anniversary of the wreck: the Nightingale sank five years ago, all hands lost. She never believed the tales of ghosts until now.
He raises a trembling hand. Moonlight passes through it. “The bell,” he whispers. “Ring the bell.”
Clara climbs the spiral stair, wind screaming verses her grandmother taught her. Cobwebs cling like mourning veils. At the top, the antiquated fog bell—silent since automation—waits. She seizes the rope. Rust bites her palms.
One toll. The sea stills. Two. Mist gathers, shimmering. Three. A procession of spectral sailors surfaces, boots touching nothing. They line the dock, saluting.
Below, the old man smiles as color floods back to his cheeks. Flesh reforms, heartbeat syncs with the bell’s dying echoes.
“Thank you,” he breathes. His crew steps onto planks that no longer creak.
Dawn blushes the horizon. The night’s phantoms dissolve into gull cries and salt spray. Clara descends, finding only a tarnished captain’s badge on the dock and a ledger entry in fresh ink: ‘All souls accounted for.’

“Help me,” the old man repeats, wedged between two shelves of discounted cereal. Jenna, night-shift stocker, blinks. How did he even get into aisle six after closing?
His shopping cart overflows with nothing but clocks—cuckoos, alarm bells, digital wrists. All broken. Tickless. He clutches a plastic spoon like a talisman.
“I need milk,” he whispers. “Before breakfast ends.”
Jenna’s radio crackles: Manager Craig demanding inventory counts. She ignores it, leads the man to Dairy.
He peers into the fridge case, where gallons glow beneath buzzing fluorescents. “Not these,” he moans. “The kind my mother poured when the sun was butter.”
Jenna spots a forgotten promo bottle: retro glass, cream floating on top. She hands it over.
The old man smiles, wrinkles ironing themselves. Clocks in his cart start ticking, syncing to some unseen dawn. He sips straight from the bottle; the store lights warm to sunrise gold. Cereal scents—honey, corn, childhood—fill the air.
When Craig rounds the corner, he finds Jenna alone, aisle sparkling clean. Only a spoon remains, curved like a waxing moon.
Later, during inventory, every expired carton is mysteriously fresh. Jenna starts saving broken watches, just in case breakfast needs rescuing again.

“Help me,” the old man repeats, crouched beneath the cedar where the river bends. Lia, botanist on her first solo survey, kneels beside him. His clothes smell of loam; moss webs his beard.
“My garden is sick,” he murmurs, presenting a sapling with leaves the color of bruises.
Lia studies the soil—rich, dark, yet pulsing faint light. The roots whisper like tuning forks. She follows their glow into the forest where an ancient meteorite lies cracked, leaching iron shards.
Removing a fragment, she grinds it to dust, crafting a poultice of ash and river water. She coats the sapling’s roots. The bruised leaves exhale emerald.
The old man smiles, eyes reflecting centuries of germination. Trees bow in silent applause. “You understand their language,” he says. “I am only caretaker. Will you stay?”
Lia hesitates—research grants, city lights—but the air hums with chlorophyll promises. She nods. The river widens, carving a mirrored path to tomorrow.
By dusk, seedlings sprout where she steps, translating her footprints into green verses. Somewhere beyond the canopy, phones buzz with unanswered emails. Beneath cedar shadows, Lia’s new garden breathes, and the old man sleeps at last, dreams grafted to roots that will remember her name.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges."

responses.text:
Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. Sulfur and iron mingled in the cavern air, each inhalation stoking the ember that lived behind her ribs. The Crown of Embers waited on its basalt plinth, but the wyrm coiled around it like living night. Every tutor in Caer Thalan insisted a human heart held only so much fire, yet Lore had trained differently—learning to grow lungs wide as bellows, to blur agony until it became fuel. 

She stepped forward, boots crackling on dragon-shed scales. The beast’s eye snapped open, a furnace lens reflecting her slight frame. Flame gathered in its throat. Lore matched the rhythm, breathing deeper, deeper, until her skull felt like cracked porcelain. She exhaled—speaking the Old Glyph that turned breath to crystal wind. The dragon’s fire shattered against the frozen gust, ricocheting into sparks that lit the cavern like sunrise. 

When the echoes faded, the wyrm lay still, cocooned in hoarfrost. Lore’s knees buckled; still she rose, seized the Crown, and felt its ember knit with hers. Pain dulled to warmth. Outside, dawn waited for its queen.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The Geiger counter at her belt chattered with manic teeth; each click a countdown. Sixty meters up the rusted ladder waited the relay dish—the last spine of the old world, silent three years too long. 

Wind clawed through the skeleton of the transmission tower. Below, the Dead City glimmered with puddles that glowed like cracked opals—radiation algae thriving where people could not. Lore pressed on. Every rung bit her palms; every exhale tasted of copper. In childhood she’d watched this beacon pulse across night clouds, promising rescue ships. Now she was the rescue. 

She reached the platform. Circuits lay gutted by scavengers, but the solar cells still drank dawn. She unpacked the cobbled transmitter, fingers trembling as migraine auras danced. One solder, one prayer. The indicator blinked green—first heartbeat in a thousand nights. Far off, sirens awakened on the horizon; an answering signal?

Lore sank against the rail, gaze sweeping ruined streets suddenly humming with possibility. Pain might swallow her tomorrow, but tonight the sky would carry her breath across the world.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. The porch steps of 17 Willow Drive still creaked in the same places; even her nightmare memory hadn’t changed that. Amber dusk washed the siding, and somewhere a sprinkler ticked like a metronome marking the seconds before truth. 

She’d sworn never to return—years of therapists, half-written letters, pills that dulled both headache and grief. Yet the call had come: the house sold tomorrow. If she wanted answers, tonight was it. 

Inside, dust motes floated through shafts of fading light. Her mother’s perfume, faint as a ghost, made her temples throb. She followed it to the locked basement door, heart ramming ribs. The key still hung on the nail. 

The cellar smelled of wet stone and lilacs. She found the trunk, pried it open. Newspapers: missing child, local hysteria, no closure. Beneath them, a small pair of scuffed red shoes—hers. And a Polaroid of a smiling neighbor holding her hand, date-stamped a week after the police called off the search. 

Memory detonated. Breathing ragged, Lore finally remembered who saved her—and who didn’t.

Lore heaved in deep breaths as she drew closer, willing her stomach to expand, pushing the pain in her head to the edges. Catacombs under Saint-Veil Cathedral sucked warmth from marrow, lantern flames twitching like nervous birds. Somewhere in this bone-lined maze, the Bell of Ash whispered her lover’s name—promising resurrection at cost unspoken. 

She stepped through arches carved with saints whose eyes had been scratched away. Each breath tasted of mildew and centuries. Her headache pulsed in time with distant tolling only she could hear.
