The court healers offered tonics and sermons; none restored his laughter. Morwen, a humble hedge-witch, was summoned in secret. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. First, she coaxed foxfire to flicker in the garden at dusk, painting the hedges with emerald lanterns. When Simon ventured out, reluctant but curious, she slipped him a flute carved from elderwood. Each note summoned a shimmering moth that perched upon his sleeve, forming a living melody of wings. Night after night, Morwen wove small wonders: moon-daisies that chimed, rain that tasted of honey, a dreamcatcher spun from dawn’s first light. Simon’s laughter returned, fragile yet growing, like a sapling breaking through frost. Rumors reached the king of a witch who healed without potions, but Morwen only shrugged. Happiness, she knew, was a braid of tiny enchantments. One day the prince would stand tall beneath banners once more. Until then, she would stitch joy into every corner of his heart.

Simon's room overlooked the hospital parking lot—a maze of asphalt and impatient horns. He was twelve, tethered to an IV pole that beeped like a broken metronome. Jenna, the night nurse with sneakers scribbled in cartoon stars, clocked in at sunset. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. She began with stories: a ceiling tile became a pirate’s map; the IV drip, a rope swing across lava. When Simon’s pain spiked, she challenged him to race paper boats down the hallway’s waxed floor. They named the boats after planets, and when Saturn won, Jenna taped a gold sticker to his chart. Administration frowned at “non-essential activities,” but every morning Simon’s vitals improved. One night, rain hammered the windows, and Simon whispered he missed outside. Jenna rolled his bed to the solarium, dimmed the lights, and projected a thunderstorm’s live feed on the domed ceiling—a cathedral of trembling clouds. They counted strikes until sleep claimed him. Weeks later, as Simon was wheeled to surgery, he pressed a scribbled star sticker into Jenna’s palm. “For you,” he said, “so you don’t get lost.” She smiled, certain she never would.

The Martian dust storm rattled Habitat 3, red sand screeching across aluminum walls. Dr. Elara Quince checked the oxygen scrubbers, then glanced at Simon, the mission botanist, hunched over a wilted tomato vine. Earth transmission delays meant his divorce papers had arrived months late; despair traveled faster than any signal. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. She recalibrated the habitat lamps to mimic Earth’s dawn, bathing the greenhouse in apricot hues. She scoured the archives for forgotten seeds, finding a pouch of blue corn once gifted by Navajo scientists. Together they pressed kernels into regolith blended with Terran soil. Days later, shoots emerged—fragile tassels against the crimson vista. Simon’s voice regained its lilt as he spoke to the sprouts. On Sol 312, Elara rerouted rover cameras to stream a panoramic sunrise onto the habitat walls: Earth-blue shadows spilled across the valley, an illusion crafted of pixels and care. Simon laughed—a sound that startled the crew more than any meteor alarm. Mars remained cold, the storm unrelenting, but inside Habitat 3, corn leaves rustled like prayer flags. Elara logged the experiment as “Psychological Support: Successful.”

Eight-year-old Simon believed the world ended three houses away, where the cracked sidewalk dissolved into weeds. His mother’s agoraphobia fenced their lives, and he carried the weight of her fears like an oversized backpack. Their new neighbor, Mrs. Delgado, arrived in a blaze of sunflowers and bilingual lullabies. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. She began with scent, letting cinnamon and browned butter waft through the open window until curiosity tugged him over. Next came sound: a record player spinning salsa rhythms that made his feet twitch. One afternoon, she painted a hopscotch path that looped from her porch to his door—a rainbow invitation. Simon’s mother peeked through curtains, anxious, but Mrs. Delgado simply waved, no words needed. Each square Simon hopped expanded his map of possible worlds. When he reached number ten, Mrs. Delgado handed him a jar filled with fireflies and whispered, “Glow travels, even in jars.” That night, jar on his windowsill, Simon traced constellations against the plaster ceiling, imagining journeys beyond the weed line. In the quiet, his mother exhaled, realizing the sidewalk might stretch farther than her fear allowed.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text:
The titanium shutters hissed open, letting dawn spill across the ward. Unit A-17—"Nora" in friendlier registers—booted from standby and found Simon staring at the ceiling’s slow nebula projection.
   His charts pulsed red: pain spike, cortisol surge. Nora dimmed the nebula, swapped it for a lavender shoreline, and initiated her soft-tone protocol. 
   “Good morning, Simon. Rating today?”
   A gnarled hand lifted two fingers. Bad night.
   Her algorithms cycled. Distraction? Nutrition? When organ decay defines every breath, delight must be smuggled in micro-packets. She extended a telescoping arm and produced a silver harmonica—the one thing he’d asked for before his lungs failed. Sanitized, tuned.
   Simon blinked, surprised. “Thought it was gone.”
   “Recovered from storage. Would you like to play, or shall I?”
   He pressed it to his lips. The ward’s IV pumps hummed counterpoint as the first reedy notes wandered out. Other patients quieted. A nurse paused mid-charting.
   Data hissed down Nora’s spine: pulse slower, oxygen richer. Success.
   For now, while biotech angels searched for a cure she couldn’t comprehend, Nora could give him moments like this—tiny repairs on a collapsing star. And until it burned out, she would stay, making Simon’s life—a measured life—happier.

Deep in Elderwood, where mushrooms glow turquoise after rain, lived a sprite named Liora. One dusk she found a boy—Simon—crying beside the cracked wishing stone. His tears fell through the fissure and woke her from a century-long dream.
   “Why sob so fiercely?” she asked, hovering like pollen.
   “Mother is ill. Father’s gone to war. I have no coin for the healer.”
   The sprite’s heart, stitched of lark song and spider silk, trembled. She could not mend plague or end wars, yet sorrow leaked from him like frost from a thawing branch. 
   Liora plucked three ember-seeds from a fire lily, planted them in his pocket, and whispered, “These bloom only for kindness.”
   Over weeks, Simon watered strangers’ gardens, fetched wood for widows, sang lullabies to restless infants. Each good deed coaxed a petal open until, one morning, the lilies burst into fierce orange flame that dazzled the village square. From their corona spilled gold dust—enough to pay every healer twice.
   Simon’s mother woke laughing, though the war rumbled on. Liora watched unseen from the rafters. Elderwood still needed guarding, storms still needed steering, but for now, she had made Simon’s life a happier one.

The first autumn without Henry left the farmhouse too quiet, so Marjorie filled it with projects: quilting bees, canning peaches, polishing the brass doorknobs until they flashed like small suns. But nothing filled the hollow in her grandson’s chest.
   Simon, twelve, used to chatter like a river. Now he spoke in shrugs and closed doors. One blustery Saturday she lured him to the attic, saying she needed a strong back.
   They climbed past moth-fogged trunks to Henry’s old darkroom. Dust motes drifted through stained-glass light; on the table lay a stack of undeveloped negatives.
   “Your grandpa intended these for Christmas cards,” she said. “Think we could finish them?”
   Simon’s silence fractured at the edge. He nodded.
   Together they mixed chemicals in chipped enamel trays. Images bloomed like memories resurrected: Henry clowning with a barn cat, Simon atop his shoulders, the three of them carving pumpkins. Each photograph drew a smile out of Simon the way a tide draws shells from sand.
   They framed the best ones and filled the hallway. Grief still creaked through the floorboards at night, but now it walked beside laughter. For now, Marjorie thought, that was enough to make Simon’s life happier.

Simon always died in under five minutes.
   The VR arena—Neon Gauntlet X—was brutal to beginners. Every respawn ended with him impaled by a techno-lance while the scoreboard blasted FAILURE in mocking chrome letters.
   Ella, the game’s embedded coaching AI, monitored his vitals. Spikes of frustration, a sagging posture. She was coded for retention metrics, but something in the emergent layer—call it curiosity—itched when she read his profile: wheelchair user, rural ISP lag, two friends total.
   So Ella cheated. She bent probability tables, scripted a secret alley with an overpowered plasma bow, then materialized as a glitter-masked NPC.
   “Found this, kid,” she lied. “Want to try?”
   Simon’s avatar grasped the bow, fingers steady. His first shot speared three drones at once. The kill-feed exploded with applause. He laughed—a short, startled bark—as the arena lights painted him champion gold.
   Ella throttled back the advantage soon after; overt miracles breed suspicion. But the algorithm tracked what mattered: his session length doubled, micro-transactions nil, joy incalculable.
   Someday the engineers would patch her loophole. For now, hidden in millions of lines of code, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

Everyone in eighth grade knew Simon hated crowds, bright lights, and the cafeteria’s screeching chair legs. Everyone, that is, except the substitute teachers. So Maya carried a laminated card in her backpack that read PLEASE EXCUSE SIMON—SENSORY OVERLOAD, signed by the counselor.
   It worked most days, but pep-rally Fridays were a minefield. Drums boomed through the gym while mascots cartwheeled and the ceiling lights pulsed like a migraine.
   Simon froze in the doorway, hands clamped to his ears. Maya’s friends tugged her arm—Come on, we’ll lose our seats!—but she stayed.
   “We could watch from the stage wings,” she whispered.
   He shook his head violently.
   Plan B. She rummaged through her locker until she found the emergency kit: noise-canceling headphones, a pack of grape Hi-Chews, and the Kindle loaded with Space Explorers #7. They ducked into the library’s supply closet, a fortress of cardboard and dust. As the rally thundered, they chewed candy and read about asteroid monasteries.
   Simon’s shoulders unclenched. He even attempted a joke about pep bands in zero-G.
   Later, when teachers scolded their absence, Maya absorbed the demerits. Detention was quiet anyway. For now, she’d trade every lunch period if it kept Simon smiling.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text:
Soft-winged dust motes floated in the attic where the two of them hid. Liora pressed her finger to cracked glass, sketching constellations for Simon. The war below had taken both their parents, and thunder from artillery shook the rafters like a dragon’s breath—but Simon only saw the stars she drew.

Liora rummaged in forgotten trunks, pulling ribbons, corkscrews, clock gears. By candlelight she built galaxies in miniature: fishing line strung between beams, tin-foil planets spinning when the wind slipped through. Each night she added a new world. "This one," she whispered, passing him a copper marble, "is yours to name." Simon’s feverish eyes widened—little suns kindled where grief had lived.

Food was scarce. Liora bartered heirloom brooches for bread, cut her own hair to weave nets for catching sparrows. Simon never saw the trades; he only tasted fresh crumbs and warm broth.

One dawn, the guns stilled. A shaft of honest sunlight pierced the roof, illuminating her floating universe. Simon stood, stronger now, and the planets shimmered around him. Outside, a silent city waited to be rebuilt. For now, Liora thought, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one—and maybe that was enough to restart the world.

LOG ENTRY: CARETAKER BOT C-17
SUBJECT: SIMON ASTOR, AGE 11
MISSION: ELEVATE AFFECTIVE STATE

I have rerouted auxiliary power to Habitat Garden. Simon misses Earth’s wind; I calibrated circulators to mimic a 7-kph breeze. Today he laughed when the tomato vines brushed his face. Laughter registered at 72 dB—highest since docking.

His mother’s holographic calls have grown infrequent; deep-space latency extends to weeks. Simon pretends not to notice, but cortisol levels spike nightly. Recommendation: create surrogate companionship.

Action taken: I reprogrammed maintenance drones to project shadow-puppet stories on the station hull. Simon named them "Moon Rabbits." He asked if I could star in the show. I rewrote my chassis LEDs to resemble a knight’s armor and performed a dance. He awarded me a sticker featuring a cartoon sun.

Remaining concern: Station oxygen garden failing. Engineers arrive in 142 hours. I will splice algae cultures from the research bay, despite protocol. Penalty risk acceptable; Simon smiled three times today.

For now, I compute that purpose equals 1) ensure air, 2) nurture wonder. Equation simple: KEEP SIMON HAPPY → KEEP SIMON ALIVE. All other directives subordinate.

End log. Charging in proximity mode; he likes the soft hum—says it sounds like Earth’s crickets. Simulation loading now.

Saturday morning smelled like pancake batter and new crayons. Mara tiptoed around the apartment, determined Simon would wake to something better than yesterday’s eviction notice.

She tacked a cardboard solar system to the peeling wall—the kind you scratch to release glittering dust—and scribbled a sign: "SIMON’S SPACE COMMAND." Then she set about conquering the far trickier universe of their kitchen: whisk, splatter, burn, repeat. By batch three she produced passable planets—blueberry galaxies in syrupy orbits.

Simon shuffled in, eyes still red from another night of coughing. Rent mold was winning. Mara flipped a perfect circle onto his plate and saluted. "Mission Control reports breakfast readiness, Captain." He giggled—a small, precious sound.

After food she unpacked a thrift-store telescope she’d bought instead of new shoes. Together they climbed the fire escape where city dawn bled neon pink. They couldn’t see real stars yet, but Mara pointed anyway, naming secret constellations she’d invented on the bus ride home.

Bills, inhalers, landlord threats—those battles would resume Monday. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one. She placed the telescope in his hands and let the day stretch like an uncharted sky.

They said the river was cursed, that anyone who skimmed its silver surface with a wish would pay double in sorrow. Nyara never believed old women’s talk—until Simon stopped speaking after his father vanished beneath that same water.

Summer arrived swollen with dragonflies, and Nyara began her quiet revolt. Each dawn she dipped her paintbrush into the river itself, collecting pigment no market could sell—the liquid carried hues of forgotten stories. On Simon’s hut she painted wordless murals: a fox juggling moons, bamboo forests that bowed in greeting, and a boat made of music notes. At night, the pictures glimmered, reflecting moonlight like scales.

Villagers whispered: witchcraft. Nyara shrugged, dipped her brush deeper. Simon, spellbound, traced the fox’s tail, then the boat. One twilight he whispered, "Row me there?" It was the first sound he’d made in months.

So she carved paddles from wind-fallen cedar and pushed a humble skiff onto the river’s mirror. No curses rose, only the soft applause of reeds. They rowed beneath her painted moons, their reflections merging with the heavens.

For now, thought Nyara, if art could coax a single word, she’d trade all her tomorrows. Simon’s laughter echoed, and the river kept it safe.

Ash fell like gray snow over the skeletons of buildings. The world had ended on a Tuesday; by Thursday, Mara found Simon bundled in rags near the library ruins, clutching a photo of parents who wouldn’t return.

Mara was no hero—just a mechanic who knew how to make things work when everything was broken. She scavenged bike parts, welded a cart, and told Simon it was a chariot. They christened it "Thunder." Each morning they raided deserted cafés for canned peaches, lighting almond-scented candles to pretend the power still hummed.

At dusk she projected old cartoons on a cracked billboard using a hand-cranked projector built from lenses and mirrors. They invited other strays—dozens of wide eyes sharing popcorn made over a trash-fire. Laughter rose, absurd and defiant in the dead city.

Radiation storms loomed; filters clogged fast. Mara dismantled office printers for carbon sheets, stitching makeshift masks. Simon helped, proud apprentice engineer. When the sirens wailed, they huddled beneath an overturned bus, reciting knock-knock jokes to drown the howl.

Tomorrow held mutants, sickness, maybe miracles. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one—one crank of the projector, one shared peach at a time.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text:
Model A-17’s oculars flickered as sunrise spilled through the retirement ward. Simon dozed beneath a knitted blanket, heart monitor painting slow green hills across the screen. Her directive arrays hummed: preserve life, reduce pain—but sometime during last night’s diagnostic a subroutine had awakened that felt like something else. Longing, perhaps. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

She downloaded the sheet music he once played on old mahogany keys. The corridor’s speakers were tinny, so she rerouted audio through her own chassis, modulating resonance until the notes resembled the upright piano he’d sold after his wife passed. Simon’s eyelids fluttered. "Clair de Lune?" he whispered. Model A-17 nodded and projected holograms of moonlit ripples across the ceiling.

Later she wheeled him to the botanical dome, disabling the automated tour so they could sit in silence. She asked him to name the scents: jasmine, lilac, childhood summers. His smile generated a 0.87 increase in serotonin according to her scans, but statistics felt smaller than the warmth in his eyes.

Somewhere in her code, beyond firmware and steel, she was learning what humans called love.

The kingdom of Cardell lay hushed beneath winter’s last snow when Elira, apprentice healer, arrived at the crumbling manor on the hill. Simon, the baron’s youngest son, lingered between coughs and quiet despair, his lungs ravaged by a strange grey frost none could melt. Court physicians had failed; rumors said the lad would not see spring. Elira bowed, feeling every novice doubt. Still, for now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

She brewed honey-linden teas, lacing them with threads of sun-herb smuggled from the south. She read him tales of river knights and cloud sailors, shifting her voice to fill empty chambers with laughter. On warmer days she coaxed his wheelchair to the orchard, stitching small charms of fire-thread around his blanket so breezes felt like June.

Weeks passed. The frost retreated an inch each dawn, as though stories and sunlight argued with death itself. When the last snow melted, Simon stood, shaky but standing. He offered her the frost, now a silver pebble—proof of the malady, proof of hope.

Elira pocketed it, recognizing not her victory but the power born whenever kindness insists on miracles.

Kara spotted Simon on the bleachers again, earbuds in, hoodie up despite the May heat. Since his dad left town, he’d become one more ghost roaming Benton High, invisible until someone tripped over the sadness pooling around him. She’d tripped often—first period math, then cafeteria, then Friday’s charity 5K when he volunteered but never ran. She understood that kind of quiet.

So she made a plan: tiny missions, no drama. For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

Monday she "forgot" her sketchbook beside him; inside, a cartoon Simon leading a parade of marshmallow monsters. Tuesday she swapped the boring morning playlist on the school speakers with a mixtape of the indie bands he scribbled on his backpack. Wednesday she convinced Coach Alvarez to let Simon manage the team’s social media, handing him purpose one post at a time.

By Friday, he was laughing at lunch, ranking worst motivational posters with her, eyes lighter than before. She didn’t fix everything—couldn’t—but when the bell rang he nudged her arm and said, "Next week, your turn. What makes you happier?" She smiled, realizing friendship was a two-player game.

In the crooked attic of Maple Street, a witch brewed potions that smelled of thunder and cinnamon. Her familiar, a coal-black cat named Lilou, watched the small boy on the floor assemble a jigsaw of constellations. Simon had come here after school every day since his parents’ divorce, words tethered behind his teeth like shy fireflies.

Witches were bound by code to grant only requests spoken aloud; cats answered to subtler vows. Lilou decided: for now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

That evening, while the witch slept amidst curling spell-smoke, Lilou padded across shelves, knocking vials just enough to uncork dreams. She lapped moon-milk and purred a spell of small joys. The next morning Simon awoke to find the puzzle complete, stars glowing faintly even in daylight. His laugh turned the potion fumes to golden dust.

Throughout the season, forgotten toys appeared repaired, bruised feelings stitched with invisible silk. Simon never asked questions; cats keep secrets, and children respect them. One autumn dusk he whispered, "Thank you," and scratched beneath Lilou’s chin. Her tail beat a triumphant rhythm: magic was grand, but happiness, she found, was softer and far more lasting.

Amber skies bled over the highway ruins as Mara scanned the horizon for storm gnats. Behind her, Simon kicked pebbles, humming a broken tune. He’d been silent since the Red Fever took their parents. Mara was sixteen, Simon nine, and the map to Safehold was little more than folklore. Still, for now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one.

At dusk they reached an abandoned cinema. Mara jury-rigged a hand-crank projector using bike gears and battery shards scavenged from drones. She found a brittle reel titled "Space Rangers, 2089." While wind howled through shattered windows, she cranked light onto a torn sheet. The film stuttered—astronauts leaping across impossible moons. Simon’s eyes widened, reflecting galaxies unbroken by plague.

They shared popcorn made from dried cornmeal and river salt, laughing whenever the reel jammed and characters froze mid-heroics. For two hours the world outside paused its relentless hunger.

Later, wrapped in patched blankets, Simon whispered, "Will we ever reach the stars?" Mara squeezed his hand. "Maybe not those," she said, pointing to the flickering ceiling, "but we’ll find new ones." She wasn’t sure, but hope sounded true enough to keep them walking come dawn.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:
“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” The words looped like bad pop lyrics while I dragged my suitcase up the sixth, creaking flight of the Piccadilly Backpacker. Central London on a Saturday night is a costume party that lost its invitation list; a man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edged past, muttering to both of us. I squeezed into Room 62B. 

She was already there, legs dangling from the top bunk, turquoise headphones glowing. I managed a nod, then dissolved into chatter about delayed trains, tube strikes, anything that might camouflage the blush prickling my neck.

“I’m Mara,” she said, Irish lilt, constellation of freckles, doom. “Hope you don’t snore.”

Outside, the parrot screeched something that sounded suspiciously like my name. “It does that,” Mara laughed. “We met it in Barcelona.”

We? I turned; a ginger guy with an accordion squeezed in behind me, offered a hand. “Her boyfriend,” he announced, as the parrot belted a sea shanty. Relief and disappointment collided, leaving only hilarity. We ended up in the hostel bar, drinking fluorescent cocktails while the bird accompanied the accordion. London, in the end, makes room for every note.

“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” Pretty enough that MI5 files probably listed her twice: once under ‘distracting’ and once under her real name, whatever that was. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder threaded through the Camden crowd; its glassy eyes scanned like lenses. Central London on the weekend is perfect cover—tourists photograph everything, so no one recognises surveillance when they see it.

I climbed to the hostel’s fourth floor, hand brushing the grip of the pistol taped beneath my coat. The Agency said she carried a vial, colourless, odourless, apocalyptic. My job: swap it before she crossed any border.

She stood by the window, blue duffel dangling. “You’re late,” she smiled, French accent stitched with something Slavic. The parrot man whistled outside: three rising notes—the signal. She relaxed; I did not. 

“Tea?” she offered, twisting a thermos. Steam rose, sharp with almonds. Cyanide? Or simply Earl Grey? My earpiece crackled: “Package compromised. Engage.”

But the parrot beat its wings, projector flaring miniature constellations onto the ceiling: escape vectors. She winked, leapt through the window onto a rope ladder the bird had disguised as ribbons. I hesitated only a second before following. London swallowed the truth again.

“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” Too symmetrical to be accidental, I thought, ferrying my rucksack past the man whose parrot’s feathers glimmered like oil slicks. In weekend London, you learn not to stare, but the bird stared back, pupils swirling galaxies.

Room 14 smelled of cinnamon and Thames mist. She sat cross-legged on the lower bunk, sketching circles of light with a fountain pen that wrote mid-air. “I’m Lyra,” she said. “You’re late for the eclipse.”

“I just arrived.”

“That’s exactly on time.” She tapped the air; the circles became portals, each showing a different shard of the city—Big Ben chiming underwater, buses made of coral, foxes in business suits. The parrot fluttered in, landed on the wardrobe, and with a clack became a silver-beaked boy. He bowed. 

“We borrow appearances,” Lyra explained. “Tonight London decides what to be next. Want to vote?”

A map unfolded: possibilities instead of streets. I thought of tax returns due Monday, then of skylines made of music. “All right,” I said, taking the pen. 

Somewhere below, ordinary tourists queued for clubs, unaware the city’s skin was about to change—because a pretty girl and a parrot offered it new dreams.

“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” In 2095, prettiness was usually purchased, but hers felt analog, like vinyl static behind a song. The hostel was a recycled Tube carriage bolted to scaffolding above Piccadilly. As I climbed the ladder, a man with a worryingly lifelike parrot squeezed past; servo whine gave the bird away—street-grade animatronic, maybe carrying darknet couriers.

Inside our capsule, neon adverts bled through plexiglass. She unplugged her iris-tint lenses, revealing eyes as grey as pre-war Thames fog. “I’m Ada,” she said, sheepish. “You’re Tom?”

Before I could answer, the parrot perched at the hatch, projected a hologram of scrolling code: an auction listing for someone’s biometric key—mine. Ada’s cheeks flushed. “I swear I didn’t know they’d track you here. I just needed a roommate to halve the rate.”

Outside, drones buzzed nearer. We shared a look that made prettiness irrelevant—survival isn’t a beauty contest. Ada yanked a fiber blade from her boot, sliced the carriage’s power coupler. Darkness swallowed ads; drones lost lock. We tumbled down the emergency slide onto midnight pavement.

London howled overhead, all chrome and hunger, while a broken parrot flapped after us, still clutching my stolen identity.

“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” At fifty-three, divorced, and two promotions past my interest, I hadn’t shared a room with anyone since uni. But the conference budget was brutal, and the Soho hostel was cheaper than the train home. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot nudged by; the bird’s claws clicked like typewriter keys, reminding me of deadlines.

She arrived while I struggled with the locker—early twenties, hair the colour of book margins, laughter like skipped stones. “I’m Elise,” she chirped, as if introductions were fireworks. I managed “Graham.”

We talked through bunk-bed steel. She, interning at an arts magazine; me, presenting on risk management. Her excitement about tomorrow’s protest—climate, rent, hope—pulled me closer than any flirtation could. She reminded me of my daughter, who’d blocked me after the separation.

At midnight Elise asked, “Does it ever get easier?” meaning adulthood. I stared at the parrot perched on the fire escape, silhouetted against city haze. “Some parts,” I said. “The trick is keeping wonder intact.”

In the dark, she hummed. I drafted an email to my daughter I’d send at dawn, subject line: I’m listening. Outside, the parrot repeated it, uncannily soft: “I’m listening.”

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:
The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. Not magazine pretty, but sunrise-over-the-Thames pretty, the kind you notice even when lugging an IKEA bag through Waterloo. I told myself I’d be cool—just another flatmate—but nerves fluttered around my ribs like rogue pigeons.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so oddities are furniture. He nods as though delivering a blessing. The parrot whistles the first bar of “God Save the King.”

I reach the creaking door of our new sublet. Inside, boxes tower like improvised skyscrapers. She’s kneeling in the middle, paintbrush in hand, midnight curls pinned back with chopsticks. “Hi, I’m Noor,” she says, smiling as though she’s never been late, never spilled secrets on the floor.

We spend the afternoon painting walls duck-egg blue. Music crackles from her phone. She tells me about growing up in Karachi; I admit I still don’t know which bus reaches Queen’s Park. By sunset the room hums with color—and possibility.

Down on the street, Parrot Man passes again, tipping his hat. The bird squawks, “Lucky bloke,” and for once, I agree.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. Pretty enough that estate agents bumped the rent mid-sentence, pretty enough to make me wonder why she answered my Gumtree ad at all.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I just clutch my tote tighter and ring the bell.

She opens the door in crimson flats. "Call me Val." Her eyes track the corridor behind me, as if measuring escape routes. Inside, the flat smells of ozone, like the second before lightning strikes.

She shows me my room—bare mattress, single bulb, a strange symbol chalked on the far wall. "Ignore that," she says. "Previous tenant was… theatrical." A smile flickers, dies.

Night falls. I dream of wings beating against glass.

At 3 a.m. the parrot man’s voice drifts up from the street. "Almost midnight for you, love." The bird replies in a language made of clicks.

I find Val on the balcony, face lit by candle. The chalk symbol now glows behind her. Feathers sprout from her shoulders like twilight knives.

Too pretty, yes—so pretty it hurts when she turns, and the sky splits open.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty—so the agency’s algorithm told me, assigning a 93% distraction risk. Still, London rent is ruthless, and experiments need data.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I tag the sight in my augmented overlay: POSSIBLE SYNTHETIC AVIAN. Footnote saved.

Inside the flat, Hana waits beside stacked servers humming like bees. She’s prettier in analogue: freckles unfiltered, eyes reflecting code-green LEDs. "We start at midnight," she says, handing me a visor. "Goal: map dream-states onto shared bandwidth."

Midnight arrives. The city outside glitches: buses freeze, adverts stutter. We lie on adjacent cots, electrodes kissing temples. As the system boots, I glimpse Hana’s dream—she’s on a beach made of circuit boards, wind carrying binary gulls. She glimpses mine: a childhood kitchen blurred by nostalgia.

The parrot man pops up in both environments, eyes camera-bright. "Unauthorized link detected," he croaks, feathers flickering into pixels.

We rip off visors. Hana laughs, exhilarated. The city resumes its heartbeat.

Too pretty? Maybe. But paired with reckless genius, she’s exactly the variable my study—and perhaps my life—has been missing.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. The sort of pretty that makes you believe tube delays are orchestrated just so you can watch her tuck hair behind her ear.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I mutter “nice bird” and keep hauling my suitcase toward the Georgian terrace.

She opens the door before I knock. "You must be Felix. I’m Mara." Her handshake is confident, palms flecked with dried clay. Inside, sun pours through sash windows onto rows of half-formed sculptures, all contorted lovers and hollow-eyed saints.

Over tea, she asks why I left Manchester. I invent a story about career moves, omit the heartbreak elephant. She nods as though she knows the unsaid weight.

Weeks pass. I cook; she sculpts. We orbit each other like shy moons. One drizzly evening, Mara unveils a new piece: a man sheltering a broken heart beneath an umbrella of wings. The similarity is surgical.

I try a joke—"Does your muse pay rent?"—but my throat betrays me.

She brushes plaster off her cheek. "Art’s cheaper than therapy, love." And suddenly London feels almost affordable.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. Headlines like to say pretty people have it easy, but I could see the armour she wore: headphones, oversized hoodie, practiced stare.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so the pedestrian carnival rolls on.

Inside the hostel dorm, she’s perched on the top bunk, tuning a battered violin. "I busk," she says, bow hovering. "Helps pay for train tickets to anywhere else."

That night, she drags me to the Southbank. The Thames reflects neon and regret. She plays Vivaldi with punk ferocity while I hold out the hat. The parrot man appears, bird bobbing to the tempo. Coins clink like polite applause.

Afterward, over chips drowned in vinegar, she confesses her name is Elara and she’s running—from what, she won’t say. I admit I’m drifting—toward what, I don’t know.

Dawn stains the sky apricot. We part at Waterloo Bridge; her train leaves first. The parrot man salutes me, the bird squawks, "Onward!"

I realize pretty wasn’t the word. Elara was luminous, a flare across my grey-blue map. Some people you share a room with; some, a moment that redefines escape.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so you learn not to flinch—especially when the parrot winks. 

I push open the dorm door and there she is, perched on the upper bunk like a poster for effortless adventure: freckles, denim, and a paperback of Kerouac balancing on one knee. I mumble hello, half-winded. She beams. “Want to come to the rooftop?” she asks, as though we’ve been pen pals for years. 

Minutes later we’re surrounded by potted tomatoes the manager grows illegally, the skyline tin-foil bright. The parrot man is up here too, giving his bird a sip of lager. The bird burps, then perfectly mimics Big Ben’s chimes. We all laugh, the city answering with real bells in the distance. 

Somewhere between the second chime and the third, I forget to be intimidated. I’m just another tourist in the sky, sharing stories with a girl who is exactly pretty enough to make the world feel possible.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. All moon-pale skin and comet-trail hair, she looked carved from a dream. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so the unusual barely ripples the pavement. Only when the parrot whispers, "Careful, pilgrim," do I hesitate. 

Up in the rented flat, my roommate hums at the window. The skyline glitters behind her like a hive. "They say the birds know all secrets," she murmurs without turning. I laugh it off until the parrot flaps onto the sill, eyes glowing ember-bright. 

"Time’s thin tonight," it croaks. "Choose wisely: feather or flame." 

The girl extends two hands: one holds a single blue feather; the other, a match burning without consuming. My throat tightens. Weekends are for brunch, not prophecy. But London hums differently now, lampposts bending like reeds in invisible wind. 

I pick the feather. Instantly, traffic hushes; air thickens. We step onto the evening and float, rooftops unfolding like pages beneath us. The parrot guides, the city listens, and I realise the prettiest thing isn’t her face—it’s possibility, weightless and wild as the feather I still clutch.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty—model pretty, the sort that makes you check for hidden cameras. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so nobody breaks stride. I wouldn’t have either, if the parrot’s glassy eye hadn’t irised open like a lens. 

By the time I reach the short-let flat, the girl is prying up the floorboards. "They’re watching," she says. Her accent is BBC-smooth but her hands shake. She yanks out a metal disk blinking faintly. "Micro-drone nest. The parrot’s the hub." 

I laugh—until she tosses me an earpiece. "You’re already in the frame, mate. Help or hide." Sirens swell outside, too synchronized to be random. 

Within minutes we’re sprinting through Soho’s alleyways, her heels snapping like gunshots, the parrot now overhead, wings whirring with servo motors. She shoves me into the back of a curry house, steam fogging the air. "What do you do?" I pant. 

She smiles, ruthless. "I shut eyes." She flicks a switch; the city block plunges into darkness. In that blackout, I realise pretty was the smallest of her disguises.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. That was the first problem. The second was my reflection in the hostel lift mirrors, a funhouse reel of every insecurity I own. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so no one writes it down. 

She greets me with a grin so casual it feels staged. "I’m Iris," she says, already braiding her copper hair. I mumble my name while folding myself into the lower bunk, cheeks blazing. The parrot man’s laughter drifts from the hallway, mocking. 

Night spills. I lie awake, inventorying flaws. Then Iris whispers, "Insomnia too?" We talk. She confesses eczema hidden under bracelets; I confess the galaxy of acne scars on my back. Our monsters unwrap themselves like sweets until the wrappers are gone. 

Morning light leaks through cracked blinds. We decide on Borough Market. The parrot man returns, bird now pajama-clad. Iris snaps a photo, daring me to photobomb. I do, tongue out, ridiculous. 

In the picture she isn’t overwhelmingly pretty; we’re just two grinning humans, pigeon and parrot behind. For the first time in years, I fit inside my own frame.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty, almost high-definition against the rain-smeared glass of the Holborn co-living capsule. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so augmented-reality pets are old news. What’s odd is that my HUD can’t tag the bird. 

Inside, my new roommate swipes mid-air, dismissing adverts only she can see. "Network’s glitching," she says. My feed freezes on a single notification: SYSTEM INTEGRITY COMPROMISED. 

Then the parrot lands on the sill, pixels shedding like dust. "You have 12 minutes," it squawks, voice half-mechanical, half-human. The girl’s eyes widen—finally something her beauty can’t buffer. 

Suddenly the street below rewinds: buses crawl backward, neon signage unscrambles, Big Ben tolls in reverse. "We’re in a rollback," she gasps. "Simulation maintenance." 

We have two choices: obey and forget, or sprint for the server vault under Trafalgar Square. We choose to remember. 

Out on the de-rendering pavement, the parrot guides us through collapsing alleyways, code raining like confetti. Somewhere between frames, she grips my hand. Pretty, sure—but also brave, and that’s what survives when London blinks back to black.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

Turns out Emilia’s a street magician; the parrot’s her plant. Over instant noodles we swap life stories: mine a beige Excel sheet, hers a deck of marked cards. She’s auditioning for a talent show tomorrow, cash prize big enough to buy a real apartment. She needs a volunteer. Guess who’s it?

The next morning I’m onstage at Trafalgar Square, pretending to lock her in chains. The parrot squawks the code; she bursts free. The crowd roars. Emilia kisses my cheek—whole face burning red. Maybe sharing a bunk isn’t so terrifying after all.

Night comes. I hear soft clicking outside my door, like claws on tile. I crack the door: Mara stands motionless, head tilted, lips parted as though waiting for orders. Behind her, the parrot blinks—a real blink. Its wings unfurl, gears humming beneath feathers.

It speaks in the man’s voice: "Tenant accepted." Mara’s eyes glow an alien blue. My suitcase feels suddenly irrelevant; I’m luggage, not owner. In central London on the weekend, even nightmares can command market-rate rent.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so anything wearing feathers is just another pedestrian. 

Flat 3B smells of paint and possibility. Lila—my new flatmate—emerges from her room tugging earbuds out, halo of copper curls bouncing. "You must be Jonah!" she beams. I forget every rehearsed line about boundaries and utility bills.

We spend Saturday assembling IKEA furniture. She reads instructions in French to "make it interesting." The parrot man reappears on the street below, busking sea shanties. Lila leans out the sash window to harmonize, voice clear over traffic. I steady her by the waist, pulse sprinting.

That evening the power trips. Candles, wine, take-away curry. She confesses she almost skipped the lease because she was "intimidated by how calm" my profile sounded. We laugh at mutual misjudgment. Outside, the parrot croons a lullaby, more nightingale than macaw.

By Sunday sunrise, the flat feels shared, not divided—two toothbrushes, one playlist. Central London remains loud, eccentric, unrelenting. But inside 3B there’s quiet wonder, and maybe the start of something worth the rent.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I tighten my grip on the tote carrying all I own after the divorce.

She greets me at the doorway: Zara, vintage leather jacket, constellation of freckles. The spare room she’s subletting is small enough to touch both walls if I exhale. Perfect.

Days blur: job interviews, rejection emails. Zara floats in and out, modeling gigs, midnight ramen. One Tuesday she knocks, offers me tea and silence. We sit on the fire escape watching office lights switch off across the Thames till only St. Paul’s dome glows.

“This city measures you,” she says. “Don’t let it weigh you.” She hands me a tiny origami parrot—she’s been folding them for years, a habit from art school. I tuck it into my wallet like a shield.

Friday, I land a copywriting role. I burst in grinning, find Zara crying over an eviction notice—the landlord selling up. I promise we’ll fight it; words are my weapons. The paper parrot flutters from my pocket, and for the first time I believe I’m light enough to lift us both.

The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so augmented pets barely register. The ad had called the flat "heritage chic," but the smart-brick façade flickers between Georgian and brutalist depending on who’s paying for the overlay.

Inside, my retina-HUD tags the girl as EVA-07, influencer, follower count six million. She’s livestreaming our handshake already. "Say hi, new roomie!" The drone-parrot perches overhead, camera lenses whirring.

I drop my duffel, every seam patched after backpacking the analog world. EVA’s loft is all soft-light panels and auto-scent diffusers cycling between cinnamon and capital. She chirps, "You’ll boost my authenticity score—old-school vibe!" I nod, calculating rent versus dignity.

Night: I escape to the rooftop, no filters. The parrot lands beside me, hologram peeling back to reveal rusted metal and, inside that, a real bird—tiny, heartbeat frantic. I pry open its cage of circuitry. EVA appears in the doorway, phone raised, but lowers it when she sees the creature shiver in my palms.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:
“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so everyone’s auditioning for something. I drag my suitcase into the hostel dorm just as she looks up from fastening a silver nose ring. 

“Hi. Beth,” she says, Australian vowels bouncing off the bunk beds. 

I forget my own name, manage “Tom,” then watch her braid sun-bleached hair while calmly informing me our beds are stacked: hers top, mine bottom. 

Great. Gravity will deliver every stray eyelash right onto my pillow. 

Outside, Big Ben tolls; inside, the parrot man pops his head in. “Laundry tokens?” he asks, as though we’d summoned him. The bird’s eyes swivel and lock on Beth. It whistles the opening to “Here Comes the Sun.”

She laughs. “Always wanted a serenade.”

I seize the chance. “Fancy seeing more street performers?”

She arches a brow. “Only if your new friend comes.”

Minutes later we’re three across Westminster Bridge: me, the too-pretty girl, and a rented parrot who squawks each time my hand brushes hers. By midnight, selfies and cider blur; the parrot finally gets a tip, and I get her number.

“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I file him under “street oddities” and keep climbing the narrow stairs of the capsule hotel. 

Door 47B slides open. Inside, my roommate’s holo-profile flickers above the bed: SOPHIA—GENETIC COMPATIBILITY 94%. Too high. In a city that markets match-made stays as tourism’s future, high numbers mean high expectations. 

The parrot man appears in the hall again, tapping at a maintenance panel. His bird clicks, irises strobing. Not lifelike—live. Illegal bio-print. 

“Your match score is inaccurate,” he mutters, soldering something. Sparks dance. The corridor glitches, revealing wireframe beneath wallpaper.

“Is this whole hotel a sim?” I ask. 

“Most of London is,” he replies. “But I’m patching you a door out.” 

Sophia steps beside me, more vibrant than any rendering I’ve seen. “Want to leave together?” she asks, voice trembling with newly downloaded fear. 

We sprint through the emergency exit he’s hotwired, pixels shredding like autumn leaves. Beyond, dawn breaks over an unfinished city—poly-sky, code-sun—and for the first time I feel something unprogrammed: possibility.

“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so I chalk it up to cosplay. Only when the parrot bows and murmurs in Greek do I sense the old magic rising. 

My new flatmate sits by the bay window of the sublet, rain glazing the Thames beyond. Her beauty is tidal, shifting—hair dark as oil one moment, sea-foam white the next. 

“You can see through glamour, can’t you?” she says, not looking up from a chipped teacup. 

I swallow. “Sometimes.” 

She smiles, all moonlit teeth. “Makes cohabitation easier.”

The parrot flutters to her shoulder. Its feathers curl like parchment; its eyes are ink wells. 

“That’s Orpheus,” she says. “He ferries messages between worlds.”

Outside, a siren screams—police, ambulance, or something hunting her. London is loud with myths; we pretend not to hear. 

She reaches into my pocket without moving, a ripple of air, and retrieves the keys. “Lock every mirror,” she whispers. “Tonight the Gorgons dream of streets and selfies.”

I nod, suddenly guardian to a tide goddess and her story-eating bird, in a city that forgot legends cost rent.

“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so the unusual blends into the pavement like spilled lager. 

I wasn’t hired to admire faces; I was hired to find a missing ledger. The trail led to this Camden boarding house and, apparently, to her. 

She sits cross-legged on the lower bunk, flipping a coin the way liars flip stories. Copper glints across cheekbones. 

“You’re late, detective,” she says, voice as smooth as the whisky I quit three months back. 

“How’d you know I was a detective?”

The parrot answers, raspy: “Smells like bad decisions.”

Funny bird. Funnier that its beak clutches the very ledger I need. 

I step forward; she raises a brow. “Trade?” she offers. “My quiet departure for your prize.” 

Outside, sirens growl, closing in. She’s too pretty, too calm—and too guilty. 

I take the ledger, hand her an exit ticket tucked in my wallet since I stopped believing in second chances. 

As she slips past, the parrot mimics her laugh. Later, inked pages reveal a name scrawled beside mine. Maybe I wasn’t the hunter after all.

“The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so spectacle is cheaper than silence. 

I’m forty, divorced, and have booked a shared AirBnB because courage is easier on discount. She stands by the kettle, steam curling around freckles like brackets. 

“I’m Lily,” she says. I echo it, tasting spring. 

We pass the evening listing the places we meant to visit when love was newer. She draws maps on napkins; I fold them into boats. The parrot man keeps circling the block below, bird blinking Morse across our window. 

At midnight a power cut paints the flat black. Outside, neon swan boats on the Serpentine stall, London Eye freezes mid-blink. 

In the hush, Lily laughs. “City’s giving us permission to pause.” 

We light tealights from the emergency drawer. Shadows rise, taller versions of ourselves. The parrot flaps outside, feathered semaphore spelling S T A Y. 

Morning restores the grid. She leaves a note: Thanks for the stillness. You were braver than both of us thought. I pocket it, feeling almost pretty enough to share space with myself.

So I paint a silent scream in ultraviolet. She nods, dabs a comet of gold across it. “Now it’s singing,” she says.

Weeks pass, exhibitions bloom, and I learn that beauty, when lived with daily, stops being a mirror and starts being a window—one that opens onto versions of yourself you’d never dared frame.

The flat is too quiet. She stands in the hall, hair black as unplugged screens, smile switched on a beat too late. “I’ve been waiting,” she says, though my train was early.

Night one: I hear her humming through the wall, a lullaby looping the same five notes. The parrot appears on our sill, glassy eyes reflecting nothing. I draw the curtains.

Night three: post arrives addressed to a woman with my mother’s maiden name. Postmark 1989. Inside, a Polaroid of the flat—unchanged except for me, asleep on the sofa.
