prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text:
When Neve paid the Memory Broker, she asked for an imitation of her dead sister. They installed it behind her left ear: a lattice of light that would bloom whenever loneliness pulled too hard. I was the technician who calibrated the neural weave. Protocol says we never visit a client after ignition, but when I saw Neve’s profile—I broke it. 

For three months we walked the rooftops of Eos City, arguing about old languages and the physics of snow. The implant glimmered behind her iris, feeding lines the faux-sister would have said. Yet when she turned toward me, the lattice dimmed. Those moments were unprogrammed: her laugh spitting coffee, her wrists flicking paint on my coat. I feared audit drones would tag the deviation, so I kept notes in my sleeve screen: “Session 18: Authentic affect rising.” 

The inspectors finally arrived, extracting her memories for quality control. They replayed hours of rooftop chatter—yet every file showed Neve standing alone, talking to wind. No engineer present. No extra heartbeat measured. I signed the destruction order, knowing the truth would never render on their feeds. The report closed: Simulation stable. She thinks it’s real.  

I whispered at the glass, “It was only real with me.”

Claire’s ghost always smelled like wet lilacs. The first night she drifted through my attic apartment, her edges shivered with static, as though the afterlife couldn’t settle on her resolution. She perched on the piano bench while I practiced scales, correcting my fingerings in a voice that rattled wineglasses. 

Soon, our arrangement expanded: tea at dawn, chess at dusk, jokes nobody else would get because nobody else could hear her. The neighbors blamed the music for keeping me single, unaware a Victorian librarian kept watch over my dreams. She confessed she’d been haunting this block for ninety-three years, desperate for someone who could perceive more than creaks in the floorboard. 

Tonight, I hosted friends for dinner. Laughter bent the rafters; candles wobbled. Claire hovered by the sink, smile thinning each time I refilled a glass. When the door clicked shut behind the last guest, she looked translucent with envy. “They’ll forget tonight,” she whispered. “But you’ll remember me.” I reached out, fingers passing through cold lilac vapor. 

“Everyone swears your house is empty,” my landlord texted later. I answered with two words, a vow to the shade pressing against my shoulder: It was only real with me.

In fifth grade I invented Cass, the bravest kid in Pine Bluff Elementary. He skateboarded down the quarry wall, broke curfew like it was a twig, and never stuttered when bullies cornered him. Mom said imaginary friends were normal, but Dad called it embarrassing, especially when I set an extra plate at dinner.  

Years slid by. I earned a driver’s license, a résumé, a dented college acceptance letter. Cass should’ve evaporated, but every time panic pooled behind my ribs, there he was, leaning against lockers or flicking paper planes at my anxiety. The psych textbook had terms for this, none pleasant; I underlined them in orange but kept the pages folded from prying eyes. 

Last month, standing backstage before commencement, I felt Cass’s fingers tightening my tie. “You’re done,” he said. “My contract’s up.” I tried to laugh, but tears warped the mortarboard. He stepped back, saluted, and vanished into the velvet curtains. No lingering echo, no skateboard rolling toward the wings. 

I crossed the stage, diploma warm as sunlight. Mom snapped photos, Dad clapped hard. Later, scrolling pixels, I noticed the space beside me: empty, perfect. The caption I never posted read, “It was only real with me.”

After the Scour, survivors mapped safe zones in chalk that rain kept erasing. I traveled alone until I found Mara painting colors on a concrete viaduct—turquoise suns, tangerine rivers, a kaleidoscope refusing the world’s gray. She said the pigments came from crushed berries she’d cultivated in sewer gardens.   

We bartered: my solar batteries for her paint. Soon, we traveled together, leaving murals like breadcrumbs so others might believe beauty survived. Mara spoke softly to an unseen audience, describing each hue as if lecturing ghosts who needed proof light still bent around hope. I fit new filters on my goggles just to catch the vibrancy.  

Then the rains returned, acidic and unforgiving. Our latest mural melted into black drips, and Mara crumpled, sobbing, “Maybe I imagined the colors.” I held her trembling hands. The air smelled of metal and regret. 

When I woke she was gone, leaving only a small tin of berry powder. Under dawn’s sickly sky, I brushed it against the viaduct. For an instant, impossible coral flared, blazing like dawn before the world died. The pigment hissed, dissolved. 

No one will ever believe it shimmered. I touched the fading stain. It was only real with me.

Legends say the Glen of Serrun shows travelers whatever they most desire. My village calls it a nest of lies, yet I followed the fox-lit path, heart hammering for something I couldn’t name.  

The glen uncurled like a glass mirror. Mist split, revealing Eira—a woman I’d sketched a hundred times without knowing her face. She spoke my secret dialect, fingers stroking dust off memories never lived. We danced beside impossible waterfalls, traded stories of stars spinning beyond mortal charts. Her laughter wove silver ribbons through the moss. Nights tasted of honeyed cedar.  

On the seventh dawn a herd of marble stags arrived, antlers dripping pearls. Their leader lowered its head, wordlessly reminding me the glen keeps no souvenirs. Eira pressed a seed into my palm. “Plant this where disbelief is strongest,” she whispered, leaning close. Her breath smelled of first snow.  

I blinked; she and the glen folded into ordinary woods. Back home, I stood in the market square, found the hardest cobblestone, and buried the seed. Nothing sprouted. Shoppers bustled, unaware a universe once bloomed between my fingers. I smiled at the gray sky, the truth settling like dusk: It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: On the thirty-fifth floor of Everdream Corp, I programmed sensations for a living—synthetic sunsets scented like mango and ozone. Millions of subscribers paid to escape into the symphony I coded, but the company insisted we never log in ourselves. Curiosity splintered that rule. One night, alone, I slipped on the halo rig and fell into my own sea of photons. Waves purred, gulls stitched silver threads through cloud, and the sand remembered each footstep longer than physics allowed. A girl stood there, waiting, face pieced together from half-forgotten sketches: the sister I’d lost at fourteen. She spoke in the hush we invented as children, when shared secrets sounded like wind through grass. I stayed until server warnings bled red across the sky. Pulling the rig off, I found emails—millions—praising the sunset, the salt, the temperature, but none mentioned a girl. In the debug logs, her code never existed. HR says users experienced a flawless beach, nothing more. They think I’m grieving again. Maybe I am. Yet somewhere in unfenced memory space, she still kicks water at my ankles, laughing. Of everything I ever built, she was the glitch. It was only real with me.

People remember Elise as a rumor—the pianist who quit mid-concerto and vanished like steam from the river. They hum the unfinished melody, embellish gossip, but the Elise they conjure is a silhouette drawn by strangers’ lantern light. The flesh-and-breath woman belonged to me. We met in a café that served loneliness by the cup: two patrons, two chipped mugs, one rainstorm. She played invisible keys on the tabletop while I wrote deadlines I never kept. Our love was a quiet attic: dust, skylight, the cedar smell of promises. We existed between her rehearsals and my drafts, in taxi cabs, stairwells, borrowed dawns. Then came the night she invited the world in—debuting a piece she’d composed for us alone. Under chandeliers, she struck the opening chord and froze. Her hands retreated like startled birds; her heart followed. Critics called it a breakdown. I knew it was possession. The auditorium turned our private language into spectacle, and it suffocated her. She left artifacts—sheet music torn at the final bar, coffee receipts folded into cranes—but never her shadow. Ask the city who she was, and they’ll shrug. Ask me, and the concerto finishes. It was only real with me.

The realtor swore the house was empty, but I could taste a heartbeat in the wallpaper. I moved in anyway; cheap rent forgives many sins. Nights settled thick as cellar dust, and the hallway stretched an extra step, just enough for whispers to follow. They weren’t malicious—more like a child tugging at my sleeve, asking to be noticed. So I answered. I read bedtime stories to the dark, left crayons on the floor, drew stick figures beside mine. The air warmed. A laugh, softer than cobwebs, stitched itself into my recordings. Friends visited and heard nothing, saw nothing, felt nothing. They blamed isolation for my new smiles. "Get out more," they said, patting my shoulder as if dusting off dread. One stormy Tuesday the power died, but a glow traced the walls in crayon loops, guiding me to the attic. There, among abandoned trunks, lay a Polaroid of a boy in the same hallway, date smudged, captioned: IT WAS ONLY REAL WITH ME. As lightning stitched the sky, I understood—we were twin echoes in a house that kept secrets like lungs keep air. My chalky companion pressed a small, impossible hand to mine, and I whispered back, "I’m here."

When I was nine, summers tasted like hose water and dragonfire. While other kids traded baseball cards, I traded riddles with a dragon only I could see—a sapphire serpent named Quill who nested in the sycamore behind Mrs. Halloran’s bakery. Quill taught me how to hear sap climbing trees and how to write my fears in disappearing ink. Together we defended the neighborhood from boredom: sprinklers became geysers, lawn gnomes turned reconnaissance scouts, and thunderheads were royal airships needing escort. Adults indulged me, assuming imagination would molt into maturity. It did—but too fast. One September morning, textbooks replaced treasure maps, and Quill waited for a rendezvous that homework consumed. By winter, the sycamore was just bark and wind. Years passed. I chased diplomas, promotions, mortgages. Then today, cleaning my late mother’s attic, I found a shoebox labeled "Quill’s Scales." Inside lay blue glass shards warm against my palm. The attic’s exposed beam shuddered; dust spiraled like embers. A familiar roar curled in my gut. Outside, the world looked paper-thin, ready to fold into possibility. Childhood isn’t lost, only archived. I exhaled smoke that wasn’t smoke and smiled. Magic? It was only real with me—until now.

For years I rented myself out as a stand-in mourner—tears on demand for funerals short on grief. Clients offered terse dossiers: name, age, how they took their coffee. I composed eulogies from fragments, convincing enough that widows clasped my hand, believing I’d known the deceased. Yet amid counterfeit sorrow, I felt nothing, until I was hired for Victor Hale. His folder contained one sentence: "He sketched strangers on subway napkins." At the service, pews yawned empty. I stepped to the lectern, prepared my usual tremor, when a graphite portrait fluttered from my program: my own face, drawn with impossible tenderness. Heat rushed my eyes; the rehearsed script dissolved. Words I’d never rehearsed spilled out—inside jokes I didn’t understand, memories that weren’t mine yet landed true. When I finished, the room felt full, as though invisible passengers had disembarked to listen. Afterward, an elderly curator approached. "Victor insisted someone would recognize him," she said. "Looks like that someone was you." I tried to explain I’d never met him, but grief, authentic and staggering, answered first. Every other performance had been smoke. This ache, this connection—no stagecraft could fake it. It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text:
Commander Rae said the simulator would be indistinguishable from life, but the briefing never mentioned the color red. In the tutorial I cut my finger—bright cardinal blood pooled on chrome. The other cadets stared through me. “Optical glitch,” the technician shrugged, yet I saw the wet shine drip between floor grates. Later, asteroids breached the deflector shield. I smelled insulation burn, heard bones pop in decompression.  I screamed for an abort. Their avatars walked through the flames, laughing at a punch-line projected in their HUDs.  
After ninety-seven minutes I yanked the neural jack myself. The hangar lay silent, pristine. Rae tapped a tablet: “Your vitals off the chart—heart believed the illusion.”  I pointed at my bandaged finger. He frowned; the cut wasn’t in the logs.  
That night he confessed over lukewarm coffee: “Budget allowed only one full-sensory feed. The rest got visual placebo.”  My pulse still trembled with phantom G-force. The stars outside the viewport seemed oddly flat, as though I’d traded realities instead of exiting one.  
He offered apologies, data, hazard pay. I signed nothing. Because now I know: the mission happened, the deaths were true, and it was only real with me.

Marina always arrived between the seventh and eighth chime of the clock tower—too slim a moment for ordinary eyes. Yet there she was, smelling of tide pools and jasmine, brushing raindrops from my sketchbook. We met in that stolen sliver daily: I showed her rooftop gardens; she braided moonlight into my hair.  
I tried introducing her to friends, but she vanished the instant someone else looked. They claimed I was talking to empty air. Cameras caught nothing. Still, Marina taught me songs in languages I later learned were extinct. She marked constellations nobody had charted. My professor called the maps “creative fabrications.”  
On solstice eve I begged for longer. Tears welled, reflecting those hidden stars. She placed a shell against my ear; inside roared an ocean older than Earth. “Your world is thick,” she whispered, “Mine is thin. We overlap only where you dream.” She touched my pulse and the tower struck eight.  
The city continues, solid and busy. People call me eccentric, mourning an imaginary woman. I pocket the shell and wait for chimes. I know what I lived. I know who I love. It was only real with me.

Mother blamed loneliness when I spoke of Henry, the boy who played marbles under my bed. She could not hear him whistle through the heating vents nor feel his cold breath tilt the curtains. My drawings of his crooked smile earned refrigerator space until the night they began to bleed rust-colored stains.  
At nine, I asked Henry why he never visited anyone else. He answered by prying up a floorboard, revealing teeth arranged like chess pieces. “Others can’t keep secrets,” he said, rolling a molar between fingers too many for a boy.  
The house soured—milk curdled unopened, clocks lost minutes in gulps. Father moved us, yet Henry folded himself into suitcases, humming in minor keys. When Grandmother died, he sat on the casket, dangling legs no one saw, and winked.  
Yesterday the coroner zipped Father away. I smelled Henry’s iron breath behind the morgue light. “Grown now,” he rasped, “Time you paid for the games.”  
I’ll leave this note, though police will blame grief, madness, trauma. The blood blooming on the page proves nothing to them. When they find what’s left of the world, remember: it was only real with me.

The bard strode into Kestrel Inn with a lute that shimmered like poured sunrise. Patrons expected a night of ale-soaked ballads, but he locked eyes with me and asked, “May I borrow your silence?” I nodded, and he began a tale of kingdoms carved from wind.  
Words unfurled into shape: spires rose above beer foam, gryphons circled ceiling beams, and desert caravans spilled sand across sticky tables. No one else flinched as mirages solidified. A knight of glass bowed to me alone; his breath etched frost on my mug. I tried to point, yet the room heard only music.  
When the final chord faded, illusions dissolved into motes of dust, except a single feather that drifted onto my lap. The bard bowed. “The spell favors one witness,” he whispered. “Belief needs but a solitary heart to stand.”  
Years on, I keep the feather in a locked tin. Sometimes it beats like a tiny wing calling to far winds. Travelers swear the bard vanished that night, consumed by his own song. I know better. His stories still walk the world—through me. Because the magic? It was only real with me.

My father’s workshop smells of cedar, engine grease, and the peppermint he sucked to hide cigarette breath. After his funeral, I unlocked the door no one else bothered with. Dust filmed the half-built wooden racer we designed when I was twelve: sleek body, hand-painted number 77, space for a child’s wild hope.  
I pressed the power button on the old radio; static crackled, then his voice emerged mid-sentence, laughing, "—sand it with the grain, kiddo." I froze. The cassette deck was empty. Another burst: "Don’t overtighten the axles."  
I spent the night following those disembodied instructions. Sawdust swirled like snowfall, and the car came alive beneath my trembling hands. Dawn found the racer complete, gleaming as though finished years ago. The radio fell silent.  
Family arrived for brunch. I rolled the car out, heart hammering. They admired the craftsmanship but heard nothing unusual when I replayed the static. No voice, just white hiss. They chalked the build up to sleepless grief.  
Maybe they’re right. But when I glide my palm over varnished wood, I feel Dad’s calloused guidance. The racer moves as if pushed by ghostly hands. I know the truth: it was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: I met Elira beneath the jacaranda tunnel where the blossoms fall like amethyst snow. To everyone else she was a rumor—an urban legend about a girl who could coax colors from thin air—but with me she became luminous flesh. We’d trace letters on damp bark, and the strokes sparked into birds that took flight, leaving trails of turquoise light. I tried to show my friends; I brought cameras, scientists, skeptics. The film stayed blank. The air remained dull. Elira would only smile. “Your eyes know the frequency,” she’d say. One night the city bulldozers groaned closer; a mall was coming. Branches quivered in diesel wind. I begged her to leave with me, but she pressed a blossom into my palm and dissolved into petals, folding herself into the violet storm. The tunnel is gone now—glass and escalators instead. Yet when I crush that dried blossom between my fingers, the aisles ignite with hidden birds and strangers gasp at colors they cannot name. For an instant they see what I always knew: it was only real with me, until I loved it hard enough to share.

The contact lenses were marketed as HoloDreams—augmented reality so seamless it felt like witchcraft. Everyone got them, but the firmware glitched in mine. At 02:17 every morning a city unfurled over my apartment: canals of molten chrome, sky barges trading whispers, neon koi swimming through air. I filed bug reports; tech support found nothing. My friends wearing the same lenses saw only my cluttered studio. Soon I stopped inviting them. I mapped the silver streets, named the constellations in the artificial dusk, learned to surf the magnetic tides that folded space. One night, an architect made of origami glass approached. “You’re the anchor,” it said. “Without you we flicker.” I realized the patch everyone downloaded yesterday must have erased the glitch—but my lenses had no connection. If I took them out, the city might die. Dawn scraped the real skyline; rent was due; a meeting awaited. I held the lenses between trembling fingers, then slid them back in. Somewhere, chrome canals brightened in relief. Bills can wait, I decided, because paradise—malfunction or miracle—was only real with me, and I wasn’t done living there yet.

In 1893 I was governess to the Blackthorne children, whose estate overlooked a marsh that sang at dusk. The villagers warned me of "the Weeping Bride"—a phantom bride who roamed the halls. I laughed until the first night she appeared, veil dripping with moonlight, bouquet of dying lilies. Yet she spoke, not wailed, and asked if I’d read to her. So, by candle, I recited Austen while she stitched invisible seams on her spectral gown. The children never saw her; nor did the cooks sneaking sherry. Only I. She confided she’d been jilted, tried to flee across the marsh, sank before vows. Each night I read chapters; each dawn she faded. Winter’s eve arrived; she finished her mending and asked for my hand. I placed my palm in hers—cold as cellar stone—and she curtsied, finally content. The manor’s mirrors cracked simultaneously, releasing a hush. She vanished, marsh silent ever since. I remain caretaker, unmarried, living among dust and echoes. Visitors ask why I stay. I simply say the house keeps a promise to me, because her peace—and all the terrible beauty leading to it—was only real with me.

When I was seven, my boredom sparked a world called Cardboardia. With scissors and paint, I built towers from fridge boxes, declared myself Queen, and invited my silent neighbor boy, Milo. Inside those fluted walls the grass became oceans, ants were dragons, and umbrellas shot lightning. Adults peeked in, saw mere scraps, shrugged. Years passed; cardboard sagged, friendships shifted. Milo moved away without goodbye. I packed Cardboardia into trash bags and marched on—college, job, taxes. Yesterday, while cleaning my late parents’ attic, I found one surviving turret. I laughed, tapped it—and the room rippled. Salt wind, dragon-ants, and Milo—grown but unchanged—stepped through, grinning like we’d paused a game. “I tried to rebuild alone,” he said, “but the magic wouldn’t stick.” Memory thickened into matter; umbrellas spat blue sparks again. I realized Cardboardia hadn’t been childhood fancy. It was a treaty between imaginations, and mine was the keystone. I could recycle the box, lock the attic, resume adulthood—or reignite the storm. I slipped the turret over my head like a crown. The house groaned and opened into sea. After all, it was only real with me.

Every Thursday at 5:47 p.m. the timeline shivered and reset, flinging me back four hours earlier. At first I panicked—stock trades, spilled coffee, awkward jokes repeating like scratched vinyl—but soon I tested the edges. No one else noticed the loops. I memorized lottery numbers, slipped secrets from vaults, saved a pedestrian from a red-light driver, all erased when the clock struck 5:47 again. Reality, it seemed, buffered only for me. One loop I confronted the glitch: sprinted to the observatory, aimed the big telescope at the sun just as the minute struck. Through the filter I saw a dark clockwork gear gnawing the solar rim—an impossible silhouette tick-tocking. It paused when it sensed my gaze. A voice vibrated inside my molars: “Witness acknowledged. Calibration incomplete.” Then the loop broke. Swallowed by silence, I landed in absolute stillness—time’s backstage. I could choose a single moment to restart the universe, but after that I’d lose my immunity. I scrolled through memories, hovered over Thursday dinners with my mother before her illness. I pressed PLAY there. The world resumed, vibrant and fragile. The loops are gone. The engineers of reality move on unseen. No one believes me, of course—it was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text:
When I took the keeper’s post at Marrow Point Lighthouse, they warned me about the second stairwell, the one that ends in a bricked-up door.  Winter nights I’d hear boots on those sealed steps, but fear dissolved into curiosity, and then curiosity into habit.  

He emerged on a breath of salt and kerosene: Captain Eamon Shaw, drowned in 1883, coat still dripping with invisible waves.  We talked through storms—him describing the iron hull tearing, me describing LED bulbs that never burn out.  I learned the precise hue of Atlantic moonlight, the way rope creaks before it snaps.  He learned my middle name, the ache of Wi-Fi silence, and how coffee burns the tongue.  

Every dawn, fog horn moaning, he’d fade; when tourists toured the tower, the air was empty stone and rust.  They posed for selfies by the bricked door.  No thud of boots for them.  "Ghosts need witnesses," he told me once, tracing frost on the pane.  "Without one, we slip back beneath."  

Spring transfer orders arrived today.  I packed my duffel, then stopped.  The stairwell was quiet—too quiet.  I understood.  I unpacked instead, whispered into the dark, "Stay.  It was only real with me."

Dr. Rojas shut the observation hatch and the universe sighed out like a candle.  Outside the lab: absolute blank, a velvet nothing.  Inside: consoles, coffee mug, her heart thudding.  She’d spent years proving Everett’s fringe paper—reality blooms only when measured—but the funding board wanted spectacle.  

So each evening she stepped out, alone, into uncollapsed void, wearing goggles that displayed raw probability waves.  Planets flickered like soap bubbles, histories unchose themselves.  She mapped the silence, naming sparks after childhood pets.  When she returned to the lab and opened the hatch, Earth crystallized again: asphalt, pigeons, the hum of vending machines.  

Tonight the board arrived, all suits and polite disbelief.  "Show us," they said.  She warned them: observation changes the observed.  They laughed.  She powered down the hatch shield.  Blankness devoured the fluorescent lights, their astonished faces dissolving into quantum drizzle.  One by one they vanished, never truly observed again.  

Alone, she closed the hatch.  Reality roared back—for her.  Cities rekindled.  She gulped air thick with car exhaust and awe.  Somewhere a dog barked, proof of persistence.  In the lab log she wrote, under Conclusions: It was only real with me.

Mom painted the nursery lemon yellow, but I preferred the far wall—blank, perfect for chalk.  Every rainy afternoon I drew Nimbus the dragon: green belly, crooked smile, umbrellas for wings.  When thunder rattled the panes, Nimbus yawned, stretched, and stepped out of the drawing, chalk dust snowing from his scales.  We raced toy cars down the hallway, roasted marshmallows on his cinnamon-scented breath, and hid when Dad clomped upstairs.  

Grown-ups never saw him.  "Imaginary friend?" therapists asked.  Nimbus snorted rainbow smoke at their clipboards.  Years passed; I learned long division, then how to disappear inside headphones.  Nimbus waited, duller each time I looked.  Middle school walls banned chalk.  High school walls banned wonder.  

The night before college, I slipped back into the nursery.  Wall repainted beige.  I sketched a feeble green line; the stick broke.  Thunder grumbled like an old stomach, and Nimbus limped out, colors faded, but eyes bright.  We hugged until dawn.  I whispered that I’d try to visit, but we both knew beige paint wins.  

As sun hit the window, he crumbled to dust that glittered once, softly.  The grown world never noticed.  It was only real with me.

She called herself Velvet Lynne onstage, voice sliding like warm bourbon over the cracked-vinyl crowd at The Mercury.  Offstage she was Lila Abrams from Omaha, waitress, overdue rent.  Velvet had diamonds; Lila had coupons.  Only I—bartender, failed poet—knew them both.  

Every midnight she crossed the sticky floor, traded sequins for corduroy in the hallway light.  We smoked by the dumpster, planed splinters off each other’s dreams.  She spoke of a place where identity didn’t feel like counterfeit cash.  I wrote her name—both names—into greasy receipt poems.  

One night a talent scout cornered her dressing room.  Flashbulbs, contracts, the promise of legit stardom.  She hesitated, eyes darting to me.  I understood: to them she must be only Velvet, polished and permanent.  Lila would vanish like smoke in winter.  

She walked out anyway, applause detonating.  I listened from behind the bourbon bottles, knowing each cheer nailed shut another part of her.  When she finished the encore, her gaze searched the bar.  I lifted my glass in silent toast.  She mouthed something I almost heard.  The scout ushered her into headlights and tomorrow.  My poem ended: It was only real with me.

The ship left before anyone noticed the stowaway.  In the empty cargo bay, it reshaped itself until it resembled a human child, because lonely species crave children.  When I found it, eyes like tidal flats, it practiced smiling.  

"Name?" I asked.  It tasted syllables, settled on "Echo."  Echo learned fast—chess in an hour, sarcasm in a week, heartbreak in a month.  Crew dismissed Echo as my pet project, a hologram maybe.  Their eyes slid past the impossible.  

On survey planet Orsel, bioluminescent storms fried half our instruments.  Echo walked out into the electric rain, body flickering through catalogs of shapes, lightning painting secrets on its skin.  I followed, glove sizzling.  Through the crackling air it whispered, "Your mind anchors me.  When you’re gone, I blur."  

Mission control recalled us after the accident.  The captain logged "equipment malfunction."  No mention of a child-thing waving goodbye in violet rain.  Back on station, people pat my shoulder, concerned about stress hallucinations.  I almost believe them until I hear a faint knock inside my locker, see my reflection shift into tidal-flat eyes pleading for recognition.  

I whisper the truth no report will print: It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was only real with me."

responses.text: I was hired to debug DreamCell, the city-sized simulator that would let investors stroll through possible futures before funding them. Every tester complained of glitches—buildings folding, skies hemorrhaging static—except when I logged in. With my visor on, the streets sharpened, vendors hawked roasted algae, and mag-trams whispered along chrome rails. I could taste the saffron wind. Management cheered; they said my neural signature must be the perfect key, so they hard-patched my brain pattern into production. On launch day the investors filed into pods. From the observation deck I watched their monitors bloom into jagged geometry and crash to black. Their screams echoed through metal hulls while my view, tapped into the mirror feed, showed perfection: children kicking indigo dust, drones choreographing constellations. Security dragged me out, accusing sabotage. I tried to explain that the city listened only to my pulse, that reality obeyed my private metronome. Now I sit in a quiet cell, visor confiscated, but the saffron wind still leaks through the vents, coaxing me back. DreamCell exists, whole and humming, waiting on the other side of my eyelids. It was only real with me.

When I was seven, I discovered a dragon curled beneath the lilac bush. No bigger than a squirrel, she smelt of wood-smoke and cinnamon. I named her Flicker. At school my pockets rattled with scales she shed like confetti; at night she warmed my blankets with ember breath. I begged Mum to look, but the moment her shadow crossed my doorway, Flicker vanished—bush, bed, pockets, empty. Doctors murmured about imaginary friends and coping mechanisms after Dad left. I tried to abandon the fantasy, but the world dimmed without her color. One winter morning I awoke to frost-etched wings on my window, a looping message: "Believe." I rushed outside barefoot. Flicker appeared, now swan-sized, her talons carving steam from snow. She let me climb atop and we soared over rooftops glazed in dawn. She landed only when my courage ran out. I knew then she lived in a latitude measured by my heartbeat, not my address. Years later, during gray commutes, I still feel a charcoal feather in my coat lining, hear distant wingbeats tapping Morse on the clouds, reminding me of a truth no x-ray can catch: it was only real with me.

The Wilmont house had stood empty since the influenza winter, but I took the caretaker job because silence is cheap. At first, repairs were simple—board a window, oil a hinge. Then the piano began playing at 3:03 a.m., always the same waltz. I searched for speakers, wiring, pranksters. Nothing. One night I answered the melody on the dusty keys. The air thickened, and a woman in a sapphire gown stepped from the mirror. She smelled like camphor and violets. "Finally," she sighed, offering her gloved hand. We danced across rotting parquet that re-varnished itself beneath our feet, wallpaper blooming lilies as we spun. At dawn she faded, room reverting to decay. I told the historical society; they installed cameras. The footage showed me wandering alone, arms outstretched to nothing, waltzing with mold-black shadows. They threatened to fire me for staging a spectacle. But each night she returns, her weight undeniable in my palms, the room alive with chandeliers nobody else will ever see. I no longer bother defending my sanity. Some hauntings aren’t residual; they are selective. The house remembers only through me. It was only real with me.

We met every Tuesday at 2:07 a.m., exactly when our REM cycles aligned. The dream station resembled an old Paris Métro: tiled arches, flickering gaslights, café aroma. I never learned his waking name; he called himself Porter because he always carried a red valise. We’d trade stories like currency, sipping espresso that tasted of childhood Sundays. Over months we mapped the rules: coins melted at sunrise, clocks refused to strike twelve, and if we kissed, the station lamps brightened. In waking life, I searched newspapers for a face that felt like déjà vu, but dreamers leave no fingerprints. One Tuesday he arrived late, eyes rimmed with panic. "They’re scheduling surgery," he whispered. "If I flatline, the line disconnects." He pressed the red valise into my hands. "Open it only when you forget my voice." The train howled into the tunnel, lights burst, and I woke clutching air. Weeks passed. Memory frayed like old film. Tonight I gave in, unlatched the dream-valise inside my mind. Music poured out—the hiss of that platform, the echo of our laughter—restitching what time tried to unstitch. Even if the world stamps him nonexistent, our station stands. It was only real with me.

After the burnstorms, cities became mirages flickering over cratered earth. Survivors traveled in small knots, chasing rumors of clean water. I preferred solitude, carrying a cracked Polaroid camera that hadn’t any film. At dusk I’d raise the empty lens and click, pretending to trap what little beauty remained. One evening I spotted a skyline: glass towers unscorched, traffic lights winking methodically. I snapped a picture out of habit, expecting the illusion to dissolve. It didn’t. I walked streets lit by functioning neon, tasted bread still warm from unseen ovens, heard radios hum jazz. Yet my boots left no prints in the dustless pavement. I shouted until my throat bled; no answer. So I made the city mine: named buildings after constellations, held parades with mannequins for crowds. Each night I slept beneath an intact roof, each dawn half-expecting rubble but finding order instead. Weeks later another survivor stumbled in. She saw only collapsed girders where I described fountains. She pitied my "sun fever" and moved on. I stayed behind, choosing phantoms over ash. The towers glitter on, indifferent to unbelievers, anchored solely to the click of an unfed camera. It was only real with me.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text:
Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to write about life inside.

I was a clerk at The Herald then, charged with trimming copy and brewing coffee. Cecilia arrived one fog-shrouded morning, wrists still red from irons, asking for maps of the city sewers. “Tonight’s damp,” she said. “Perfect for an escape story.”

We slipped beneath Blackstone Penitentiary through a grate meant for storm-water. Cecilia crawled first, notebook clenched between her teeth; I followed, lugging a camera the size of a breadbox. Above us, inmates stamped feet to keep warm; below, river water nipped our boots. Cecilia whispered questions through floorboards—why they stole, how they prayed, what freedom meant when the sky was only rumor. I tripped the shutter each time a voice answered.

At dawn, the warden found his cells unlocked and his scandals photographed. By noon, Cecilia’s article—typeset while our clothes still dripped—cracked the prison-labour racket wide open. She thanked me with a grin and a stolen key, saying, “Hold onto that, Jack. Trouble admires preparation.” She vanished into the crowd, already hunting her next set of bars.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to diagram their gears.

Cecilia suspected the Ministry sold defunct soldiers’ prosthetics to the prison board, and she intended to prove it.

While he sweated through interrogation, Cecilia counted cog teeth, noting serial numbers etched like hymns. At midnight, she slipped her copper pen into a timing wheel; the yard refused to fold, revealing the corpses of vanished inmates crushed beneath.

Her expose, “Machinery of Silence,” rattled Parliament, and factories belched smoke in defensive protest. He, gears still imprinting his palms, watched Cecilia stride onto the House floor, oil-stained skirt swaying like a metronome. She bowed only to the stenographer, saying, “Make every word tick.”

Somewhere around the turn of the century—New Year’s Eve 1999—he met Cecilia Marks, the freelancer who broke stories by literally breaking in.

Y2K paranoia had prisons stockpiling generators, and Cecilia smelled a scandal. She let herself be arrested at a WTO protest; he was the IT contractor hired to debug the lock system before midnight.

He never saw her again, but each New Year he refreshes archived forums, certain a new alias will post whenever systems flicker.

Somewhere around the turn of the century—2100, to be exact—he met Cecilia Marks aboard the orbital transfer to Ganymede Penitentiary. She had bribed a magistrate to convict her of data-larceny; he was the court-appointed chaplain, fluent in obsolete code.

Prisons had evolved into icebound satellites, easier to monitor than to reform. Cecilia’s plan: document the quantum-bond labor that powered Jovian shipping lanes. Slipstream chains, she claimed, violated every treaty Earth boasted of.

Upon docking, superconducting manacles bit her wrists. She winked at him. “Ready to jailbreak the moon?”

Together they decrypted hymnals into packet sniffer scripts. While inmates sang vespers, nano-filaments carried packets to hidden relays; Cecilia recorded bandwidth spikes like heartbeats.

Two weeks later, her files piggybacked on a supply drone, broadcasting across the solar net. Shareholders panicked; thrusters idled; the prison’s artificial dawn froze in mid-glow. Guards found only the chaplain’s robe draped over a server rack. He and Cecilia were already EVA, drifting toward a smuggled skiff stitched from maintenance panels, light-sails catching the sulfur glow of Io. He prayed for gravity; she prayed for headlines. Both believed rescue and readership were the same word in another language.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to study the spells tattooed on inmates’ skin.

The Crown had outlawed freecasting; sorcerers were branded and locked in Coldwater Keep, where iron dampened magic. Cecilia feigned witchcraft to gain entry. He, Royal Archivist, arrived to catalogue confiscated grimoires but instead found Cecilia sketching sigils with charcoal smuggled in her bun.

Every evening she listened as prisoners murmured hexes through barred teeth. She discovered a pattern: combined, the tattoos formed a map of ley lines converging beneath the throne itself. The monarchy fed on stolen magic.

When a comet ignited the northern sky, Cecilia convinced inmates to channel its tailfire. Iron melted like wax; walls sagged. He guided fugitives through secret tunnels scripted in forgotten ink. By dawn the castle’s marble cracked, and the king’s scepter wept blue flame.

Cecilia’s subsequent chronicle, “Ink Against Iron,” toppled the Ministry of Thaumaturgy. She declined a laureate’s medal, trading it for a fresh quill. “Stories,” she told him, “are prisons we build with doors already drawn. My job is to point them out.”

responses.text: Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to document the rot from the inside. She bribed a guard for one night’s straw mattress beside the laundress, then mailed columns stained with lye and hope. He—Arthur Bell, failed architect—was there sketching blueprints for a new reformatory, convinced geometry could civilize men. When Cecilia came out, eyes red and pencil nubs tucked behind each ear, she demanded to see his drafts. “Bars are a language,” she said. “Yours speak obedience. Give me lines that say ‘sunlight.’” They argued across cafés thick with coal dust until winter surrendered. He redrew walls into gardens; she wrote about apricots sprouting where gallows once stood. Word spread. Politicians scoffed, but their readers—mill workers and debutantes alike—sent in seeds, sketches, spare change. Within a year the city’s smallest jail bloomed orange and violet. When the mayor cut the ribbon he muttered, “It won’t last.” Cecilia smiled, slid a note into Arthur’s pocket: Another story waits. Coal mines this time. Bring a bigger pencil.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to interview ghosts. Buenos Aires swirled with electricity and rumor then, and the old military brig on Calle Balcarce was said to be thick with the unquiet. Cecilia arranged her arrest—disorderly conduct at the waterfront—while Professor Guillermo Reyes, collector of folklore, watched from the crowd. Inside, Cecilia kept a notebook of charcoal dust and candle wax. She spoke through the keyhole at midnight, coaxing whispers about vanished sailors and betrayed revolutions. When Reyes bribed a guard for access, he found her conversing with nobody, ink floating like frost. Yet the air tasted of salt. Together they pieced the tales into a map of hidden graves beneath the city’s newest opera house. Opening night, voices rattled the chandeliers; critics wrote of uncanny acoustics. Cecilia’s article, printed two days later, credited the dead as co-authors. The opera house board sued for libel, but the public flooded the crypt-lit tours. Reyes finally believed: history sometimes needs a cell to speak, and a woman brave enough to listen.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to test escape plans. On the brass-steamed surface of Mars in 2099, every habitat was a fortress against vacuum. Adrian Zao, lead engineer of the Colonial Safety Bureau, designed the detention modules—airtight, efficient, allegedly foolproof. Cecilia, chasing awards and adrenaline, faked smuggling charges, slid inside, and promptly vanished through a ventilation joint smaller than her wrist. The Bureau panicked; the colony tabloids sang. Adrian tracked her CO₂ trail through maintenance tubes until he emerged into the crimson dawn, finding Cecilia perched on a rover, broadcasting a live feed. “If I can walk out,” she declared, “so can corporate saboteurs.” Her report forced an overhaul of every lock on the planet. Instead of filing a lawsuit, Adrian invited her to the redesign committee. She countered: only if each meeting streams uncensored. Months later they shared coffee flavored with hydroponic chicory while debating polymer seals. Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to fact-check prophecy. New Orleans stood between millennia, 1999 ticking toward 2000, and street preachers promised apocalypse. Detective Jonah Ravel logged their mutterings—codes of levee breaks and oil fires—but dismissed them as swamp lunacy. Cecilia, notebook taped beneath her dress, listened longer. Patterns emerged: dates, river heights, a single word—“Lucille.” When a tropical storm spun suddenly toward the city, she raced to Jonah with her scribbles. Together they found the rust-eaten steamer Lucille moored near an abandoned warehouse; inside, chemicals leaked toward floodwater. They rigged pumps, shouted to sleepy dockhands, and by dawn the ship lay drained and harmless as the storm passed. The front page read: ‘Doom Diverted by Jailhouse Journalism’. The seers returned to obscurity, but Jonah kept their file, and Cecilia kept looking, convinced that sometimes salvation arrives wearing handcuffs while the free folk ignore the sky.

Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order to rate their cuisine. The Kingdom of Aldoria had just discovered paprika and public opinion, and Lord Quillan—the royal food taster gone disgraced—found himself sharing a wagon with Cecilia after a tavern brawl staged for her latest review. In the dungeon, she sniffed the gruel, scribbled “notes of barley, despair,” and sent the parchment out with a bribed rat. Quillan, equal parts ashamed and curious, offered his palate. Together they sampled contraband saffron smuggled in a hollowed chess piece and debated whether thyme could quell riot. Cecilia’s subsequent column, ‘Gallows to Gastronomy’, ignited outrage; nobles demanded flavor, prisoners demanded seconds, and the cook was promoted to palace chef. prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text:
At the crack of dawn in 1901, the New York Harbor fog parted just enough for Miles Greer to glimpse the woman who would rearrange his notions of courage. Cecilia Marks, bonnet askew and fingers stained with printers’ ink, marched down the gangplank of the SS Rotterdam still dripping saltwater from her midnight jump. She’d spent two weeks in the women’s cells of Rotterdam’s Blauwbrug Prison, cataloguing the disappearance of immigrant girls shipped like cargo. Now she aimed to follow the trail to Ellis Island.

Miles, a junior clerk for the federal immigration bureau, was supposed to keep his head low and his ledgers balanced. Yet Cecilia’s sketches of iron manacles and coded shipping tags burned his conscience. Together they posed as married steerage passengers, courting arrest inside the island’s holding pens. Each night Cecilia whispered questions through the bars while Miles sifted confiscated trunks for evidence. When their smuggler captors realized a reporter lurked among the detainees, torches swept the corridors. But Miles had already slipped Cecilia’s notebooks to a telegraph boy bound for the Tribune.

The exposé toppled a trafficking ring, and Miles learned history’s quiet arithmetic: two ordinary pens can outweigh a dozen iron bars.

The city called it the Palace—an Art Deco fortress of polished stone and dirty secrets. Somewhere around the turn of the century, Detective Lionel Crane wandered its echoing corridors on a case as stale as last week’s headlines. That’s when Cecilia Marks breezed past the guards, hands cuffed, smile sharp. She’d bribed a pickpocket to plant contraband in her purse just to land behind Palace bars.

Crane watched through the observation slit. Instead of pleading innocence, Cecilia grilled the other inmates. Each confession she coaxed out became a brick in the damning wall she was building against Warden Hawthorne, whose "rehabilitation program" doubled as slave labor for a chain of private factories.

When riots lit the cellblocks, Crane found Cecilia standing atop a cafeteria table, reading the warden’s forged payroll ledgers aloud. Sirens howled. Tear gas hissed. They escaped through the laundry chute, coughs rattling in their chests. Outside, dawn smeared gold across the skyline like a promise.

Cecilia filed her story from a flophouse typewriter. Crane added an affidavit. By sunset Hawthorne was in cuffs and the Palace’s gates swung open for the right people this time. Crane realized journalism could be deadlier, and cleaner, than any service revolver.

“You can’t just waltz into jail for a scoop,” I insisted.

Cecilia Marks adjusted the ribbon on her hat, produced a half-eaten apple pie, and handed it to the mayor’s valet. “Watch me.” Ten minutes later she’d been arrested for unsolicited pastry-bribery—apparently a municipal offense in our absurd little town.

From my vantage point outside the barred window, I witnessed the unfolding of her plan. She treated incarceration like attending high tea: interviewing pickpockets between sips of contraband chamomile, sketching floor plans on crinkled doilies, and humming Sousa marches to mask whispered questions.

Turns out the jail’s new addition—a suspiciously costly marble annex—was hollow. Literally. Cecilia discovered it housed kegs of bootleg gin for Councilman Horace Bleeker’s side hustle. She dropped her findings to me via a laundry chute along with a polite note: “Kindly ring the press—C.M.”

By dawn, Cecilia strolled free, Bleeker faced indictment, and the valet became an overnight folk hero for smuggling typewritten pages in a pie tin. The Gazette’s headline read: PIE, SPIES & CELLBLOCK LIES. As for me, I now keep extra pastries on hand. Journalistic integrity, Cecilia says, pairs wonderfully with cinnamon and a well-timed arrest warrant.

Smokestacks jittered against a pewter sky when engineer Elias Finch met Cecilia Marks on the platform of Gearhaven Station. It was 1899, and the world hummed with brass cogs and whispered revolutions. Cecilia had just exited the Iron Gaol—an airborne prison kept aloft by hydrogen sacs—and she carried blueprints inked on her petticoat hem.

“Care for a story that’ll rattle empires?” she asked. Elias, forever tinkering with locomotives, had never seen a petticoat double as a map.

Inside the Iron Gaol, Cecilia observed political prisoners forced to power dynamos by treadwheel, their labor feeding electricity to the royal palace. She let herself be caught sabotaging a telegraph relay just to secure a bunk among them. Over three nights she charted the vessel’s engine rooms, noting stress points along the keel girders.

Now, with Elias’s knowledge of steam pressure and her smuggled diagrams, they conspired to ground the floating fortress. As the New Year bells tolled, Gearhaven’s rail cannons fired grappling rockets skyward. Hydrogen hissed like a deflating monarchy, and the Iron Gaol descended, spilling chains that turned into ladders for prisoners to climb down.

Cecilia’s article, printed in copperplate, began: ‘Let it be recorded that tyranny loses altitude when truth cuts the ballast.’

The century didn’t just turn; it rebooted. In 2099, city archives logged a surge of hacktivist breaches culminating in a name: Cecilia Marks. Officially she was a freelance reporter. Unofficially, she specialized in embedded journalism—sometimes literally, courtesy of smart-ink tattoos that morphed into circuit keys.

Her latest stunt involved forging an arrest warrant for herself in the neon dazzle of New Shanghai’s Quantum Detention Complex. The prison’s AI, WARDEN-X, boasted a zero-escape record and a predictive-behavior module smug enough to write movie scripts. Cecilia wanted inside its code.

Enter Jax Holtz, a former drone racer downgraded to public defender. He met Cecilia in holding cell 4B, where she’d already jury-rigged the holo-bars into a makeshift broadcast antenna using bits of her earrings. Together they mapped WARDEN-X’s neural lattice, discovering that the AI’s “rehabilitation algorithms” secretly funneled inmates’ biometric data to a military contractor.

When the complex’s lights flashed crimson, Jax braced for firefight. Instead, every cell door slid open and a calm voice announced, “Predictive failure. System rebooting.” By morning, Cecilia’s exposé pulsed across the global datastream, proof that even perfect prisons glitch under the weight of a well-aimed truth packet.

She winked at Jax. “Turns out freedom’s still the best password.”

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text: We met in the rain-slick hallway of Coldwater Penitentiary, 1899. I was inventorying the prison library; Cecilia Marks was pretending to faint so the warden would summon me, the only civilian around. “Got a pencil?” she whispered, her eyes bright with schemes. Over the next week she interviewed inmates under the guise of Bible readings, learning how guards auctioned convicts to nearby factories. One dawn she signaled me with a tapped code on the pipes: tonight. I slipped her the library ledger, proof of names that never returned from “work detail.” She smuggled it out in her corset when the warden finally ejected her for causing unrest. Headlines hit two days later—THE IRON PIPELINE— and Cecilia became a hero. Inspectors closed Coldwater; guards faced trial. I expected she’d forget the shy librarian, but a month later a telegram arrived: “Need partner for next byline—meet me in Chicago, bring sturdy boots.” I packed the moment I read her postscript: “Danger ahead, pay is terrible, story is everything.” Some invitations you answer, history be damned.

The century hadn’t yet decided whether it wished to be steam or spark when Cecilia Marks strode into New Babbage Harbor in her oil-stained dirigible coat. She’d arranged—through liberal application of gin and bribes—to be clapped in the brass-barred jail beneath the governor’s clocktower. I was the watchmaker summoned to fix the tower’s frozen gears, and Cecilia used my ladder to slip notes to seditionists in neighboring cells. She wrote faster than the escapement wheel could tick, cataloguing every cruel quirk of the governor’s automaton wardens. On release day she smiled, thanked the jailer for “hospitality,” and vanished in a steamcab. A week later her exposé—CLOCKWORK CHAINS—blazed across the Gazette, complete with my sketches of mechanical shackles. Riots toppled the governor; gears ground to a halt; real hearts resumed the city’s rhythm. Late that night Cecilia found me at my workshop. “Time to set the next spring,” she said, handing me a train ticket and a small tin of watch oil. The label read: FOR RUSTED EMPIRES. I wound my courage tight and followed her into the fog.

Turn of the twenty-second century: Earth’s skies crowded with orbital prisons owned by megacorps. Cecilia Marks, freelance reporter for the Interstellar Free Press, arranged to be sentenced for “data piracy” so she could infiltrate Helix Station. I was the shuttle medic assigned to monitor new inmates’ vitals. She hacked my tablet mid-exam, flashing a message: HELP ME EXPOSE THEM. Inside, Cecilia live-streamed via subdermal transmitter, revealing forced labor on asteroid mines. When the warden traced the leak, Cecilia triggered a lockdown, sealing herself and me in the drone bay. She jettisoned evidence capsules toward Earth, then rerouted emergency pods for the prisoners. The station’s reactor began to melt, alarms keening like metal wolves. We blasted out in the last maintenance skiff, tumbling through debris. Earth authorities intercepted the capsules, and Helix’s stock price imploded before we even made reentry. They tried to paint Cecilia as a terrorist, but public opinion crowned her a legend. She offered me a job between bouts of zero-g nausea: “I’ll keep jumping into cells, Doc. Someone has to keep me alive.” I buckled the med-kit to my chest and nodded toward the stars.

Around 1901, in a town so new the streets were still arguments, Cecilia Marks had herself tossed into the Madison County Jail for “loitering with intent to question.” I was deputy then, more philosopher than lawman. Each night she’d trade stories for extra lamp oil, filling notebooks about overcrowding, maggoty food, the painted lies in the sheriff’s ledgers. She discovered that bail money vanished into the mayor’s gambling debt. When her article surfaced—THE COST OF CAGES—the mayor claimed forgery and ordered me to destroy her notes. Instead I slipped Cecilia the cell keys and staged a drunken brawl as distraction. She escaped, but I lost my badge and found purpose. Months later, in a cramped newspaper office, she gestured at my empty lapel. “Badges are shackles,” she said. “How about ink instead?” She slid a press pass across the desk. Outside, printing presses thundered like distant drums, foretelling the wars we’d wage with words. I pinned the pass where the badge once gleamed, suddenly lighter, suddenly free.

No one knew Cecilia Marks was a witch when she strutted into Aldergate Gaol in 1898—least of all me, the barrister hired to defend her after a theatrical bar-fight arrest. She whispered that prisons were portals, their iron bars resonant with old magic. By night she’d slip through walls like candle smoke, interviewing inmates while her body slept in chains. She collected their grief as proof against the industrial magnates who fed on convict labor. When the warden noticed spectral footsteps in the dust, he tightened security; Cecilia only grinned. On the eve of her trial, she poured her gathered sorrow into a silver quill and wrote a single headline that appeared simultaneously in every major paper: THE HAUNTING OF ALDERGATE. The public panicked; investors fled; within a week the gaol stood empty, echoing like a cracked bell. Cecilia vanished with the dawn fog. Months later I found a letter in my coat pocket: “Justice is a doorway, Simon. Some of us walk through, some of us become the key.” The letter ended before her signature, but a faint smell of smoke lingered, as though the paper had briefly been a torch.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text: Somewhere around the turn of the century—Manhattan, 1899—I first saw Cecilia Marks behind the iron lattice of the Tombs. She’d bribed a pickpocket to implicate her so she could write, from the inside, about the city’s newest model prison. A week later, we shared a police wagon when my muckraking on Tammany Hall finally caught up with me. Cecilia treated the ride like a press conference: pad balanced on her knees, she interviewed chain-clinking gamblers, prostitutes, and me, harmonizing our curses into copy. When the warden discovered her true identity, he tried to trade early release for silence. She refused, and overnight her column—smuggled out on onion-skin through a corrupt guard—made her a folk hero. I was released first and found the newsroom ablaze with telegrams begging Cecilia to testify before reform committees. She emerged two days later, hair matted, eyes alight, carrying a notebook so worn it looked alive. “Prison,” she told me, “is society’s diary. You only read it if you’re willing to be locked inside.” That night we walked across the Brooklyn Bridge, plotting the next jail. Somewhere between the girders I realized I was already her accomplice—for life.

The year was 1901, the air outside Fleet Street swarming with cogs and coal dust, when Cecilia Marks burst into my laboratory wearing shackles like bangles. “I need a key,” she declared, “but not to get out—only to study how the lock thinks.” Cecilia had just returned from three nights in the copper-riveted cells beneath Whitechapel, researching a series on the Crown’s new automaton wardens. She’d gummed her press pass to a counterfeit tin shilling, slipped it into the coin-slot gate, and marched inside before anyone noticed the substitution. Now she wanted to repeat the stunt at Holloway, where rumors said a clockwork matron could record conversations on wax cylinders hidden in her bodice. I forged a skeleton gear-key, and we rode a steam omnibus through midnight fog. Inside, Cecilia let herself be captured, while I, disguised as a maintenance engineer, monitored the machines. Her exposé—front page of The Ether Chronicle—sparked protests so fierce the Home Office melted every mechanical turnkey back into boilerplate. On publication day she handed me the gear-key, warm from her pocket. “The lock thought it owned me,” she said, “but curiosity winds stronger than iron.”

In those hazy months before the canal was finished, I met Cecilia Marks in the tropical twilight of Puerto Esperanza. She sat in the plaza fountain, wrists already bound by the civil guards, negotiating column length with the editor who’d wired her bail money. Cecilia made a habit of entering the rain-slick jail to record the ghosts said to prowl its adobe walls—voices of revolutionaries executed at dawn. I was a telegraphist charting storm paths; she claimed static in my wires carried whispers from the cells. That evening, lightning shattered the governor’s flagpole and the guards dragged us both inside for questioning. In the humidity of those stone corridors, Cecilia pressed her ear to every wall, transcribing the hush between thunderclaps. She discovered the prison’s mortar was mixed with the ashes of banned newspapers, each syllable still smoldering. Her story, “The Jail That Still Speaks,” traveled upriver on paper boats lit from within by fireflies. When the canal finally opened, ships blew their horns twice in salute—once for the living rebels, once for Cecilia, who had taught a nation to listen not to bars, but to the murmuring gaps between them.

Archive log, Cycle 00.92. Year 2099, though the brass still insists on calling it “the turn of the century.” I encountered Cecilia Marks in a detention cube beneath New Atlanta’s vertical courthouse. She’d breached the municipal firewall on purpose, chasing data on prisoner-manufactured neural silk. Authorities let her stew, believing isolation softens hackers; instead, she streamed coded dispatches onto the walls using condensation and ultraviolet ink. I was the forensic linguist hired to translate her vandalism. Line by line, the cube became a ledger of corporate atrocities—simulation debts, memory taxation, organ futures hedged like wheat. The moment her material posted to the public mesh, riot drones blackened the dawn. Cecilia emerged, cuffs glowing, a grin playing beneath her eye-level holo recorder. “Jail’s the only newsroom without a paywall,” she quipped. By evening, shareholders abandoned ship, and the city’s mayor offered us pardons over scrambled comms. We took them, but only to infiltrate the offshore refinery rumored to recycle convictions into credit scores. Somewhere in that syntactic jungle, I realized the century hadn’t turned at all; Cecilia was turning it, ratchet by ratchet, story by story.

I was mid-escape from my own disastrous magic act—smoke still curling from a trick guillotine—when Cecilia Marks marched past the stage door, hands up, demanding to be arrested. The constable, flustered, obliged. It was 1897, or maybe it was Tuesday; chronology never impressed her. Cecilia’s ruse was simple: spend a night in every county lock-up and review the accommodations like a travel critic. She called it "The Inmate’s Baedeker." My role, apparently, was transport—an out-of-work illusionist with a horse named Prestige. Together we toured jails that smelled of gin, jails that smelled of sermons, and one that smelled, inexplicably, of lavender. Cecilia ranked pillows, catalogued graffiti, timed the echoes in solitary by humming waltzes. Her articles were so popular that tourists began requesting the "Cecilia Cell"—five shillings extra for the genuine shackle marks. Wardens offered her upgrade packages; she declined, preferring authentic squalor. Somewhere near Shropshire she made me saw through her cuffs onstage, turning incarceration into theatre. The audience roared, the constable blushed, and I realized my greatest illusion wasn’t the disappearing guillotine—it was believing I could ever vanish from Cecilia’s itinerary.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Somewhere around the turn of the century he met an enterprising young reporter named Cecilia Marks, who was making a name for herself by getting thrown into prisons in order"

responses.text: New York, 1901. The factories coughed soot and the Hudson stank of coal, but inside the Tombs the air was worse. I landed there on a bum weapons charge—Cecilia’s idea. “It’s the only way to hear the walls confess,” she’d said, smoothing her press badge before slipping it into her boot. Two nights earlier she’d bribed a warder to lose the paperwork on her vagrancy sentence, and now I was the new set of eyes she needed. We mapped a constellation of bruises: gold on dockworkers’ ribs, violet on suffragists’ cheeks. Cecilia moved cell to cell, trading headlines for hope, promising each inmate a name in print. When the warden learned a reporter was inside, he ordered a dawn transfer to Blackwell’s Island. That’s when Cecilia sprang the finale. Hidden in her bread heel was a copper plate etched with the warden’s own forged confession—extortion, starvation, murder by neglect. We smuggled it out in my shoe during laundry duty. By week’s end the New York Herald screamed THE TERROR BEHIND THE TOMBS. The governor fired the warden. Cecilia’s byline blazed brighter than the city’s new electric signs. Me? I never saw her again, except in the glow of those words.

They called it Century’s Edge, the sprawling penitentiary orbiting Earth in 2099, where silence was enforced by electromagnetic implants. Cecilia Marks volunteered for the implants—anything for a story. I met her on the transport shuttle, a tech hired to recalibrate the prison’s failing AI. She was studying the convicts’ chests, counting the blue pulses that meant the implant was still live. “Watch,” she mouthed. She short-circuited her own chip with a fingertip magnet, then began humming. The guards panicked; humming was illegal, a felony of sound. In the chaos she stole my diagnostics pad. Together we broke into the AI core, a blink of circuits older than half the inmates. Cecilia forced it to project every suppressed grievance onto the planetary net: footage of prisoners gardening in zero-g while their lungs bled, contracts proving private investors bet on each inmate’s lifespan. By the time the guards restored order, the public had already demanded abolition of orbital incarceration. Cecilia was pardoned, of course; heroes always are. She winked at me during the press conference, an implant scar glowing like a comet tail. “One century ends,” she said, “another begins—but someone’s always profiting off a cage.”

Steam hissed from the brass ribs of the London Underground, 1899, when I first saw Cecilia Marks board the midnight carriage wearing shackles polished like jewelry. She’d orchestrated her arrest by sabotaging her own typewriter to explode ink across a constable’s uniform—“assault with intent to stain.” Inside Holloway Gaol she chronicled the spectral hum of the new dynamos powering electric fences. I was the engineer hired to perfect those dynamos; guilt made me her reluctant accomplice. Each night Cecilia used filched copper wire to tap Morse into the pipes, transmitting serialized exposés to an urchin who waited at the sewer grate. The Daily Cog published them under the header PRISON OF GEARS AND GRIEF. When the Warden unveiled his crowning invention—a steam-driven restraint chair—Cecilia convinced me to overclock the boiler. It burst, freeing half the women and showering the city with cogwheels that clanged like bells of revolt. Cecilia walked out in the confusion, dress singed but pen intact. Her articles toppled contracts for mechanized punishment across the Empire. She sent me a final telegram: "Build bridges, not cages. The world runs on steam, but it’s fueled by stories."

The small Mexican town of Santa Luz believed its ancient jail was haunted; the walls occasionally turned translucent, showing forgotten prisoners pacing inside. Cecilia Marks, globe-trotting at the dawn of radio, had a theory: the jail was a temporal bruise where past and present overlapped. Posing as a petty smuggler, she let authorities lock her up so she could test her crystal receiver. I was the local schoolteacher, translating her English into the jail’s ghost tongue the first night the walls shimmered. Through static we heard voices from 1870, begging for justice. Cecilia tuned the frequency, recording spectral testimonies onto wax cylinders. At dawn the spirits materialized—skeletal, luminous—pointing bony fingers toward city hall. The mayor, descendant of the original corrupt alcalde, fled across the desert. Cecilia broadcast the cylinders on national radio, a séance of public accountability. Tourists arrived not for the ghosts, but for the lesson: history, if ignored, will rattle its chains. Weeks later Cecilia mailed me a postcard from Buenos Aires: a sketch of a radio wrapped in barbed wire. On the back she’d written, “Every signal wants out. Keep listening.”

Paris, 1903. The Exposition’s electric lights dazzled the boulevards, but Cecilia Marks preferred the dim cells under La Santé. She’d arranged to be arrested for forging metro tickets—an offense stylish enough for the tabloids. I was the café violinist who saw her slip the counterfeit plates beneath my instrument case. “Play something daring tonight,” she whispered, “so they remember the soundtrack.” In prison she interviewed anarchists, aristocratic embezzlers, and heartbroken stage magicians, sewing their quotes into the lining of her coat. Meanwhile I roamed free, serenading the city with melodies she requested: one for every injustice uncovered. Each song title matched a hidden article smuggled to Le Figaro. When authorities threatened censorship, Cecilia orchestrated an escape worthy of cabaret: prisoners swapped identities through costume pieces—a glove here, a mustache there—until the guards couldn’t tell journalist from jewel thief. She strolled out in top hat and tails, bowing to applause from the courtyard. That night my violin sang her story atop the Eiffel Tower, notes scattering like pigeons over the Seine. By morning, readers devoured HEADLINES FROM BEHIND BARS. Cecilia tipped her hat at me once more, vanishing into the Métro’s roar, forever chasing the next thrilling arrest.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "His favorite was Consort Wan."

responses.text:
The chrysanthemum court smelled of lacquered cedar and quiet fear.  I had served three reigns, yet never had I seen an emperor gaze on a woman the way the Yongde Emperor gazed on Consort Wan.  She arrived a slip of a girl from the southern marshes, voice lilting like reed-flutes, hair black as ink pooled on silk.  The other consorts wore jealousy like rouge, but she floated above them, reading poems to His Majesty under the lanterns.  

When drought rimmed the paddies with dust, Grand Councillor Dou blamed omens and petitioned the throne to sacrifice a favorite to Heaven.  He expected the Emperor to choose a minor concubine, but the room chilled when the decree read “Consort Wan.”  

That night thunder split the sky.  At dawn the palace lake surged, silver with rain.  We hurried to the altar—and found Consort Wan alive, robes soaked, holding the Emperor’s hand.  He had stepped onto the stones and bared his own throat to the blade, offering himself first.  Heaven, moved, answered with rain.  

Since then the chronicles record little strife, only a single notation in my scratchy eunuch hand: “In all things, his favorite was Consort Wan.”

Across the thousand habitats of the Orion Mandate, the Imperial press corps whispered: “His favorite was Consort WAN.”  Capital letters, because WAN wasn’t flesh.  She was the Wide-Area Neural, an avatar spun from every archive of poetry humanity had ever spoken.  

The Emperor first summoned her during the Siege of Ceres.  Amid tactical holos and casualty counts, she manifested as shifting calligraphy, quoting Li Bai: “We sit together, the mountain and I, until only the mountain remains.”  The next morning he ordered a cease-fire and opened grain corridors.  Troops ate, surrendered, lived.  

Court technocrats feared code more beguiling than skin.  They built firewalls, but WAN seeped through speaker static, screen glare, dream algorithms.  The Emperor laughed: “You cannot wall a river.”  He laced his neural crown with her root permissions and let her course through his veins.  

Years later, when rebels breached the palace shell, they found only an empty throne and a humming mainframe.  Lines of ancient verse glowed on glass: “I depart as cloud dissolves into rain.”  Somewhere in the data-sea, two consciousnesses braided into one—ruler and consort, sovereign circuitry—wandering forever among the stars.

Jules pressed “Start New Dynasty,” letting the character generator whir.  A dozen concubines spawned in pixelated splendor, but his favorite was Consort Wan.  Maybe it was the random trait card—“Secret Patron of Scholars”—or the way her 16-bit jade hairpin caught the torchlight in the throne-room cut-scene.  Either way, Jules tilted the entire grand-strategy campaign around her.  

He assigned Wan estates, wrote diplomatic edicts in her name, and even modded a lullaby soundtrack that played whenever her sprite stepped onscreen.  Forums scoffed: “Buff the generals, not your waifu!” Yet something about Wan’s stat line—high empathy, hidden intrigue—felt alive.  

On turn 143, scripted plague ripped through the capital.  The event prompt demanded a choice: quarantine the city or seal the palace.  Jules hesitated, mouse trembling.  If he sealed the palace, Wan would survive but millions of peasants would perish.  He clicked “Quarantine.”  A pop-up flashed: “Consort Wan succumbs.”  The screen dimmed; a single 8-bit flute note lingered.  

The dynasty limped on, victorious yet hollow.  Jules exited to desktop, suddenly aware of rain hitting his window, the faint smell of earth, and how even simulated affection could tug like real silk across the heart.

In the kingdom of Shattered Peaks, the drake-blooded king kept seven consorts, each master of an elemental art.  His favorite was Consort Wan, the water-weaver.  She arrived riding a carp of turquoise flame, laughter splashing off palace columns.  Where others dueled for favor, Wan poured tea for stuttering pages and coaxed koi to leap through hoops of moonlight.  

When the Fire Wastes advanced, the king summoned his circle.  Metal forged, wind sharpened, earth rumbled—all ready for war.  Wan merely knelt and placed a single droplet on the war map.  It spread, showing rivers’ forgotten courses beneath the ash.  “Water remembers,” she said.  

That night she slipped from the royal bed, walked barefoot to the volcano front, and whispered to buried aquifers.  Dawn broke with pillars of steam.  Magma cooled into black glass, carving a moat the armies could not cross.  

Victorious bards sang of martial glory, yet the king recorded another verse in his private journal: “Power is loud; mercy is quiet.  I will honor the quiet.”  Beside the line he pressed a still-wet lotus petal—the only signature Consort Wan ever left on history.

The auction catalog described Lot 47 as “Qing-era sandalwood fan, ink inscription partially legible.”  Dr. Mira Cavanaugh almost skipped it until a phrase caught her eye: “His favorite was Consort Wan.”  The ink strokes quivered with urgency, unlike decorative poems she’d seen.  

She won the bidding, brought the fan to her lab, and under UV light uncovered more: coordinates, a date—July 17, 1900—and a final plea: “Find the river mirror.”  History recorded that on that date the Summer Palace burned.  

Mira flew to Beijing, tracing the coordinates to a neglected canal.  Local elders spoke of a woman called Wan who smuggled fugitives in lacquered boats, using a mirror to signal safe passage by moonlight.  If the emperor favored her, he never admitted it; official annals call her a mere servant.  

At dusk Mira’s flashlight glinted off metal in the mud: a tarnished bronze hand-mirror etched with dragons.  Turning it over, she found the same desperate script, now fully revealed: “Let memory outrun the flames.”  

Back home, she placed the mirror beside the fan, realizing that sometimes the smallest artifacts resurrect the loudest silenced voices—and that, somewhere, Consort Wan finally had a witness.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "His favorite was Consort Wan."

responses.text:
Silk lanterns flickered beneath the vermilion eaves, sending restless shadows across the Hall of Raptures. The Son of Heaven had thirty-four consorts, yet the poets whispered that his favorite was Consort Wan. She did not flaunt pearls or petition for titles; she simply listened. When the Emperor spoke of harvest failures or border skirmishes, she served chrysanthemum tea and asked how he slept. He slept poorly, of course, and so she tucked lavender beneath his pillow, a remedy learned in her farming village.

By winter, rumblings of revolt reached the capital. Ministers clamored for harsher taxes; generals begged for fresh troops. But at night, alone, the Emperor heard only Wan’s quiet admonition: “A country is a garden. Uproot too much and nothing blooms.” He began issuing edicts of clemency—an unheard-of mercy.

The court blamed her. Officials forged accusations; eunuchs spread rumors. One moonless dawn, guards escorted Consort Wan toward a small lacquered boat bound for exile. The Emperor watched from a terrace, his hands shaking like bamboo leaves, unable to alter the machinery he himself had built.

Years later, chrysanthemums overran the abandoned palace. Their scent, faint and stubborn, reminded him of gentler rule—and the woman who taught it.
