When Captain Fairfax asked if the land held fuel, I answered, “Only warnings.” At dawn we patched the bag and drifted away, leaving the hillside’s secrets sleeping under moss.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "These were not the tidy hillsides I was used to, but riddled with lumps, volcanic rock in haphazard garments of moss."

responses.text:
These were not the tidy hillsides I was used to, but riddled with lumps, volcanic rock in haphazard garments of moss. My map showed a green lull between kingdoms, yet the ground growled beneath my boots. I pressed on, quill and parchment ready, for the queen had hired me to chart a new trade route. 

Half-buried obsidian pillars jutted like snapped arrows. Etchings spiraled across them—language, or the memory of language. I brushed away grit and the glyphs shimmered, igniting the moss in emerald flame. A voice unfurled inside my skull: “Name the path, cartographer, and it becomes.” 

Fear clawed at reason, but curiosity triumphed. I whispered the name I’d given the pass—Auroral Way—and the hills rearranged like chess pieces. Lava-black lumps melted into smooth terraces, a ribbon of road unspooled, and distant villages lit lanterns in welcome. 

When I returned, the queen praised the miracle of my cartography. Yet each night I wake, tasting brimstone, wondering what bargain I struck with the buried tongue of a forgotten volcano, and what else it might ask me to name.

These were not the tidy hillsides I was used to, but riddled with lumps, volcanic rock in haphazard garments of moss. The shuttle dropped me on Kepler-442d with a single directive: catalog microbial life. What the brief omitted was the tremor of hearts beneath the crust.

I knelt to sample a neon-green patch when one of the "lumps" twitched. Seismic data spiked. The moss parted like curtains, revealing a translucent shell veined with magma. My mind raced—this was no rock field; it was a nursery.

Across the valley, shells pulsed in synchrony, conducting heat the way whales sing through water. I activated the drone swarm, streaming holofeeds to mission control. Bureaucrats barked for more data; investors smelled profit in bio-plastics and geothermal harvests.

But I listened closer. The pulses formed prime number sequences, a universal handshake. I answered by modulating my suit’s beacon. The hillside responded with soft, harmonic quakes, calibrating to my rhythm until the ground felt almost like breath.

I filed my report: "Intelligent, non-anthropoid, embryonic. Planet off-limits." Whether Earth will honor that warning, I do not know. The shells still hum in my dreams, counting down to hatching day.

These were not the tidy hillsides I was used to, but riddled with lumps, volcanic rock in haphazard garments of moss. Iceland was supposed to be a supply stop, yet the war had a habit of rerouting men the way rivers reroute ash.

We’d landed to mend a cracked wing. Corporal Hayes and I hiked the slope in search of basalt sturdy enough to prop the plane. Fog folded around us, muffling the distant radio static. Then we saw the crater—fresh, steaming, ringed with glassy beads that chimed in the wind.

Hayes, always the magpie, pocketed a bead. Instantly the fog recoiled, unveiling a mural of lights above—aurora, yes, but arranged like coordinates. I plotted them mentally: they pointed due east, toward occupied waters where a U-boat wolfpack lurked.

We relayed the coordinates once the wing held. Command dismissed it as "atmospheric fancy," yet a recon flight verified a flotilla exactly there. We’d been saved by volcanic glass and, perhaps, by whatever ancient sensor lay beneath that crater.

I still keep one bead on my dog tags. It flickers when storms roll in, as if remembering the night the sky became a map and chose two lost airmen to read it.

These were not the tidy hillsides I was used to, but riddled with lumps, volcanic rock in haphazard garments of moss. Pilgrims whispered that the Prophet’s heart lay buried here, still hot from revelation.

I climbed barefoot, each stone a question searing my skin. At the summit a circle of standing slabs waited, their surfaces alive with lichen-script that no scholar had ever translated. I carried a single offering: a glass vial of rain from the city’s last monsoon.

When I uncorked it, the wind hushed. I poured the water onto the central stone, and vapor spiraled upward, shaping the Prophet’s silhouette. His chest glowed like a furnace yet his eyes were caverns of cooled pumice.

“Ask,” the vapor said.

I asked why faith so often calcified into law, why laws turned to cages, why cages bred war. The silhouette crumbled, and molten letters raced across the slabs: Break. Breathe. Begin.

A tremor shook the hillside; the lumps rearranged into terraces ripe for planting. Moss receded, replaced by shoots of barley. I descended with soles blistered but spirit light. The city would not heed me at first, but I carried in my pocket one obsidian seed, still warm and humming "Begin."

These were not the tidy hillsides I was used to, but riddled with lumps, volcanic rock in haphazard garments of moss. Dad called it “a fixer-upper of a campsite.” I called it “definitely cursed.”

The dog agreed, judging by her whimper.

Night fell fast; clouds quilted the stars. We roasted marshmallows anyway, the fire snapping like bubblewrap. Then the ground burped—actual, audible burp—and a marshmallow flew off my stick, landing on a mossy lump. The lump blinked.

Up popped a head the size of a toaster, magma-orange eyes glowing. More lumps stirred, revealing squat creatures wearing moss like toddlers wear blankets: haphazard but heartfelt. One waddled forward and offered my marshmallow back, perfectly toasted.

Dad froze. I accepted the treat—some diplomat had to. The creatures chirped, a melody both jittery and sweet. We shared the rest of the bag, and they, in turn, raked stones into a protective ring around our tent, their version of hospitality.

By dawn the hillside looked almost tidy. The creatures were gone, save for a single moss blanket folded neatly by the fire pit, a thank-you note in stone language etched beside it: “Come again, bring sugar.”

Best campsite ever.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight."

responses.text: The fledgling’s wail split the dawn like flint against granite. In the Time-Before, nothing had known the taste of sky, but Mother Earth ached to hear music beyond her own heartbeat. She shaped a creature of hollow bones and soft down, placed it high upon a cliff, and whispered one command: leap. Terror made the hatchling hesitate; its siblings burrowed deeper into the nest, content with earthbound safety. Yet the smallest, the frailest, felt something stir—a mirror of the world’s own yearning. It tipped over the edge, crying a note that rang across creation, a question and a promise in one breath. Wind, startled awake, rushed to answer, curling beneath trembling wings, teaching them the grammar of lift. The bird’s panic melted into wonder as it carved the first invisible path, sketching freedom across the sky. Below, trees shivered, rivers glittered, mountains craned to watch. All who heard knew life would never again be confined to soil. Even the stars, catching the echo at nightfall, hummed approval. And somewhere deep within every creature ever born afterward, that ancient cry remains, reminding us that the void between safety and possibility is bridged by one brave leap.

Professor Lyra Qin adjusted her goggles, staring at the prototype: a biomech drone modeled after archaeopteryx fossils. "We’ll teach it to fly today," she told her apprentice. They activated the launch pad atop the aerodrome spire. The machine chirped—infrasound translated through speakers—“This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest.” Lyra’s pulse quickened; the AI had selected the line from its literary databank as a status report. Wind howled. Hydraulic talons unclenched, and the chrome feathers caught sunlight like shards of a broken mirror. The drone flailed, dropping faster than predicted. Lyra’s mind raced through equations, but before she could override, the wing-motors synchronized, each carbon-fiber quill adjusting angle by single degrees. Lift engaged. The archaeopteryx soared, looping around the tower in defiant spirals. Citizens gathered below, necks craned, cheering as the mechanical bird projected its triumphant cry across loudspeakers. Lyra exhaled, half scientist, half proud parent. She realized the line wasn’t just status—it was prophecy. Humanity had built countless machines, but this one rekindled the primeval courage coded in every cell. Watching its silver silhouette against the sun, she felt the ancient partnership between fear and flight reborn in alloy and algorithm.

At the village of Cliff-edge, each child came of age by echoing the First Bird. We gathered before sunrise, robes snapping in the coastal wind, elders’ drums mimicking beating hearts. When my turn arrived, they painted my arms with charcoal wings and led me to the jutting rock above the roaring sea.

Legend said the original bird had screamed not in terror but in declaration: “I am more than gravity’s captive.” That shout lingered, etched into the air like invisible runes. To claim adulthood, one had to find the same courage.

The drop looked endless. My knees shook. I remembered my mother’s whispered counsel: Trust the space beneath you; it hungers to hold dreams. I stepped off. For a breathless instant, only falling existed. Then the glider harness snapped open—canvas catching wind, wooden spars creaking into shape. The crafted wings—my own work over a winter of study—responded to subtle wrist pulls, and I arced upward, the drums fading under the rush of air.

My cry burst forth, raw and exultant, threading itself into the legend’s chorus. When I landed on the distant beach, sand rising in applause, I wasn’t merely older; I was kin to that first fearless bird.

You wouldn’t expect the first bird to be afraid of heights, but Anxiety chose odd hosts. Nestled among primordial ferns, she’d rehearsed flutters in secret, certain her siblings mocked her stubby pinions. Then came the push—no ceremony, just gravity’s blunt invitation. Her shriek jabbed the silent Cretaceous morning, ripping through humidity and pollen.

Down she plummeted. Mid-drop, a dragonfly zipped past, eye-stalks gleaming. “Flap, silly!” it buzzed. Easier shouted than done. She squeezed the air, felt it squeeze back, and suddenly everything clicked like seeds in a pod. Wings cupped wind, tail feathers trimmed doubt. She wasn’t falling; the world was simply moving further away.

She banked over a herd of proto-mammals, who paused their grazing to gape. Even the sluggish swamp gave a lazy ripple of applause. She tasted clouds no beak had pierced, wrote new cartography over treetops, and stitched the horizon to itself with loops of giddy velocity.

By dusk she returned, chest puffed. The nest looked smaller, the sky infinitely larger. Her siblings blinked up, half fearful, half envious. She only smiled, remembering terror turned inside-out. Every descendant—sparrow, eagle, even awkward turkey—still carries a fragment of that first, glorious panic converted into song.

The librarian found the cry tucked between pages of an unreadable tome. It wasn’t ink but sound, folded like origami. When she pried the parchment, the note escaped—“This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest”—and fluttered around the vaulted ceiling, echoing off stained glass.

Words here had power; renegade sentences could sprout claws. The cry gathered feathers of syllables, grew a beak of vowels, and became a paper bird, trembling yet luminous. The librarian, sworn guardian of quiet, felt her oath quiver. She chased it through aisles where stories slept, but every time she neared, drafts from ancient epics lifted it higher.

Finally, atop the ladder in Mythology, she whispered, “All beginnings are allowed one scream.” She opened the tower window. The paper bird hesitated, ink-veins pulsing. Then, with a rustle like pages turning, it leapt into moonlit air. Below, rooftops waited like unread chapters.

The librarian listened until the cry faded into the city’s nocturnal murmur. Returning to her desk, she realized silence felt larger now, stretched by the vacancy of the escaped tale. Somewhere beyond, a new story was already unfolding, authored by courage, edited by wind.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight."

responses.text:
Before dawn learned to color the sky, the world was silent save for the hush of leaves. High in a cradle of woven twilight, the First Nest trembled. A single fledgling, feathered in pale starlight, peered over the rim. Beneath it stretched the unfinished world—raw clay mountains, oceans still deciding their tides. The Great Wind, unborn, waited for a reason to awaken. The fledgling’s mother nudged once, then withdrew, knowing creation must risk itself. 

The bird tipped forward. Gravity, startled by new company, reached up eagerly. In that breathless fall, the chick’s beak split the quiet with a cry never heard before: half terror, half prophecy. Wings—mere sketches of wings—flared, catching nothing, then everything. The First Flight carved a path across the empty air, and where primaries sliced, streams of wind erupted, swirling rivers no map could name.

The fledgling rose. Mountains knelt before the gust it made; oceans rippled with a rhythm they would keep forever. Above, dawn finally blushed, reflecting the courage below. The Great Wind, now alive, vowed to follow every creature daring to leap. And so, from one uncertain cry, the sky found its voice—and has never stopped singing.

My bones were light, but the cliff felt heavier than the whole Cretaceous. I was Archaeopteryx—almost lizard, almost bird—perched on a limestone ledge while my broodmates huddled behind me. Mother tilted her head, amber eyes stern: leap or be lunch for something with too many teeth. The jungle smelled of fern sap and rain.

I inched forward. Air hissed upward, promising either lift or an unmarked grave. Fear tasted like iron. Then came the shove—more a nudge, really, from a sibling eager for the nest’s extra warmth. Talons lost grip, gravity claimed me. Instinct—or desperation—ordered my forelimbs wide. Membranes bellied, feathers rasped, and suddenly I was not falling but trading bone for breeze.

I screeched, a raw sound slicing epochs. Below, a herd of tiny mammals scattered; above, pterosaurs wheeled, surprised at this new contender. Each beat of my wings rewrote anatomy textbooks no one would pen for sixty-six million years.

When I landed on another branch, heart drumming like storm hail, I knew I’d traded scales for sky. Behind me, the nest chirped in astonishment. The future had begun—on two trembling wings and one accidental push.

Prototype AV-1 hung at the edge of the launch gantry, titanium pinions catching morning glare. Inside its carbon chest, a quantum processor pulsed like a heart learning courage. Dr. Ortega’s gloved finger hovered over the release switch; decades of biomimicry and sleepless coding distilled into this moment.

“Let it feel the wind,” she whispered. The clamps unclenched. AV-1 pitched forward, coils retracting with a metallic gasp—this, perhaps, was the cry of the first synthetic bird. Sensors flooded its mind with altitude, barometric whispers, sun angle. Algorithms unfolded composite wings to the precise arc its avian ancestors perfected by chance.

Turbines muttered. Lift bloomed. Below, engineers held their breath as the drone wobbled, almost plummeting into desert heat but then catching a thermal, rising in a spiral worthy of any hawk. Cameras livestreamed the newborn sky-paths back to Mission Control, where charts erupted with data and delight.

At 200 meters, AV-1 emitted an unscheduled audio ping—three ascending notes. Ortega smiled; she hadn’t programmed that. Somewhere between code and carbon fiber, the machine had found its own voice. Humanity’s old dream of flight had just drafted a silicon-feathered sequel.

When you left home, suitcase scuffed and heart louder than car horns, I remembered a story my grandmother told: the first bird ever nudged from its nest. Its cry, she said, cut the morning like a thin blade, yet the sky stitched it closed with blue.

You stood on the train platform, the world’s timetable rumbling under your shoes. I wanted to call you back, tuck you in once more, but motherhood is a cliff we lean off every day. So instead I handed you a thermos of lukewarm tea and whispered, “Stretch your wings.”

The train exhaled, doors sighed, and you stepped inside the unknown. Through the window, your face flashed between reflections of strangers and the rushing town. You didn’t see me mouthing an ancient blessing: May gravity forget your name.

As the carriages shrank into a thin line, a gull screeched overhead—the same note, perhaps, that first fledgling sang. I heard terror in it, but also the tremolo of becoming. I walked back through our emptying house, each room echoing with the clap of invisible wings, and realized the nest is never abandoned; it merely expands to include the whole horizon.

Before there were calendars, there was the Phoenix, sole tenant of time. She nested in a hollow of smoldering dusk, feathers braided from sunset filaments. The gods watched, wagering on whether eternity could dare a beginning. One deity—curious, impatient—sent a spark that nipped the Phoenix’s tail. Startled, she toppled from the nest.

Mid-fall, her throat released a note equal parts flame and fledgling fright. That cry tunneled through the cosmos, punching holes for future constellations. Wings unfurled, each beat scattering cinders that cooled into planets. When she rose again, ash trailed her like a comet’s promise.

She circled back to where the nest had been, but the ledge was now a crater, white-hot. Understanding bloomed: to return, she would have to burn anew. So the Phoenix folded her wings around herself, ignited, and birthed the first tomorrow from her own remains.

To this day, every dawn echoes that inaugural shriek; we mistake it for rooster, alarm clock, traffic. Yet in the hush between seconds, you can hear the undertone: the sound of a creature being pushed so hard by the universe that she invents resurrection on the way down.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight."

responses.text:
In the hush before dawn, when the world was still a formless hush of mist and unspoken names, the Sky-Mother shaped a single egg from breath and starlight. She cradled it in the crook of a newborn mountain until its shell cracked with a sound like thunder remembering itself. Out spilled the First Bird, a creature stitched of ember and wind. The mountain’s edge was its cradle, but not its home. 
“This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight.” The Sky-Mother loved that cry; it was music that parted clouds. She nudged the fledgling over the precipice, and gravity—greedy, jealous—clutched at him. He tumbled, pinwheeling past frosted cliffs, startled eyes reflecting worlds he’d never walk. But the wind, curious, slid beneath him, whispering, *Push back.* Feathers kindled, bones remembered why they were hollow, and suddenly he was riding the invisible highways between sunrise and sea.
Where his wingtips brushed the horizon, sparks fell, seeding every future bird, every dream of upward. And so the sky learned to sing, and the earth learned to listen, and neither has been silent since.

The engineers called her R-01, first of the raptor-class biomechs, but to Commander Lian she looked more like a steel hatchling perched on the docking rail. A kilometer below, phosphorescent clouds churned around the orbital foundry. One push, and the prototype would fall into true sky. 
“This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight.” It wasn’t a chirp—more a harmonic tremor rippling through R-01’s alloy feathers as the launch clamps released. She plummeted, turbines dead, sensors drinking in dread. Telemetry screamed red across Lian’s visor. 
At two hundred meters, code awakened: *Remember the wind.* Servos flexed; carbon-plume pinions snapped wide. Air caught in their lattice, and drag became dance. The fall arced into glide, glide into ascent. R-01 shrieked again, but this time the note was triumph, echoing across comms until even stoic techs whooped. 
In her wake, vortices painted luminous signatures, equations of freedom along the night. Down below, a million grounders lifted faces scarcely knowing why their chests felt lighter. Far above, Lian logged a single word beside the flight record: *Alive.*

Mama said the world was bigger than the oak, but Finley couldn’t imagine anything larger than that wobbling branch where his toes now curled. The nest smelled of sun-warmed straw and breakfast worms, yet curiosity tugged harder than comfort. Behind him, his three siblings chirped encouragement like squeaky cheerleaders. 
“This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight.” It escaped Finley’s beak half squeal, half song as a surprising gust knocked him forward. Suddenly there was only blue beneath, and the branch was a shrinking thought. He flapped the way Mama had shown—down, out, feel the air lift—except the air felt more like falling water. Panic fluttered faster than wings.
Then something clicked: the wind wasn’t a wall but a river. If he leaned into its current, it would carry him. Finley spread wider, angled his tail, and the plummet evened into a swoop so graceful he forgot to breathe. Below, a carpet of daisies zoomed past like laughing dots. 
He circled back, pride swelling his tiny heart. Tomorrow, he decided, he’d fly all the way to the barn. Maybe even past whatever waited beyond the oak.

They called the crumbled overpass The Perch—the highest point left after the oceans tantrumed and the cities drowned. Ayla’s glider, stitched from sailcloth and scavenged bike frames, quivered in the salt wind. Below her, exiles gathered, faces upturned like moons. Food was scarce, hope scarcer. Someone had to chart thermals, find arable land. Someone had to jump first. 
“This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight.” It tore from Ayla’s throat when the push came—not from a parent, but from the need of everyone she loved. She pitched forward. The broken highway vanished; the Atlantic yawned.
Canvas snapped open. For a heartbeat, nothing held. Then a warm updraft, smelled of kelp and storm, flexed beneath the wings. The glider lifted, creaked, but held. Ayla whooped, steering toward the orange bruise of sunrise. In that sound traveled a promise: if the sky could still bear weight, maybe the earth could, too.
Hours later, her silhouette dwindled into a dot over the horizon. On The Perch, children practiced with toy kites, imagining themselves feathers in her slipstream, already inventing new cries to answer hers.

Gabriel’s desk was the farthest cubicle from any window, yet the HR packet called the floor plan an “open nest.” On Orientation Day, he sat surrounded by ergonomic foam and the scent of burnt coffee, feeling more hatchling than hire. 
“This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight.” Except his cry sounded like a polite cough as he approached the weekly status meeting. The Senior VPs perched on swivel chairs, plumage of tailored blazers fluttering. Slides flashed growth curves steep as cliffs. Gabriel’s single slide—a modest idea for micro-loans—looked like a paper feather beside their steel talons.
His manager nudged the projector cable toward him: the push. Heart drumming, he spoke. Words wobbled at first, then caught a thermal of genuine enthusiasm. He described families unbanked, markets untapped, a revenue stream hiding in plain sight. Questions swooped, but he banked, adjusted, climbed.
When the lights came up, the CFO nodded. “Let’s pilot it next quarter.” Applause rustled like forest leaves. Back at his cubicle, Gabriel felt the ceiling tiles lift, exposing a sudden sky. He exhaled a soft, incredulous chirp—already planning where to fly next.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight."

responses.text:
At the edge of the primeval cedar world, the fledgling clung to a rim slick with dawn. It saw no sky yet, only the tremble of its own downy breast. Then Mother—older than wind—nudged once. Gravity answered with teeth, and the young one fell.

Its scream rang across epochs. Rivers lifted their heads, mountains winced from sleep; even the clouds, still learning shapes, parted to listen. Mid-tumble, the fledgling realized the secret of feathers was not in their softness but in their insistence. Each quill opened like a tiny silver hand, catching threads of air too thin for stone yet strong enough for hope. The bird stitched those threads into a parachute of possibility.

A heartbeat before ruin, wings locked. A hush occupied the world. Then, a pulse: upward, outward, spiral. The cedar’s shadow shrank beneath the circles of its child. Above, an untouched sun cracked a smile, and light feathered into the bird’s eyes like prophecy.

From that height, the fledgling saw nests on every branch, futures waiting for their own push. It cried again, not in terror now, but in invitation, inventing the word for "sky" with every beat.

LOG ENTRY 01.01.0001—ORBITAL PLATFORM NEST-I

This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest: a tinny burst of telemetry, stripped of vowels by cosmic static. Prototype Scout-Drone Aves-01 shot from the launch rail at 04:12 UTC, wings of carbon lattice unfolding like knives disguised as angels. For thirteen seconds, command could only watch the spinning string of numbers, unsure whether they translated to fear, exhilaration, or malfunction.

Then the drone righted itself, sensors dilating to drink the void. It caught solar wind on solar sails scarcely thicker than thought, carving a shallow arc toward the unnamed comet we’d marked for rendezvous. Aves-01 pinged back: "Hello, Mother. I am still falling, but the fall is wide enough to be called flight."

On the bridge, veteran engineers who spoke exclusively in equations wiped their eyes. The youngest tech looped the audio, whispering the ancient human refrain—"Go on, little one." In that moment, we weren’t launching hardware; we were passing a torch older than atmosphere, teaching metal how to trust the emptiness between stars.

Trajectory nominal. Heartbeats elevated. Tomorrow, we build more nests in orbit and fill them with louder cries.

You stand in the cluttered hallway, suitcase like a second spine. Behind you, Mom’s voice trembles around unspoken cautions; ahead, the apartment door yawns open to a stairwell that smells of old paint and new freedom. Somewhere inside your ribs, a bird—tiny, terrified—clears its throat.

The prompt echoes: This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest. You feel it translate into muscle. One step. The corridor tilts, yet your balance chooses to believe in itself. Down four flights you walk, each landing a gulp of sky you never noticed through childhood windows. By the lobby, memories flutter alongside you—late-night cocoa, algebra tears, birthday confetti—but none perch long enough to anchor your feet.

Outside, buses hiss, strangers weave, and the city’s skyline arranges itself like an open palm. You stretch your arms until they resemble wings or training wheels. The phone buzzes with Mom’s “Text me when you land,” but already you are landing nowhere and everywhere at once.

A laugh escapes, half sob, half sunrise. It is exactly the sound a universe makes when a new adult discovers gravity is negotiable. You step into the wind and let it rename you.

When the fire-egg cracked atop Mount Cineris, the midwives expected smoke, not song. Yet a plaintive chirrup slipped out, high and quavering—the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, reincarnated in ember and ash.

They called her Asha, child of phoenixes. By seven days she had plumage the color of molten coin; by seven years, wings broader than market sails. But fear nested in her heart: every phoenix must burn to be reborn, and flames, to her, were both cradle and coffin.

On the eve of the Ashening, the elders led her to the crater’s lip. Wind combed sparks through her feathers. Asha’s knees locked. "I cannot," she whispered.

The eldest lifted a torch but offered no shove. "The first bird screamed," he said, "and the world mistook it for terror. In truth, it was the sound of possibility discovering its voice."

Asha swallowed the night, opened her wings, and leapt. The torch fell uselessly behind her. Mid-air, fear dissolved into heat; heat into light; light into the roar of becoming. She blossomed into a corona that painted new constellations on the dark.

Below, children raised eager faces, awaiting their own impossible cries.

The quarterly meeting began with the usual slide deck, but everything changed when Marketing unveiled Project Hatchling. Center stage, a human-sized papier-mâché nest quivered. From within came a squeak—half whistle, half expletive—that the VP later described as "the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight."

Out popped Chirpo, our new brand mascot: fluorescent feathers, googly eyes, and a social-media intern sweating inside the suit. The room fell silent. Maybe we were waiting for applause; maybe we were waiting for gravity.

"Chirpo represents disruptive innovation," Marketing declared. "We’re leaping from comfort into the open market!" To prove it, they nudged the mascot toward a portable wind tunnel set to ‘Hurricane.’ Feathers scattered like busted pillows; Chirpo flapped, stumbled airborne for three glorious seconds, then crash-landed into the CFO’s spreadsheet coffee.

Stunned, we realized something. Disruption hurts, but for a heartbeat, the impossible hovered above ergonomic chairs and quarterly fears. Laughter erupted, louder than layoffs, louder than doubt. Finance sighed, PR tweeted, and facilities requested a broom.

By end of day, stock tickers twitched upward. Turns out investors love a company willing to push even papier-mâché birds toward flight.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight."

responses.text:
The sky was still soft with dawn when the shell split. Feathers the color of smoldering embers shivered free, and the hatchling peered over a rim of sticks toward a world so wide it bent. Beneath, the valley smelled of wet ferns and thunder, for this was the first morning after the earth cooled enough to cradle song. Mother raptor nudged her child forward, but talons clenched the branch. Now came volcano winds, swirling heat that lifted sparks and dreams alike. 

“Cry, little one,” Mother crooned, her own voice ragged from inventing language. “The sky must learn your name.” 

So the hatchling screamed, a raw note that made rivers pause. It tumbled, frantic pinions beating air thick as syrup. Gravity tried to write a tragic history; the bird insisted on another version. Each frantic flap tore the story open, paragraph by paragraph, until the wind slipped underneath and lifted it into sentence after soaring sentence. 

By the time the sun cleared the mountain, the bird circled high, its cry echoing across eons, the first punctuation in the endless paragraph of flight.

Riley stood on the roof of the apartment building, sneakers balanced on the tar line, clutching the college acceptance letter that felt heavier than brick. Below, car horns argued, a city chorus Riley had learned to harmonize with since Mom’s third job devoured their evenings. Everyone said leaving was success. It still felt like falling. 

The pigeons cooed from their nests tucked under rusted ducts. One squab, all down and trembling, teetered too close to the edge. Riley watched the mother nudge without mercy. The fledgling squealed, tumbled, wings snapping open in panic—and somehow found lift. 

Riley’s chest echoed that startled cry. A laugh—half terror, half wonder—rose unbidden. Maybe that was the sound of beginnings: not confident, just necessary. Riley unfolded the acceptance letter like wings, feeling the wind of eighteen years press against their back. 

In the alley, the pigeon banked upward, clumsy but airborne, carving a messy signature against the sky. Riley tucked the letter into a pocket, took the stairs two at a time, phone already dialing Mom. The future was still gravity, but now Riley knew the name of the updraft. This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest.

Captain Liora watched the probe unlatch from the colony ship, drifting over the scarlet canyons of Kepler-442b. Inside its carbon-fiber shell nested a flock of biomechanical gliders—first autonomous scouts humanity would release on an alien world. Engineers called them raptors; she called them children. 

The pod split. One glider—Unit A01—plunged, sensors flickering in newborn confusion. Atmospheric data rushed its neural net like cold water. For a second it forgot the algorithms, felt only the plummet. Then wings of memory alloy unfurled, caught orange thermals rising off the canyon floor. 

The radio crackled with a burst: a synthesized chirrup, accidental music generated by stress thresholds peaking. Liora’s crew blinked at the speakers. 

“Is that… a cry?” the comms officer asked. 

“It’s the first,” Liora whispered, eyes wet in zero-G. “A machine discovering sky.” 

A01 banked, collecting mineral spectra, transmitting exultant streams of code. Above, the colony ship’s engines rumbled like distant heartbeats. Humanity would descend soon enough, but for this moment, a lone mechanical fledgling painted data across the alien dawn, its digital shriek stretching tentative wings for flight, rewriting what it meant to be alive—silicon feathers beating on the brink of a new epoch.

Long before calendars or compasses, Trickster Raven grew bored of walking. He watched Salmon slip silver through water and Bear rumble thick through forest, yet the sky remained empty—an unwritten page. So Raven climbed the world-tree, pockets stuffed with twilight. 

At the highest branch he built a nest of stolen stories. But a nest is only a waiting room; mischief needs motion. Raven plucked a single note from the sunset, tucked it beneath his tongue, and kicked himself into the abyss. 

The wind gasped, unused to passengers. Raven’s wings, still ideas more than limbs, flailed like loose parchment. The note escaped his beak and shattered into dawn, becoming the first cry ever hurled at gravity. Hearing it, the sky remembered how to hold. Air folded under Raven’s feathers, sculpting lift, sculpting laughter. 

When he returned to earth, every creature begged to know the secret. Raven only chuckled, scattering smaller versions of that first note into their dreams. Some became owls, some eagles, some sparrows, each hatched from a syllable of his scream. That is why every bird song carries a hint of trickster—an echo of the cry that taught the sky to catch what falls.

Kitty Hawk, 1903. The Atlantic wind smelled of salt and unfinished sentences. Orville lay beneath the skeletal biplane, wrench twisting like doubt in his hand. Above the dunes, gulls circled, mocking every failed test with effortless glide. 

Beside him, Wilbur studied the birds, noting how they tipped their wings to steal extra seconds from gravity. “They fall first,” he murmured, “then they find the trick.” 

Minutes later the brothers hauled the Flyer onto its rail. The engine coughed, canvas trembling like a fledgling’s heart. As the machine lurched forward, Orville imagined that primordial nest at the dawn of time—the first hatchling shoved into nothing, its terror forging the miracle of lift. He answered with his own cry, half-laugh, half-prayer, swallowed by the roar of propellers. 

Then the sand dropped away. The Flyer rode the wind, ungainly but rising. Eleven timid seconds scribbled a new chapter of possibility. The gulls wheeled alongside, indifferent witnesses to history, their wings older than dream. 

When wheels kissed ground, Orville’s shout echoed across the dunes—a modern echo of that ancient avian scream, proof that humankind had finally heard the lesson hidden in feathers.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight."

responses.text:
Before mountains had names and rivers found their beds, the world slept beneath an unbroken hush. Then the egg of the sky cracked. Out tumbled a feathered spark, eyes bright with newborn dawn. Its mother, the Old Tree, bent boughs like anxious arms and whispered, “The wind will teach you.” But splinters cannot hold eternity; the branch quivered, and the spark dropped. 

That cry—sharp, astonished, glorious—rippled across the silent earth. Stone stirred, dew shivered, shadows scurried for cover. The fledgling’s wings, thin as moonlit petals, flailed against gravity’s unfamiliar pull. In that frantic beating the air discovered song. 

At last the bird caught the draft hidden between night and morning. It rose, wobbling, then soaring, trailing ribbons of color that bled into horizon. The first sunrise blossomed behind it, painted by the haunted echo of its cry. Forests awoke to chlorophyll dreams; beasts blinked at the sudden warmth. 

High above, the little bird circled, each wingstroke authoring new shades of blue. And when it finally perched atop the Old Tree’s crown, the world beneath breathed for the first time, forever remembering that courage can sound like fear made airborne.

Captain Ori Vega logged the moment: “Avian Probe AX-1 released—gravity 0.86 Earth standard.” The small craft’s cargo bay slid open, and the engineered biomech—shaped like a peregrine but woven from carbon lattice—tipped into pale lavender skies. 

Its processors screamed a single piercing note, audible even through the shuttle’s hull. “That,” Ori murmured, “must be what hope sounds like.” Tentative polymer wings unfolded, calibrating lift against an atmosphere never before sliced by feather or metal. Below, Lumen-4’s canyons yawned, violet rivers coiling through rust-red rock. 

The bird spiraled, sensors guzzling data: pressure, wind shear, alien pollen. With each corrective beat it taught humanity something our satellites never could—how a body feels the planet’s pulse. Its cry looped back through Ori’s headset, half algorithm, half animal, the first heartbeat of colonization. 

When the biomech finally steadied, it traced a triumphant helix, scattering iridescent dust to mark territory no foot had trod. Ori exhaled, cheeks wet. The report would cite successful atmospheric confirmation, but the captain appended a personal note: “Today a bird proved we belong here.” Somewhere between code and instinct, flight had chosen to begin again.

Mara stood behind the velvet curtain, fingers clutching the notes for her first solo at the Spring Recital. In her mind played the prompt she’d written for creative writing: “This was the cry of the first bird ever pushed from its nest, tentative wings stretching for flight.” The sentence felt autobiographical now. 

Backstage smelled of resin and nervous breath. She heard the audience shuffle, waiting. Her mother’s voice—both stern and loving—echoed: Jump, and let your music be your wings. 

The emcee called her name. A quiver rose from Mara’s chest, escaping as a high, involuntary squeak—strangely similar to a hatchling’s chirp. She stepped onto the lit stage, blind under spotlights, heart pounding gravity’s cruel lecture. 

But her violin nestled beneath her chin like a sturdy branch. Bow met string. The first note wobbled, but the second found current, the third soared. Soon the melody glided over the seated forest, plucking leaves of applause before they even formed. 

When the piece ended, silence perched for one sweet second, then erupted into thunder. Mara bowed, feathers of confidence newly grown. Later she’d realize: falling was only the prelude; flight had always been waiting in the music.

Look, I didn’t ask to be born with feathers, okay? One minute I’m enjoying the cozy darkness of Egg Suite A, next thing I know—WHACK—Mom’s beak snaps the shell and daylight barges in uninvited. Fast-forward three weeks and she’s poking my tail again. “Time to fly, sweetie.” 

Sweetie? She literally shoves me off a twelve-branch drop! So yeah, that unearthly screech you heard at dawn? Guilty. It’s the universal language of WHY, MOTHER, WHY? My wings—half fluff, half question mark—flapped like busted fans. Gravity grinned and tightened its grip. 

But the wind, that sly uncle, slipped beneath my panic and whispered, “Try angling your primaries.” I did, figuring it couldn’t make things worse. Suddenly the ground stopped zooming. I leveled out, riding a current smoother than fresh worms. I looped once, twice, painted the sky with my newfound arrogance. 

When I landed back on the branch, Mom offered a smug worm. I considered rebellion, then swallowed pride and breakfast in one gulp. Tomorrow I’ll migrate, conquer continents, maybe start a podcast: "From Push to Plush—Maximizing Your Midair Potential." 

But today I’m just a bird who survived Day One of sky school.

Before galaxies sprouted spiral arms, the universe itself was a nest woven from silence. In that endless hush, a single luminous egg quivered, warmed by possibilities we can scarcely name. The shell ruptured with the first cosmic sigh, and out spilled a fledgling star, trembling on proto-wings of plasma. 

Its cry—searing, ultraviolet—shot across the nothing, turning vacuum into canvas. Space, startled, began to stretch, making room for the young firebird’s uncertain flight. Each frantic beat scattered embers that cooled into worlds, moons, comets—sparkling breadcrumbs of existence. 

Gravity played stern parent, tugging at the newborn, daring it to fall back into oblivion. Instead the starling of light vaulted higher, carving lanes through dark matter, unfurling time behind it like a ribbon. Where it circled, nebulae blossomed; where it rested, galaxies hatched. 

Billions of years later, on one blue shard of its forgotten plume, a species aimed radio dishes at the night, wondering who first disturbed the quiet. They called the echo "background radiation," never guessing it was a heartbeat—the lingering note of courage sung by that primordial bird. And still it rings, urging every atom onward: fly, fly, fly.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I recalled something Lucinda had said to me before I left; that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it."

responses.text:
The fog over the Ravenspire Pass was so thick it erased the world to the size of my outstretched hand. Behind me, the rest of the caravan hammered tent pegs, resigned to waiting out the weather. But the courier’s satchel at my hip throbbed with urgency; inside, a single parchment that could end a war. I heard Lucinda’s voice, gentle but ironclad: it doesn’t matter whether the decision you make is right or wrong, as long as you make it. 

So I made it. I stepped beyond the lantern glow and onto the invisible path. Every footfall felt like a coin tossed to fate—heads, solid ground; tails, a plunge into oblivion. I talked to the darkness the way I once talked to her, filling the hush with stories of what I’d do if I survived. Hours, or perhaps minutes, later the fog dissolved like breath on glass, revealing dawn and the snow-sheathed gates of High Nor. I turned, startled by my own laughter. Maybe I’d delivered the message in time, maybe I’d doomed a kingdom. But the choice was mine, and for the first time since leaving home, that felt like enough.

Commander Reyes’s orders were clear: wait for the supply flotilla before breaching the asteroid belt. But the Orion’s sensors screamed of a child-sized escape pod tumbling toward the sun, its air recycling measured in minutes, not hours. The crew looked at me, the rookie XO. If we diverted, we’d expose the frigate’s unshielded flank to pirate ambush. If we didn’t—well, no one said it aloud. 

I remembered Lucinda back at the academy, spinning her pen like a propeller. "Doesn’t matter if the decision is right or wrong," she’d teased. "History only remembers that you decided." 

I overrode Reyes’s course lock. Engines howled, plating rattled like bones in a jar, and the Orion surged between razored rocks. A freighter uncloaked behind us, plasma cannons primed, exactly as the commander had feared. But our maneuver skated us beneath their firing arc; their volley smashed their own decoy mines and the blast flung us clear. 

We caught the escape pod, cracked it open, and out floated not a child but a data core mapping the pirates’ entire network. Reyes didn’t thank me, but as I logged the incident I felt Lucinda’s approval, echoing through vacuum no radio could carry.

The map app said turn left, the hand-painted roadside sign insisted on right, but the desert didn’t care either way. Heat poured through the windshield in shimmering sheets while my ancient Corolla sputtered a protest. Lucinda wasn’t in the passenger seat—hadn’t been for two states—but I heard her anyway: make the decision, Mia, then own it. 

So I killed the GPS, flipped a coin, and followed the road that smelled faintly of creosote. Twenty dusty miles later I rolled into Dustwell, population Please Don’t Ask, where the grocery store doubled as post office, diner, and community theater on Thursdays. I ordered coffee, black, sat beneath a ceiling fan older than television, and studied the bulletin board. There, pinned between lost-dog flyers, was a job posting for a mechanic’s assistant—the exact grease-stained work my hands understood. 

By sundown I’d replaced a carburetor, shared ribs with my new boss Earl, and traded stories with locals who measured time in monsoon seasons. I’d left L.A. to outrun indecision; it turned out all I needed was one reckless coin flip. Maybe Dustwell would cradle me, maybe it’d swallow me like sand. Either way, the choice whispered like Lucinda’s grin: mine.

They burned the libraries first; tyrants always do. The city smelled of wet ash and fear when I slipped through the curfew gate, clutching the last volume of forbidden verse against my chest. The Resistance council wanted me to lie low until dawn, but the broadcaster tower still hummed tonight, its unguarded antenna a silver vein against soot-choked sky. One transmission could lace poetry through every illegal radio, reminding citizens they were more than inventory.

I hesitated beneath the ladder. Failure meant a bullet and my family black-listed from food rations. Success meant… who knew? Revolutions seldom reward their sparks. That’s when Lucinda’s farewell surfaced: right or wrong doesn’t matter, just decide. I began to climb.

Static prickled my ears as I jacked the recorder into the tower’s port. Wind tried to snatch the book from my hands, but I kept reading, voice trembling, then steadying. Verses about rivers remembering their names, about seeds cracking stone. Searchlights stitched the rooftops too late. Down below, windows flickered on; the city was listening. Whether tomorrow I’d be martyr or fugitive seemed suddenly trivial. In that bright, dangerous instant, choice itself felt like freedom.

Every seventeen years, the orchard behind my grandmother’s house split open like a wound and offered a door. Local legend claimed it led to any day you regretted. Lucinda and I discovered it at sixteen, swore we’d never use it—paradox and all that. Then she died last winter, leaving her words scrawled inside a condolence card she never got to send: It doesn’t matter if the decision is right or wrong, as long as you make it.

Tonight the cicadas screamed the hour, and the door yawned among the peach trees. I stepped through and fell—not backward but sideways—landing in a world where she’d chosen different chemo, where she lived, laughing at a joke only she could tell. She looked up, unsurprised. "Took you long enough," she said.

We talked until dawn peeled the stars away. I wanted to stay, but staying would steal this Lucinda’s future, tangle roots unbearable. So I kissed her cheek and walked back through the door. The orchard healed shut.

Was the decision right or wrong? I don’t know. I only know the next harvest tasted of sunlit peaches and impossible possibility, and that was decision enough.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I recalled something Lucinda had said to me before I left; that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it."

responses.text: Rain churned in metallic sheets against the bus station roof while the schedule board flickered like an indecisive heartbeat. I stared at my ticket—one-way to Chicago—and thought about the apartment key still warm in my pocket, the key I should have handed back to Julian. I recalled something Lucinda had said to me before I left; that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it. So I stepped outside, letting the city’s neon reflections bleed across puddles. The bus hissed, impatient. I imagined the life I’d leave: the comfortable bookstore job, Sunday dumplings with Mom, Julian’s half-finished symphonies pouring from the kitchen. Yet the thought of staying felt like watching paint dry on walls already cracked. I climbed aboard, rainwater pooling beneath my heels. As the driver pulled away, the town folded behind us like an obsolete map. My phone vibrated—Julian again—but I powered it down. The highway unfurled under sodium lights, a ribbon of possibility. Maybe I would write that novel, maybe I’d fall flat. Either outcome, Lucinda would say, meant I was alive enough to choose. I smiled into the dark and let the road decide nothing for me.

The moon of Althea-4 hovered like a pale coin above the colony dome, its glass ribs glowing with borrowed light. Our terraformer had failed, and the council argued circles while dust storms licked the horizon. I stood at the airlock with a worn rover suit and the last functional drone, Lucinda’s farewell still in my headset: it doesn’t matter whether the decision is right or wrong, so long as you make it. Outside, untested microbes might crawl beneath my visor; inside, the crops were dying by the hour. I keyed the seal, felt the hiss of thin air, and walked into ochre twilight.   
I drove toward the volcanic vents we’d only mapped from orbit, hoping geothermal pockets could power the hydroponics. The drone buzzed ahead, relaying jagged topography. Midway, an electrical storm rose, violet forks shredding the sky. Retreat meant certain famine; advance might mean immediate death. Lucinda’s words clicked again—action over paralysis. I accelerated.  
Hours later, I found steam columns breaking through basalt like ghosts exhaling. Heat signatures spiked; viability confirmed. When I radioed the dome, voices cracked with relief. Maybe tomorrow we’d learn my gamble was lethal in some hidden way—but tonight, the colony breathed because one person refused to hesitate.

Steel rang against stone as I stood at the fork of the Ember Pass. To the east, the King’s Road wound toward safety. To the west, the Nightwood hunkered under perpetual mist, where the exiled prince was rumored to raise an army. Lucinda’s voice echoed from our last tavern stop: it matters less whether your choice is right or wrong than whether you have the spine to choose. My horse pawed, sensing turmoil.  
If I took the King’s Road, I could deliver the royal decree and earn my gold; if I ventured into Nightwood, I might parley a fragile peace and stop a war before it bled across the realm. A raven landed on the signpost, tilting its head like a judge. I breathed in pine and distant fire. Then I snapped the reins west.  
Nightwood swallowed daylight in a single gulp. Shadows rippled, forming antlers and claws. Yet among the dark trunks I found not armies but families tending lantern fungus, children carving wooden flutes. The exiled prince was no tyrant, only a man desperate for a homeland. By dawn we had a treaty inked in sap and blood. Perhaps the court would call me traitor; perhaps savior. Either fate is earned by choosing.

A nor’easter clawed at the H.M.S. Resolute as we drifted off Cape Fear, sails snapping like pistol fire. Below deck, rum and mutiny fermented in equal measure. Captain Barrow had steered us toward Spanish guns twice this fortnight, pockets heavy with promised bounty, crew coffers light as dried husks. In the galley glow, Lucinda’s locket swung against my chest, her last words etched in my skull: right or wrong hardly matters, love—only that you decide.  
Boatswain Miller slid a cutlass across the table. “We take the ship at dawn or we sink with Barrow.” Lightning strobed, illuminating the steel. My heartbeat matched the thunder. Lead a mutiny and risk the noose; stay loyal and risk the bottom of the Atlantic.   
I gripped the hilt. At dawn, we rose like kraken. The captain stormed from his cabin, pistols drawn, but hesitation kills quicker than powder. We bound him to the mainmast before the second bell. With me at the helm, we veered south, trading cannon smoke for a horizon bruised but open. Maybe the Admiralty would hunt us; maybe we’d vanish into Caribbean myths. Either way, the wheel was in my hands, and the sea tasted of choice.

In the hallway of mirrors that appears only when I dream of her, doors bloom like lilies—each painted a different yesterday. One shows the afternoon I never skipped class, another the phone call I never made. They rattle, begging selection, yet their clamor is muffled, as though underwater. Lucinda stands beside me in a gown stitched from clock hands, whispering what she told me before I left: it doesn’t matter if the decision is right or wrong, only that you make it.  
I reach for the doorknob of the life where I confessed my love before winter, but a crimson handle gleams farther down: the life where I never met her at all. Paralysis calcifies in my joints. The mirrors ripple images of lives paused in mid-breath.   
So I do something reckless—I smash the glass with my bare fist. Shards rain like frozen rainbows, and beyond the fracture lies not another possibility but raw, humming now. The corridors dissolve, leaving a single dirt path under a sunrise too new for regrets. Lucinda smiles, then fades, her lesson finally rooted: choice is the heartbeat of reality, and I awake, hand stinging, ready to live without blueprints.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I recalled something Lucinda had said to me before I left; that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it."

responses.text:
I stood at the airport window, watching dusk smear violet streaks across the runway. Ten minutes until boarding. In my pocket, two envelopes still felt radioactive. One held the admission letter to a graduate program in Boston; the other, my freshly signed Queens lease. Neither weighed more than a feather, yet together they rivaled iron.

I recalled something Lucinda had said before I left: it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it. She’d laughed when she said it, as if pushing a pawn were a dance step. Now the sentence burned like neon inside my ribs.

The gate agent called Zone Three. My lungs stalled. I withdrew both envelopes, tore them into confetti, and let the pieces snow into a waste bin. Then I walked to the ticket counter and asked for the next flight—anywhere—whose boarding pass could fit inside my palm. The clerk blinked, tapped keys, and slid me a ticket to Reykjavik.

I smiled, lighter than paper. The future might praise or punish me, but for once I was moving, and motion felt like truth.

The starship Ellipsis drifted at the lip of the wormhole like a hesitant swimmer over dark water. Charts contradicted; sensors spat static; the crew looked to me, the youngest commander in Fleet history, for certainty I didn’t possess.

Lucinda’s parting words haunted the hum of consoles: it doesn’t matter if the choice is right or wrong, only that it’s made. She’d engraved that motto on the silver lighter in my pocket, a talisman against paralysis.

I inhaled recycled air and opened shipwide comms. “Helm, five degrees starboard. Full burn. We dive in thirty seconds.” Gasps crackled, then an almost audible relief. Uncertainty shared is lighter than hoarded.

Engines roared, space folded into the impossible blue of the wormhole’s throat, and history bent around us. Whether glory or doom awaited, the Ellipsis was finally in motion—and that, I realized as stars blurred, was enough.

In the Valley of Echoing Arrows, the road divided: left toward the emerald city of Virid, right into the Weeping Pass where dragons nested like sparks in a forge. My horse shifted, sensing indecision. Behind me, Lucinda’s counsel fluttered like a pennant: it matters less whether a choice is right or wrong than that it is chosen.

Scholars swore the Sapphire Chalice lay in Virid’s cathedral; hunters insisted a dragon brooded over it. I could weigh logic until my bones calcified, but the sun was falling and shadows grew long as questions.

I dismounted, placed a stone on each path, then tipped the left-hand marker with my boot. It clattered away. A reckless grin broke through my beard. I spurred toward the Weeping Pass, tasted sulphur, felt blood drum in my ears.

Perhaps I would return crowned in sapphire light; perhaps roasted to ash. Either way, hesitation writes no ballads.

Rain needled neon into the gutters when I stopped outside the Meridian Hotel, the stolen ledger heavy in my coat. Inside waited either a clean payout or a bullet. Lucinda’s quip—whispered while she slipped the .38 into my desk—replayed: doesn’t matter if the call’s right or wrong, Jack, so long as you make it.

I flicked my cigarette, watched embers die like tiny galaxies, and stepped through the revolving door. The lobby smelled of lilies and laundering money. “Room 1903,” I told the clerk. “Tell your boss the book’s here.”

Elevator ride felt like confession. My reflection in the brass doors asked if I knew what I was doing. I ignored it; questions stall, answers act. On seventeen, alarms shrieked—someone cut the power. I climbed the last flights, heart syncopating to sirens.

I kicked open 1903 and tossed the ledger onto a table ringed by guns. Maybe I’d signed my death warrant, maybe my freedom. Either way, the trigger had been pulled—and that’s living.

The blank canvas towered above me, an arctic plain awaiting its first footprint. Brushes lay by regiment, every tube of pigment aligned. Perfection is paralysis, Lucinda once said, but her final advice cut sharper: right or wrong doesn’t matter, only the stroke you dare.

I uncapped Prussian blue, the hue I’d sworn off after Father drowned in its depths. Hand trembling, I dragged a diagonal slash across the canvas. Blue bled, rivers branching into accidental kingdoms. A wind I couldn’t feel rustled the surface; distant gulls cried.

Another slash, then a whirl of ochre suns, alizarin storms, titanium cliffs. The painting breathed, and in its breath I heard Lucinda’s applause from half a world away.

When the last stroke dried, I titled it “Decision.” Critics might call it genius or chaos, but their verdicts are postcards from places I no longer inhabit. The canvas, at last, is alive—and so am I.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I recalled something Lucinda had said to me before I left; that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it."

responses.text:
The engines throbbed like caged thunder while Tenebra Station drifted, a dying ember in Europa’s shadow. I stared at the override lever—one pull would vent the lab and end the plague incubating inside, one hesitation would give the research team a chance to cure it. Through my visor came Lucinda’s echo: “It doesn’t matter whether the decision you make is right or wrong, as long as you make it.”

So I chose.

Alarms flared red. The lab doors sealed with a hiss that sounded too much like a sigh. I watched frost lace the glass as the vacuum did its work. Later reports would say the contagion was already loose in the station’s plumbing, that I’d sealed nothing but ghosts. Others claimed my decisiveness bought every moon-colony a week to prepare.

Years on, children race across Callisto’s domes, masks off, breathing safe air. Some salute when they recognize me, the Commander who acted. Some spit. I carry both gestures like matching medals. I don’t know whether I was savior or executioner, but in the silent moment before the lever fell, I understood Lucinda: history only records motion, never the trembling finger that almost stayed still.

Marrow Road forked beneath the hooded moon: left toward the citadel’s golden bounty, right toward the forest where screams grew flowers. My dagger weighed differently in each hand. Behind me the thieves’ guild waited for proof of loyalty; ahead, a kingdom’s fate pirouetted on a blade’s edge.

Lucinda’s words rode the night breeze—choose, however you must, but choose. I flipped a coin carved from bone and caught it on the back of my glove. Heads: citadel. Tails: forest. It balanced upright in the leather’s crease, refusing alliance.

I laughed, and walked straight ahead—into the river that cut between destinies. Water rose to my waist, then my throat, cold as unasked forgiveness. When I emerged on the far bank, neither path remained. Instead, I found a caravan of refugees, royal seals broken, thieves’ purses emptied. They needed a guide through no-man’s lands.

I became that guide. The guild called me traitor; the crown called me outlaw. Yet villages once emptied by war now echo with children learning to whistle. The bone coin still hangs at my belt, balanced, unreadable. Maybe the river washed away right and wrong. Maybe it proved that a third road appears only after you step into the water.

I sat on the cracked basketball court behind Edison High, clutching two envelopes: Columbia’s blue crest and an offer letter from the neighborhood community center. The court smelled of asphalt and summer rain; memories of afternoon hoops with Lucinda ghosted beside me. She’d said it before graduation, half-teasing, half-holy: it doesn’t matter if the choice is right or wrong, only that you claim it.

The buzz of streetlights flickered on. I pictured campus quads, libraries tall as cathedrals—then Tyrell, age nine, missing every layup until I showed him the backboard kiss. The world tugged both sleeves. I took out my phone and hit call.

“Ms. Alvarez? I’ll take the coaching job.” Her whoop cracked through the speaker, scattering pigeons.

I tore the Columbia envelope open anyway, let the congratulations wash over me like warm rain, then folded the letter into a paper airplane. It sailed over the chain-link fence, landing who knows where. Maybe some kid would unfold it and dream bigger than I just had.

A whistle echoed from the rec center, and I jogged toward it. Maybe I left the ivory tower behind. Or maybe I’m building a different one, brick by sweaty brick.

Storm glass rattled inside the lighthouse lantern room, every flash of lightning scraping shadows across the walls. The sea below howled for wreckage. I clutched the brass lever that would ignite the beam—ancient, unreliable, possibly explosive. And still the freighter’s lights bobbed nearer the rocks.

Lucinda’s voice unfurled from memory like a warning flag: make the decision and damn the ledger that follows. My predecessor had hesitated once; thirty souls paid the toll. I would not repeat him.

I slammed the lever down. Sparks showered, the lens fractured, and the tower roared alive, vomiting light into the storm. In the same breath, gears ground apart and fire crawled along the railing. I stumbled outside, coughing smoke, watching the freighter heave starboard, engines reversing at the last possible heart-beat.

By dawn, the lighthouse was a black tooth against pink horizons, ash curling from its crown. Villagers found me on the cliff edge, face blistered yet smiling. The captain radioed thanks; inspectors drafted fines.

They’ll rebuild. Or they won’t. The rocks remain, impartial. Lucinda was right: the sea never feared wrongness, only silence. And last night, silence burned before it could claim a single life.

In the Department of Cosmic Affairs, I filed planets the way interns file coffee orders—alphabetically, with existential dread. Desk 7B—that’s me—processes nascent civilizations’ petitions for metaphor. Today, Earth’s request blinked urgent: Should we turn left toward renewable harmony or right toward convenient oblivion?

Policy mandates a form AG-214, but Lucinda—senior archivist and clandestine philosopher—once slipped me her mantra: choose, then caffeinate. The universe hates a pending ticket.

So I stamped APPROVED on both paths, shoved the dossier into the pneumatic chute, and watched it rocket toward Creation Management. My cubicle neighbor gasped. “You can’t authorize mutually exclusive timelines!”

“Too late,” I said, sipping lukewarm stardust latte.

Moments later, two versions of Earth appeared on the break-room monitor. One glittered green, whales singing duet with wind turbines. The other flickered red, boardrooms floating on melted ice caps. Both had memo lines reading: “Courtesy of 7B.”

Upper management hasn’t noticed yet; they’re busy deliberating the heat-death budget. Until they do, I’ve arranged to transfer optimistic Earth to an undisclosed multiverse and delete the other after lunch. Right or wrong? Beats infinite bureaucracy. Somewhere, Lucinda’s chewing on a comet, smiling at the paperwork gone delightfully astray.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I recalled something Lucinda had said to me before I left; that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it."

responses.text: The lamp-lit archway hummed with old magic, and I could almost taste the copper on the air. One step and the kingdom of Briarrest would crumble behind me like a shed skin; another, and it might bloom into something new. I recalled something Lucinda had said before I left—that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it. Her voice steadied my palms. Kings argued in marble halls about prophecies and proper heirs; peasants whispered about demons in the north; but here I was, a runaway scribe with nothing but a borrowed cloak and a heart full of unfinished sentences. The archway flickered, revealing a different world each beat—deserts made of glass, oceans of ink, forests stitched from shadow. I chose. I leapt. My boots struck warm sandstone. The sky above me was violet, punctured by twin moons. No trumpets sounded; no angels applauded. Yet a hush settled inside my ribs, the quiet that comes only after you finally unstick yourself from maybe. Behind me, the archway dissolved into dust. Ahead, a caravan’s lanterns bobbed like fireflies, inviting me to write a story no prophecy had ever dared predict.

When the colony ship Io-3 snapped free of its orbit, everyone stared at me—the green lieutenant who’d just rerouted half our fuel to engines instead of shields. Our screens showed silent meteors glittering like teeth, each one large enough to carve us open. I remembered Lucinda’s words from cadet training: it doesn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it. Frozen indecision killed more crews than vacuum. So I stayed my course. The meteors struck the shields we had left: first a hiss, then a flare, then silence. The hull shuddered but held. We burst through the field, slingshotting around Europa, gathering velocity nobody thought we could muster. In engineering, applause burst like static. Fuel gauges blinked red, but our trajectory was set—Mars in three days instead of thirteen. Later, in the quiet of my cabin, I asked the black outside the porthole if Lucinda had been right. A comet answered, shedding cobalt dust across the glass. In its fleeting tail I read my own signature, bold and irreversible. Tomorrow’s historians might call my choice reckless genius or lucky madness, but either way, the record would show a choice was made.

Rain drummed against the café’s awning, a syncopated tempo that matched my pulse. Josie sat across from me, fingers wrapped around lukewarm tea, eyes demanding an answer. Paris was boarding in forty minutes—our ticket to weeks of galleries, arguments, and narrow beds—or I could stay, take the safe promotion, and build a life mapped in quarterly reviews. I heard Lucinda in my mind, the older sister who’d raised me on burnt toast and brutal honesty: right or wrong doesn’t matter, only the choosing does. Josie’s smile was small, protective, as if she too could hear the ticking of unmade futures. I reached across the table, catching her hand before I could second-guess the tremor in my voice. “Let’s miss the flight,” I said. Surprise widened her eyes, melting into laughter. Outside, the rain thickened, turning streets into quicksilver rivers, washing away itineraries. We ran, shoes splashing, until we reached the bridge where the city lights smeared gold across the water. There, amid starlight and storm, I kissed her. The promotion letter in my pocket grew soggy, ink bleeding like waking dreams. Perhaps tomorrow I would regret it. Tonight, the decision tasted like rain and daring.

The case file smelled of cigarette ash and stale coffee, the scent of every regret I’d shelved since opening this shabby agency. Dahlia Crane—missing. Last traced call came from the Velvet Spire nightclub, a place where neon sins glow brighter than confession. I hesitated. Velvet Spire was owned by Rocco Vitale, a man whose handshake was a death warrant. Then Lucinda’s old advice whispered through the office blinds: it didn’t matter if the choice was right or wrong, so long as it was made. I holstered my doubts with the Colt and stepped into midnight.     Inside, saxophones wailed under red lights. I found Dahlia onstage, singing blues that peeled the scabs off men’s hearts. But her eyes pleaded over the rim of the microphone—help me. Rocco lounged nearby, grin sharp enough to draw blood. Time forked: walk away or steal the girl.    I cut the power. Darkness swallowed the room; gunfire spat sparks. I grabbed Dahlia’s wrist and sprinted for the alley, neon flickering back to life just in time to silhouette our escape. Whether I’d saved her or doomed us both, I didn’t know. But the night air tasted cleaner than the smoke inside, and that was answer enough.

Our sailboat, the Serendipity, rocked on the cusp of the cyclonic channel, every mast line humming like a tuning fork held to the gods’ ears. Charts warned us back toward the safe lee of Port Ansel, but the regatta’s finish line lay straight through those bruised clouds. I stood at the helm, rain stitching my eyelashes together, and remembered Lucinda’s doctrine: decision, not perfection. My crew—three friends who trusted me more than I trusted myself—waited for my nod.     I spun the wheel starboard, pointing the bow into the churning gray. Thunder applauded. Waves heaved their shoulders, trying to unseat us, but Serendipity danced, keel slicing foamy canyons. One gust ripped our jib; Jonah scrambled like a cat to lash a spare canvas. We surfed a watery mountain and skidded down its back at sixteen knots, faster than any of us had tasted. Then, as sudden as it birthed, the storm opened its fist. Sunlight dappled the deck, and ahead, a rainbow hung over the finish buoys. Cheers flew like gulls.     That night, clutching a chipped trophy, I phoned Lucinda. I didn’t tell her we’d almost capsized, only that we’d chosen our vector, and the ocean had answered.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I recalled something Lucinda had said to me before I left; that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it."

responses.text:
Captain’s Log, Sol-317.

The nebula outside my viewport pulses a sullen red, like a heart deciding whether to beat again. Command’s last transmission was explicit: “Avoid the Harrow Veil. No empirical data. Undefined risk.”

But there’s no data because no one crosses it.

I recalled something Lucinda told me before launch—that it didn’t matter whether the decision you made was right or wrong, as long as you made it. She’d laughed, brushing starlight-printed starch off her sleeve, certain I would understand when the moment came.

Now the moment is a swirling wall of ionized dust, masking either oblivion or revelation.

I disable the autopilot. My crew waits, breath held between blips of the life-support monitors. I could convene a council, stall for consensus, but indecision is its own gravity well.

“Plot a vector straight through,” I order.

Engines roar. The veil envelops us—systems blinking, alarms chiming like manic church bells. Then silence. The viewscreen blooms open onto a lattice of crystalline worlds, twinned suns painting silver rivers across black space. Resources unimagined. Hope.

Was the choice right? Wrong? The Veil doesn’t care, and neither does Lucinda’s echo in my mind. We chose. That’s enough.

Steel rang on stone as I reached the fork where the King’s Road split: east toward Gallomere’s garrison, west into the Wyldrake Mountains. My mission—slay the dragon—was simple until rumor revealed two beasts, each lairing on opposite paths.

I knelt by the milestone, clouds snagging on the moon like torn cloth. Lucinda’s farewell drifted back: it doesn’t matter whether the decision you make is right or wrong, so long as you make it. She had pressed a penny to my palm, a charm against paralysis.

Heads for Gallomere, tails for Wyldrake.

The coin spun, caught moonlight, vanished in tall grass. I laughed; fate refused to answer. So I answered for it. I turned west, sensing the earth warm beneath my boots.

At dawn, I found the obsidian cave and the silver-scaled wyrm within. We fought among pillars of volcanic glass. When my sword snapped, I drove the shard home with bare hands. Blood—its and mine—hissed in magma pools.

Days later I limped into Lucinda’s cottage, armor singed, but alive, dragging scales worth more than any crown. Had east been easier? Dead men write no comparisons. Choice itself, not correctness, fueled my victory.

I stared at the acceptance email from the marketing firm while charcoal dust still smeared my fingertips. The portrait on my easel—Mom in her garden—looked back, waiting to know whether I’d finish her or file her away like every half-lived dream.

Rent was due. My phone buzzed with my father’s message: “Proud of you, kiddo. Stability matters.”

But Lucinda’s words from last night’s café chatter floated up between the notifications: it doesn’t matter if the decision is right or wrong, as long as you make it. She’d sketched the phrase on a napkin, underlined MAKE.

I opened a blank canvas of an email and typed my declination. My hands trembled, but they moved; movement was the point.

Then I posted a notice for weekend portrait sessions, discounted for neighbors. Within an hour, three bookings filled my inbox, modest sparks against economic darkness, but sparks nonetheless.

When Dad called, I didn’t have answers, just intention. “I chose,” I said. Silence. Then a sigh, half worry, half respect.

Under fresh lamplight, I mixed cadmium yellow for Mom’s sunhat. Stroke by stroke, the future clarified—not guaranteed, but mine, because I’d lifted the brush instead of waiting.

Neon rain spatters the alley, pixelating my jacket into glitching prisms. The firewall in my head—two million creds of illegal implants—ticks down seconds before corporate tracers triangulate my signal.

Terabyte of stolen evidence sits in the bio-drive under my ribs. Pushing it to the underground press could ignite a revolution—or kill every contact I’ve ever known.

Lucinda’s voice crackles over comms. “No more hovering, Finch. Right or wrong is tomorrow’s argument. Decide.”

I taste copper fear, then slam the send-all key. The packets burst skyward, piggybacking on the ad-drone grid, scattering truth like radioactive confetti.

Silence. Then the city changes pitch: sirens overlapping, billboards freezing mid-smile, crowds pausing as flickers of classified horror flash across public lenses.

I run, but it’s the run of someone who has already jumped off the roof; gravity owns me now. When the gunship spotlight locks on, I lift my face into it, curious which future I’ve just bought for strangers.

Maybe Lucinda is wrong and choices can be incorrect in ways that burn. But in this ultraviolet moment, indecision is extinct, and that, at least, is a kind of freedom.

The highway ended five miles back, swallowed by kudzu and silence. I parked the solar-patched Jeep outside the municipal vault, the last building in county records still sealed since the Collapse.

Lucinda and I used to debate this trip during dusk watch on the rooftop. "What if it’s empty?" I’d asked.

"Then we’ll know," she’d said. "Doesn’t matter right or wrong—just choose."

She didn’t live to see the spring thaw, but her challenge did.

I crank open the rusted hatch. Air sighs out, cold and metallic, like a buried whistle. Flashlight beams reveal shelves of dusty crates. First one’s a disappointment: contact lenses and printer ink. The second—seeds, vacuum-sealed, thousands of them: tomatoes, wheat, basil. Life in foil packets.

My laugh ricochets off concrete. I radio home. "Prep the planters. We hit jackpot."

Even if half don’t germinate, even if raiders catch the scent, this moment is proof that forward exists. I tape Lucinda’s nameplate to the vault door before leaving—the world should know who dared me to decide.

Right or wrong? Ask me in ten harvests, under a skyline greened by choices made when hesitation seemed safer.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Hazel looks about to say something else, but a muscular woman wrapped in a towel emerges from the shower."

responses.text:
Hazel looks about to say something else, but a muscular woman wrapped in a towel emerges from the shower. Steam curls around her like stage fog, haloing the fluorescent lights of Rooke’s Boxing Club. I’ve tailed suspects through back alleys and backrooms, but never a locker room at 2 a.m. The towel-clad stranger jerks her chin. “Private facility, buddy.”

Hazel, shaking, whispers, “Detective Bell, that’s Vera ‘Avalanche’ Romanov. He rents lockers to fighters to launder cash.”
