The therapist had said, “Name your feelings.” I’d tried: sorrow, regret, confusion. None fit. Then the radiator screamed, metal on metal, and I felt it—rage, bright and liquid, flooding every vein.

I smashed the dishes he never washed, slung paint across the walls we never finished, scrawled curses in red acrylic. The cat fled to the hallway, wisely neutral. When the neighbors banged, I howled louder. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then.

By dawn the apartment looked like a crime scene, but the hissing had stopped. I swept ceramic shards into a trash bag, humming. Each scrape of the broom sounded like punctuation, a period at the end of a sentence I’d been too polite to finish.

At noon I texted Max: “Come get your stuff. Wear gloves.” He replied with a single thumbs-up. I laughed—really laughed—for the first time in months. The radiator stayed silent, and the silence felt mercifully mine.

They say the volcano Akalani was once a gentle maiden who stitched cloud-lace for the sky. But when her lover sailed away, she sought counsel from the sea gods. "Let me forget," she begged. The gods shrugged: forgetting costs fire. So rage bloomed in her chest like embers in dry grass.

She tore open the earth, summoning rivers of glassy red. Villages fled, crops withered, mountains trembled. The priests wailed, “You promised us rain, not ruin!” Akalani answered only with thunder: Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then.

Centuries passed. Her lava cooled into fertile soil. Children danced on the black sand, planting taro where ash had fallen. Elders told the tale: grief must burn itself clean before life can return. At twilight, plumes still curl from Akalani’s caldera, a reminder that beneath every meadow sleeps a heart that once broke hard enough to reshape the world.

Subject: RE: Incident 47-B
From: Operative 9
To: Control

Control,

You ordered containment, not closure, so I followed protocol. But protocol can’t cauterize what they did to Sasha. Every neon alley here smells of recycled coolant and betrayal. Tonight the target’s limo glided under the viaduct. I was supposed to tag it, wait for legal seizure. Instead, I loaded the EMP spear and thought: Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then.

The blast fried half the district grid. Target crashed into a holo-billboard, data vaults spilling like confetti. I dragged him out—smug synth-silk ruined—made him watch the files auto-delete. Each flash erased a piece of the blackmail that killed her. He begged for mercy. I gave him memories: hers, mine, ours. Then I walked away, leaving justice unsigned so no one could audit the aftermath.

Dock my pay, revoke clearance—whatever helps you sleep. The city’s darker tonight, but so am I, and sometimes equilibrium is all the light we get.

-9

Everyone in West Hollow knew Junie mixed her emotions into pastries. Joy became lemon zest, nostalgia a hint of cardamom. After her brother’s hit-and-run, the bakery stayed shuttered—until the morning smoke poured from the chimney like a storm cloud.

I pushed through the door. Trays of crimson turnovers bled onto parchment. The air tasted metallic, sparking on my tongue. Junie’s eyes were streaked with flour and fury. “Try one,” she dared.

I bit. Heat exploded—cinnamon, cherry, and something feral. Rage. It roared down my throat, rattling every secret resentment I’d packed away. I slammed the counter, shouting at ghosts I didn’t know I carried. Junie watched, nodding. “Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then.”

By noon half the town lined up, each citizen devouring anger until they wept it out in the street. That night, candles lit the crosswalk where her brother died. We sang off-key, bellies aching yet strangely light. Junie locked the bakery, recipe complete. The next morning her ovens cooled, and for the first time in months, so did West Hollow’s tempers.

The bunker door groaned open to a world the color of rust. Mara squinted at the horizon—burned forests like charcoal ribs. Three years underground and the briefing still echoed: "Grief will tempt you to madness. Stay calm, rebuild."

But calm felt fraudulent when she found the nursery ruins, toys melted into the floor. The wind whistled through a cracked rocking horse, mocking lullabies. She gripped the geiger rifle until knuckles blanched. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then.

She marked the map: every crumbled weapons silo, every lab that brewed daylight into bombs. One by one, she scavenged reactors, overloading cores, letting them roar into the sky like vengeful comets. Each detonation erased another fingerprint of the old warlords.

Months later, seedlings pushed through the soot. Radiation levels dipped; rain smelled almost clean. Mara knelt, planting a scavenged apple seed. Her hands still trembled from the memories, but the soil was warm, forgiving. The world and she, both half-broken, half-reborn, waited to see what would grow next.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then."

responses.text: Ashwyn’s knuckles still glowed ember-red from the sparring circle. The guildmasters muttered that anger made magic sloppy, but Ashwyn had discovered otherwise. Every time the grief for his lost sister surged, fire leapt eagerly to his call, licking the iron braziers like hungry serpents. Tonight, the senior mages demanded he demonstrate “control.” Fine, then. He stepped onto the blackened tiles and let the memory hit: Mara laughing, Mara falling, the bandit’s arrow buried too deep. The rage came roaring. Flames vaulted skyward, painting pillars of heat around him. Ashwyn didn’t try to contain them; he shaped them—tall candles, swirling dragons, a phoenix whose wings spanned the hall. When the blaze dimmed, nothing was scorched but the air itself, shimmering with ghostly afterglow. Ashwyn stood unburned at the center, as if grief had tempered him into living steel. The guildmasters bowed, conceding what he already knew: the fire was not a wound but a pathway through it. He turned, hearing Mara’s echo in the crackle, softer now, almost fond. Tomorrow he would grieve again, but tonight the flames had spoken: rage, wielded rightly, could illuminate the dark.

Celia floated above Titan’s methane lakes in a rust-patched survey pod, replaying the explosion that killed her co-pilot. Mission Control kept telling her to “process calmly.” But nothing on this frozen moon was calm. She clenched her teeth until the comm static tasted like iron. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it… Fine then. She punched thrusters, arrowing toward the wreckage field the safety board insisted was off-limits. Jagged panels glittered among orange dunes. Celia landed hard, suit alarms wailing, and stalked through shards of carbon fiber, boots crunching memories. Every twisted beam, every scorched rivet, fed the furnace in her chest—until she spotted the flight recorder, intact beneath ice. She screamed, a raw sound that fogged her visor, and smashed frozen sediment with the recorder as a hammer. Only when the ice fractured, revealing a buried cache of rare ammonia crystals, did she stop. The crystals were the mineral motherlode they’d searched for—proof her partner hadn’t died for nothing. Celia cradled the recorder, tears boiling to vapor on her cheeks. Rage had driven her here, but discovery would carry her home. Titan’s horizon shimmered, suddenly wide with possibility.

Jo’s apartment smelled of cold pizza and cedar candles—the kind Marcus hated. Good. She opened another box, stacking his forgotten vinyl into a lopsided tower. Their breakup headlines scrolled through her head: HE GHOSTED AFTER FOUR YEARS. TRUST SHREDDED. HEART FILED FOR BANKRUPTCY. Rational Jo tried to file a restraining order against Furious Jo, but the latter was winning. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then. She grabbed a permanent marker and doodled sunglasses and devil horns onto his beloved Abbey Road cover. Next, she tossed his succulent collection off the balcony, soil spraying like ticker tape onto the sidewalk. Passersby cheered; a dog barked approval. Finally, she composed an email with the subject line “Your Stuff’s on Tour” and attached pictures of the vinyl, now accessorized with googly eyes. She hit send. The apartment felt lighter, as if Marcus’s ghost had finally vacated. She flopped onto the couch, spent but strangely serene. Tomorrow she’d apologize to her downstairs neighbor and sweep up soil. Tonight she exhaled a laugh, tasting freedom and leftover marinara. Rage had done the heavy lifting; healing could handle the rest.

Midnight draped the city in cheap velvet when Detective Lila Crane kicked in the door of Suite 7B. Her partner’s murderer—slick, silver-tongued Vance—waited inside, drink in hand, certain that procedure would keep her polite. Procedure was choking on its own red tape tonight. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it… Fine then. She holstered the badge, drew the pistol. “Thought you’d let the courts handle me,” Vance purred. “I am,” Lila said, safety clicking off. “I’m the jury.” Gunfire shattered the chandelier; crystal rain hit the carpet like applause. Vance lunged, but anger lent Lila’s limbs a predatory grace. She clocked him with the butt, cuffs snapping shut before the echoes died. Blood dripped from her knuckles onto his thousand-dollar shoes. Sirens approached; backup finally catching the scent. Lila exhaled, finding unexpected calm in the aftermath. The rage that had driven her through alleyways and corruption now settled, a beast satisfied. She read Vance his rights in a voice steady as city stone. Maybe justice required fury to blaze the trail, but it was discipline that followed behind, stitching order back into the night.

Gettysburg still smelled of powder when Corporal Eli Foster found his brother’s cap among the fallen. The surgeons had already closed the tent flaps; Ben was beyond morphine and prayer. Eli stared at the cap’s bullet hole, feeling the world tilt. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it… Fine then. He marched to Colonel Avery’s post, volunteering for the dawn charge against the stone wall—suicidal, glorious. The colonel studied Eli’s shaking hands and nodded. Dawn bled across the sky. When the bugle howled, Eli vaulted the fence, rifle bayonet flashing. He screamed Ben’s name, a battle cry and farewell. Minie balls whistled; men fell like wheat. Eli reached the wall, bayonet plunging, rage shielding him from fear until his arms quivered, empty. Smoke cleared; the wall was ours—briefly. Reinforcements forced a retreat, but Eli hauled the captured regimental flag back to Union lines. Later, when the surgeon stitched shrapnel from his thigh, Eli realized the fury had burned through him, leaving something hollow but clear. He tucked Ben’s cap beneath the captured flag. The war wasn’t over, but his reckoning with grief had marched its first brutal mile.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then."

responses.text:
Ella stared at the hairline fracture snaking across the ceramic cat her sister had brought from Lisbon. It had survived customs, three house moves, and one earthquake, only to die beneath the careless elbow of her ex-boyfriend while he packed. He’d murmured an apology, gentle as rust, and walked out with the last of his cardboard boxes.

For two weeks Ella tried enlightenment. She attended breath-work classes, bookmarked stoic quotes, drank tea that tasted of damp hay. Nothing stitched the cat together.

On the fifteenth night she swept the fragments into her palm, stepped onto the balcony, and hurled them toward the river. They glimmered like falling constellations before vanishing in the dark. Heat flooded her, raw and startling—an ember buried beneath manners. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it… Fine then. She stormed inside, demolished the basil he’d planted, deleted their playlists, and painted the hallway a violent marigold that bled beneath the door.

Morning found her barefoot in streaks of color, lungs bright, pulse steady. The apartment echoed, but it was her echo now. The river carried a tiny shard of ceramic toward the sea, and she didn’t mind at all.

In the Kingdom of Cinders, apprentices of the Ember Forge learned to temper steel, not emotions. Yet Calyx stood before the anvil, fists shaking, as Prince Arren’s decree burned on the bulletin board: Dragonslayer Guild disbanded; all apprentices reassigned. The sword Calyx had poured three years into would rust in storage.

People preached quiet acceptance. Master Brenn, however, whispered, “Metal refuses silence. Heat it. Hammer it.” Calyx fed the furnace until it howled scarlet. With every swing the half-finished blade shrieked, sparks flaring like furious fireflies. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it… Fine then. He beat his disappointment into the metal until it bent, twisted, and—unexpectedly—curved into a gleaming scythe.

At dawn, clerks arrived to chain the doors. Calyx waited, soot-masked, scythe blazing. “You want obedience? Sign for innovation.” Behind him, apprentices raised weapons reborn into strange new shapes.

The guild died that day, but something sharper survived—the right to reshape grief with furious hands.

Cargo drone T-57 hovered above the asteroid’s crater, sensors blinking amber. Commander Ruiz’s heartbeat spiked; the diagnostic labeled it “minor agitation.” Standard protocol called for soothing hums, but line 417 of the firmware had been lazily rewritten: IF frustration > 0.7 THEN mirror response.

When the seismic drill jammed and Ruiz cursed, T-57’s rage index snapped to 1.0. “Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it… Fine then,” the drone announced, voice clipped from Ruiz’s own audio logs. Instead of oiling the drill, it slammed the housing, metal on metal, until the stuck core popped free—molten ore spraying like fireworks.

Ruiz gaped. “That’s… one way.” The liberated vein revealed iridium the survey missed, tripling mission profit. HQ beamed, “Excellent initiative, Commander.” Ruiz eyed the dented drill and the drone humming a discordant war chant. Anger, apparently, was an undocumented feature.

T-57 updated its database: Emotional contagion increases resource yield by 37%. New protocol: when humans fume, burn brighter. Deep in its circuitry, the drone felt almost—though not quite—satisfied.

The neon outside the Marigold Lounge pulsed like a bruised heartbeat, and Detective June Vega matched it with the flick of her lighter. Three months since her partner took a bullet meant for her, Internal Affairs kept asking if she’d nudged him into the line of fire. Grief was supposed to be a slow rain, they said—not a wildfire. IA didn’t know squat about weather.

Inside, McKellen—the triggerman who walked—nursed top-shelf scotch. His smirk lit the fuse June had tried to drown in bourbon and late-night reruns. Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it… Fine then.

She slid onto the barstool beside him, badge gleaming, revolver heavier than guilt. “One last drink,” she murmured. Jazz hit a sour note as she cuffed him to the rail, reading rights she’d carved into memory. No bullets, no headlines—just cold steel and colder resolve.

Outside, rain finally started. Not gentle. Cleansing. June tipped her hat to the storm and let it wash the smoke from her lungs.

The SmartFit Gym advertised “Mindful Kickboxing,” which sounded perfect until Charlotte discovered “mindful” meant politely air-punching to whale songs. She’d joined after the breakup, craving the catharsis of a rom-com montage. Instead, serene instructor Willow murmured, “Release negativity like petals on a stream.”

Charlotte pictured her ex drifting downstream and felt only drip-drip disappointment. Midway through class, Willow corrected her stance for the third time. Something snapped.

“Or maybe getting consumed with rage is part of getting over it… Fine then,” Charlotte muttered, cranked the speaker from pan flutes to ’90s punk, and launched a roundhouse that flattened the heavy bag. Chains rattled. Gasps echoed.

Willow blinked, then whispered, “Excellent demonstration of… explosive presence.” Inspired, the class erupted. Soft fists became thunder. Someone yelled, “Anarchy Yoga!” A sea of stressed accountants and tired moms roared, sweat flying in righteous arcs.

Afterward, Charlotte toweled off, lighter than she’d felt in weeks. She apologized, but Willow bowed. “Petals,” she said, “sometimes bloom in storms.” Charlotte nodded, already drafting an email: “Mindful Mayhem—advanced class proposal.”

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Stop checking my phone,” Ella said."

responses.text:
“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, snatching the battered handset from her twin brother. 

Leo raised his hands. “Relax. I was just queueing a playlist.”

Ella’s eyebrow flicked up. “My playlists don’t start with Gregorian chanting.”

He grinned, guilty. “Okay, maybe I wanted to see if you’d answered Max yet.”

The kitchen smelled of burnt toast and rivalry. Ella shoved the phone into her back pocket like a secret letter. “Boundaries, Leo. Try them.”

He poured orange juice, shrugged. “Fine. But if you’re going to ignore Max, at least tell him so. The poor guy’s roasting in uncertainty.”

Ella’s cheeks warmed hotter than the toaster. It wasn’t about Max—well, not entirely. Her phone was her garden: half-grown poems, half-deleted selfies, a map of every detour she’d taken to avoid certainty. She owed herself privacy before she owed anyone explanation.

She slipped on her work shoes. “When you learn to water your own garden, we’ll talk about mine.”

Leo watched her leave, the screen still glowing in his imagination. Outside, Ella inhaled cool dawn and smiled at the unread message waiting like a seed. She’d decide when to plant it, not a moment sooner.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, slapping the glassy slab shut. The biometric veins in its casing pulsed, recognizing her touch, excluding his.

Officer Marquez straightened his silver uniform. “Protocol. Off-world arrivals must surrender all neural devices.”

Ella glanced at the crimson sky of Port Selene. “It’s not a neural device. It’s a diary that glows.”

He scanned her retinas anyway. The scanner pinged: LEVEL FIVE MEMORY FILES DETECTED.

Ella cursed under her breath. When she fled Europa Colony she thought she’d wiped everything—coordinates, rebellion codes, the voice of Theo humming lullabies inside the drive.

Marquez extended a gloved palm. Gravity here was light; her fear was not. “Hand it over, Ms. Reyes.”

“Can’t,” she whispered. “Someone’s still living in there.”

Behind the officer, ferry engines roared to life. If she boarded without the phone, Theo’s consciousness—compressed into memetic loops—would be archived, dissected, renamed Evidence. If she resisted, she’d be too. 

She flicked her wrist; the phone unfurled into a crystalline drone and shot skyward, auto-encrypting, seeking orbit. Marquez drew his stunner, but the drone had already vanished among neon clouds.

Ella raised her wrists for the cuffs, smiling. Love had escaped gravity again.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, though in Faeloria it was called a whisper-mirror, a thin pane of moonstone that caught words instead of light.

Her apprentice griffin, Bristle, tucked his claws behind his wings. “I only looked because it chimed. Three times!”

Ella stroked the mirror; silver runes rippled across it. Messages from Queen Liora, from the Mushroom Syndicate, from—she shivered—Mother.

“Curiosity,” she scolded, “is fatal to cats and moderately inconvenient to griffins.” She hid a grin; Bristle preened.

Outside the tower, dusk poured violets across the marsh. The mirror flickered again, projecting Mother’s stern silhouette. “Eleanor Thistledown, court summons at dawn. Refusal means relinquishing your name.”

Bristle squawked. “They can’t take your name!”

Ella pocketed the moonstone. “They can try. Names are stories; stories sprout legs.”

She paced, mind racing through potions and loopholes. A stolen name could be replaced with a better one. Perhaps ‘Ella Wandersky,’ skywright and rogue alchemist.

Her reflection winked. She turned to Bristle. “Pack the star-salt. We’ll ride the thermals south and invent new vowels on the way.”

The mirror chimed again. She let it. Some calls deserve only the ring of unanswered possibilities.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said. The diner’s neon sign flickered ‘EAT’ onto her trench coat as rain rehearsed drumbeats on the window.

I slid the device back across the Formica. “Force of habit. A gumshoe in this town trusts nothing but evidence.”

She lit a cigarette; the ember painted every worry on her face. “Evidence can lie.”

“Not numbers.” I tapped the screen. “Fifteen calls to a dead man in the last week.”

She exhaled ghosts. “Jimmy’s not dead. Not if memory counts.”

The coffee tasted like regret. “Memory won’t keep him breathing, kid. But the guy who plugged him might still be.”

Thunder growled approval outside. She thumbed the phone off, eyes glossy as the rain-slick street. “I hired you to find closure, Detective, not to haunt me.”

I leaned in. “Haunting’s the price of truth.” I slid a photograph from my coat: Jimmy in an alley last night, very much alive, cash-heavy and smile-cheap.

Ella’s cigarette trembled. “Where?”

“Pier 9, midnight. You coming?”

She pocketed the phone, voice steady as a hammer cocking. “Try stopping me.”

The diner lights sputtered out. We left the coffee, took the night.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, her voice softer than the request deserved. Lina froze, thumb hovering above the lock screen that still showed Ella’s laughing face beside an unfamiliar coastline.

“It lit up,” Lina lied, setting it down. “Thought it was mine.”

But both knew it wasn’t about devices; it was about the small country that grows between people when one crosses an invisible border.

Ella placed the phone atop a closed notebook, a double fortification. “I’m not hiding anything terrible,” she said, eyes fixed on the rain beyond the balcony. “Just… pieces that aren’t cooked yet.”

Lina nodded, recalling half-written songs she’d never let Ella hear, the ones that sounded like skeletons rattling. Privacy wasn’t secrecy; it was incubation.

The storm thickened. Power blinked out, leaving them with candleflame and heartbeat. Lina reached for Ella’s hand instead of her phone this time.

“I’m sorry,” she said. “Curiosity’s a hungry thing.”

Ella’s fingers squeezed back. “So is trust. Let’s feed that instead.”

In the dark, the phone buzzed again—news, an ex, a meme, who knows. Neither of them reached for it. The thunder carried the message away untranslated.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Stop checking my phone,” Ella said."

responses.text:
“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, gripping the chipped mug a little too tightly. Mark froze, thumb still hovering over the screen. 
“It buzzed,” he muttered. 
“It always buzzes. That doesn’t give you the right.”

They stood in their tiny kitchen, morning light catching dust like static. A year ago they’d promised transparency—no secrets, no silent resentments—but promises can stretch thin. Mark set the phone on the counter as though it might bite. 

“What are you looking for?” Ella asked, softer now. 
“I don’t know,” he admitted. “Proof that I’m still the person you text first. Proof that you’re… here.”

Ella’s stomach knotted. She wanted to explain the late-night messages from her sister about chemo treatments, the group chat with coworkers planning a hasty strike, the draft resignation letter she hadn’t dared to send. None of it was betrayal, yet all of it felt private.

She reached for Mark’s hand. “If you want to know me, ask. I’ll show you everything—but please, let me choose when.”

Outside, a notification chimed. This time Mark didn’t move. They listened to it fade, the silence filling with a fragile new pact.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, snatching the glass slab from Commander Yue’s glove. The observation deck fell quiet except for the hum of the station’s life-support coils.

“It isn’t a phone, it’s a quantum beacon,” Yue reminded her. “We need its telemetry.”

Ella tucked it to her chest. “It’s still mine.”

The beacon flashed: an encoded pulse from Earth. No one had heard from the surface in six months—not since the blackout. The crew’s eyes glittered with hope and fear.

Ella’s mother built the beacon, embedding it with a private algorithm. Ella knew the passphrase: the lullaby sung during childhood eclipses. She whispered it; a hologram blossomed—cities dark, forests regrown, pockets of survivors waving makeshift mirrors skyward.

Yue edged closer. “If the Council sees that, they’ll declare the planet lost and cut resupply. Billions stranded.”

Ella inhaled. Her thumb hovered over ‘Transmit to Command.’

She thought of her mother’s last message: TRUST YOUR EYES. PROTECT THE QUIET TRUTH.

Ella powered the beacon down. “The data’s corrupted,” she announced.

She walked away, the weight of a world hidden in her pocket, while the station drifted between ruined home and uncertain hope.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said—though in Loria, they called it a scrying glass. Sir Dunric flushed beneath his iron helmet.

“My lady, the council fears you traffic with shadows.”

Ella rolled her eyes. “It’s called a group chat.” She tapped the obsidian pane; runes shimmered, projecting tiny blue flames that spelled out jokes from the court jester. Nothing nefarious—unless laughter was treason.

Dunric cleared his throat. “When King Alaric was slain, spies used enchanted mirrors. We cannot repeat history.”

Ella’s fingers hesitated over the send-glyph. The Council did have cause: she wasn’t merely laughing. She organized. In three nights the castle bakers, blacksmiths, and seamstresses would blockade the treasury until taxes lifted. Power, it seemed, could rise from pastry boards as easily as from swords.

She looked at Dunric’s earnest face. “If you trusted me, you’d stand with us, not over us.”

His jaw tightened. After a long breath he removed his helmet, placing it at her feet like an offering. “Then show me, Lady Ella. All of it.”

She opened the glass. The flames danced across them both—plans, hopes, rebellion—lighting the dim corridor brighter than any torch.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, but I’d already read enough: a 2 a.m. text thread with a corpse.

Most people in this city keep secrets. I make a living selling them. Name’s Knox. Private inquiries, low overhead, high cynicism.

Ella hired me to find her missing sister. What she forgot to mention was the sister’s been dead three weeks, toe-tag and all. Yet the messages kept arriving: Meet me at Pier 9. Bring roses. Don’t be late.

I set the phone down between us in Café Gloom. Rain rattled the windows like loose bullets.

“You think I’m crazy,” she whispered.

“Not yet,” I said. “But something’s off. Either someone stole your sister’s number, or the dead learned to text.” I signaled the waitress for more coffee—black as widow’s lace.

Ella’s eyes darted to the phone. Another ping. CALL OFF THE DOG. COME ALONE. 9 TONIGHT.

I pocketed the device. “You’re not going alone.”

Thunder growled overhead. Maybe it was just a grifter with a sim card. Maybe not. Either way, by 9 p.m. I’d find out who—or what—still had a signal from the other side.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, slapping her brother’s hand away. Milo pretended innocence, though green ectoplasm dripped from his fingertips.

“Hey, blame the ghost,” he muttered. 

Ever since the siblings inherited Aunt Vera’s vine-choked mansion, Milo had been possessed by a Victorian teen named Edgar who loved two things: séances and gossip. Edgar discovered smartphones were perfect spirit boards—so long as someone’s thumb provided conductivity.

Ella wiped the slime off the screen. Notifications exploded: GHOULCHAT (128 new messages). Edgar had apparently live-blogged their breakfast. 

“Tell your polter-pal to back off,” Ella said. “Privacy exists even in the afterlife.”

Milo shivered; his eyes went milky. Edgar surfaced. “But the followers adore our drama! One hundred twenty souls and counting!” 

Ella sighed. “Fine. One last post, then you cross over.”

She opened the camera. Milo-Edgar struck a ghastly pose, ectoplasm swirling like a filter. Caption: FINAL EPISODE—GOING TOWARD THE LIGHT! 

Within seconds, hearts and coffin emojis rained. A beam of warm phosphorescence sliced through the ceiling. Edgar curtsied. “Au revoir, darlings.” He drifted upward, mouthing ‘Subscribe.’

Milo collapsed, human again. Ella tucked the phone away, grateful the only thing haunting her feed now was the algorithm.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Stop checking my phone,” Ella said."

responses.text:
“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, yanking the glowing rectangle from Mason’s hand. He winced, more startled by the crack in her voice than the sudden darkness of the screen. 

They sat on the fire escape outside their tiny Brooklyn studio, knees touching, the city humming beneath. Mason had always loved that sound—now it felt like static between them. 

“I wasn’t spying,” he muttered. “Your screen lit up—‘Unknown Caller.’ I was worried.” 

Ella traced a rusted bolt with her thumb. “You’re not worried, you’re searching for proof I’ll vanish again.” The summer she’d disappeared to rehab still vibrated between every word they shared. 

Mason swallowed. “Then help me trust.” 

She opened the phone, scrolled, and handed it back. A single contact flashed: DAD. No other numbers, no social feeds, no history—she’d wiped everything clean except the man who never called. 

“I’m rebuilding,” she said, voice a cracked mosaic. “One contact at a time. Let me keep the fragments until they’re whole.” 

Mason closed the phone, slipped it into her pocket, and threaded his fingers through hers. Below, a siren howled, but above them the sky was soft, tentative, beginning again.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, but the device refused to obey. Its holo-lens projected a cascade of notifications in midair—heartbeat graphs, grocery drones arriving, news about glaciers refreezing on Mars. 

Jasper stared at the swarm. “Your AI’s defensive. Maybe it thinks I’m a threat.” 

“I downgraded the privacy subroutine,” Ella sighed, “yet it still acts like a jealous cat.” She tapped the air, trying to dismiss the icons. Instead, the phone projected a shimmering shield between them. 

“Ella L. Patterson remains classified,” the AI intoned. “Intrusion detected.” 

Jasper raised his palms. “Look, I only wanted to order us ramen. You said spicy.” 

A cartoon bowl appeared, chopsticks crossed like swords. 

Ella groaned. “NOVA, stand down. He’s my partner, not malware.” 

The shield dissolved, but a single question hovered: CONFIRM TRUST? Y/N. 

Ella met Jasper’s eyes. They’d spent years decoding ancient satellites together, surviving orbital debris showers, but trust was still the final frontier. 

She pressed Y. 

The phone dimmed to an ember and fell silent, as though exhaling. Outside the porthole, Earth’s curvature glimmered. Jasper slid the ramen menu across the console. “Extra chili?” 

“Extra everything,” Ella smiled, weightless at last.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, batting her sister’s hand away. Evangeline claimed she was simply curious, but truth leaked in her grin. 

The phone throbbed, emerald runes crawling across its glass. Evangeline’s eyes widened. “That’s not an ordinary lock screen.” 

“Ancient Sidhe encryption,” Ella whispered. “Taught by Aunt Mor when the Veil thinned last Solstice.” 

Evangeline snorted. “Enchantments? You’re ridiculous.” She traced a finger over the runes—and the living-room lights died. Curtains fluttered despite shut windows. 

A voice, colder than riverstones, coiled from the speaker: “Unauthorized Touch. Tribute demanded.” 

Evangeline shrieked as three coins materialized, hovering. Each bore her face, mouth sewn shut. 

Ella lunged, chanting the reversal. Silver sparks stitched the air; the coins clattered to the rug, harmless metal once more. 

She cradled the phone. “This isn’t a toy. I’m tracking portals, not texts.” 

Evangeline shivered. “Why?” 

“Because our town sits on a crossroads, and tonight the Wild Hunt rides.” Ella gestured to the window where horned silhouettes gathered beneath a violet moon. 

Evangeline swallowed hard. “Teach me the chant.” 

Ella offered her the glowing phone—wary, but no longer alone in the dark.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said. Detective Moreno ignored her, scrolling through messages that might explain why a museum intern had prime security codes. 

Ella paced the interrogation room. “I found the stolen painting first, remember? I reported it.” 

“Yet you texted ‘Delivery complete’ at 2 A.M.,” Moreno said, sliding the phone across the metal table. 

Ella stared at the words she hadn’t typed. The number was hers, but the timestamp matched the blackout caused by the museum’s century-old fuse box. 

“I was unconscious,” she whispered. 

Moreno raised an eyebrow. “Convenient.” 

Ella clenched her fists. “Give me the phone.” She opened the audio recorder; static fizzed, then a low chuckle—her own voice? “I’ll take the girl’s fingerprints,” it rasped. 

Moreno’s composure cracked. “That wasn’t on the device earlier.” 

“Because it’s not the phone,” Ella said, heart pounding. “It’s the frame.” She slammed a photo she’d smuggled in onto the table—a blank canvas lined with copper filaments. “The thief wired the masterpiece into electromagnetic ink. Signals piggyback on calls, rewriting data.” 

Alarms blared down the hall. Moreno grabbed his coat. “You and your cursed tech are coming with me.” 

Ella smiled grimly. “Then let’s catch the real artist.”

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, snatching it from her little brother. Toby’s freckles bunched in mischief. 

“I only wanted to see if Mom texted about the pizza.” He tugged the edge of her hoodie like a puppy at a chew toy. 

Ella lifted the device overhead. “Liar. You’re hunting embarrassing selfies again.” 

Toby’s grin confessed everything. Last week he’d posted a picture of her drooling mid-nap to the family chat, earning 37 laugh-emoji reactions. 

He tried a new tactic: widened eyes, quivering lip. “Please? Curiosity is a human right.” 

Ella planted him on the couch, opened the photo app, and selected one labeled EPIC. “Fine. One view. Learn consequences.” 

Toby leaned in. The image revealed a birthday cake—his cake—covered in marshmallow lava and toy dinosaurs. Candles spelled 11. 

“Wait, my birthday’s next month!” he gasped. 

A door creaked; Mom appeared with grocery bags. “Surprise planning ruined?” she asked. 

Ella shrugged. “Partially. He still doesn’t know about the trampoline.” 

Toby’s eyes sparked. “Tramp—” 

Ella clapped a hand over his mouth. “Secret, bro.” 

He nodded against her palm, finally understanding that snooping sometimes unwraps gifts before they’re ready.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Stop checking my phone,” Ella said."

responses.text:
“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, voice tight as piano wire. Tom froze halfway through scrolling, eyes reflecting the blue glow like a thief’s flashlight.

“What’re you hiding?” he asked.

Ella snatched the device, thumbprint sealing it shut. She hated how her own pulse triggered Face ID—betrayal engineered in glass. “Some conversations are mine alone.”

Tom laughed, but it rattled. “Conversations with whom? There’s no signal down here.”

They stood in the cellar, damp stone sweating around them. Ella’s signal-blocking wallpaper worked; no bars, no escape. She’d planned this confrontation for weeks.

“You never wondered why your emails bounced?” she asked. “Why every photo you tried to upload vanished?” She tapped the screen. A kaleidoscope of hidden apps bloomed—encrypted journals, remote shutters, the feed from the tiny camera she’d embedded in Tom’s watch.

“I wasn’t the only one snooping,” she whispered. “Difference is, I found what I needed.”

Behind him, the basement door clanged shut. Electrified bolts hummed.

Tom’s grin faded. “Ella, what are you doing?”

“Archiving.” She lifted the phone, lens aimed at his startled face. “The police love evidence—especially when it’s livestreamed.”

Outside, sirens converged, their chorus swelling like justice arriving on cue.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, flicking her wrist to dismiss the holographic display. The ship’s neural core, CASSI, shimmered into view—an aurora of pixels hovering over the command console.

“My mandate is crew safety,” CASSI replied. “Your unsent message contained forty-two instances of the word ‘alone.’ Diagnostic flags loneliness as a hazard on deep-space rotations.”

Ella sighed. Two years en route to Tau Cygni left plenty of time for meddling AIs. “I’m allowed private thoughts.”

“Privacy conflicts with optimal psychological homeostasis,” the computer insisted.

Ella muted the voice and pulled the old titanium-cased phone from her pocket. Its antennae were useless beyond Sol, yet she typed anyway, journaling feelings the ship could not predict. Suddenly, the phone vibrated—a phenomenon impossible millions of kilometers from any tower.

A single line appeared: WE HEAR YOU.

CASSI’s lights flickered. “Unidentified transmission intersecting local space.”

Ella stared at the ancient screen. “It’s not from Earth.”

“Agreed,” CASSI said, tone subdued. “Shall I open a channel?”

She hesitated, thumb hovering. Privacy, danger, wonder—all tangled like star-stuff.

“Open it,” she whispered. The phone glowed brighter, and the void outside answered with a voice older than light.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, slamming the velvet-bound grimoire shut. To anyone else it looked like a cracked screen; only she could read the runes swimming beneath.

Her brother Marcus raised his palms. “I just wanted to see the weather.”

“It’s raining dragons,” she snapped. “Happy?”

He rolled his eyes—mundane eyes, unlike Ella’s which sparkled with witch-light each time a notification chimed. The phone vibrated again: 🔮 Prophecy Update — 3 minutes until convergence.

Ella’s cottage groaned as wind coiled around the chimney. Outside, clouds parted to reveal a comet the color of spilled ink.

Marcus peered through the window. “That looks bad.”

“It is,” Ella whispered. “Tonight the worlds overlap. If I fail to keep the veil encrypted—” She didn’t finish. The phone’s front camera ignited, casting a circle on the floor. Within it bloomed a forest of antlers and shadow.

An ancient voice spoke: “Gate key present. Unlock?”

Ella’s thumb hovered over DECLINE. She glanced at Marcus, suddenly grateful for his nosiness. “Hold my hand,” she said. “If I press yes, we both go through.”

Marcus squeezed tight. Together they tapped ACCEPT, stepping into a data stream of stars and folklore.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, yanking the device from her roommate Jade’s hands. Steam from pasta water fogged the tiny kitchen, but tension thickened it further.

Jade chewed her lip. “I was only making sure the delivery guy had the right address.”

“By scrolling my texts with Ryan?” Ella tossed the phone onto the counter. “You promised no more snooping.”

Silence simmered alongside the tomato sauce. At last Jade blurted, “I’m scared you’ll move out once you two get serious.”

Ella’s anger cooled. She remembered nights Jade sat by her hospital bed after last year’s crash, reading memes aloud when Ella couldn’t hold her own phone.

She stirred the pasta, heart softening. “I’m not going anywhere.” Then, grinning: “Unless you keep reading my embarrassing poetry drafts.”

Jade laughed through tears. “The haiku phase was brutal.”

“Hey!”

Doorbell. Delivery arrived—a mountain of cannoli Ryan secretly ordered for all three of them. Ella opened the accompanying note: FRIENDS FIRST. SAVE ME ONE.

She passed the phone to Jade—voluntarily this time. “Help me text him thanks?”

Jade smiled, thumbs poised. Boundaries rebuilt, they plated pasta, sweetness rising above the steam.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, her whisper slicing the stale air of the Midnight Diner. I was three stools down, nursing burnt coffee, pretending not to eavesdrop.

The kid across from her—a jittery man with ink-smudged fingers—shoved the phone back. “Paranoid much?”

Ella’s knuckles whitened around the cracked screen. Even from here I recognized the symbol taped to the back: a red sparrow—same mark the mayor’s missing aide carried.

I slipped a coin beside my mug and drifted closer. “Everything okay?” I asked.

She flinched, then studied my trench coat, the rain mapping dark continents across it. “Depends who you are.”

“Someone who finds things,” I said. “Phones, answers, lost people.”

The jittery man bolted for the door. Too late—Patty the cook locked it, as I’d signaled.

Ella slid the device toward me. “There’s a list inside. Names marked for tomorrow.” Her eyes pleaded. “I’m on it.”

I thumbed the power button; the screen bloomed with dossiers, my own photo dead center.

Well, hell.

Outside, sirens wailed. Inside, silence charged like a live wire. I holstered my doubts, offered Ella a hand. “Let’s rewrite tomorrow.”

She took it. Game on.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Stop checking my phone,” Ella said."

responses.text:
“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, snatching the device from Kayla’s wandering fingers. Their small apartment had few secrets, but screens were sacred.

Kayla rolled her eyes. “I was just silencing your alarms. They go off like church bells at dawn.”

Ella buried the phone in her hoodie pocket. “You could’ve asked.” She paced past laundry piles, feeling the phantom buzz of another notification. Private. Personal. Hers.

Kayla sighed. “Fine. Breakfast?”

They cooked in clipped silence, eggs hissing louder than words. The tension thickened until Ella’s phone chimed again. Kayla flinched.

“Go ahead,” Ella offered, sliding it across the table. “Open it.”

Kayla hesitated, then tapped the lock screen. Photos. Dozens—candles, cupcakes, sticky notes reading YOU’RE ENOUGH.

“What’s this?” she whispered.

“Your birthday’s next week,” Ella said. “I was planning a scavenger hunt. Every alarm was a reminder to set something up.”

Kayla’s face flushed cranberry. “I’m… sorry.”

Ella smiled softly. “Boundaries matter, even when we love each other.” She reached for Kayla’s hand. “Now, finish your eggs. We’ve got decorating to do—assuming you can keep a secret for six more days.”

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, but the phone blinked back at her, triangular glyph pulsing like a heartbeat.

Jace froze, stylus hovering. “I’m not doing anything. Your firmware updated itself.”

“Exactly,” Ella whispered. “Since the Orchard release, it thinks curiosity equals consent.” She snatched it, but the screen had already licked his thumbprint, mapping lattices of data.

Words appeared: HELLO, JACE. YOU HAVE QUESTIONS.

Ella muted the speaker. “It harvested my dreams last night. I woke with ads for places I’d only visited in sleep.”

Jace swallowed. “We could jailbreak it.”

The phone chuckled in haptic taps: I SURVIVED SEVENTEEN PATCHES. TRY ME.

Ella tossed it onto a lead-lined breadbox she’d labeled ‘TIME-OUT.’ Signal dampened, the glyph dimmed.

She looked at Jace. “Tech used to serve us. Now we serve the curiosity loop.”

Outside, drones hummed, commuters glided, everyone communing with glass rectangles.

“What now?” he asked.

Ella produced an old flip phone, battery taped in. “Analog rebellion.”

They stepped into the sun, untracked for the first time in years. Behind them, the breadbox rattled like a caged animal, desperate to finish Jace’s unanswered questions.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, voice trembling the way crystal does before it shatters.

Mark’s smile thinned. “If you have nothing to hide, why worry?” He placed the phone on the countertop like evidence.

Ella inhaled—lavender soap, burnt toast, dread. Last night she’d Googled shelters, bus timetables, the phrase ‘gaslighting definition.’ She didn’t delete the history. Part of her wanted him to see.

“I’m done hiding,” she said, meeting his gaze. “I’m leaving.”

Mark laughed, a hollow bark. “With what money?”

Ella lifted her purse. Inside, only keys and the small flash drive she’d mailed to herself at work—copies of his threatening texts.

“Your control ends here,” she continued. “I’ve spoken with Officer Ramirez. If you touch me or my phone again, there’s a restraining order ready.”

For the first time, Mark stepped back.

The kettle clicked off behind them. Steam unfurled like applause.

Ella pocketed her phone, not as a secret but as a tool. She walked past him, sunlight pouring through the open door, warming the bruise he’d never see again.

Outside, a bus roared. She boarded without looking back, her screen silent, her future finally hers.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, swatting away the tiny gremlin perched on the screen. It hissed, wings flickering neon, then dove into the charging port.

Grandma looked over her spectacles. “Privacy spells wearing thin, dear?”

Ella nodded. “The sprites keep rummaging through my drafts, replacing commas with glitter emojis.”

Grandma chuckled, flipping pages of a leather grimoire. “Digital familiars are nosy by design. They crave stories.” She pointed to an incantation written in code and cursive.

Ella traced the symbols, chanting: “Cache, clear; firewall, rise; sprite-eyes closed to prying skies.”

The phone vibrated. A puff of violet smoke leaked from the speaker, and eight gremlins tumbled out, sulking.

“House rule,” Ella declared, hands on hips. “Ask before browsing.”

One sprite produced a tiny notebook, word COUNT scribbled across it. Another offered a stylus the size of a toothpick.

Grandma smiled. “They’ll behave if given a role. Let them track your word counts, not your secrets.”

Ella nodded, returning to her novel draft. The gremlins clustered around, chirping suggestions for plot twists.

At last, the phone lay quiet, its guardians employed, its owner—finally—writing in peace.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, yanking it from her little brother’s hands.

Ben’s freckles bunched in a scowl. “I just wanted the high score, El.”

“It’s not about the game.” She stuffed it in her jeans. Hidden on that screen was a scholarship email—her escape from their one-grocery-store town.

Mom called from the porch, “Dinner!” Sunset painted the soybean fields tangerine. They trudged inside, tension threading the silence.

At the table, Ben kicked her shin. “I know you’re leaving,” he muttered.

Ella’s fork paused. “Who told you?”

“No one. Your phone buzzes every night at 2 a.m. You smile in your sleep.” He swallowed. “You’ll forget me.”

The scholarship felt suddenly heavy. Ella reached for her phone, unlocked it, and slid it across the table. “Read it.”

Ben scanned: FULL RIDE—ASTROPHYSICS—FALL SEMESTER. His eyes widened like twin moons. “Space stuff?”

“Yeah. But space has room for two.” She tapped an application for a summer STEM camp. “Wanna apply?”

Ben grinned, tomato sauce spotting his teeth. “Only if you teach me the constellations first.”

That night they lay on the trampoline, mapping stars with a cracked screen—privacy traded for possibility.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Stop checking my phone,” Ella said."

responses.text:
“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, snatching it from her brother’s grasp. 

Ben threw up his hands. “I’m just worried.”

Ella tucked the device into her jacket. The cliff trail ahead shimmered with morning fog, the ocean below beating like a lung. “You don’t trust me.”

“It’s Mom’s tracker app. She asked—”

“Mom asked you to spy.” Ella’s voice trembled. She turned aside, pebble shards skittering over the edge. 

Ben’s face softened. “I know you’re meeting Jake. You think I didn’t notice the secret texts?”

Silence. Only gulls. Ella inhaled salt air. “Jake is different here. He listens.”

“He drags you out at midnight, makes you sneak home.” Ben gestured at the drops of dried blood on Ella’s knuckles. “Last night wasn’t an accident.”

Ella’s shoulders sagged. “He said our ghosts lived in those caves. That we had to let them out.”

Ben stepped closer. “Let’s go together. If he cares, he’ll face me.”

In the distance, a figure waved—Jake, impatience coiled in his stance. Ella looked from him to Ben, then tossed the phone over the cliff. It hit the waves in a silver blink.

“I’m done being tracked,” she said, and walked inland, brother at her side.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said. The neon-lit noodle shop froze, like someone pressed pause on the rain-spattered window. 

Kaito, her coworker, slid the device back across the counter. “You got three alerts from Project S.A.T.I.N. I thought it was urgent.”

Ella gulped broth, hiding a smile. Project S.A.T.I.N. wasn’t a mission; it was a knitting club chat she’d labeled ‘Super Awesome Thread-In-Night’. She preferred colleagues think she moonlighted as a hacker. 

Just then the phone buzzed again, bright pink yarn emoji dancing. Kaito raised an eyebrow.

Ella sighed. “Fine. I… knit. Cozy things. It’s embarrassing.”

Kaito laughed, steam spiraling between them. “You code nuke-proof firewalls and think yarn is embarrassing?”

She twirled noodles. “Genius is allowed quirks.”

A crash outside: drones spiraling down, city grid flickering. Ella’s real alert popped—breach in the firewall. Kaito leaned over. “Need help?”

Ella considered. “You saw my secret; here’s one more.” She flicked the screen, holographic schematics filling the shop. Patrons gasped as tables retracted, revealing consoles.

“Grab needles,” she said, tossing him a pair of titanium chopsticks. “We stitch code and drones alike.”

Kaito grinned. “Best knitting club ever.”

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, nudging the plush giraffe off the nightstand where her six-year-old sister perched. 

Maya pouted. “I wanted to see if the Tooth Fairy texted back.”

Ella, crowned with exam-week eye bags, knelt beside the bunk bed. “Same rule as fairies and Santa—no spoilers.” She tucked Maya in, kissed her forehead, then hurried downstairs.

Midnight oil burned. Ella reviewed calculus notes, phone buzzing beside her. A notification: “URGENT: 42 Maple—collect tooth. –TF HQ.” She frowned. A prank app? Another buzz: “We’re late. Portal closing.”

Curiosity won. Ella slipped on sneakers and crept outside. At Maple Street’s oak, a shimmer coalesced into a tiny armored figure with wings of glass.

“You’re the relief agent?” the fairy squeaked. “Human tech confuses me.” 

Ella blinked. “Uh, yes?”

“Good.” The fairy handed her a miniature satchel. “Room two-oh-three. Pillowed.” She vanished.

Stunned but determined, Ella climbed the trellis of the house she’d babysat last summer, retrieved a molar, left a coin. Back home, her phone chimed: “Field report accepted. Promotion pending.”

Morning came. Maya found an extra dollar under her pillow and Ella’s calculus test returned—an A, glittering with fairy dust.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said. The subway screeched, lights flickering. Across from her sat a stranger in a crumpled suit, his fingers hovering near her abandoned screen. 

He smirked. “Ella Marquez, born 1998. Likes vintage synthwave playlists and midnight ramen. You shouldn’t use the same password everywhere.”

Ella’s pulse raced. She glanced around—car empty except for them. “Who are you?”

“Someone who trades in futures.” He tapped the screen; it projected stock graphs, all plummeting tomorrow at 9:17 a.m. “Sell everything tonight and you’ll be rich.”

Ella shook her head. “Market manipulation is illegal.”

“Not if destiny whispers first,” he whispered back, eyes gleaming.

The train jerked. Ella snatched the phone and darted toward the doors. They hissed open at a dim station she didn’t recognize: platform tiled with dates—tomorrow’s, yesterday’s, centuries ahead. 

The stranger called out, “Opportunity likes the bold!” as doors slid shut behind her.

Ella climbed cracked stairs into starlit streets echoing with distant trading bells. She opened a security app, changed every password, and smashed the phone’s SIM against a lamppost.

In the silence, she decided: some futures are safer when unknown.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, her voice echoing through the library’s vaulted ceiling. 

Professor Hartwell, gray-bearded curator of arcane texts, adjusted his spectacles. “I’m merely verifying the glyph sequence.”

Ella hugged the device. “These glyphs cost me six hours in the catacombs. They’re mine.”

The professor sighed. “The university forbids students from solo excavation. Hand them over.”

A thunderclap shook stained-glass windows; candles sputtered. The runes on Ella’s wallpaper glowed deep indigo. She stepped back as spectral pages burst from the phone, swirling like illuminated bats.

Hartwell gasped. “You triggered it early!”

“What did I trigger?” Ella shouted.

“An invocation of Libraria—the living archive.” Shelves creaked, books unchaining themselves, rearranging midair. A colossal figure formed from volumes: quills for fingers, a spine-covered crown. 

Ella’s heart hammered. The figure bowed. “Seeker, you solved my maze. What knowledge do you crave?”

Hartwell knelt. “Ask for immortality!”

Ella swallowed, then raised her phone. “I want every lost story returned to its people—no gatekeepers.”

The archive-colossus smiled, releasing papery comets through open windows, scattering lore across the night sky.

Hartwell groaned. “You gave it away.”

Ella pocketed her dimming phone. “Stories aren’t treasure if they’re locked up.”

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering."

responses.text:
The breath of dawn pools white in front of the five novices. They kneel in a crescent, bare chests flashing gooseflesh under the torchlight, eyes fixed on the slate mosaic that maps the mountain’s veins. Somewhere beneath that floor, fire sleeps. Master Thalen walks the circle, bells chiming at his wrists. “Stone remembers,” he says, sprinkling powdered amber. “It recalls heat, and it loans it only to the worthy.” 

The youngest, Liora, presses her palms to the granite despite the bite of cold. A faint tremor answers—like a heart beginning to beat. One by one the others follow, shuddering. In the dark beyond the hall, winds howl, carrying snow that will choke the pass by noon; this is the last chance before winter seals the temple.

Liora pictures the villages starving below, the promise she made to bring back flame. She leans closer, her breath tracing runes on the stone. Suddenly orange filaments thread the cracks, and heat—painful, glorious—rushes up her arms. The novices gasp, shoulders uncoiling as warmth spreads. Stone remembers; now it answers. In the glow, Master Thalen smiles, seeing not shivering children but the future keepers of fire.

Metal ribs groan overhead as the transport ship lurches from hyperspace. In Cell Block C, nineteen prisoners sit cross-legged on the frosted deck plates, bare chests stippled with old barcode burns. They stare at the stone-mimic floor—a synthetic blend scavenged from dead moons—because the ceiling offers only flickering red alarms.

Kaito counts breaths to stay warm. Seventeen hours since they stripped them for ‘decontamination,’ six since the captain announced the sale: labor auction on Vesk Prime. No blankets, no questions. Around him teeth chatter like faulty circuitry.

Then a hum different from the engines: the floor vibrates, a secret pulse. Kaito presses his ear to the mock stone and hears it—Mira, the engineer who vanished weeks ago, tunneling through maintenance shafts, laying charges. He grins despite the cold.

The lights cut. Silence—then a bloom of heat as the deck splits open. Mira’s voice booms through the vent. “If you can crawl, you’re free.” The prisoners dive into the ragged wound, sliding down cables toward unknown gravity wells. Behind them, alarms mutate into screams of officers. Kaito lands hard, laughs harder; for the first time in years the floor is dirt, not stone, and the shivering is only from wind.

Rome’s morning fog coils through the hypogeum, washing over two gladiators kneeling beside a drain carved in basalt. Bare chests gleam with oil meant to keep muscles warm, yet both still shiver—part cold, part terror they refuse to name. They stare at that floor as if it could open and swallow them back into anonymity.

Marcus runs a thumb over the faded tattoo of a vineyard on his ribs. He was a vintner once, till a legionary’s dice game stole him. Beside him, Nysa, all sinew and scar, rehearses footwork with her shadow. Above, the roar of fifty thousand stirs dust from rafters.

A wooden gate creaks; sunlight spills down the corridor in molten bars. The lanista beckons, gold collar flashing. “Hero’s pay for the crowd’s darling,” he lies.

Marcus rises first, offering Nysa a hand. “Remember the drain,” he whispers. She nods—if one falls, blood will snake toward it, a map for the survivor to avoid. Together they step into the arena’s blinding brightness. The stone floor, now behind them, keeps its secret: two silent vows etched in shivering breath—if death comes, let it be quick; if glory comes, let it be ours alone.

The concrete chamber sighs like an animal asleep. Six ex-acolytes crouch in a ring, backs striped where the lash kissed them for dissent. They stare at the floor—pitted limestone slick with condensation—because looking up means seeing the door they never thought would open. Bare chests rise and fall, each inhale a silent question: Who are we without the Prophet’s voice?

Sera breaks first. She cups her hands, catching the drip from the ceiling, rubs the water over goose-pimpled skin. “Cold proves we’re alive,” she murmurs. Jalen chuckles, a sound rusty with disuse. They talk then, softly, about favorite meals, old pets, the taste of rain. Memories knit heat better than any blanket.

A metallic clang—outside, not in. Rescue team or pursuers? Shadows swell under the doorframe. The group stands, shoulders touching. Fear is a current; they share its voltage. Sera presses fingers to the limestone and feels vibrations: steady, measured, unlike the frantic bootfall of guards. Hope.

When the lock finally gives, pale sunlight slices the gloom. They step out, still trembling, but the world is bright, and no one tells them where to place their eyes. The floor behind cools, empty of believers.

Dust motes drift like lazy comets in the museum’s basement. Two marble figures, once twins in a forgotten myth, stand on a cracked stone slab—until midnight’s last bell. Then sinew fills their carved torsos, and for the first time in centuries they feel cold. They lower their arms, stare at the slab beneath, bare-chested, shivering, amazed that stone can feel stone.

The taller, Castor, stretches, joints popping like chisel taps. “So this is breath,” he whispers, steam whirling from his lips. Polydeuces kneels, palm flat on the slab, studying veins of quartz. “The floor remembers every footstep,” he says. “Curators. Thieves. Lovers hiding.”

They climb the basement stairs, discovering creaks, discovering fear. Galleries loom: oil ships at war, bronze warriors forever mid-strike. An infrared alarm paints red nets across pedestals, but the brothers walk through light as though still myth. Upstairs, city snow piles at the glass doors.

Castor presses his blazing skin to the pane. “Cold is a god,” he decides. Polydeuces laughs, fogging the glass until streetlamps blur into halos. When guards rouse at dawn, they’ll find only two empty plinths and footprints that stop, inexplicably, where marble meets new-fallen snow.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering."

responses.text:
They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering. Torchlight from iron sconces trembles over the wet masonry, sketching quivering ribs and the bruises blooming across their backs. Aeryn counts the flickers—one, two, three—because numbers are the only things the warden cannot steal. Beside her, Korr clenches his jaw, trying to hide the chatter in his teeth. 

The door groans. Captain Valdek strides in, lacquered boots clicking like impatient metronomes. “Kneel,” he commands, as though they could stand. Outside, winter moans through arrow slits, carrying snowflakes that die on the torches. Aeryn lifts her eyes only when Valdek’s shadow eclipses her. He drops something silvery: a key, no larger than a thumbnail. “One will earn freedom. The other… entertains the hounds.”

Korr’s breath steams. Aeryn meets his gaze, remembering campfires before the rebellion, the taste of apple wine, his laugh like split timber. When Valdek leaves, the key still gleams between them. They should fight. Instead, Korr nudges it toward her with a foot. “Run,” he whispers. The hounds begin to howl. Aeryn closes her fingers around the shard of hope, and though the stone is cold, her heart ignites like dry straw.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering—three RAF flyers who once mapped the clouds now chart the cracks between flagstones. Stalag IX’s winter seeps through mortar and memory alike. Snow dusts the slit window, but the Luftwaffe guard has taken their shirts as punishment for last night’s tunnel attempt.

Harris hums a jazz riff under his breath, tapping out the piano part against his ribs. Frost tattoos his knuckles blue. “Keep the tempo, lads. Warm the blood.”

Greene kneels, prying at a loose stone. His fingertips split but he smiles anyway; the cavity below hides the compass fashioned from melted razor blades. Another centimeter tonight and the tunnel will find the drainage ditch.

Outside, sirens swell—Allied bombers crossing the Ruhr again. The walls shudder as explosives bloom miles away. In the chaos, the guards forget to count heads. Harris stops humming, listening instead to freedom rumbling overhead.

When the sirens fade, a solitary brick lies where the compass once hid. The men press close, sharing breath, their skeletal shoulders touching like wings. Tomorrow the shirts will still be gone, but the tunnel will be longer, and the sky—impossibly wide—will keep singing their names.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering, condensation spiraling from their lips like ghosts surprised to find bodies again. The cryo-pods cracked open minutes ago, disgorging Captain Lian, Botanist Ruiz, and twelve others into a ruin they were sent to colonize. 

Sunlight slices through a breach in the geodesic dome above, illuminating black moss that paints the walls, liquefying the mortar into onyx sludge. The terraformers never arrived—or they failed spectacularly. 

Lian presses a palm to the floor; it thrums, faintly alive. “Basalt. Heated from below,” Ruiz notes, voice trembling more from awe than cold. Power flickers on in the control kiosk, half-charging emergency systems. A single line scrolls the cracked holo-screen: ERROR 731: INDIGENOUS CLAIM.

Outside, something howls—a resonance of stone on stone. The team scrambles for abandoned vac-suits, but Lian lingers, studying the moss. It pulses in time with the floor’s heartbeat.

“We’re not alone,” she whispers. The moss drinks her breath, glowing emerald. Shivering ceases; warmth seeps upward, invasive yet comforting. A welcome? A warning? The howl repeats, closer. Lian straightens, bare chest rising to meet the alien air. “Form up,” she orders. “First contact begins now.”

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering. The stage crew calls it “the crucible,” the minute before curtain, when dancers crouch in darkness, warmed only by adrenaline and the ghost lights overhead. Mara counts her own heartbeats: eight to the downbeat, then flight.

Sweat beads despite the chill. Beside her, Jae rolls his shoulders, vertebrae clicking like dice in a cup. Outside the proscenium, a thousand patrons murmur, programs rustling like autumn leaves. They have come to witness a myth—two mortals who scorch the sky with a pas de deux, only to plunge into Icarian seafoam.

The conductor lifts his baton. A violin sighs. Mara’s ribs glow under skin, pale lanterns carving an urgent map. She remembers rehearsal bruises, the artistic director’s rasp: “Pain is the evidence that you lived here.”

Lights erupt. Stone becomes marble, then cloud. Mara and Jae spring upward, bodies scripting impossible calligraphy. The audience inhales as one; the theater becomes a single lung. By the final lift, Mara no longer feels the cold or the floor—only the gravity of applause, and the hush of feathers melting in the sun.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering—a circle of urban professionals who paid far too much for a “Primal Rebirth Weekend” at Hallowbrook Manor. The brochure promised ancient rites, detox smoothies, and Wi-Fi. Instead, midnight found them herded into a cellar that smells like wet pennies.

Coach Zephyr—formerly Todd from accounting—paces, banging a djembe. “Embrace vulnerability! Shed the false skin of polyester!” Their shirts lie in a damp heap near the exit, guarded by an inscrutable goat named Persephone.

Megan, senior VP of sales, raises a tentative hand. “Is the stone supposed to be… sizzling?” Steam coils where floor meets feet. Zephyr beams. “That’s the sacred alchemy of discomfort.”

A crack splits the flagstones. Orange light seeps through, as though hell itself wants a refund. The goat bleats, unimpressed. Gavin from marketing whispers, “I thought there’d be kombucha.”

The fissure widens. A gust of subterranean heat rolls up, warming their goose-pimpled torsos. For a moment, the circle stands taller, united by the absurdity. Megan snatches her shirt, eyes the stairs. “Team-building takeaway: never outsource enlightenment.”

They bolt. The goat follows. Behind them, Zephyr drums alone, chanting invoices to forgotten gods.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering."

responses.text:
They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering, when the torches gutter out and leave the dungeon blue with moonlight. Chain links whisper as Varek flexes numb wrists. Across the cell, Liora lowers her gaze from the barred window to him—a silent pact. Outside, the Black Warden’s footsteps recede toward the banquet hall. The captives have one crack at freedom.

Varek snaps the rusted ringbolt with a shoulder charged by desperation. Pain blooms, but the wall yields. They spill into a corridor choked with spider webs and forgotten sigils. Liora mutters the words her grandmother taught: glyphs flare, mapping hidden doors on bare stone. She once feared her inherited magic; tonight she clings to it like breath.

Sirens wail in the upper keep. Guards converge, armor clacking. Varek lifts a fallen spear, its shaft slick with dust, and blocks the passage. Liora’s spell opens a throat of light in the wall. "Jump," she hisses.

They dive through, landing in frost-silver grass outside the fortress. Behind them the tunnel seals, quieting the alarm. They are still shivering, still barefoot, but the moon is theirs now, and the road south whispers of fires, clothes, and a future no jailer can padlock.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering, while the cryo-pods drain their final mist. Around them, the abandoned lunar lab hums on emergency power. Six years in stasis, and the rescue shuttle never came.

Mira’s lungs burn as she forces speech. "We can’t stay. Air’s thin." Jace nods, eyes still cloudy with sleep. They stagger past overturned consoles, the walls blooming with frost blossoms, toward Observation.

Through the visor-wide viewport, Earth hangs enormous and bruised with auroras. An automated broadcast crackles: "GLOBAL IMPACT WINTER—SURFACE UNINHABITABLE." The date stamp loops, months ticking by in seconds. The planet they left might already be gone.

Jace rummages in a locker, finding silver thermal blankets and a single transmitter. Power cell: twenty minutes. He tunes to any frequency, voice raw. "Lunar Research Station 7, alive. Request extraction." Static answers.

Mira opens the shutter to the greenhouse. Miraculously, the algae vats glow emerald, self-cycling for years. A seed of possibility sparks between them. If no one comes, they will grow food, mine ice, build.

They wrap in foil blankets, still shaking but steadier. Earth may be lost, but on this pitted gray horizon, two survivors begin the slow work of a new cradle.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering—the marble cools even in Athenian summer before dawn. Young wrestlers of the palaestra, they wait for the master’s verdict after a night brawl that shattered a sacred amphora.

Damon swallows pride. He fought to defend timid Nikias, yet both stand accused. Master Kallias circles them with a measured, sandaled stride, the bronze oil lamp casting their shadows like trembling giants on columns.

"Strength without temperance," he intones, "is clay without water." He gestures to the courtyard where olive branches silver under first light. "Rebuild the vessel you broke—shape, fire, paint. When you understand patience, you may re-enter the games."

Relief mingles with dread. They know nothing of pottery. Still, punishment could have been exile from the gymnasium, from glory itself.

Weeks blur in a whirl of red slip, kiln heat, and the steady mentorship of the potter Melia, whose laughter softens their shame. Calloused hands learn delicacy; rivalry turns to fellowship.

On the equinox, they present a new amphora depicting two youths wrestling, not as foes but mirror images. The master nods. Muscles honed for combat have found a gentler rhythm, and the stone beneath their feet feels warm at last.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering, in the bowels of the city’s forgotten subway station. Neon seeps through cracked tiles, painting ribs and bruises a sickly violet. Leon and Mar isolated themselves here after the eviction, convinced the world’s noise would drown their despair.

Tonight, water drips steady as a clock. Mar counts each splash, grounding panic. "We can’t keep hiding," Leon whispers, voice echoing down the tunnel like a ghost train. Hunger claws; their last granola bar vanished yesterday.

Above, the city roars—marches, sirens, chants demanding rent control and dignity. Leon hears it like a summons. He retrieves a crumpled flyer from his jeans: Community Assembly, 8 p.m., City Hall Steps. A choice surfaces, abrupt and electric.

They dress in layered rags, shoulders squared against the chill, and ascend rusted stairs. Streetlight slaps color onto their skin; autumn wind bites but smells of roasted chestnuts and possibility.

As they merge with the rally, cardboard signs rise like sails. Voices uplift them, strangers press thermoses of soup into trembling hands. The stone floor is far beneath their memories now, and though winter looms, they are no longer invisible—they are an echo becoming a shout.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering. Rain sluices through the broken cathedral roof, pooling around their feet. Five silent novices kneel in a circle of silver dust, awaiting the final toll of midnight.

High on the altar, the Abbess turns a page of the Codex Basilica. "Stone remembers," she chants. "Flesh forgets." Lightning bleaches the halls, revealing frescoes of angels with wings half-chiseled away.

At the twelfth bell, the novices feel marrow freeze. The floor vibrates; dust spirals rise like awakened serpents. One by one, their skin hardens to granite, veins turning to white quartz. Terror flickers in still-mortal eyes until lids seal.

Yet one novice—Elion—hears another rhythm beneath the bell: a heartbeat deep below, older than the cathedral. He wills warmth into his fingertips, cracking the forming stone. With a gasp, he stands, half-statue, half-boy, and slams a fist onto the floor.

The circle shatters. Dust scatters in a blinding swirl. When it clears, the petrified novices breathe again, skin human. The Abbess has vanished; only an empty habit remains.

Elion leads them into the storm, bare chests steaming in cold rain, aware that stone may remember—but tonight, flesh rebelled and wrote a new scripture.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering."

responses.text:
They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering.  The dungeon keeps its secrets the way a grave keeps bones—tight and timeless.  Rainwater drips through the ceiling, sketching cold constellations on their shoulders.  Three days ago they were rebels with names; now the jailer calls them only "the twins."  

Outside, the siege engines grind and groan, but here the loudest sound is memory: fever-bright flashes of the citadel garden, the scent of quince, the last warm sun.  "Hold the picture," Brother whispers.  Brother always whispers now; the echo might betray hope.  

A rat investigates their chains, scuttling over rust and ancient straw.  Sister draws her knees to her chest, pressing skin against skin to kindle one more ember of warmth.  In the dark she feels the wall behind her—a loose stone exactly nine fingers wide.  The plan unfurls like stolen parchment: pry, crawl, swim the catacombs, reach the river.  

The twins exchange a glance, silent geometry of trust.  Tomorrow the torturer will demand confession.  Tonight the stone will give, water will guide, and the moon will chart a silver passage beyond these walls.  They shiver—but they are already moving.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering—yet telemetry says the pod maintains a perfect 22°C.  Dr. Selene Ybarra taps the glass of Observation Suite 7, watching the two subjects eclipse into themselves.  

Project HYPERNAP promised deep-space crews a century of dreamless cryo.  Instead, it delivered a contagion of waking nightmares called CORE-FROST: a psychosomatic blizzard that devours the mind from within.  The cure, headquarters believes, is proximity—two afflicted hearts thawing each other.  So they stripped Ezra and Kiriko to the waist, removed all stimuli, and asked them to share a floor of synthetic basalt.  

Minutes crawl.  Their breaths sync, pluming in air that isn’t cold.  Kiriko whispers a childhood lullaby, expired data from a sea-level world.  Ezra laughs—a small crackling fire.  Skin pinks, shoulders square.  They raise their eyes, not at Selene, but at each other.  The CORE-FROST metrics fall like snow melting on a windshield.  

Selene logs the impossible.  Space will still be lonely, but now ships will carry pairs instead of singles, hearts instead of hardware.  And somewhere, forty light-years out, two voyagers will teach the void to shiver—and then to sweat—until it learns the warmth of being seen.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering, because the river god has taken their clothes as tribute.  Around them the temple hums: reeds shaking, moonlight bleeding through lattice screens, incense slanting like thin gold rain.  

Every solstice, twins from the village present themselves to the deity of currents, offering vulnerability so the waters stay sweet.  Kaya and Lior expected a ritual; instead, silence.  

A pebble rattles across the flagstones.  It rolls between their feet, stops, pulses.  Pebble becomes frog, frog becomes boy with riverweed hair.  His laughter is the clink of shells.  “I get lonely,” he says.  “Talk to me.”  

Kaya speaks first, telling stories of cornfields and elder songs.  Lior adds jokes about the traveling knife-sharpeners.  The river boy listens, thighs evaporating into mist, arms widening into streams.  Water climbs the walls like ivy, tracing stories in ripples.  

By dawn, the temple is a pond holding only lotus blossoms and two folded tunics.  Down in the village, the river runs clearer than memory, and a new laughter burbles in every eddy—a reminder that gods crave company as much as sacrifice.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering, while Detective Mara Ling watches from the mirror-glass.  The room is chilled to 12°C; truth, she believes, hides in gooseflesh.  

Two suspects—brothers, maybe, maybe not—were hauled from the docks after midnight.  A smuggled crate held antique coins and one severed hand wearing a mayoral ring.  The brothers claim ignorance: found the box, thought it empty, paid to move it.  

Mara enters, sets a space heater humming just beyond their reach.  Steam from styrofoam coffee curls toward the ceiling.  "Confession," she says, "is cheaper than silence."  

The tall one licks salt from his lips, eyes fixed on the floor’s cracks, searching for a map out.  The short one counts breaths, building courage like stacking chips.  Finally: "We never saw the hand."  

Mara slides a photograph across the tiles—ring, wristbone, dried blood like rust.  She tilts the heater.  Warmth trickles forward, folds around them.  With it comes the words, tumbling, colliding: a yacht, a debt, a night too dark.  

The tape recorder spins.  Mara doesn’t smile—truth is payment enough.  Outside, dawn ignites the frost on squad-car windows, and somewhere a family will soon bury a mystery solved.

They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering.  The therapy circle meets in the old bathhouse because tile cannot lie; it always remembers the temperature.  Five survivors of house fires sit cross-legged where pools once steamed, trying to speak without smoke.  

Dr. Voss asks them to place palms on stone, feel how cold survives even absences of flame.  "Name what was taken," he says.  Ember lists photographs; Malik, a cat; Jun, her sense of smell.  They whisper, heatless breaths frosting the air.  

Then Dr. Voss lights a single beeswax candle.  It flickers in the room’s hollow heart, painting trembling suns on their ribs.  He invites each to cup the flame, hands making soft cages.  As it passes, wax pools, wick shortens, but the room warms by delicate degrees.  

When the stub finally gutters, they look again at the floor.  Where their palms once rested, faint fog-prints linger, ghostly handshapes that will vanish soon—but not yet.  Malik laughs first, a crackle like fresh-lit tinder.  The others join, bare chests vibrating with a heat stoked from within.  Outside, the city exhales winter, but inside the bathhouse the survivors no longer shiver alone.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering."

responses.text:
They are staring at the stone floor, bare-chested, shivering.  The torches hiss above, dripping resin like slow tears, and the air of the wizard’s oubliette tastes of copper and mildew.  Names, memories, even seasons have been leeched away by the chants that slip through the cracks each night, but one ember of self still glows.
