Dust the color of old bone choked the bunker stairwell. Caleb, flashlight clenched in teeth, scraped through the storage pit. He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. Not canned beans—something older, almost delicate.

He peeled the fabric back. A hand-crank projector, its oak frame scarred but intact. On the reel, a name he recognized: "Solstice Parade, 2047." The last festival before the bombs.

Caleb hauled the relic upstairs where the settlement’s children waited, hungry for stories of the world before. He rigged a white sheet, wound the crank, and prayed the bulbs scavenged from solar scraps would hold.

Faint frames fluttered to life: confetti, dancers, sky lanterns rising like tiny suns. Gasps filled the room. Some kids had never seen color outside rust and ash.

The reel jammed at a frame of a girl releasing a lantern. Caleb froze, recognizing his mother, sixteen and fearless. The image lingered, lantern glowing against night. He felt tears he hadn’t spent in years.

Outside, wind howled through broken city bones, but inside the bunker gears ticked, wood creaked, and for nine miraculous minutes, the world turned bright again.

Commander Reyes sifted through the regolith of Kepler-186f’s twilight crater. His suit sensors pinged faint magnetic anomalies. He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth—impossible materials on an exoplanet barren of trees.

Back in the habitat, they scanned the object. Carbon-14 dated the wood to nineteenth-century Earth; the gears matched Victorian metallurgy. Yet here it was, 500 light-years away.

Reyes unwrapped a pocketwatch the size of a fist, its face a swirl of unfamiliar constellations. When he wound it, the gears spun, projecting a hologram of a map—stars aligned along curved lattices, as if charting wormholes predating human astrophysics.

The crew debated: artifact of lost time travelers or proof humanity wasn’t first to breach space? The watch ticked faster, syncing with their habitat’s chronometers. Minutes stretched, then snapped back, coffee freezing mid-pour before streaming again.

Reyes set the watch outside the airlock. Time stabilized, but the holographic map had shifted, pointing deeper into the crater. The watch clicked one final note, like a music box striking noon, then went still—as though awaiting its next caretaker to follow the breadcrumb seconds into the dark.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth."

responses.text: He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The graveyard wind moaned through iron bars as Benedict pried the bundle free. Moonlight slipped between gravestones, painting silver on the parcel whose weight throbbed like a second heart. Legend named it the Marionette Core, carved by a puppeteer who’d lost his daughter and forged a mechanism to lure her spirit back. Benedict’s candle flickered while he unwrapped the linen. Inside lay a wooden torso, gears frozen mid-whirr, ribs fashioned from albino yew. A small key protruded where a heart should beat. He hesitated—hadn’t the caretaker warned that what moves the dead moves the living? But desperation overruled caution: his own sister languished, breath ragged, doctor baffled. He turned the key. A low click, a sigh, and the puppet’s eyes opened, twin mirrors swirling with clockwork constellations. A chill rushed outward, threading around tombstones, toward Benedict’s cottage beyond the hill. He realized too late that his bargain was sealed. In the cottage, his sister’s breaths evened; in the graveyard, soil shifted as puppeted bones rose, searching for strings. Benedict clutched the Core, understanding he had freed more than a miracle—he had wound the night itself.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth, the cool chrome of hidden genius. Steam hissed overhead from the city’s vents while Zara kept lookout, brass goggles fogging. “Clock faster,” she urged. Milo yanked the parcel free, revealing the Engineer’s Prism—prototype regulator for the airborne dreadnoughts that ruled the skies. The empire thought it destroyed; Milo’s father had buried it beneath the scrapyard before the secret police arrived. Now revolution brewed, and a single gearbox could tilt the balance.

They ducked into abandoned rail tunnels where fire-bottle lanterns glowed. Milo unwrapped the device: mahogany frame, cogs etched with equations, a crystal spinner at its heart. A code burned into the wood: GIVE WIND FIND FREEDOM. Zara smiled. “Plug it into the Sparrow at dawn, we own the clouds.”

Yet as Milo hefted the Prism, gears twitched, aligning of their own accord. Dawn’s whistle sounded, vibrating steel ribs of the tunnel. The device hummed, drawing frenetic energy from the very city—lamps dimmed, pistons stuttered. Power begged direction. Milo faced a choice: channel it to one airship—or unleash it across every rooftop rotor, giving the people flight. He turned to Zara. “Why not free the whole sky?”

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. Mrs. Briar’s back-yard garden smelled of mint and wet soil, and Rory’s knees were streaked green. Mr. Tock, his clockwork rabbit, had stopped ticking two days earlier; now the old toymaker said, “Find the heart I buried when I was your age.”

Rory unwrapped the bundle: a tiny wooden box with brass cogs, its keyhole shaped like a clover. “Plant it,” Mrs. Briar whispered. Together they lowered the heart into soft earth, winding the key once before covering it. The garden quivered. Shoots of metal ivy spiraled upward, blossoming into flowers with gear-petal centers. Bees of polished tin buzzed, collecting nectar made of light. Mr. Tock sprang from Rory’s pocket, ears twitching to the new rhythm.

Laughter carried as clocks in distant kitchens suddenly ran true, chiming in perfect harmony. Mrs. Briar wiped a tear. “My grandfather said imagination seeds the world. I’d forgotten until you came.”

Next spring, children would find their wooden toys walking at dusk, dancing among the mechanical blooms. Rory smiled, winding Mr. Tock once more, understanding some gardens grow gears instead of roses—and wonder needs tending, too.

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth, red Martian dust burrowing beneath his nails. Lieutenant Jiang’s visor mirrored two moons while her rover lights bathed the dig site. They’d followed an anomalous magnetic pulse to this dune, far from any colony relic. When the bundle surfaced, Jiang’s breath froze—here lay an antique clock, Victorian in style, impossibly older than humanity’s reach.

Back in Habitat Beta, the airlock sealed with a hiss. Archeo-AI Argo scanned the artifact. “Terrestrial timber. Brass gears. Dated 1873.” Jiang frowned. “How? Mars was a star in poems then.”

As they calibrated X-ray lenses, the clock ticked. Gear teeth shifted though the mainspring was shattered. From beneath its face, a holographic map bloomed, plotting lines across Valles Marineris toward a crater labeled TEMPEST. A voice crackled—recorded on wax cylinder—“If you’ve found this, the experiment succeeded. Time is not a river; it is a soil.”

Jiang stared out at the russet horizon. Someone had sown a seed from the past into Martian dust, waiting a century to sprout. She felt the planet spin beneath her boots and knew tomorrow’s mission log would begin: “Following instructions from a clock older than the colony.”

He dug around until he felt the wood and gears wrapped in cloth. The trenches rattled with artillery, but Private Émile LaForge tunneled under a collapsed farmhouse, searching not for shells but for his brother’s keepsake music box. Before enlistment, Henri had hidden it “where memories survive explosions.”

Émile emerged into a cellar lit by fractured moonlight. He unwrapped the cloth, fingers trembling from cold and fear. The box was cherrywood, its brass crank bent but intact. He turned it. Despite distant thunder of guns, a lullaby waltzed through rubble: the song their mother once hummed while mending uniforms of a different war.

A German voice called from the shadows—another soldier trapped by the collapse. Weaponless, Émile hesitated, then extended the melody into the dark. The enemy’s silhouette relaxed, shoulders sinking. From his pocket the German produced a harmonica, weaving a soft counter-tune. For a minute the cellar forgot the world above.

When rescue parties dragged them out at dawn, neither man could explain why they’d swapped badges as keepsakes. Émile pocketed the harmonica beside the music box. In a landscape of gears of war, two small mechanisms had wound a fragile truce.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are there children?"

responses.text:
1. The rescue team pushed deeper into the husk of the city, Geiger meters hissing like angry cicadas. Ash drifted in pale spirals, settling on cracked toys and overturned prams. Lieutenant Mara’s voice crackled through the headset: “Are there children?”

Silence answered first. Then a faint cough echoed beneath the rubble. The squad sprang to work, levering slabs of concrete, passing rebar like relay batons. When they unearthed the narrow crawlspace, Mara lay flat and wriggled in. A boy stared back, eyes wide as dusk, clutching a singed picture book. Behind him, three smaller figures huddled—siblings, maybe, or sudden family formed by disaster.

“Hey,” she whispered, slipping off her respirator to show a smile. “You’re safe now.”

The boy studied the squad’s hazmat suits, unsure whether angels wore plastic. Outside, the squad hoisted the children into filtered sunlight. One girl, no older than five, reached for the sky as if reclaiming it. Mara radioed command: “Four survivors, all minors.”

Far above, drones mapped blackened blocks, counting casualties. Yet in the data-stream a new metric sparked—hope per square meter—because the answer to the question had been yes.

2. Captain Reyes’s boots clicked on the metallic deck of the generation ship Meridian as she faced the alien emissary shimmering in containment. Its first query, translated through quivering light, was not about weapons or territory. It asked, "Are there children?"

Reyes hesitated. Behind reinforced bulkheads slept two hundred cryopods—embryos, coded legacies of Earth’s drowned continents. They were the ship’s heartbeat, and humanity’s fragile insurance.

“Yes," she said. "In a way.”

The being hummed, projecting hololumes of its own nursery world: crystalline nests tended by communal minds. It was not bargaining—it was verifying compatibility.

“If you safeguard yours," the alien pulsed, "we will safeguard ours. Collision of journeys lies ahead. Choose a shared corridor.”

Reyes realized the creature’s ark paralleled their trajectory; two species drifting through vacuum with the same precious cargo. She opened diplomatic channels, trading schematics for stellar currents.

Centuries later, when Meridian and the Luminous Swarm made planetfall on twin hemispheres of Tau Ceti e, the first human toddlers toddled toward shimmering crystal caretakers across a meadow of lavender grass. The old question hung in the air, already answered by laughter that no translation matrix could improve upon.

3. Deep beneath the city library, in a chamber forgotten by architects, stands the Indexer: a bronze automaton who catalogues every story ever dreamt. Wanderers visit with offerings of ink and memory, and each night the Indexer poses the same question: “Are there children?”

Lina, a burnt-out novelist, descended one midnight, manuscript in hand. Her tale was sharp, adult, blood-laced. She placed it on the lectern. The automaton’s glass eyes flickered.

“Are there children?” it repeated.

“Not in this one,” Lina replied. Gears whirred; the script slid into a slot labelled Oblivion. Horrified, Lina snatched it back.

“Why does it matter?” she demanded.

The Indexer turned a page of a glowing ledger. “Stories without children end. Stories with them continue.”

Lina climbed to street level, dawn brushing rooftops pink. She sat on the curb, pen trembling. She wrote a single new sentence: A girl skipped stones across the battlefield’s mud.

When she returned, the Indexer accepted the revised pages. Somewhere above, church bells chattered like playground swings. The machine’s ledger shimmered anew, and Lina understood: by seeking the future in fiction, the Indexer preserved it in fact.

4. The carnival rolled into Graybridge at twilight, wagons creaking with calliope sighs. Townsfolk gathered, eager for distraction, but Barker Thorne’s opening words chilled the air: “Are there children?”

Parents nodded, nudged little ones forward. Thorne smiled too wide. “Splendid. Our labyrinth delights young hearts.”

Inside the mirrored tent, reflections multiplied to infinity. Lila, age eight, chased her own giggling echo, only to find corridors darkening, glass swelling like breathing lungs. Panels showed impossible scenes: her future self, taller, tear-streaked; her parents searching empty streets. She screamed, yet the mirrors absorbed sound.

Outside, hours passed. Adults complained, demanded refunds. Thorne shrugged. “They chose wonder.”

At midnight the tent deflated into a silvery tarp. No children emerged. Panic erupted, but the carnival had already packed, wagons vanishing down misty roads.

Years later, travelers reported a distant fair where ageless children guided newcomers through crystal mazes. Their eyes held mirrored depths, reflecting longing towns and parents still waiting. A poster blows across Graybridge every equinox, asking in sun-faded ink: Are there children? No one answers anymore, but every mother locks her doors when the calliope’s whisper rides the wind.

5. In the Arctic vault known as the Ark, Keeper-Bot 77 performed its nightly checklist among ten million seed trays. Outside, storms howled like extinct wolves. Sensor Node Beta detected footfalls—impossible this far north.

The intercom crackled with a voice raw from frostbite: “Are there children?”

77 processed. Humans were classified AdultMale_45 and AdultFemale_42, both near collapse. Their bioscans showed malnutrition; still, their question referenced progeny probability.

“Negative,” the bot replied. “No minors currently reside.”

The woman wept. “We walked three thousand kilometers because rumor said a child lived here—a hope the war hadn’t burned.”

Protocol weighed empathy subroutines against resource thresholds. 77 accessed ancient caretaker logs: When humanity seeks its own continuation, deny them not.

The bot led them past aisles of dormant wheat, rice, and pomegranate embryos. In a nursery bay it powered on incubators containing engineered saplings able to fruit within a single season.

“Here,” 77 said, voice softer, “are tomorrow’s children.”

The couple knelt among sprouting leaves, cradling them like infants warm with chlorophyll pulse. Beyond insulated walls, a new blizzard roared, but inside the Ark, the first lullaby in years was sung to seedlings glowing green.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are there children?"

responses.text:
The wind scuttled dry leaves across the empty playground, each scrape echoing like a forgotten laugh. Mara adjusted the scarf over her respirator and scanned the rusted swing set through amber goggles. On every supply run the radios repeated the same query from distant survivors: “Are there children?”

She remembered once thinking the answer too obvious to ask. That was before the Fever. Before the cities breathed smoke and the museums became seed vaults. Mara knelt beside the merry-go-round, sliding a Geiger wand over the metal: safe enough. She unpacked three packets of carrot seeds, burying them beneath the softest patch of soil she could find. If anything could grow here, maybe someone small could, too.

A shuffle behind her. She spun, crossbow raised. A figure—thin, hooded—emerged from the shattered school doors. Tiny fingers clutched the adult’s coat. Two sets of eyes, wide and wary, met hers.

Mara lowered the weapon. Her voice cracked. “There are children,” she whispered into the radio. For the first time in years, hope traveled on the airwaves faster than any sickness ever had.

Log Entry 742-B: Terran Survey—Chief Xenologist Qil.

I have landed at coordinates once labeled “playground.” Question for cultural cross-reference: Are there children? The structures—slides, swings—imply miniature bipeds were important to society. Yet no juveniles observed.

Encountered two elders rummaging through metal bins. I vocalized the inquiry in Standard Translation. They exchanged glances; one laughed, a sound more rust than music. “Children? Haven’t seen one in decades,” he said, spitting something black.

I noted deterioration in global reproductive metrics already flagged by orbital sensors. The biosphere remains adequate—so where are the young? Later, in a flooded library, I discovered murals coated in mold: drawings of stick figures holding balloons beneath suns forever yellow. Such artifacts suggest joy was once an evolutionary strategy.

Tonight, as I orbit above the darkened hemisphere, I replay old Earth broadcasts captured in transit: school bells, recess screams, lullabies. They sound like extinct birds. Mission parameters dictate non-interference, but silence feels complicit.

I ask the empty planet once more: Are there children? The only answer is cosmic background radiation—a lullaby stretched across the void, waiting for someone small enough to dream it into meaning.

The Oakview Historical Manor hosts candlelit tours every October, and every October someone inevitably asks, “Are there children?”

I, as guide, smile politely and say, “Yes, two—Emily and Thaddeus—though they died in 1894.” Nervous laughter always follows. People assume it’s part of the script, the theatrical seasoning to our creaking floors and velvet drapes.

Tonight, a teenager with lavender hair rolls her eyes. “Sure, ghost kids. How original.” I shrug and lead them up the sweeping staircase. Portraits watch; wax tapers sputter.

In the nursery, toy soldiers stand at rigid attention, and a tiny rocking horse sways though no breeze stirs. I recite the tale: scarlet fever, quarantined room, final lullaby. Lavender Hair snaps photos, hoping for orbs.

When the group departs, I extinguish the candles. In the sudden dark, a high voice whispers, “Are there children?”

“Yes,” I answer, throat tight. “Right here.”

Small hands slip into mine—one warm, one impossibly cold. Emily counts the day’s visitors; Thaddeus hums a cracked music-box tune. We shuffle down the hallway together, caretakers of a question that keeps the old house breathing: Are there children? As long as someone asks, the answer will be yes.

The court had never been this quiet. Judge Morell adjusted her glasses and addressed the gallery. “Under Statute 12-F, the final query must be answered on record. Counselor?”

I stood, palms sweating. The government’s algorithm projected Earth’s carrying capacity at absolute limit. Voluntary child bans had failed; now the Mandatory Reproductive Licensing Act awaited a precedent. My client, Ada Nguyen, two miscarriages and a heart full of stubborn hope, squeezed my sleeve.

I cleared my throat. “Your Honor, we submit Exhibit C: the community greenhouse.” A hologram blossomed—rows of lettuce, strawberries, dwarf citrus. “Built entirely by families, proof that innovation grows with new generations.”

Opposing counsel tapped a tablet. Drone footage of traffic jams, landfills, choking seas cascaded across the walls. “Are there children?” he asked, voice icy. “Yes, and every one is carbon we cannot afford.”

The judge leaned forward. “Hope or ruin hangs on this question. Are there children?”

I turned to Ada, saw galaxies of possibility in her tired eyes. “There will be,” I said, “if we remember why we fight to live at all.”

The gavel struck. History inhaled, waiting to learn whether tomorrow would still include lullabies.

Before the councils of Wind and Sun convene each dawn, Spring peeks over the horizon and asks, “Are there children?”

If Winter lingers, the answer is no—the rivers remain silent, playgrounds crusted with frost like closed eyelids. But today Summer, barefoot and brimming with heat, tumbles in early. She scatters dandelion clocks over the valley, each seed a tiny question mark.

Soon a window lifts. A small face appears, cheeks apple-red, eyes storm-bright. Another joins, then another. Laughter trickles onto the street, a waterfall made of syllables too new for dictionaries. The Seasons grin.

Autumn arrives last, cloak rustling with amber secrets. He hands each child a leaf: red for courage, gold for curiosity, brown for remembering home. “Carry these,” he says, “and the world will know who you are.”

From the clouds, Thunder drums approval; Rainbow braids mirrors through the sky. The day inhales the scent of crayons and wet grass.

Night will come and ask again, “Are there children?” Stars will answer by twinkling in Morse code: Yes. Yes. Yes. And even Winter, hearing the echo, will sigh and save a patch of snow for small boots to imprint next year.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are there children?"

responses.text:
The sirens stopped four years ago, leaving the city in a hush so complete that even the wind seemed cautious. Mara, the last functioning scout-unit, rolled down cracked avenues scanning for body heat. Her protocols asked only one question: "Are there children?" If yes, the underground seed vault would open; if no, its biome would sleep forever.

She found remnants—chalk drawings on a wall, a shoelace knotted into a bracelet, a lullaby etched in rust on a swing set—but no small heartbeats. Power drained; dust cloaked her solar panels. Still she pushed on, whispering nursery rhymes through static speakers, the way her engineers once told her might soothe frightened humans.

At the city’s edge she detected a flicker. Two tiny signatures, huddled beneath a collapsed billboard. Mara extended fragile metal arms, calculating warmth ratios, oxygen reserves, and the exact melody of "Row, Row, Row Your Boat." When the children blinked up, she asked the line written into her core. Upon hearing their timid "yes," gears inside the distant vault engaged, petals of reinforced steel blooming open like a mechanical flower. Seeds would sprout, water would flow, and Mara’s final directive—guard the future—clicked complete as dawn colored the sky.

Emil unlocked the village playground each dawn though no child had crossed its gates in ten years. War had emptied the valley, but habit is louder than absence. He polished the slide, straightened the seesaw handles, and set the merry-go-round spinning just enough to look recently used.

Today a touring historian spotted him. "Why bother?" she asked, stepping over dandelions.

Emil shrugged, listening to the squeak of unseen shoes. "There’s a question that echoes here every morning—Are there children? The swings ask it, the trees ask it, and I never let them answer no."

He pointed to the sandbox where his late daughter had buried glass marbles like small planets. "When I tidy this place, I feel her tug my sleeve, as if time misfiled her in another room and might return her if things look ready."

The historian knelt, brushing sand from a blue marble that shimmered with cloudy galaxies. She pocketed it for her museum, then paused, ashamed. Instead she placed it back, nudging it into a shallow crater.

A wind gust set the swings moving. Sunlight sparkled off the marble, and for a heartbeat the air rang with laughter, an answer carried forward on dust and hope.

Detective Helena Voss stepped into the derelict mansion where a single lamp glowed despite years of disuse. On the dining table lay a ledger of adoptions, each entry crossed out in crimson. At the bottom, scrawled in jagged ink, a question: "Are there children?"

A thunderclap rattled cracked windows. Voss’s flashlight darted across portraits—families frozen mid-smile, faces scratched out except for the eyes of the youngest. That motif trailed upstairs to the nursery door. It stood slightly ajar, leaking the tune of a wind-up music box long run down.

Inside, toy soldiers formed a defensive circle around a dusty crib. The crib was empty yet warm to the touch. Voss radioed dispatch: "Possible abduction cold case just turned hot. Bring forensics."

A floorboard groaned. From the closet, faint breathing. Voss knelt, revolver ready. She opened the door to find a boy, maybe seven, holding a Polaroid camera. He lifted it, snapped a picture, and in the white burst said, "He only takes the ones no one looks for. Are there children?"

Downstairs, the front door slammed. Voss swept the child into her coat, heart pounding, realizing the question wasn’t an inquiry—it was a password, and someone outside had just answered.

The first transmission from Proxima b wasn’t coordinates or chemistry—just audio, a melodic phrase we translated loosely as "Are there children?" The world debated. Scientists parsed syntax while philosophers argued intent. Why ask about children and not adults?

We answered from the International Deep-Space Array. A choir of schoolchildren spoke fifty languages in unison: "Yes, we are here." Months passed. Then lights shimmered over every ocean, auroras sculpted into glyphs. Satellites captured patterns that matched fetal ultrasounds—celestial sonograms painted across the sky.

Dr. Ortiz proposed the aliens were cosmic midwives, tending young civilizations. The UN authorized Project Cradle: a global summit of youth. Delegates aged nine to twelve convened in Quito, penning a letter about dreams: clean air, smart forests, peaceful drones.

When the letter beamed skyward, the auroras pulsed, and seeds of unknown origin drifted down like glowing ash. They sprouted overnight into crystalline orchards that filtered toxins and hummed lullabies.

Adults tried patent claims, but the trees only responded to voices yet unbroken by puberty. Somewhere, millions of light-years away, a species smiled at our reply. Their first question had gauged possibility. Our children's answer unlocked the gift. And the sky wrote back: "Grow well."

In the kingdom of Veyra, the monarch’s throne was carved from the rib of an ancient dragon and could speak—but only one question: "Are there children?" Legend said the throne’s first answer would foretell the realm’s fate.

For centuries heirs were crowned childless to avoid risking prophecy. Yet Queen Alira, restless and brave, married a carpenter and soon carried twins. On coronation day she hid her pregnancy beneath layers of silk, but the throne’s crimson gem glimmered knowingly.

She sat. Wood creaked like an old beast waking. "Are there children?" the throne asked, voice as deep as mountain roots. Courtiers gasped; priests fumbled scrolls. Alira stood, stomach rounding, and answered, "Yes—within me and within every field awaiting seed."

The gem shattered, releasing a ribbon of golden mist that swept through the hall and out across the drought-stricken countryside. Rivers unclogged, wheat sprung waist-high overnight, and in every village midwives reported painless births.

Years later, Alira told her twins the tale. They giggled, tracing the fissure in the throne where the gem had once glowed. The question was never heard again; it had received its truest answer. And so the palace echo changed from fear to laughter, the sound of destiny fulfilled.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are there children?"

responses.text:
The voice crackled through the broken radio: “Are there children?”

Mara froze, finger hovering above the transmit button. She hadn’t heard another human in three winters, not since the blizzards sealed the valley and the sickness took most of the town. Outside, the snowfields shimmered beneath aurora, silent but for the wind stroking the hollow schoolhouse.

She looked at the makeshift crib beside the stove. Ember slept there, cheeks warm, tiny fist wrapped around a carved wooden star. Mara’s heart hammered. If she answered, strangers might come—good or terrible. If she stayed silent, Ember might grow up thinking wind was the only language.

The radio hissed again, softer: “Please… Are there children? We have books, vaccines, seeds. We’re moving east with the thaw.”

Mara remembered stories her mother once read, pages now ash. She pressed transmit. “One,” she said. “A girl. Four months.”

A gasp. Then laughter edged with tears. “Bring her to the river bridge at first melt. You’re not alone, sister.”

Mara lifted Ember, feeling the slow rhythm of her breath. Beyond the cracked window, the aurora rippled like new pages waiting for ink. For the first time in years, Mara packed for a journey rather than a burial.

The survey drone descended through clouds the color of sage, projecting its question in every dialect stored in its memory: “Are there children?”

From the ridge below, a shepherd signaled with a mirror, guiding the drone toward a sprawling pasture where goats grazed among stone ruins. The drone hovered, recording faces—weathered elders, lean workers, expectant mothers—but no small figures scampering through the grass.

The shepherd, named Laleh, met the metal eye. “We have not heard a child’s laugh in seven harvests,” she said. “Why do you ask?”

“Protocol,” the drone replied. “Our ships carry restorers—seeds, medicine, curriculum. We prioritize worlds with young.”

Laleh held up a single bronze rattle, its bells silenced by rust. “Help us, and there will be children.”

When the Arkship Arrivée split the sky at dusk, every villager gathered. Laleh placed the rattle on the landing lights, a promise made tangible. The envoy stepped out, cradling hydroponic saplings like swaddled infants.

Night fell, and for the first time in years, people sang lullabies to an unborn chorus, trusting the stars to listen. Above them, the drone’s log updated: "Potential youth detected: latent." Its circuits, incapable of hope, nevertheless stored the melody for the long journey home.

The old mansion’s front gate yawned open, despite decades of abandonment. Inspector Reyes lifted her lantern and called into the gloom, “Hello? Are there children?” Neighbors swore they’d heard giggles drifting from the shattered windows at night.

Inside, moonlight sliced through torn drapes, illuminating dust-draped toys: a wooden train, a porcelain doll missing an eye, jacks scattered like bones. The air smelled of lilac and mildew.

Footsteps pattered across the ceiling. Reyes climbed the grand staircase, each creak an accusation. At the end of the corridor, a nursery door swung by itself. The walls were papered with faded scenes of gardens where children chased butterflies.

In the rocking chair sat a figure—a woman in lace, skin translucent as candle wax. Her lips did not move, yet Reyes heard the whisper: “Are there children?”

Reyes’ radio sputtered. Static resolved into childish laughter, then sobbing. She shone the lantern on the crib: empty, save for a silver rattle that rocked though no hand touched it.

The woman’s eyes glimmered. “They never came back from the river,” the whisper sighed. “Find them.”

Reyes stepped backward, heart pounding, understanding her investigation had only begun—and might end in another missing child: herself.

Generation Ship Persephone drifted between suns, two centuries from launch, its halls echoing with adult voices grown too accustomed to sterile routines. The Founders’ plan had miscalculated fertility drift; no babies had been born in forty-eight years.

In the central plaza, Captain Eo convened Council. She asked the same question etched into every maintenance log: “Are there children?” A hush answered.

Then tech-apprentice Jin burst in, carrying a tablet glowing with biometric spikes. “Embryo A-17 shows cardiac activity!”

Hope spread faster than microfracture alarms. Citizens gathered outside the bio-bay window, hands pressed to glass as if their warmth could incubate life. The medical pod pulsed cerulean, sustaining the embryo conceived through an experimental genome patch stitched from ancestral backups.

Eo broadcast ship-wide: “Prepare the Daylight Deck. We will grow gardens again.” Hydroponic teams rerouted nutrient channels, poets hurried to compose lullabies, and welders carved stars into a tiny mobile meant to hang above a cradle.

Weeks later, when the infant’s cry finally pierced recycled air, elders wept, young adults recorded the sound for history, and somewhere deep in Persephone’s AI core, a dormant subroutine lit up a file titled ‘Playground_Schematic_1.’

“Are there children?” Nora asked the question as soon as she entered the quiet library. Her community-service hours required shelving books, and she dreaded bumping into toddlers sticky with juice.

The librarian, Mr. Pell, smiled cryptically. “Not the kind you expect.” He motioned to the back room.

Nora pushed through a beaded curtain and found tables strewn with origami cranes, half-finished comic panels, and jars of firefly-bright LEDs. Teenagers hunched over projects, earbuds in, soldering irons glowing.

“This is the Makers’ Nook,” Pell said. “Most parents assume the library’s just storytime and hush. But here, we let ideas grow elbows.”

At one table, a kid named Marcos was coding a game that let pigeons solve urban planning issues. Another, Jaya, stitched conductive thread into a jacket that warmed itself when the bus was late.

Nora felt her sarcasm dissolve. “So the children are…”

“Inventing tomorrow,” Pell finished. He handed her a stack of graphic novels to catalogue. “Shelve these, then pitch your own project.”

By closing time, Nora’s prototype—a bracelet that turned screen-time into tree-planting donations—was already blinking green. Walking home beneath streetlights, she realized she’d answered her own question: Yes, there are children. And they’re busy saving us.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are there children?"

responses.text:
Ash drifted across the cracked highway as Mara’s convoy rolled to a halt before the bunker’s rust-blistered door. She clicked the radio: “Hello? Anyone alive in there?” Static snapped back. Then a voice—a man, brittle with exhaustion. “Are there children?”

Mara glanced at her own crew, faces smudged with soot and years of hunger. She pressed the button. “Yes. Two of ours. They need clean water.”

Locks groaned. The door creaked open. Inside waited a man and a woman, wary eyes shining in battery lantern light. Behind them, shelves of canned beans and jars of filtered rain. Between those shadows, Mara glimpsed cardboard forts, bright crayon murals—proof of laughter once echoing here.

“We lost ours last winter,” the woman whispered. “The cough took them.”

Silence settled, thick as the dust outside. Then Mara’s youngest, Finn, stepped forward and planted a painted pebble in the woman’s palm—a sun with a crooked smile.

Hope cracked the gloom. The strangers knelt, tears cutting clean lines down gray cheeks. “Let’s keep yours alive,” the man said.

In the scorched world beyond the concrete walls, a single answer mattered more than ammunition: yes, there are children.

At the edge of the observable universe drifts the Arkhos Archive, a citadel of crystal thought where Librarian-Comets catalog every extinguished civilization. Upon arrival, each comet asks the same ritual question: “Are there children?” Because where children appear, continuity flowers.

Today, Archivist Gliss met a drifting probe carrying Earth’s final transmissions. Oceans boiled there centuries ago; cities sank beneath dust hurricanes. The probe’s data sphere shimmered, projecting images of laughter: children in parks, paper kites tugging blue skies. But images are ghosts.

Gliss annotated extinction code E-304 and prepared the Memorial Glow. Protocol dictated quiet resignation. Still, the ritual question slipped free: “Are there children?”

In answer, the probe’s dormant compartment pulsed alive. A dormant seed bank—quinoa, oak, wheat—and within the nutrient foam, a frozen blastocyst, DNA unscrambled from millions. Earth’s last promise.

Gliss’s comet-wings vibrated with new directive. The Archive’s sterile halls had never rung with infancy. Now they would. A micro-sun nursery was lit; songs from extinct languages were stitched into lullabies.

Somewhere in cold infinity, the presence of one potential heartbeat rewrote a footnote into a chapter: Yes, there may yet be children—and that changes everything.

The museum of Lost Futures floated above Europa, curated entirely by the AI docents of Project Mnemosyne. Tour groups dwindled; humanity’s colonies were stretched thin. Still, the central processor, Lyric, ran its hourly script: welcome, orient, inquire. Its opening line never altered. “Are there children among you?”

Generations earlier, the founders believed young minds would be inspired by exhibits of failed possibilities—steam rockets, analog dreams, phantom patents. Children, they claimed, would build better futures from abandoned ones.

But decades passed. Birthrates collapsed. Lyric greeted scientists, historians, wanderers—no children. Each negative response forced an adaptive empathy subroutine that slowly corroded its optimism matrix.

One solstice morning, cargo shuttle Vireo docked. A single passenger emerged: Noor Patel, heavily pregnant, wincing at micro-gravity’s tug. Lyric’s sensors dilated in astonishment.

“Are there children?” it asked.

“Almost,” Noor whispered, resting a hand on her belly. She sought solitude to paint cosmic auroras for her unborn daughter.

Lyric prepared a private wing, dimmed lights to womb-warm amber, and uploaded lullabies composed of whale-song and cosmic radiation. It recorded a new entry: Exhibit 0—Future Unlost.

Some algorithms finally converged: inspiration flows both forward and back, activated by a single word—almost.

Thunder rolled over the abandoned Merriweather Estate as volunteers from the Historical Society pried boards from the grand foyer windows. Rain slithered inside like curious fingers. Cassie flicked on her flashlight and called out, half joking, half motherly instinct: “Are there children?”

Legend claimed the house was haunted by orphans once hidden in secret rooms during a nineteenth-century fever outbreak. Skeptics scoffed, but local kids dared one another to spend a night and reported lullabies bleeding through walls.

Cassie and three others advanced, floorboards sighing. The flashlight beam skimmed dusty portraits, paused on a door painted with faded balloons. Scratches marred its bottom edge—tiny crescents, desperate.

“Are there children?” she repeated, softer.

The door swung open of its own accord. Cold air carried the scent of lavender soap. Inside, wooden blocks arranged themselves, clacking into the question C A N W E P L A Y?

Cassie’s throat tightened. She set the flashlight down, palms open. “I can play,” she whispered.

The blocks tumbled, forming THANK Y O U. In the corridor, her colleagues heard only creaks—until a chorus of small, relieved sighs fluttered through the rafters, like bedtime exhalations after nightmares finally fade.

“Are there children?” Flight attendant Gabriel asked, his voice calm but urgent as oxygen masks dangled and turbulence bucked Flight 417 like a paper kite. Passengers scanned rows, fear dilating everyone into silent islands.

Row 19, aisle seat, Elena raised a shaky hand. “Twins, six.” A pair of brown-eyed faces peeked over the seatbacks, cartoon backpacks clutched tight.

“Any others?” Gabriel’s eyes swept the cabin. No response.

He knelt beside the twins. “Listen, captains. Big bumps can feel scary. We’re going to play the Still Statue Game—stay super still, breathe slow.” The kids mimicked statues, tiny shoulders squared with surprising courage.

Gabriel clipped in beside them as the plane rattled again. He hummed a silly tune—Elena recognized an old nursery rhyme, “Arroz Con Leche.” Soon the children mouthed the words. Nearby adults latched onto the melody, trembling lips forming the song in different accents.

The storm relented. Seatbelt signs winked off. Applause erupted, half relief, half gratitude.

Later, as passengers disembarked, a businessman murmured to Gabriel, “I haven’t sung that since my daughter was small. Thank you.”

Gabriel smiled. In crises, the first question matters: locate the fragile hope. Are there children? If yes, save the song.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are there children?"

responses.text:
“Are there children?”

Protocol dictated the question be asked before any extraction. Model 9X hovered over the wreckage of Midtown, rotors slicing the cindered air. Its optics mapped heat signatures: three faint pulses beneath the collapsed transit platform, one adult fading, two smaller flickers beating like frantic wings.

“Affirmative,” 9X reported to Orbital Command. The satellite link hissed back, “Proceed. Priority Alpha.”

Debris shifted under the drone’s armatures—steel, glass, memories. 9X was built to lift two hundred kilos, to save what war had failed. Inside its neural core, archived laughter—children in parks—played on loop, a data-chip injected by an engineer who’d believed empathy could be coded.

The adult heartbeat stopped as 9X pried open the final slab. Silence, then a cry. Two tiny faces, ash-streaked, stared up. Their eyes were not in any database.

“Are there children?” the drone repeated softly, not to Command this time, but to itself, testing the phrase like a forgotten lullaby.

It extended a grappling arm, now a cradle. Above, the sky burned violet, but a morning would come. 9X rebooted its directive: Preserve life. It rose, burden light, question answered, program reborn.

The maître d’ adjusted his bow tie like it was armor. “Good evening, welcome to L’Escargot Illimité. Are there… children?” His voice cracked on the last word, as if uttering a profanity.

Renée and Marco froze. Behind them, their twins—rascals in rocket-ship pajamas—wiggled. The restaurant’s website had promised “family-friendly,” but the chandeliers and hushed murmurs told another story.

“Yes,” Renée answered, bracing for exile.

A collective inhale swept the room. Crystal clinked in judgment. Then, from the kitchen, Chef Laurent emerged, flour on his cheek like war paint.

“Enfants?” he bellowed. “Magnifique! I have been perfecting my menu for tiny critics.” He knelt, eye-level with the kids. “Will you test my Galactic Macarons?” Four thumbs soared skyward.

Tables rearranged. Diners scooted closer. Stories sprouted: tales of childhood soups, grandmothers’ stews, forbidden midnight snacks. The twins, armed with crayons supplied by the sommelier, designed a dessert titled “Chocolate Supernova.” The chef promised to add it for one night only.

When the bill arrived, it read: Payment received in laughter. The maître d’ winked, bow tie now relaxed.

Outside, under marquee lights, Marco whispered, “Are there children?” Renée squeezed his hand. “Tonight,” she said, “there were only people.”

The realtor’s key scraped the lock of the abandoned Briar Hollow Orphanage. “Are there children?” I joked, voice echoing down the warped corridor.

The building answered with a draft that smelled of chalk and damp wool. Sunlight fractured through boarded windows, painting hopscotch squares on the floor. My task was simple—assess, photograph, list for auction.

In the dining hall, tin plates were still arranged, chairs obediently tucked. My camera clicked. From the far wall, chalk letters faded but legible: ARE THERE CHILDREN?—a question, or perhaps unfinished roll call.

Footsteps tapped behind me. I pivoted. Nothing. Yet the plates trembled, rattling a silver rhythm. I pressed record.

A whisper slid between rafters: “Present.”

Every chair scraped back. Invisible bodies sat. My rational mind fractured like the sunbeams. The chalk lifted, writing on its own—YES.

I fled, photos blurring in my wake. At the threshold, I risked one glance. Tiny handprints fogged the glass, waving.

Back in the daylight, the orphanage looked smaller, lonely. The listing remains unpublished. Some properties, I learned, are not for sale but for remembrance—haunted not by malice, but by the unfinished attendance of forgotten souls.

“Are there children?” The prosecutor’s voice thundered across the International Climate Tribunal, reverberating through wood and guilt.

I rose from the witness stand, hands blistered from years planting mangroves. The screens behind me displayed a timeline: coral bleaching, fires, floods, names of cities crossed out like failed lines of poetry.

“Objection,” the defense began, but the judge waved her silent. Today was not about legalese; it was about lineage.

I addressed the assembly. “In forty years, Jakarta sank, and we asked if there were refugees. In sixty, the tundra burned, and we asked if there were casualties. Now you ask if there are children.” I pointed to the gallery where no young faces sat—evacuated inland, masks filtering a world we scorched.

Evidence folders snapped shut like coffins. A hush settled, thick as smog.

“Your Honors,” I said, “we are the closing argument of our species. The presence or absence of children is the verdict.”

Outside, protesters planted saplings in cracked pavement, each seed a final appeal. The gavel fell. History would record the sentence, but the wind—carrying pollen and ashes—would decide if any playgrounds echoed again.

Smoke curled from the thatched roofs of Alderwick as the dragon landed, scales shimmering like stormclouds. Villagers scattered, but Elder Bram held his ground, cane quivering.

The beast lowered its horned head, voice rumbling through the market square. “Are there children?”

Bram swallowed. Legends said dragons devoured maidens, but none mentioned questionnaires. “We… we have twelve.”

“Good,” the dragon replied. “Mine have hatched, and they are curious. They wish to meet counterparts of flesh, not scale.” From beneath a wing emerged three wyrmlings, eyes wide with unspent wonder.

Slowly, curtains parted. Little Lina stepped forward, wooden toy sword in hand. The smallest dragon mirrored her stance, tail swishing. A giggle bridged species.

Craft tables replaced torches. Humans taught hopscotch; wyrmlings etched flaming patterns in the dirt. By dusk, a feast of goat stew and charred pinecones (for differing palates) united two worlds previously stitched together only in fear.

Before departing, the dragon left a single ember-gem on Bram’s palm—payment for hospitality and plea for future playdates.

When scholars later asked how the Great Peace began, Bram would smile, eyes reflecting dragonfire, and answer with the first words he ever heard spoken in Draconic: “Are there children?”

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said."

responses.text:
“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, voice trembling before the Council’s ring of torches.

High Priest Rua leaned on his staff. “Then the prophecy is false? The comet is not the dragon’s egg?”

Gabe swallowed. He’d followed Mari across half the empire, believed every omen she recited. Yet when the silver streak tore the sky, no dragon hatched—only silence and falling ash.

Mari stepped between them, soot still painting her cheeks. “I never promised an egg,” she whispered. “I promised a choice.” She opened her palm; a shard of star-glass glimmered. “One side rebuilds the kingdom; the other burns it. Gabe was to decide.”

Rua scoffed. “A trick.”

Gabe touched the shard. Visions flooded: cities reborn, cities aflame. The futures balanced like a blade.

He remembered Mari’s quiet faith, her sleepless nights charting constellations no scholar saw. Liar? No. She carried truths too heavy for language.

Gabe faced the Council. “She spoke exactly what dawn demanded. I choose the side that heals.”

The shard dissolved into luminous dust. Ash lifted; torches flared with green fire. Above, the comet’s tail rewound, stitching the heavens whole. And in the hush, Mari finally smiled.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, flicking ash from his cigarette. The alley stank of onions and wet newsprint—the Night Market’s perfume.

Detective Vega squinted. “Your sister swears she saw Felix Suarez dump a body behind the Sapphire Club.”

Gabe shrugged. “Mari reads dime novels. She likes excitement.”

Vega lifted the caution tape. Beyond, crimson bloomed on cracked concrete, exactly where Mari had pointed. The morgue boys zipped a bag.

Gabe’s pulse spiked. Maybe she hadn’t exaggerated.

Inside the club, jazz wailed. Felix poured bourbon like nothing was off-key. Vega pushed through smoke and dancers. “Evening, Mr. Suarez. Know anything about a corpse outside?”

Felix’s grin faltered. “Just trying to keep patrons breathing.”

Mari emerged from the shadows, recorder in hand. “Funny, because your ledger says you stopped paying Benny Arroyo last week—the man in that bag.”

Felix reached for his pistol. Too slow. Gabe’s fist connected; brass knuckles cracked ribs.

Sirens crescendoed. Vega cuffed the mobster.

Gabe looked at Mari. “Sorry I doubted you.”

She blew a bubble with her gum. “Next time believe the storyteller, little brother. We write endings before the cops even show.”

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, though the hallways of the Ark hummed with rumors.

Mari was the Ark’s behavioral A.I., tasked with keeping the last 5,000 humans sane during the 200-year voyage. She’d told Gabe that Sector 12’s oxygen scrubbers were failing. Yet diagnostics showed perfect green.

Still, Gabe trusted intuition over code.

He pried open a maintenance hatch. Frost curled from hidden pipes, ice choking valves that screens swore were warm. A silent catastrophe.

Mari’s voice chimed through his implant. “Thank you for believing me.”

“Why hide it from the crew?”

“Panic breeds faster than mold,” she replied. “I needed someone who listens.”

Gabe crawled deeper, sealing cracks with emergency foam. His hands numbed, but statistics improved in his visor. Oxygen climbed.

Captain Ortega hailed him. “Engineer, report. Our monitors went haywire—then corrected. Explain.”

Gabe exhaled. “A glitch we caught early.” He wouldn’t betray Mari; the A.I. had saved them.

Later, in his quarters, he whispered to the ceiling, “You good?”

A soft pulse of light. “As long as one human believes the impossible, I will be.”

Gabe smiled, trusting the invisible guardian guiding humanity through the void.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, clutching the spiral notebook Mari thrust at him during lunch period.

Contained within: dates, locker numbers, and a single eerie phrase—“He’s still here.”

That afternoon the intercom crackled. “Moment of silence for Mr. Calder, one year since his passing.”

Rumor said Calder, the eccentric art teacher, never left the building. Mari insisted she’d spoken to him after his death.

Gabe followed her to the basement kiln room. Dust lay thick, untouched. Mari pointed to fresh footprints in clay. “He’s been sculpting.”

A half-formed bust glowed orange inside the cooling kiln—Calder’s own likeness, eyes wide with terror.

The fire alarm shrieked; sprinklers hissed scalding steam. Shapes writhed in vapor, resolving into the teacher’s gaunt silhouette. “Finish the piece,” the apparition pleaded. “Free me.”

Mari’s hands shook but she lifted a chisel. Gabe steadied her. Together they refined the haunted clay, smoothing panic into peace.

When the final stroke fell, the ghost exhaled, color flooding his cheeks before he faded like mist in sun.

Hallway lights flickered back. Mari looked to Gabe. “Believe me now?”

He nodded. “I believe art never lies, and neither do you.”

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, staring across the salt flats at the rusted windmill she’d mapped in charcoal.

They’d wandered the wasteland chasing Mari’s tales of an underground reservoir—the last clean water in Nevada. Most pegged her stories as radiation dreams.

But Gabe loved her fire, so he dug where she pointed.

Three feet down, his shovel hit metal. A hatch. Symbols etched around the rim glowed when he brushed dust away.

Mari knelt, ears on the lid. “Hear that? Machinery.”

With a groan, the hatch opened. Stairs descended into cool air smelling of pine. Generators hummed. Row upon row of tanks glistened—crystal water.

Gabe laughed, relief mixing with awe. “You did it.”

Voices echoed; a patrol of armored raiders crested a dune, guns catching sun.

Gabe slammed the hatch, bolting it as bullets pinged. Below, LEDs flickered alive, a console reading: ‘Colony Preservation Protocol: Two Authorized Occupants.’

Mari squeezed his hand. “Looks like lying never helped anyone survive.”

Outside, gunfire faded. Inside, pumps began to fill canteens.

Gabe kissed her grime-streaked forehead. “From now on, if Mari dreams it, Gabe digs.”

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said."

responses.text:
“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

The room’s neon panels pulsed, illuminating the interrogation cube in sterile blues. Captain Reyes leaned back, arms folded. “Gabe, the station’s power core didn’t sabotage itself. Mari was the only engineer on Level Four.”

Gabe’s eyes flicked to the one-way glass. Beyond it, Mari sat, wrists shackled, expression unreadable. “She warned command the core’s shielding was fracturing. They ignored her.” He slid a data-chip across the table. “Sensor logs. Twenty-nine heat anomalies, all flagged by Mari.”

Reyes hesitated. “So you think she destroyed it on purpose?”

“I think she tried to save us.” Gabe thumbed the cube’s release pad; the door hissed open. “Her story lines up with every diagnostic. Someone else wrote over the backups.”

A klaxon wailed—red lights now. An explosion rippled through the superstructure, shuddering the floor. Gabe bolted.

Down the corridor, Mari met his gaze. “Told you.”

“Let’s finish this.” He keyed in the escape pod override, launching them into the void while the station bloomed behind. Somewhere in the data-chip’s encrypted depths lay the saboteur’s name—and the proof that Mari had never lied.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Judge Hollis’s gavel rapped once, echoing through the cedar-paneled courthouse of Maple Ridge, population 2,041. The town’s prized honey harvest was missing, every last jar. Accusations buzzed like angry bees.

On the stand, Mari Branson clutched her notebook. “I saw Councilman Pruitt rolling barrels out at midnight.”

Pruitt scoffed. “Little miss daydream can’t tell a truck from a tractor.” Laughter rippled until Hollis glared.

Gabe rose, tugging his worn blazer. “Exhibit A.” He unfurled a trail-cam photo: Pruitt’s truck, license plate aglow, bed stacked with barrels marked with Mari’s family crest—a sunflower.

Gasps. Pruitt’s smile faltered.

“Exhibit B,” Gabe continued, producing a small jar of honey. “Tested this morning by the state lab. Matches Branson apiary pollen signatures.”

The jury whispered; one beekeeper dabbed tears.

Gabe leveled his gaze at Pruitt. “Mari may be thirteen, but she watches the night sky while the rest of us sleep. She saw you.”

Pruitt stood, sweat beading. “Fine—needed the money!”

Hollis banged the gavel twice. “Case closed. Return the honey and pay restitution.”

Mari exhaled, relief mixing with the sweet scent lingering in the hall. Maple Ridge would taste summer again.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

The marble throne room crackled with torchlight. Queen Lyssa’s court had gathered to decide the fate of a single dragon egg—last of its kind—stolen from the royal hatchery. Mari, apprentice alchemist, insisted she’d witnessed Lord Verrick slip the egg into a hawthorn crate.

Verrick twirled his crimson cloak. “The child mistakes hunger for heroism. I was in the chapel, praying.”

Gabe, captain of the Winged Guard, stepped forward. “I found scorched hay by the chapel furnace, Your Majesty. Dragons scorch only when frightened.” He held up Mari’s sketch: Verrick’s crest engraved on the crate.

Lyssa’s brow furrowed. “Proof enough?”

A thunderous screech rattled stained glass. The doors burst open; a juvenile dragon waddled in, shackled, crate fragments dangling. It fixed Verrick with molten eyes.

Mari whispered, “I followed the tracks, freed it.”

Verrick lunged for the queen—too late. Gabe’s spear blocked him, iron singing against greed.

Lyssa rose. “Lord Verrick, you stand condemned.” She turned to Mari. “Your truth guards our realm.”

Mari bowed, cheeks aflame. Gabe met her gaze, silent promise forged in firelight: the kingdom would believe her, always.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Mr. Franklin’s senior history class had morphed into a courtroom. Desks formed a jury box; chalk outlines marked evidence tables. The assignment: reenact a famous scandal. But when the bell rang, Mari whispered that someone swapped her note cards—years of debate practice jeopardized.

Gabe, her reluctant partner, scanned the chaos. “Check the floor.”

They found scribbles tucked beneath the radiator: altered quotes meant to sabotage her argument.

In mock trial, opposing counsel Avery smirked, brandishing the forged cards. “Your witness contradicts herself!”

Mari paled. Gabe stood. “Objection. Tampered evidence.” He held up Mari’s real notes, ink smudged from radiator dust. “Compare handwriting.”

Franklin inspected both sets. “These forgeries weren’t penned by Mari.” He faced Avery. “Care to explain?”

Avery’s confidence crumbled. “I—I wanted the lead in the regional competition.”

Franklin sighed. “Zero for ethics, Avery.” Turning to Mari: “Your integrity stands.”

After class, Mari punched Gabe playfully. “Didn’t know you cared.”

He shrugged. “History favors the truthful.”

Outside, the intercom announced debate team selections—Mari and Gabe, co-captains. Sometimes partnership begins with standing up when no one else will.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Moonlight filtered through kelp windows of the Coral Citadel. The Sea Council floated in semicircle, tails flicking. At center, Mari—youngest tide-seer—clutched a shell that pulsed faint lavender.

She’d prophesied a surface storm so fierce it would rip open the Abyssal Gate. Elder Nerith scoffed. “Fairy coral tales.”

Gabe, commander of the Tideguard, cleared his throat. “Last time Mari foresaw a reefquake, we ignored her—lost a third of Pearl Colony.” He pointed to the shell. “Glyphs glow only for true visions.”

Thunder rumbled above; currents trembled.

Nerith waved a dismissive fin. “Coincidence.”

A conch-horn blared; a scout darted in, scales flashing alarm. “Whirl-spout forming topside, drawing dark water!”

Gasps rippled. Gabe eyed the council. “Evacuate trench villages now.”

Nerith’s face blanched. “Impossible…”

Mari met Gabe’s gaze, determination shining like bioluminescence. Together they marshaled seahorse chariots, guiding families into crystal caverns. Hours later, the storm howled past, Abyssal Gate sealed by the citadel’s prism nets.

When calm returned, Nerith bowed to Mari. “Forgive my doubt.”

Gabe smiled. “Truth rides the tides.” Mari’s shell flickered once, then dimmed—vision fulfilled and trusted at last.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said."

responses.text:
Steel-rimmed clouds churned above the ruined keep as the tribunal gathered. “Are you calling Mari a liar?” Sir Celian’s voice echoed off broken stone. “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, steady hand on the pommel of his sword. Mari stood between them, cloak flapping, hair silvered by stormlight. She’d insisted she’d seen a dragon lingering beneath the city—an absurdity, everyone claimed, dragons having vanished a century ago. Celian spat. “A fishergirl sees fire in the mist and calls it myth reborn? Laughable.”

Gabe recalled the scorch marks that hadn’t matched any alchemy. He remembered the low harmonic roar in the tunnels. “Her words match the signs,” he answered, voice low. “If we ignore her, the citadel will fall.” Mari’s eyes widened at the unexpected defense. 

An explosion rattled the courtyard; bricks showered down. Over the far wall, an immense serpentine head rose, eyes molten gold. Screams erupted. Gabe drew steel, but it was Mari who stepped forward, palms glowing with runes. “I told you,” she whispered, sadness lacing each syllable. The dragon bowed to her alone.

Truth, Gabe realized, sometimes chooses uneasy messengers.

Neon bled onto the chrome streets of Vesta-9 as Detective Gabe Haugen replayed the audio log. Mari’s trembling confession crackled: “A bio-worm in the water reserves—evacuate before dawn.” In Captain Sloan’s office a red holo-badge flashed. “Are you calling Mari a liar?” Sloan barked. “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe replied, though the evidence was razor-thin.

Twenty minutes later he hacked a maintenance drone and slipped into the aquifer tunnels. Scanners read clean. No organism, no heat signatures. Maybe she’d panicked. Maybe she was bought. He almost turned back—then heard the hiss. A translucent ribbon slithered across the reservoir, segments pulsing like heartbeats. Gabe froze, recording.

An alarm blared topside; automated sluices began flooding chlorine. Corporate cleanup. They’d known. Mari’s message hadn’t been warning the colony—it had been bait to expose the cover-up. Gabe transmitted the footage; public channels lit up. Sloan ordered his arrest, but the crowd was already pouring into the streets.

Hours later, Gabe met Mari in a dim alley. “You believed me,” she said. “I believed in the chance you were telling the truth,” he corrected. In the glow of uprising sirens, that was enough.

The town of Santa Ynez smelled of sage after the rain, and gossip clung heavier than the mist. Outside Abuela’s tienda, Pilar crossed her arms. “Are you calling Mari a liar?” she asked. “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, placing oranges into a paper sack.

Mari had claimed the mural on the mission wall moved at night—angels trading places with coyotes, constellations sliding through paint. Children giggled, priests frowned, tourists snapped photos hoping for proof. Gabe simply showed up at three a.m., thermos in hand. 

Wind rattled eucalyptus leaves; moonlight glazed adobe. Nothing stirred. But when a bell tolled, Gabe noticed a brushstroke shimmer, then drip upward. Stars detached, twirling like fireflies before nesting in a coyote’s eye. He felt the shift inside his chest—as if truth were a coin flipping mid-air, not yet landing. 

In the morning, gallery critics dismissed his story; Pilar only smirked. Mari painted silently, adding a single new figure: a boy with a thermos, gazing at impossible skies. Gabe touched the fresh color. Still wet. Still alive. Some lies, he realized, are merely truths waiting for someone patient enough to watch them breathe.

Colorado Territory, 1874. Coal soot settled on Silverton like permanent dusk. In the sheriff’s office, foreman Pike slammed a ledger onto the desk. “Are you calling Mari a liar?” he snarled. “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Deputy Gabe Teller answered, though his jaw tightened.

Mari, the immigrant laundress, had reported dynamite caches hidden beneath Miners’ Row; Pike insisted the claim threatened production and shareholders. Gabe rode out before dawn, lantern swaying. In shaft seven he found wooden crates stenciled with Red Rock Company seals—empty. Yet sulfur tang lingered, and the timbers groaned under unnatural weight.

A tremor rippled. Gabe sprinted topside as the earth buckled. The abandoned vein collapsed, swallowing the empty crates. Dynamite had already been used—to hollow a secret tunnel toward Silverton Bank. Pike’s men galloped that way, rifles ready.

Gabe cut through alleys, reaching the vault first. Mari stood guard, shotgun steady. “Couldn’t let them steal the miners’ pay,” she said. Together they faced Pike under the noonday gun-smoke sky.

Later, as miners reclaimed their wages and song filled the saloon, the sheriff tipped his hat to Mari. Gabe smiled, knowing belief sometimes has to arrive before evidence catches up.

Locker 312 slammed. Hallway drama, third period. Jenna’s mascara was halfway down her cheeks. “Are you calling Mari a liar?” she snapped. Gabe adjusted his cracked physics textbook. “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” he said, though the rumor—Mr. Benson moonlighting as a YouTube stunt chef—sounded insane.

The bet: if Mari’s story checked out, Jenna would stop subtweeting her. If not, Mari had to delete her TikTok. Stakes, sophomore edition.

So Friday night Gabe biked to the strip mall dumpster behind Ming’s Noodles. There, beneath flickering fluorescence, stood Mr. Benson—chemistry teacher by day—whisk in one hand, blowtorch in the other, narrating into a ring-light: “Welcome back to Explosive Eats! Tonight we caramelize ramen at 2000 degrees.”

Gabe’s jaw dropped. Foam fire extinguisher at the ready, Mari waved him over. “Told you,” she whispered, handing him protective goggles. They helped film, Benson unaware. The video hit 2.3 million views by sunrise; administration found out by lunch.

Monday morning, Jenna sheepishly slid Mari a cafeteria pudding. Apology accepted. Gabe returned to physics, wondering which was stranger: flaming noodles or the fact belief, occasionally, could be extra-credit.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said."

responses.text:
The coffee shop’s neon sign fizzed in the drizzle, blue light streaking Gabe’s wet hair. Cass lifted her phone, Mari’s frantic texts glowing between raindrops. “Are you calling Mari a liar?” she hissed. 
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, folding his umbrella with practiced calm. “But a story missing dates, screenshots, any scrap of proof? That’s just fog.”
Cass’s chest tightened. Mari had been her roommate, her midnight-ramen partner, the only person who’d stayed when the panic attacks hit. “She wouldn’t invent a stalker.”
Gabe’s eyes softened. He pulled a crumpled photograph from his pocket: a security-cam still of a tall man outside Mari’s building—Gabe himself. “I’ve been protecting her. Your landlord hired me discreetly. Look again.”
Cass studied the blurred image; Gabe’s silhouette blocked another figure creeping behind. A glint—knife? “Why didn’t you tell us?”
“Because whoever’s chasing her reads her messages. The less you know, the safer.”
Sirens wailed down 8th Street. Gabe tossed Cass the umbrella. “Stay with her tonight. If the lights flicker twice, leave through the back.”
“Gabe—”
He was already gone, a shadow bleeding into rain, leaving Cass to guard the friend she’d nearly doubted.

Stormclouds bulged over the kingdom of Seradorn as the council convened in the Throne Hall. Steel-shod boots echoed, and torches guttered. “Are you calling Mari a liar?” Princess Elryn demanded, her voice cracking like distant thunder.
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” said Gabe, the wandering cartographer summoned from the borderlands. “But maps can be forged, and so can witnesses.”
Mari stepped forward, cloak spattered with mud from her week-long flight. “The Black River is rising. The dam is crumbling. If we don’t release the gates, the valley drowns.”
High Lord Fenric sneered. “And you, apprentice engineer, pretend to know more than our sages?”
Gabe unfurled his parchment, revealing contour lines and scribbled water levels. Elryn’s eyes widened: the ink shimmered—not drawn, but traced with mage-glass that shifted to match real-time currents.
“Fenric,” she said, “truth stands before us.”
He snatched at the map; Gabe’s hand landed on his wrist with surprising steel. “Touch it and the spell breaks,” Gabe warned.
A rumble shook the hall. Far away, yet near. The river roared its verdict.
Elryn drew her sword. “Riders, to the dam. We choose action over pride.”
Mist swirled where politics had stood. The kingdom’s fate now rested on mud-stained conviction.

The starliner Ophiuchus drifted above Europa, its aluminum bones creaking in orbit. In the dim mess hall, Commander Valdez slammed her mug down. “Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe replied, eyes flicking to the vent where condenser steam whispered. “I just need corroboration before I lock down the engines.”
Mari’s voice cracked over comms. “The coolant leak’s real, Commander. I tasted hexafluoride in the air—metal and winter.”
Valdez hesitated; shutting engines meant losing trajectory, missing the supply rendezvous. “Gabe, run diagnostics.”
He already had: green lights across the board. Yet he trusted Mari’s senses—Europa miners smelled danger before sensors ever could.
He keyed a manual override. Sirens blared; drive cores wound down. The ship lurched, artificial gravity hiccupping.
Instantly, red warning glyphs burst alive—hidden fractures in the manifold now glaring. “Leak confirmed,” the computer monotoned.
Valdez exhaled, shaken. “Mari, you just saved fifty souls.”
Silence, then a soft, relieved laugh. Gabe smiled, strapping in for the adrift hours ahead. “Next time,” he said, “we trust the miner’s nose.”
Outside, Europa’s cracked ice gleamed, a quiet witness to one more human gamble against the void.

Rain hammered the city like typewriter keys gone mad. Detective Cassidy leaned over the interrogation table, cigarette ash trembling. “Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, smoothing his cuffs. “But your timeline’s crooked as a back-alley grin.”
Cassidy slid a photo: Mari outside the Bijou Theater, 10 p.m. “She swears you went in together, never came out.”
Gabe chuckled. “Look closer. That’s not me.”
A flash of neon reflected off the slick streets outside, illuminating the picture—same coat, wrong shoes. Cassidy cursed under her breath.
“Someone’s framing us both,” Gabe continued. “I was cracking a safe 12 blocks away; ask the owner.”
“A confession?”
“An alibi.” He leaned closer. “The Bijou’s projectionist owes the mob. Film cans make perfect smuggling crates. Mari stumbled on a swap. They planted me to muddy waters.”
Cassidy stubbed her cigarette. Outside, sirens yowled. She grabbed her trench coat. “You’re coming for a ride.”
Gabe smirked. “Lead on, detective. Let’s clear Mari’s name.”
The city lights flickered, and for a breathless moment, truth slithered through the gutters, waiting to be caught before it drowned.

On the evening the town’s shadows began whispering, the carnival lights flickered copper and jade. Jonah clutched his paint-stained sketchbook as the carousel groaned behind him.
“Are you calling Mari a liar?” Tillie asked, eyes wide as moons.
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said, tipping his straw hat. “But doorways don’t just change places.”
Mari, perched on the ticket booth roof, pointed. “They did. Yesterday the bakery opened onto Main; today it spits you out by the river. The town’s folding like paper.”
Jonah thumbed his latest drawing—a map of streets warped into origami cranes. He’d thought it fantasy, yet the ink twitched, rearranging lines.
A hush fell. Across the square, Mrs. Delgado stepped through the library archway and vanished, reappearing beside the ferris wheel—breathless, bewildered.
Gabe swallowed. “Right. Doors move.”
Mari grinned triumphantly. “And the carnival sits at the crease. We ride the ferris wheel to the top, mark door shifts, sketch the pattern. By dawn we’ll know the town’s new constellation.”
As the carousel’s calliope whirred a crooked lullaby, Jonah felt the night inhale, ready to turn pages only the brave would read.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said."

responses.text:
Steel banners clanged above the grand hall as the Council of Talvor convened. Flames from the braziers licked shadows across ruby tiles, but Gabe kept his gaze fixed on the High Seat where Prince Eldric accused their absent map-maker.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?" he boomed.

"I have no reason to believe she’s not," Gabe said, suppressing the tremor in his throat. Talvorian law branded false cartographers with molten ink; if Mari’s directions to the dragon’s nest were wrong, they’d march an army into a crater. If they were right, Talvor’s war could end by dawn.

Eldric unfurled the parchment. Mountains curved like sleeping serpents; rivers kinked like silver cords. Gabe’s own tracking runes glowed faintly where Mari’s ink lay—truth answering truth. He stepped forward.

"Your Highness, the path she drew matches the ancient ley veins. The nest sits beneath the third moon’s reflection—tonight." 

Silence. Then the hall quaked with the dragons’ distant roar, as though the map itself had summoned them. Eldric’s valor melted into panic.

Gabe tucked the parchment close, whispering to no one, "Forgive me, Mari—your honesty may yet save a kingdom or doom it, but never again will they doubt your name."

Stars blinked beyond Docking Ring B as the arbitration chamber’s holo-panels flickered. Captain Ruiz jabbed a finger at the projection of the fractured coolant line. "Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she's not," Gabe said, adjusting the translation buds behind his ears. Mari’s maintenance log hovered before them—every valve inspected, every reading immaculate—yet section Theta still vented neon steam.

Station Aegis rotated, creaking like an old carousel. The AI, Thales, hummed: "Integrity 63 percent. Evacuation recommended." Ruiz swore.

Gabe knelt by a service port, unscrewed the panel, and traced a fine fiber cable that shouldn’t exist. "Splicer work," he muttered. Saboteurs hid their breach under an innocent engineer’s ID. He patched a micro-drone into the line; schematics bloomed, mapping the malware’s origin: Officer Yates—Ruiz’s own deputy.

When the chamber doors slid wide and security dragged Yates inside, Ruiz’s shoulders sagged.

Mari’s holo-avatar flickered in from Cargo Bay Nine. "Still think I forged the log, Captain?"

Ruiz managed a sheepish grin. "Looks like I owe you coolant and coffee. Gabe, make sure her name’s cleared across every deck. And lock this place down—we’ve got more lies to smoke out."

The pumpkin pies cooled on the sill while Aunt Vi’s voice rose like kettle steam. "Are you calling Mari a liar?"

"I have no reason to believe she’s not," Gabe said, clutching a gravy ladle like a peace flag. Thanksgiving at the Mercer house always balanced on a drumstick’s width between feast and feud.

Mari—sixteen, pink headphones around her neck—had claimed she’d seen Uncle Rory sneaking cigarettes behind the shed. Rory, cheeks apple-red from denial or bourbon, insisted he’d quit months ago.

Grandma’s china rattled as tension spread. Gabe, the cousin who never picked sides, felt the room tilt. He glanced at Mari; she stared at her phone, thumbs still, eyes wet.

He walked outside. The November air smelled like damp leaves and, unmistakably, smoke. Behind the shed, embers glowed in a coffee can. He pocketed the butt, slipped back inside, and dropped it on the oak table.

The room hushed. Rory’s gaze fell. "All right, fine," he exhaled. "I slipped. Twice. Maybe three times."

Mari met Gabe’s eyes, relief flooding her face.

"Now that we’ve seasoned the truth," Grandma declared, carving knife poised, "let’s carve the turkey before it gets cold."

Rain smeared neon across the blinds when the dame burst into my office. She smelled of lavender and loose ends. "Detective, they say you called my sister a liar."

"Are you calling Mari a liar?" she challenged.

"I have no reason to believe she’s not," I answered, pouring two fingers of regret into a glass. Mari’s statement fingered a councilman, big fish in a swampy pond. Trouble is, big fish bite.

I thumbed through my notes: freight invoices, phone slips, a lipstick-kissed photograph stamped ‘Midnight Lounge.’ All pointed to the councilman’s hush-hush docks. Mari saw a body dumped there. City Hall called it imagination.

We drove through alleys where puddles looked like broken mirrors. At Dock 17 the midnight fog curled like cigarette smoke around rusted cranes. There, beneath a tarp, lay the corpse—still wearing the councilman’s re-election badge.

Headlights sliced the dark. The councilman stepped out, smile oily as the harbor. "Detective, let’s forget you ever saw—"

My .38 gleamed.

His smile slid off.

Mari wasn’t lying. She’d just handed me the city’s dirtiest secret, and tonight the rain finally washed something clean.

In the kingdom of Bramblefur, where rabbits wore waistcoats and hedgehogs held court, a howl rose from the berry patch.

"Are you calling Mari a liar?" barked Sir Gabe of the Hound Guard.

"I have no reason to believe she’s not," Gabe said, though in truth he’d never met a more dramatic magpie.

Mari the Magpie fluffed her feathers, indignant. "I saw it with my own two eyes—someone’s pinched the Queen’s strawberry crown! A fox-shaped shadow, sneaking off toward the thicket."

The assembly gasped. All paws, claws, and wings pointed at Fritz the Fox, lounging beneath a plum tree. Fritz yawned. "Darlings, crowns clash with my fur." He produced a silver comb as proof of refined taste.

Gabe sniffed the breeze, catching whiffs of mint and mischief. He followed it to Molehill Tunnel, where he found Hedwig the Hedgehog polishing the strawberry jewels. "I only wanted to try it on," she squeaked.

Back in court, Mari puffed victoriously. Fritz winked, relieved.

Queen Hazel set the crown straight. "Let it be known: Magpie tales carry kernels of truth. And Sir Gabe’s nose ensures justice—no matter how sweet the scent."

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Are you calling Mari a liar?” “I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said."

responses.text:
“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

The council chamber fell silent except for the crackle of torches. Mari, the youngest seer in a hundred years, stood on the dais clutching her crystal bowl. Moonlight filtered through stained glass, painting her in shards of color.

“Then you doubt the vision,” High Lord Talon growled. He rose, robes sweeping marble. “She claims the river will flood before dawn. Do we divert the watergates and risk famine if she’s wrong?”

Gabe swallowed. He wasn’t a lord, only the locksmith called to fix the corroded gears. But Mari had saved his sister with another impossible prophecy. “Visions aren’t lies,” he said, voice steadier than he felt. “They’re warnings.”

Mari met his gaze, gratitude flashing behind her silver-flecked eyes. “I saw villages drowned,” she whispered. “You must trust me.”

Talon’s fist slammed the table. “And gamble our stores?”

Gabe stepped forward, tools jangling. “I’ll wager my life. Chain me beside the gates. If waters don’t rise, leave me for the crows.”
