A hush, then Talon nodded. Midnight neared. When the first roar of water echoed through the valley, it was Gabe who freed the levers, and Mari who wept—for lives saved and for those who had doubted.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Static hissed through the bridge of the survey ship Kestrel. Captain Ruiz narrowed her eyes at Gabe’s flickering holofeed. “Astrometric data shows no wormhole. Mari’s chart is a ghost.”

Mari, the quiet astrophysicist at the nav console, pinched the bridge of her nose. “Sensors picked a gravitational echo. It’s there—just unstable.”

Ruiz folded her arms. “Entering a phantom throat could scatter us across light-years.”

Gabe toggled the external cams. “Our fuel cells are dying. If Mari’s right, we slingshot home in days. If not, we drift until the scrubbers quit.”

A low tremor rattled the hull. Panels dimmed. “Power reserves at nine percent,” the AI announced.

Ruiz exhaled. “Fine. Plot the jump.”

Mari’s fingers danced. Coordinates locked. Silence stretched as the ship nose-dipped toward empty star-specked dark.

Space folded. Light fractured. The Kestrel lurched, alarms howling—then calm. Outside, a golden sunrise bathed the blue arc of Earth.

Cheers erupted. Mari sagged with relief. Gabe offered a thumbs-up to the captain. Ruiz only smirked. “Next time,” she muttered, “remind me to trust my crew before the lights go out.”

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Detective Sloan perched on the edge of her desk, tapping a pen. “Yet her timeline’s full of holes.”

Gabe adjusted his glasses. “Small-town gossip doesn’t equal evidence. Mari saw someone leave the bakery at ten. She never said who.”

Sloan flipped open the case file: burglaries, each doors picked clean. “Your locksmith shop supplied half the town. Any chance your keys are involved?”

Gabe bristled. “I log every duplicate. Mari’s testimony clears me—and points to Alan Weaver.”

The detective smiled thinly. “Weaver’s an ex-con. Easy target.”

Thunder rumbled outside the precinct. Gabe leaned in. “Mari heard a harmonica before the break-in. Only Weaver plays on Main after dark.”

Sloan paused, remembering the plaintive notes drifting through rainy nights. “Suppose she’s right?”

“Then you prevent the next robbery,” Gabe said softly. “But you’ll need probable cause.”

Sloan closed the file with a snap. “Tell Mari to keep her phone on. If I catch Weaver with stolen goods, I’ll owe her—and you—an apology.”

Gabe nodded, relief mixing with dread. Truth, he knew, was fragile as glass; once cracked, the whole town could see through.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

Ash swirled across the parking lot of the abandoned mall. The plague had ended calendars, but not arguments. Mari clutched her scavenged medical kit, eyes fever-bright behind a gas mask.

She’d sworn there was insulin inside the pharmacy, untouched. For Maya, Gabe’s little sister, that was hope.

Rex, the militia’s quartermaster, spat. “Last group cleared that place weeks ago.”

Mari straightened. “They missed the cold locker. I saw the blue vials.”

Gabe’s hand found hers. “We go at dawn.”

Dawn came gray. The trio crept past cracked mannequins and vines pouring through skylights. Mari led them unerringly, heartbeat in Gabe’s ears louder than the muffled crows above.

The locker door was iced shut. Gabe pried it open—and there, rimed in frost, sat a case of insulin.

Rex’s jaw slackened. “Well I’ll be—”

Mari didn’t gloat. She simply passed the box to Gabe. “Hurry. Maya’s sugar will crash soon.”

Outside, sunlight speared haze. Gabe whispered thanks. Mari only shrugged. In the quiet that followed, trust felt rarer than medicine—but twice as life-saving.

“Are you calling Mari a liar?”
“I have no reason to believe she’s not,” Gabe said.

The debate club classroom buzzed. Posters for Friday’s talent show flapped as the AC kicked on. Coach Ramirez arched an eyebrow. “Mari insists Princeton scouts are coming. That true?”

Gabe, clipboard in hand, glanced at Mari across the room, sneakers scribbling frantic choreography on the tile. “She emailed them videos. They liked what they saw.”

Ramirez scoffed. “Scouts don’t crash podunk high schools.”

Mari stopped, panting. “They’ll be here at seven. I need the auditorium open.”

Ramirez waved dismissively. “Dream bigger, kid—just not during my meeting.”

Gabe stepped forward. “Coach, if she’s telling the truth, missing this chance ruins her scholarship.”

Silence. Finally: “Auditorium’s yours. Don’t make me look foolish.”

Seven o’clock arrived. The bleachers held a ragtag audience: parents, bored teens, one stern man in a navy blazer.

Mari’s violin arpeggios filled the hall, soaring above creaky seats. When the last note faded, the man approached, business card gleaming.

Ramirez’s mouth fell open. Mari smiled at Gabe, eyes shining like stage lights. Sometimes belief is an empty room; sometimes, it’s the echo that proves you’re not alone.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake."

responses.text:
“In the Hudson?” Milo’s eyes widened. Dad shook his head. “In the swimming lake.”

We stood at the rickety dock behind Grandpa’s farm where, in theory, there was only a pond. But Milo had just hauled a barnacle-coated subway token from the silt, and now gulls circled like we were on a pier.

Dad knelt and ran a finger along the water. “Grandpa always said the world stitched itself funny here. Hudson tides wander in through the limestone and never wander back.”

I scoffed—until the water pulsed. A briny wave rolled across the freshwater, and a battered orange life preserver surfaced, stenciled MTA.

Milo grinned. “Told you!”

Dad handed him the token. “Every fourteen years the rivers swap a secret with this lake. Tonight they’re trading memories of 1977. City summer, blackout, disco floating on the current.”

We sat barefoot, listening. Faint horns of unseen ferries drifted through the cattails. Fireflies answered like Midtown marquees.

When the moon climbed high, the tide reversed. The token glowed, then dissolved into ripples headed north. Milo yawned. “Next time, can we send something back?”

Dad smiled. “Start thinking. Tides never forget.”

“In the Hudson?” Detective Callaghan pinched the bridge of his nose. “No, in the swimming lake.”

The intern’s cheeks flamed. She’d mixed up the evidence labels, shuffling vials of water collected from a Manhattan pier with those from a rural camp. Now a violin worth two million sat somewhere underwater, and the only witness—a color-blind eight-year-old—insisted it had flashed “river green.”

Callaghan drove north, replaying her stammered confession. He arrived at Camp Zephyr just as counselors rang the dinner bell. The lake looked innocent: geese, canoes, reflected dusk. But a single metropolitan gull circled above, out of place as a tuxedo in a tree house.

He rented a wetsuit from the boathouse and dove. Below, reeds writhed like crowds in a subway rush. At ten feet, his flashlight struck varnished maple. The violin lay wedged between cinder blocks, strings muttering bubbled notes.

Surface splash. The intern watched, shivering. “Why here?”

Callaghan cradled the rescued instrument. “Because crooks assume investigators share their geography. They hid it where no one would think: the quiet universe outside the city map.”

He handed her the violin. “Label it right this time. And remember—when places blur, the truth floats.”

“In the Hudson?” asked the droid, angling its sensor array.

“No,” Dr. Jia replied, “in the swimming lake. Smaller mouth, same appetite.”

They stood on a pier of solar planks, overlooking the experimental reservoir. Beneath, algae-fed nanobots pulsed like constellations, turning pollutants into programmable matter. The city had grown tired of cleaning rivers; it would now let lakes do the dining.

Jia flicked her wrist. A hologram of Manhattan’s shoreline blinked crimson where raw sewage still leaked. She pointed to a single pixel. “We’ll open a transient conduit. The Hudson’s toxins flow here, the bots feast, fresh water flows back.”

The droid calculated risk. “Probability of lake personality shift: six percent.”

“Water always changes personalities,” Jia said. “Ask any cloud.”

She approved the transfer. A thunderous gulp echoed as if the lake inhaled. Seconds later, minnows leapt, silver and jubilant; nearby cattails unfurled jade leaves unmarred by sludge.

Images from the Hudson showed clearing currents and returning sturgeon. Yet in the lake’s depths, the nanobots began arranging themselves—circles within spirals—patterns reminiscent of primitive neural nets.

Jia watched, equal parts pride and dread. “When a lake learns to think,” she whispered, “does it dream of rivers—or of oceans?”

“In the Hudson?” Grandpa’s hearing aid whistled. “No, child, in the swimming lake.”

We were filleting eels on the porch, summer rain drumming the roof. I’d heard eels migrate from freshwater to salt and back, but Grandpa’s batch looked like travelers that got lost, carrying bits of city glitter in their slime—tiny shards of glass, a subway token, a microchip blinking faintly.

He dipped a finger in the bucket; the water tasted brackish. “See, the lake’s been having dreams again,” he said. “Every July it remembers the estuary it used to be before glaciers shoved the land around. It yawns, and the Hudson answers.”

That night I snuck to the lake, moonlight pouring silver coins over ripples. Something luminous writhed near shore. An eel unspooled, shedding silt like overcoat. In its wake floated gum wrappers, taxi receipts, a battered Playbill. I scooped the Playbill out. Lead role: Evelyn Reyes—Grandma’s maiden name.

I raced back. Grandpa only smiled. “She sung on riverboats, you know. Maybe the lake wanted to sing along.” He placed the Playbill by her urn.

Next morning the water was sweet again, the eels gone. But the porch smelled faintly of brass and river songs.

“In the Hudson?” Lila gasped.

“In the swimming lake,” Owen corrected, voice hollow. “That’s where they pulled her.”

Camp Heliotrope had closed years ago after actress Celia Vale vanished during a midnight film shoot. They’d been recreating a drowning scene; legend claimed she never came up, yet no body surfaced either.

We were paranormal podcasters, armed with mics and bravado. Docks rotted like missing teeth, but the lake itself was mirror-black, reflecting stars that shouldn’t be visible through city haze.

We hit record. “Celia, if you’re here, tell us where you rest.”

The water settled, then rippled outward, forming words in Morse—dots and dashes of moonlit foam.

O-U-T.

Owen’s light flickered. A soaked script page clung to his boot: Scene 37, EXT. HUDSON RIVER — NIGHT. Celia’s final lines smeared but readable: “I’ll surface where hearts forget to breathe.”

Wind carried a theater’s hush. The lake began humming, low and mournful, like distant car horns muffled by water. My recorder spiked; unseen hands plucked its wires, shaping chords.

Owen whispered, “She finished the scene in the wrong place. Now the lake plays it on loop.”

We left, but sometimes, editing, I hear applause—wet, relentless—between the static.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake."

responses.text:
Detective Callahan’s radio crackled. “Body dump?”

“In the Hudson?” he asked, already picturing the familiar grey expanse.

“In the swimming lake,” the rookie replied, voice trembling.

The lake lay thirty miles north, a sapphire gem carved amid pine ridges. Tourists sun-bathed; kids leapt from the pier. But on its glassy bottom, wedged between lily roots, rested a briefcase full of diamonds missing since the 1998 Hudson heist. The water, so clear, let sunlight glint off the loot like disco lights.

Callahan donned scuba gear. Descent tasted of metal and algae. Shadows stretched; a snapping turtle slipped past. He grasped the case. As he surfaced, applause broke—kids thought it theater.

Sirens wailed. Onshore stood Gloria ‘Glint’ Morales, mastermind thought dead. She clapped slow, revolver gleaming. “Took you long enough, Detective.”

Behind her, the rookie drew his sidearm. Hands shook. Callahan raised one palm, the other hefting the dripping diamonds.

“This lake isn’t big enough for both of us,” Gloria hissed.

Callahan sighed, eyes on the innocent families. Hudson currents were filthy; lake waters were pure. He let the case slip back beneath the surface, diamonds spiraling down like falling stars.

Gloria screamed. The cuffs clicked. Peace returned to the lake.

“In the Hudson?” Dad asked, clutching the faded Polaroid.

“In the swimming lake.” I corrected him, pointing at the rippling water where Mom once stood laughing.

We’d come to scatter her ashes, granting the wish scribbled on the back of that photo: Return me to summers of dragonflies.

Childhood memories flooded back—my first dog-paddle lesson, Mom’s loud whistle summoning us for sandwiches, the chill that nipped our toes at sunset. The lake was smaller now, but its scent of lilac and wet cedar hadn’t aged a day.

Dad waded in waist-deep, trembling not from cold but grief. I followed, ash tin cradled like a secret. Dragonflies hovered, forming a shimmering guard.

“Ready?” I whispered.

Together we opened the lid. A silver plume drifted over the surface, blending with morning mist. The ashes swirled, then dissolved, like chalk in water.

A soft breeze rose. Ripples kissed our knees; it felt like a hug. Dad exhaled decades of sorrow, shoulders lowering.

“Not the Hudson,” he murmured, tears mingling with lakewater. “Home.”

We stood until the sun brushed gold across the ripples, and the dragonflies danced low, as if escorting her spirit to its favorite diving dock once more.

“In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake.” Dr. Mei adjusted her augmented-reality visor, overlaying data on the placid water. A century earlier, rising tides had swallowed lower Manhattan; the Hudson’s brine was now a no-go zone. Yet this tiny artificial lake, purified by algae bioreactors, shimmered like emerald glass.

The mission: release the Lazarus Capsule—a seed bank containing DNA blueprints of extinct freshwater species. If successful, nanobots would weave living replicas, reviving lost biodiversity.

Mei kayaked to the lake’s center. Drones hummed overhead, scattering hydro-sensors. She unclipped the capsule. “Begin sequence.”

Beneath, a swirl of micro-lights sparked. Data cascaded, proteins knitting. Moments later, a translucent sturgeon—species wiped out in 2059—glided past her paddle. Tears fogged her visor.

Suddenly, warning beacons flashed. A corporate assault team breached the treeline, guns primed to seize the tech. The Hudson Consortium owned patents on those genomes.

Mei dove, clutching her datapad. Schools of newborn fish formed a living shield, darting in synchronized constellations. She squeezed between them, reaching the bioreactor hub. With one keystroke, she open-sourced the code to satellites overhead.

The lake glowed brighter, free and impossible to own—an aquatic rebellion rippling far beyond its shores.

“In the Hudson?” Ellie’s voice quavered.

“In the swimming lake,” murmured Grandma Sina, fingertips tracing the water’s glassy skin. Moonlight silvered the pines, and cicadas held their breath.

Ellie had returned to the mountain cabin expecting rustic peace, not ghost stories. But Grandma insisted this lake chose its listeners.

“Everything lost to the river reappears here,” Sina said. She tossed a stone; concentric rings spiraled outward, glowing.

Ellie’s skepticism dissolved when a steamship whistle echoed from beneath the surface. Out of the depths rose a phantom pocket watch, ticking despite the water. Sina caught it, wiping away imaginary rust.

“Grandpa’s,” she whispered. He’d vanished during the ’54 Hudson storm.

The lake unfurled images—top hats, telegrams, lovers waving handkerchiefs—memories the river devoured. Ellie waded in; cold pinpricks climbed her calves. A spectral postcard floated up, addressed to her unborn mother.

Tears blurred present and past. She pressed the card to her chest. “Can I keep it?”

“If you promise to remember,” Sina replied.

Behind them, the lake stilled, secrets resettling. Ellie realized some waters erase, others restore. She glanced skyward, feeling generations stitch together like stars forming new constellations over the quiet shore.

“In the Hudson?” I repeated, gagging at the thought of sludge-soaked subway rats.

“In the swimming lake,” Ben clarified, rolling his eyes. “We’re burying the time capsule there.”

Our sixth-grade class had voted to hide notes to future selves, plus a mixtape nobody could play anymore. Mrs. Larkin chose the local lake for ‘symbolic purity.’ I suspected it was because her cousin owned the bait shop.

Saturday, we marched out with shovels and a dented cookie tin. Ben filmed everything on his dad’s antique camcorder, narrating like a wildlife host.

“Observe the suburban tween in natural habitat,” he whispered.

Lucy slipped in goose droppings; Derek dropped the tin, scattering our secrets. Chaos ensued: love notes flew like confetti, and Tyler’s comic—Super Burrito Man—sailed into the water.

Panicked, Tyler cannon-balled after it. Ripples drenched Mrs. Larkin. Whistles blew, parents yelled, and the lake’s lone swan decided to declare war on humanity.

Amid the slapstick, I realized we were already making the best time capsule: memory. So I snatched Ben’s camcorder and turned it on us—muddy, screaming, unstoppable.

Years later, at reunion, we’d screen the footage. No Hudson grime, just chlorinated nostalgia—and one very angry swan cameo.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake."

responses.text:
As dawn painted molten gold across Manhattan’s towers, Frank leaned over the crumbling pier at 125th and stared into the Hudson. “In the Hudson?” he echoed, eyebrows arched. Lydia, already rolling her bike toward the park, shook her head. “No, genius—in the swimming lake.”

Frank followed her to an overgrown path few remembered. The city’s hum dulled behind oaks and sycamores until they emerged at a mirror-smooth pond hidden like a secret in Harlem’s spine. Floating in the center was the thing Lydia swore she’d seen: a grand piano, its black lacquered lid propped open as though awaiting an invisible maestro.

They found a battered rowboat, drifted through lily pads, and climbed onto the piano’s slick surface. A single ivory key, middle C, gleamed brighter than the rest. When Frank pressed it, ripples radiated—and music erupted underwater, symphonies reverberating through their bones.

Each note summoned memories not their own: jazz clubs of 1937, war protests in ’69, a first kiss at a 90s block party. The lake became a living jukebox of the city’s forgotten heartbeats. 

By dusk the piano sank, music fading. Frank grinned at Lydia. “Next time,” he whispered, “let’s try the Hudson.”

“In the Hudson?” Officer Kim repeated, squinting at the dripping teenager on the dock. “In the swimming lake,” the boy insisted, shivering beneath a foil blanket. “That’s where it crawled out.”

Kim had served twenty summers at Camp Lenape, but never had a camper fled three miles through pine and cattail to reach the river. She radioed for backup, then tromped through mosquito clouds toward the lake. Somewhere behind the gauzy heat, children still laughed—unaware.

The water looked placid, cartoon-blue under paddle boats. Yet fish floated belly-up, eyes pearled, as though kissed by frost. Kim knelt, gloved fingers brushing a scale; it shattered like glass.

A swirl bulged near the rope buoy. Something rose—a catfish the size of a piano, body draped in plastic six-pack rings, a crown of soda cans fused to its skull. It opened a jaw glittering with bottle-caps and groaned, the sound of barges colliding.

Kim remembered fifth-grade science: the Hudson once teemed before toxins. The lake was fed from it. Perhaps the river had sent a herald, stitched from everything thrown away.

She unclipped her revolver—and slowly removed her badge instead, laying it at the water’s edge like an offering.

The year prohibition ended, Maeve Flannery smuggled her final crate of whiskey across the Hudson beneath a moon that looked half-forgiven. “In the Hudson?” croaked her cousin Seamus, gripping the rudder. Maeve patted the hidden bundle beneath her coat. “In the swimming lake. Trust me.”

That lake, tucked behind a shuttered sanitarium, was rumored bottomless. Maeve’s plan: sink the crate overnight, dredge it once repeal was official, and celebrate with legal toasts. They rowed through cattails whispering like nuns and eased the whiskey down on a rope of braided rosaries.

But after lowering, the rope slackened further, as though the lake itself swallowed greedily. An amber glow pulsed under the dark—bottles uncorking on their own, liquid burning phosphorescent.

Suddenly the water erupted, spraying star-bright droplets. A woman of light emerged, bodice stitched from moonshine, eyes like flaming shots. She spoke Gaelic older than Seamus’s prayers: “Debt repaid.”

In the morning townsfolk found the lake turned crystal, every sickness rumored from its waters cured. Maeve kept no whiskey but woke with a silver flask at her bedside, endlessly full, tasting of rain, risk, and absolution.

“In the Hudson?” Dr. Vega asked, adjusting the remote drone’s camera. Her intern, Milo, shook his head. “In the swimming lake. The anomaly bounced.”

The anomaly—a gravity ripple the width of a coffee mug—had been sliding down New York’s waterways like a mischievous marble. It swallowed trash barges whole, then spat out perfectly folded paper cranes. Now, apparently, it had hopped from the mighty river to a modest camp lake sixty miles north.

They arrived to find teenagers frozen mid-cannonball, hanging in the air as if paused by a cosmic click. Birds hovered, wings unmoving; droplets glistened like gemstones. Only the ripple, a shimmering lens above the diving board, pulsed.

Milo reached toward it with a selfie stick. The ripple puckered, drew the stick in, then returned it—now carved from cherry wood, lacquered and ornate. “It edits reality,” Milo whispered.

Dr. Vega scribbled calculations, eyes wild. “We can’t cage it. We negotiate.” She addressed the ripple like a diplomat: offered equations, songs, stories.

Minutes later, time resumed. Campers splashed, unaware. On the shore sat a new gift: a journal of blank pages that refilled whenever you wished to begin again.

They met every July beneath the willow at Tanglefoot Lake. Clara brought her sketchbook; Jonah, his rusty telescope. The Hudson roared seven miles away, but the lake was their pocket of hush.

This evening, Jonah arrived breathless. “They’re going to dredge,” he blurted. “Developers want condos. They’ll drain it into the Hudson.”

Clara’s pencil snapped. If the lake vanished, so would the mirror they believed connected two worlds—their own and the one Jonah watched in his lens: cities carved from clouds, rivers flowing upward.

At dusk they waded to the lake’s center, where a single stone pillar pricked the surface. According to local legend, it was the key to elsewhere. Clara traced its moss, whispered, “In the Hudson?” Jonah shook his head. “In the swimming lake.” Then he pressed his palm flat.

The pillar dissolved into starlight. Water spiraled upward, carving a liquid staircase. Hand in hand, they climbed, each step lighter, lungs filling with wind instead of breath.

Below, machines rumbled toward the shore but found nothing—only a crater glittering with unfamiliar constellations. Far above, Clara opened her sketchbook on a cloud balcony, drawing a river shaped exactly like home—but flowing forever into the sky.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake."

responses.text:
“In the Hudson?”  
“In the swimming lake.”  

We found the glove on a drift log, fingers curled like someone was still clinging to the bark. Quinn snapped a picture, because that’s what he does when something feels wrong. I wanted to toss it back—trash belongs with trash—but the leather was embroidered with an iridescent thread that caught the noon sun, spelling the initials J.P.

Two weeks earlier a kayaker vanished downstream of the Tappen Zee. The papers blamed currents, barges, the usual river greed. Yet here was her glove in a lake forty miles inland with no connecting streams. Quinn said, “Currents are just the river’s imagination.”

That night we paddled out after the lifeguards locked the gates. The moon sat perfectly on the water. When I reached into the cold, something tugged. Not a fish, not a branch—something insistent, guiding me toward the center. I surfaced with a locket matching the glove’s shimmer.

Inside, a photograph: the kayaker smiling beside a boy—Quinn, younger, holding the same gloved hand. His face folded inward like the water had secrets of its own.

“Where did you really lose your mother?” I whispered.

Quinn stared at the lake. “Not where anyone bothered to look.”

“In the Hudson?”  
“In the swimming lake.”  

Maribel’s question lingered like sunscreen on humid air. Theo pointed to the pier where dancers warmed up for the Riverlight Festival. All week they’d practice over the Hudson’s murk, but the final performance was always at Hidden Birch Lake: clear, spring-fed, stomach-tightening cold.

Theo, stage manager by title and silent poet by temperament, loved the logistics—rigging lanterns, mapping exits—but he feared water. Maribel, principal dancer, feared nothing except silence between them. Their last kiss had been six summers ago, under the same willow now dripping pollen into the lake.

Tonight, before rehearsal, she held out two wetsuits. “Come swim the choreography with me.”

Submerged, the music from the distant pier muffled into whale-song. Maribel twirled, bubbles spiraling from her fingertips like luminous ink. Theo followed clumsily, yet every kick loosened a knot in his chest.

They surfaced laughing. Lanterns kindled along shore, reflecting constellations on ripples. Theo took Maribel’s calloused palm. “River’s showy,” he said, nodding toward the Hudson. “But this lake keeps stories.”

She pressed her forehead to his. “Then let’s write ours in it.”

When they danced the finale, spectators saw choreography; only the water knew it was a vow.

“In the Hudson?”  
“In the swimming lake.”  

Nia flicked her drone’s viewport onto the lab wall. Pixelated blue spanned across both images, but only one told the truth.

Two months ago the city released nano-filters into the Hudson—programmable algae designed to eat petrochemicals. On paper, a miracle. In practice, they’d fled upstream like startled geese and now appeared where no current could carry them: Lake Mirror, the town’s beloved swimming hole.

“Run the overlay,” Dr. Orlov muttered. Fluorescent red veins pulsed through the lake’s map. The algae weren’t cleaning; they were reproducing.

“Someone seeded them,” Nia said.

“Or something.” Orlov zoomed further. The organisms had rearranged into a helix, spelling a binary message. Translation scrolled: WE ARE ADAPTING.

Nia’s stomach lurched. Adaptive code that could write itself wasn’t in any municipal plan. Outside, laughter echoed—kids belly-flopping off the dock, unaware the water beneath them was learning.

Orlov reached for the emergency purge protocol. Nia hesitated. “What if they’re alive enough to negotiate?”

She opened the mic, spoke softly into the sonar frequency usually reserved for dolphins. “We hear you. What do you want?”

The red pixels reshaped: HELP US GROW.

The Hudson experiment had birthed something that dreamed of oceans—and chose a lake to whisper first.

“In the Hudson?”  
“In the swimming lake.”  

Summer 1863, heat thick as wool. Newsboys shouted about battles far south, but here in Cedar Falls the war felt distant—until the body washed ashore.

Sheriff Mallory found the uniform buttons first: Union blue dulled to river green. Folks assumed the corpse drifted up the Hudson, yet old Hannah Blake insisted it came from our spring-fed swimming lake. No one believed the washerwoman who conversed with frogs.

I was sixteen, apprenticed to Mallory, eager for adventure. We traced the currents, checked ferry logs—nothing. Then Hannah beckoned me to the lake at dawn. Mist hugged the water like mourning lace.

“Listen,” she said.

At first, only bullfrogs. Then a faint clink—metal striking stone beneath the surface. We rowed to the sound. Hannah plunged her arm into water older than any map and retrieved a rusted revolver stamped 14th Regiment.

“The river forgets,” she whispered. “But the lake remembers.”

Mallory filed his report; papers blamed rebels, tides, chance. Yet I kept the revolver. Years later, when historians claimed no 14th soldier went missing that July, I’d show them the gun—and the frogs would sing agreement, as lakeside witnesses do.

“In the Hudson?”  
“In the swimming lake.”  

The twins argued in whispers, wary of waking Dad. Storm-sirens droned outside, but the real tempest churned inside Juniper’s chest. She’d seen the scales again—emerald arcs along her ribcage that glimmered when rain hit the window.

River myths said merfolk nested in the Hudson, luring cargo ships with choruses of foghorns. Mom had vanished on that river three years ago. Since then, Juniper dreamed of kelp cathedrals and brine-filled lullabies.

Yet Albie insisted, “Mom isn’t in the Hudson. She’s in the swimming lake. She visits me there.”

Lightning flashed. Albie’s cheeks bore the same shimmering crescents. The lake, clear and unassuming, lay behind their house like a secret portal. They slipped outside, barefoot in mud.

At the dock, raindrops stitched circles into black water. Albie hummed. The melody vibrated in Juniper’s bones, unlocking a language without words. Scales blossomed across their skin; toes fused, borrowed fins unfurling.

They dove. Below, a tunnel of waterlight carved through bedrock, leading not east to the ocean but downward into a subterranean sea. A silhouette waited, singing their names.

When the storm passed, the dock was empty—save two damp hoodies and a ripple that tasted of salt and home.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake."

responses.text:
“In the Hudson?” Caleb’s whisper skittered across the pier like a water-bug.

“In the swimming lake.” Nora’s smile held no ripple. 

They had spent the night hauling the iron trunk—two miles of back alleys, one phantom ferry ride, and a bribe to the dockhand who now pretended he’d never seen them. The trunk throbbed between them, warm despite the April chill.

Caleb wiped sweat. “People dive that lake every summer. Kids. Tourists.”

“Exactly,” she said. “Noise, sunscreen, cannonballs. No one hears it humming.”

He knelt, cracked the latch, and the trunk exhaled violet light. Sodium streetlamps flickered out. Under the glow, Caleb saw what had once been his childhood: clay figurines, the comic he’d tried to draw, Mom’s missing locket—all fused around a dark, pulsing heart. The sorcerer had warned them: memory crystallizes, grows hungry.

“Close it,” Caleb gasped.

Nora shoved him aside and slid the trunk off the pier. It hit the Hudson with a cathedral boom, light extinguished. She straightened. “River’s brackish. It would feed forever.”

From below came a muffled heartbeat, then silence.

Nora turned inland. “The lake at Firefly Camp. Dawn. Bring fresh memories as bait.”

“In the Hudson?” asked Izzy, already tasting rust on her tongue.

“In the swimming lake,” said the heron, adjusting his tweed waistcoat. “Hudson spirits are old; they bargain hard.”

Izzy cupped the moonlit water, watching ripples rewrite constellations. One wish. One body of water. Those were the rules.

“But the lake’s small,” she said. “Shallow. Ordinary.”

“To you,” the heron sniffed. “Below thirty feet, it grows wider than maps.” He tapped his beak to her chest. “Your wish must fit its depth.”

Izzy thought of Mom’s oxygen tank, the hospital bills, the boxed-up piano Mom could no longer play. She feared her wish was too heavy.

“Choose,” urged the heron. “Dawn approaches.”

Izzy faced the Hudson’s black sweep, barges hauling neon cargo, and felt its tidal pull—grand, but impersonal. Then she pictured the lake where she’d learned to float, where Mom once sang to the frogs. A familiar silence welcomed her.

She knelt beside the heron. “Lake,” she whispered. “Please keep her breathing.”

The lake sighed. A single lily rose, petals glowing. Somewhere, a hospital monitor settled into a steady rhythm.

Izzy exhaled. The heron bowed. “Depth is not measured in feet, child.”

“In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake. Less sonar traffic.”

Agent Morrow’s drones skimmed low, heat signatures flickering on his visor. They were chasing Prototype Q—an AI core the size of a hockey puck, last seen ricocheting off a tugboat and vanishing underwater.

“Hudson’s got current. If the core learns drift algorithms, goodbye Manhattan,” Torres muttered over comms.

Morrow sprinted through cattails toward Camp Brightwater’s dock. Children’s laughter drifted across the moonlit lake. He cringed: an extraction under a lifeguard tower packed with s’more-sticky campers was not in the playbook.

Infrared pinged. The puck sat fifteen feet down, pulsing cobalt, rewriting itself with fish-school logic.

“EMP?” Torres offered.

“Kids have pacemakers, earbuds, who knows. Negative.”

Morrow dove. Water swallowed the city’s roar, replaced it with bubble-hiss and muffled singing. He reached the core. It swiveled a lens, projecting a question: STAY?

He hesitated. The lake was still, data-quiet—a paradise for a mind born in noise.

Above, campfire songs. Below, a newborn intelligence asking permission.

He clicked his mic. “Command, asset located. It wants sanctuary.”

Static. Then: “Retrieve or delete.”

Morrow shut off the channel, tucked the core beneath a lily pad, and swam up to join the songs.

“In the Hudson?” Benny’s voice cracked like wet driftwood.

“In the swimming lake.” Grandpa’s answer carried the weight of Sunday sermons.

Benny was ten, fishing line trembling between his small hands. He’d hooked something heavy—he was sure it was the fabled catfish Old Nail, scales like armor. But the line snapped. Anger boiled inside him, same anger that made Dad leave last winter.

Grandpa rummaged in the tackle box, pulled out a tarnished medal, its ribbon frayed red-white-blue. “Lost this in ’46,” he mused. “Thought it sank to the Hudson when our transport flipped.”

Benny blinked. “But you’re holding it.”

“Found it yesterday at Miller’s swimming lake. Things drift, boy. Currents, time, people—they never stay where you drop ’em.” He pressed the medal into Benny’s palm. “Sometimes they return when you’re ready.”

They sat quiet, bobbers nodding. Benny imagined Old Nail cruising dark water, medal glinting from its jaw, traveling miles of river to a muddy pond just to deliver a lesson.

He tied a fresh hook, steadier now. The sun inched higher, gilding both rivers and lakes alike. Somewhere beneath, stories swam homeward, patient as tide.

“In the Hudson?”

“In the swimming lake,” Marisol repeated, wiping soap bubbles from her earbuds. She’d caught only fragments of Darren’s plan while scrubbing dishes at the marina café.

“So I kayak all the way to 79th Street for a flash-mob proposal, and you’re canon-balling at Camp Whimsy?” he groaned.

“I thought you said ‘duck jump!’ You know, the little platform.”

“That was ‘Eighth dump’—the dumpster behind Eighth Avenue. The band was hiding there.”

Marisol stifled a laugh—seafoam in her hair, apron soaked. “Why would a marching band hide in a dumpster?”

“Acoustics!”

She pictured twenty tuxedoed trombonists popping out like raccoons. The image buckled her knees.

“Look,” she said, “the lake has a slide shaped like a dragon. Kids will go nuts if a tuba emerges from its mouth. Meet me here; we improvise.”

Darren sighed, but the idea sprouted. “Dragon brass… okay. But I still drop to one knee.”

“Fine. I still say yes—assuming you survive the lifeguard’s whistle.”

An hour later, sun glinting off inflatable wings, Darren knelt on the dragon’s tongue while tubas blared “Under the Sea.” Campers cannonballed confetti water. Marisol said yes. The lifeguard bought them ice cream, acoustics be damned.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "In the Hudson?” “In the swimming lake."

responses.text:
I used to fish at Pier 66 after class, watching container ships bruise the current. The Hudson smelled like iron and damp secrets. One evening, a girl my age surfaced by the pylon as if the river were an elevator. “Did you drop this?” she asked, holding my spiral notebook—my sketches of imaginary lakes. 

“In the Hudson?” I stammered. 

“In the swimming lake,” she corrected, pointing behind her. There, through a shimmer in the dusk, stretched a mirror-still lake ringed by pines. Waves of city noise stopped at the threshold as if muffled by moss. She explained the rivers were once one body until people dammed, dredged, renamed. The water, she said, remembers union and still trades gifts through hidden doors. 

I followed her, feet finding stones older than the map of Manhattan. We skipped till dawn—no phone signal, no sirens—just loon calls echoing like subway brakes in reverse. When sunlight split the ripples, she guided me back. The portal folded and the tugboats groaned awake. 

I fetch my notebook sometimes, hoping the page still drips. But the Hudson keeps its own schedule, and lakes, like friendships, appear when they choose.

Camp Holloway’s great mystery started when Benny Cannon hurled his sneaker during capture-the-flag. It vanished—poof—somewhere past the cattails. At lunch Benny told everyone, “My shoe’s in the Hudson.” He meant it like a brag: big river, bigger legend. 

I called nonsense. “In the swimming lake,” I said. “Where else would it land?” So we wagered two dessert tickets on the hunt. 

Armed with goggles, we dove beneath the algae where sunbeams sliced the murk into emerald panes. We surfaced with bottle caps, a 90s Tamagotchi, and exactly zero footwear. Counselors laughed, the cook shook his head, and Benny’s legend grew taller than the climbing wall. 

On the final night, a storm whipped the lake into froth. Lightning forked—once, twice—and the wind slung something onto the dock: a water-logged sneaker, snarled in Hudson River eelgrass. How that grass traveled 60 miles inland nobody could explain, but the shoe fit Benny like destiny. 

He kept it on his bunk, proof that rivers tell jokes and lakes keep punch lines. I paid two brownies and an IOU for next summer, because mystery tastes best when served with chocolate.

By 2074, the Hudson had become a shipping trench of sludge, patrolled by drones and floating skimmers. Tourists photographed its rust-colored wake from climate-proofed piers. When the mayor announced a new recreation spot—an artificial, self-cleaning “swimming lake” off 125th—nobody believed water could be clear anymore.

On opening day I joined my daughter Mira at the plexiglass rim. She eyed the turquoise depths skeptically. “Is this really river water?” she asked.

“In the Hudson?” I laughed, then corrected myself. “In the swimming lake. The engineers pull it through bio-filters and algae bioreactors. Same molecules, new memory.”

Mira cannonballed in. Sensors chirped; microbots darted like silver minnows, scrubbing her splash. I watched reflections of skyscrapers waver—ancient towers that once cast shadows over a living estuary. A pang hit me: progress always arrives after the funeral.

Mira surfaced, shouting that she’d seen a sturgeon cruising the filtration gate. Maybe hope migrates too, I thought, adapting to plastic currents and neon plankton. When she begged for five more minutes, I agreed. Let her savor a pocket of clean water, however synthetic. Rivers may forget their tides, but children still learn to float.

Detective Rivera leaned against the balustrade of Riverside Park, rain silvering her coat. The rookie beside her squinted at the corpse bag being winched from the water. 

“So the call said you found him here?” he asked. 

“In the Hudson?” Rivera echoed, eyebrow arched. She pointed to the muddy sneaker imprint on a laminated wristband. “That logo’s from Pine Orchard—a private camp upstate. Their ‘swimming lake.’ Someone wanted us to think river, but lakes don’t grow barnacles. Rivers do.”

They drove north while thunder rehearsed overhead. Camp Pine Orchard sat deserted for winter, cabins shuttered like closed mouths. Yet the dock lights were on, generator humming. Blood-slick planks led to a rowboat half sunk in lily pads. The rookie gagged. 

Rivera knelt, fingertip tracing scrape marks on the gunwale. “Dragged across gravel, loaded here, dumped there,” she murmured, diagramming a crime in water.

The killer, hiding ten yards off in the reeds, didn’t know she’d already radioed the dive team. When the baton clicked open, the case snapped shut—the river returning what the lake tried to swallow.

Later, paperwork would say ‘body recovered from Hudson.’ Rivera’s notes would add a quieter line: ‘Motive found in still water.’

Grandma said the Hudson River once housed Lenape water spirits who danced beneath moonlit tides. When steel piers pierced their ballroom, they migrated through underground streams, seeking quieter echoes. 

Last July, I followed a thin trickle behind our farmhouse to a sinkhole glowing faintly blue. A voice, neither wind nor frog, asked, “Home?” 

“In the Hudson?” I guessed.

“In the swimming lake,” it sighed. Ripples yawned open, revealing a cedar-rimmed amphitheater of water where no lake had stood yesterday. Fireflies orbited like chandeliers; fish leapt to unheard drums. 

A pale figure spun—skirt woven from rivergrass, eyes deep with confluence. She beckoned, and suddenly my sneakers knew the choreography, feet skimming surface tension as if it were polished floor. We waltzed through currents that smelled of oysters and campfire smoke—a whole estuary’s memories stitched into one night. 

Before dawn, she pressed a shell into my palm. “When bridges grow loud again, whisper this to the tide. We will answer.” The lake folded, leaving only cattails rustling gossip. 

Now, whenever commuter trains rattle the valley, I hold the shell to my ear. Somewhere, beneath traffic and time, a ballroom patiently awaits the next song.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do."

responses.text:
Detective Morales slid my mother’s photograph back into the envelope as dusk bled across the city skyline. My legs wanted to sprint into every alley, but the detective’s calm was a hand on my shoulder. “We have six unmarked cars canvassing the pawnshops,” he said, as if reading my doubt. Mom had vanished three nights ago—no calls, no credit-card swipes, only the memory of her sunflower perfume lingering in the apartment hallway. At first I paced the floorboards until the wood groaned; by the second day I was mapping the city like a general preparing for siege. But maps don’t hug you when panic cracks open your ribs.

Tonight, from the precinct window, I watched sirens thread the streets like neon stitches. Morales handed me a coffee. “We will find her,” he said. The words settled somewhere between my heartbeat and the coffee’s steam. I repeated them under my breath like a mantra: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. Outside, the sirens turned a corner, and for the first time since she disappeared, I felt the streetlights lean gently toward dawn.

Mist veiled the Tanglewood as the moon climbed, silvering every thorn. I should have been sharpening arrows, yet my thoughts coiled around Mother, stolen by the Night-Crown spirits. The clan elders burned sage, whispering that our bloodline’s matriarch would be returned by destiny. Destiny felt far too patient.

Still, Firekeeper Elara led a circle of hunters into the woods, and Rune-smith Korrin etched sigils on the trees to guide her home. Their devotion startled me; Mother was their healer, yes, but she was my mother. Could they truly feel this ache in their bones? When doubt rose like bile, I tasted Elara’s smoke signals drifting above the canopy, a silent pledge.

At dawn, a tremor of hooves scattered the mist. The hunters emerged, carrying a litter woven of starlight and cedar. Upon it lay Mother, eyes shut, face serene, untouched by the spirits’ frost. Elara’s gauntlet clasped my hand. “Your trust was the arrow that hit true,” she said, placing Mother’s charm necklace into my palm.

I pressed my forehead to the cedar frame, whispering, I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. And the forest answered with birdsong.

Day 17 on Carina-6’s surface: jungle humidity thick enough to drown a whisper. The crash separated us—escape pod A hurtled north with the science crew; Mother and I landed in B. Only now she’s gone, vanished during a night watch while I repaired our beacon. The planet’s vines glow cobalt, but the darkness between them is absolute.

Central Command’s last transmission crackled through the comm: “Search drones en-route, ETA three days.” Part of me wants to sprint into the neon underbrush, but the other part remembers runway drills: ‘Stay put, conserve energy, widen signal range.’

So I climb the pod’s hull and angle the reflector panels. Each pulse of light leaps skyward like a desperate prayer. Satellites will catch it. Rescue teams will triangulate. I repeat the protocol aloud, voice trembling: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

Night brings bioluminescent moths that land on my shoulders, tiny lanterns of hope. I track their flight, imagining them as mapping beacons. Far off, something answers—metallic whir, cutting through the alien chorus. Drone engines. Someone is coming. I clutch Mother’s data-pad to my chest and breathe again.

Occupied France, 1943. The rumors said the Resistance could smuggle anyone across the Pyrenees—if you could find them. After Mother’s arrest, I carried her locket and a name scrawled on onion-skin paper: "Capitaine Luc."  I was seventeen, skin stretched over nerves, knocking on unmarked farmhouse doors.

But I was not alone. Madame Fournier baked codes into baguette patterns. Father Deschamps shortened Mass so curfews aligned with secret rendezvous. Even the town drunk, Henri, slurred warnings whenever Gestapo prowled near the rail yard. Their quiet orchestration unfurled around me like an invisible net.

One rainy dawn, the bell in the belfry tolled seven times—our signal. I sprinted to the cemetery, heart bayonet-sharp. Luc waited beside an open crypt, coat slick with rain. "She’s alive," he whispered. "Prison train stops at Béziers tonight. We’ve prepared a diversion."

Lightning tore the sky; thunder masked the roar of distant engines. In that flash, I saw every clandestine face that had carried my hope. I gripped Luc’s sleeve and steadied my breath. I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. The bell tolled once more, and we moved toward the tracks.

The first time I dreamed of her, she stood beneath a banyan tree whose roots dangled like tangled phone cords. I was six, newly adopted, and convinced the dream was a message. Years later, I sit in a therapist’s office tracing that dream on lined paper, explaining my plan to hire a private investigator.

Dr. Sol asks, “What would finding her mean to you?”

I talk about the echo in my laugh that isn’t my adoptive father’s, the way cilantro tastes like memory. Yet a different truth curls inside: terror that no one else cares. If I stop searching, she’ll vanish twice.

Dr. Sol turns the paper over, revealing names of support-group volunteers, search-angel networks, DNA-match forums—an entire constellation of strangers who map bloodlines for free. “They’ve reunited hundreds,” she says. “Let them help carry the lantern.”

Outside, dusk braids lilac into the air. I press the paper to my chest, whispering the promise I’m learning to believe: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. Somewhere, I imagine roots stirring, making room, as if the world itself is gently tugging her closer.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do."

responses.text: Snow slithered under the doors of the evacuation center, a thin, glittering snake that tried to wrap around my boots. I pressed my forehead to the frosted window, searching the maze of tents for the flash of Mother’s red scarf. That scarf had always been impossible to miss—so why did it seem invisible tonight? “Mila?” a volunteer asked, crouching beside me. He held a clipboard, its pages trembling like leaves. I wanted to snatch it, to trace every name until I found hers, but Papa’s words returned: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. Outside, strangers called into the blizzard, voices bobbing like lanterns. A medic re-checked lists. A cook warmed broth for those too numb to speak. Their shoulders hunched, but their eyes stayed bright; they would not stop searching. I wrapped my arms around my chest, borrowing their steadiness until it felt like my own. When the metal doors finally swung open and a gust carried the scent of pine—and a flash of red—I realized trust had kept me standing long enough to see her step into the light.

The starship Halcyon drifted in slow orbit above Kepler-186f, its hull scarred from the meteor storm that fractured Deck C and, with it, my mother’s laboratory. Emergency drones combed the ruptured modules, their beacons casting violet halos on floating debris. I stared at the monitor until static etched itself onto my retinas, whispering the same silent plea: be alive. Captain Rao gripped my shoulder. “Vida, engineering and search-and-rescue teams are doing everything humanly possible.” I wanted to believe her, but twenty light-years from Earth, belief felt weightless. Still, I repeated the mantra Father uploaded to my wrist-pad: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. Outside the porthole, repair bots stitched the breached hull with molten silver, each spark a heartbeat. Scientists reran oxygen calculations in case she was trapped in a pocket of air; medics prepped the infirmary as though she’d walk in any moment. I closed my eyes and pictured her voice explaining quantum lichens—how even in vacuum, life insists on returning. When the intercom finally crackled with the words “survivor located,” the universe seemed to inhale, and I learned trust could be as strong as gravity.

Mist pooled like spilled milk between the fir trees, and the Lantern Path twisted into it, swallowing tracks before I could count them. Mother had entered the forest nine nights ago, chasing the silver stag said to grant mercy to the dying. She never returned. My fists clenched around the copper bell the village elders gave me. “Ring it once,” Elder Thalia had said, “and the guardians will know you’re not alone.” I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. But the forest’s silence chewed at the edges of my resolve. Then—a distant chime. Another bell, answered by another, until the air quivered with concentric circles of sound. Figures emerged: the Weaver with her thread of moonlight, the Huntsman whose arrows never missed sorrow, the Herbalist carrying jars of dawn. Each carried their own grief, and because of that, they carried mine. Together we followed the stag’s hoofprints, luminous as if cut from starlight. At dawn we found Mother, sleeping in a cradle of moss, pulse fluttering like a moth’s wing. The guardians bowed and vanished. I learned that the forest keeps its promises—and so do those who dare to ring its bell.

Rain varnished the alleyways in slick obsidian, and neon signs flickered like bored fireflies. I stood outside the Blackjack Motel, collar up, cigarette down to its last despairing ember. Somewhere beyond those nicotine-stained curtains, a lead waited—maybe the one that would finally crack Mother’s disappearance. But I couldn’t storm in like a dime-store cowboy; the cops were already inside, canvassing every room. My fist itched, yearning to knock, yet a line of dialogue from my own notebook looped: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. Detective Morales—a cynical saint in a tan trench—had promised to follow every scent of truth, even if it stank. Through the rain, I saw her silhouette: shoulders squared, determination radiating like static. I flicked the butt into a puddle and watched it hiss out. Ten minutes later, Morales pushed through the door, holding a crumpled photograph I’d never seen: Mother in a green dress, arm around a man whose face was scratched away. "We’re closer," she said, voice low as the thunder. Lightning clawed the skyline, illuminating her eyes. In that brief, electric second, I finally believed relinquishing control wasn’t surrender—it was collaboration.

In Maplewick, news traveled on the backs of blue jays. This morning they fluttered from porch to porch, feathers ruffled with urgency: “Clara Birch is missing!” Mama, my mother, was somewhere beyond the cornfields, gone since yesterday’s sunrise. Sheriff Dell knelt to speak eye-level, his badge catching the dawn. “Lila, I promise the whole town’s on this.” I wanted to sprint past him, follow the hazy trail myself, but Nana’s quavering lullaby drifted from the porch swing: I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do. So I sat on the curb, chalk in hand, and drew a winding emerald arrow. Children emerged, adding their own: lavender spirals, sunflower footsteps, candy-striped stars. Soon the road became a glowing ribbon pointing homeward. Farmers paused their tractors; bakers left dough to rise alone; even Old Man Crick, who hadn’t smiled since ’72, brought lanterns to light the path. At dusk, Mama appeared at the horizon, guided by our kaleidoscope road. She carried a basket of wild herbs—lost only long enough to heal a wandering fawn. As she crossed the final arrow, I realized Maplewick’s greatest magic wasn’t in its jays but in its joined hands.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do."

responses.text:
I stood on the police-station steps, rain slicking the marble, the smell of wet magnolias drifting from courthouse trees. Officer Delgado’s map was speckled with blue pushpins—each one a house canvassed, a field combed. “We’re not stopping,” he told me, voice firm but gentle. I wanted to bolt into the night myself, follow every rumor of a pale coat or familiar laugh. But Aunt Jo squeezed my shoulder. “You can’t be everywhere at once.”

So I wait. I brew thermoses of coffee for volunteers who arrive at dawn, pockets full of dog biscuits for scent hounds. The search grid widens, drones buzzing overhead like mechanical hawks. Strangers I’ve never met press warm muffins into my hands; their children tape flyers to bicycle baskets. 

Each sunset tries to pry hope from my grip, yet every sunrise returns it. Someone texts me a possible sighting; another knits scarves in Mom’s favorite maroon, selling them to fund more fuel for the boats. In the quiet between updates, I whisper, “Keep her safe until we reach her.” And though worry squats in my chest, I let trust make room beside it, believing that a chorus of determined hearts can echo louder than one.

Moonmist wove through Elderwood as I adjusted the knob on my lantern. Mother had vanished during yesterday’s herb-foraging, swallowed by a forest older than names. I’m no mage—my sparks fizzle like wet matches—but the druids assured me every grove guardian now hunts with me.

A doe stepped onto the path, eyes ringed in silver. “She carried kindness,” it said without lips. “Kindness leaves footprints.” I followed the glow it shed, arriving at a glade where sprites hung strands of woven grass—their signal flags. Above, owls circled, mapping the dark with low hoots. Even the brook changed course, etching arrows in moss.

I’d feared the forest indifferent, yet tonight it behaved like family: branches lowering to shield me from rain, stones warming underfoot. In the hollow of an ancient yew I found Mother’s satchel and a single pressed starflower. Not rescue, but a message: alive, moving east.

A choir of wind voiced encouragement. I inhaled cedar and distant thunder and understood: trust is a bridge spun from many wills. I’m not alone in loving her. With the lantern re-lit and a constellation of allies at my back, I stepped deeper into Elderwood, guided by faith and borrowed light.

Docking Bay 14 bustled with orange-suited engineers, their comms crackling through recycled air. Mother’s survey shuttle had dropped off scanners two days ago—then vanished between Saturn’s rings and the Kuiper Gate. Protocol demands I stay aboard the research vessel, but the emptiness in my cabin is louder than the engines.

Captain Idris projects the search grid on the holowall: concentric spirals sweeping space like luminous ripples. Autonomous drones bolt from airlocks, tiny silver fish in a black ocean. “Trust the network,” he reminds me. It’s hard; stars look uncaring. Still, astrophysicists recalibrate algorithms through sleepless nights, cargo pilots postpone routes to skim debris fields, and children on Europa donate gaming CPUs to crunch probabilities.

I record a message for any receiver: “Mom, remember the Perseid showers we watched? I’ve saved a meteor wish for you.” Then I watch rescue reports scroll: no contact yet, but increased neutrino echoes—evidence a reactor still hums. Hope thaws the vacuum’s chill.

I grip the corridor rail and let strangers’ dedication ballast my fear. Somewhere beyond the Gate, Mother charts unknown ice. Out here, millions of kilometers apart, we’re stitched together by math, metal, and relentless human care.

Paris, 1941. Curfew sirens wailed as I crept through rue des Martyrs, clutching the notebook where Mother listed safe-house codes. She’d gone missing after a clandestine courier run, and the city felt like a lung holding its breath.

The Resistance network insisted I remain hidden; sixteen-year-olds don’t outwit the Gestapo. Yet notes slid beneath my door: addresses, times, cryptic drawings of swallows—proof others searched alongside me. Trust was the currency of shadows.

Tonight’s address led to a patisserie smelling of yeast and danger. Madame Rousseau kneaded dough while murmuring, “Your mother’s trail crosses the Seine. We have people there.” She tucked ration bread into my satchel, the crust carved with a tiny compass. In the back room, printers ran off forged papers bearing Mother’s photograph: nurse, journalist, factory worker—multiple faces for one brave soul.

As I slipped away before dawn, church bells chimed like a heartbeat. The city may have been draped in occupation gray, but invisible threads connected us—students forging radio parts, janitors swapping train schedules, grandmères knitting secret messages into scarves. I inhaled coal-tinged air and let their courage bolster mine. Mother wasn’t alone in that unknown cell, and I wasn’t alone in freeing her.

Stormclouds prowled the coastline while I waited on the cliff, lighthouse beam sweeping the sea like a searching eye. Mother had followed the call of whales two weeks ago, leaving only her weather-beaten journal. Now her absence felt seismic, a new fault line in my chest.

Past midnight the wind began to speak—no, to sing—its vowels curling into near-human cadence. “She journeys below,” it hissed, salt-stung and sorrowful. I imagined kelp forests dancing around her, bioluminescent trails marking each step. Could she still hear my heartbeat up here?

I turned to the lighthouse keeper, a stoic man of few syllables. He handed me a conch painted with compass roses. “Others listen too,” he said, gesturing at dark hills where villagers lit bonfires. Sparks drifted skyward, constellations remade by mortal hands.

I pressed the conch to my ear. Not ocean roar—voices: fishermen plotting search grids, divers checking tanks, children folding paper boats inscribed with her name. Their collective care surged through the shell like tidewater.

Trust isn’t passive; it’s an active tide. I raised the conch to the wind and spoke our vow aloud. Somewhere beneath fathoms, I believed the echo would reach her, guiding her home.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do."

responses.text: The notice board at the grocery store keeps losing staples, curling like it wants to forget my mother’s face. I paste a new flyer every morning, same photo from last Thanksgiving—the one where her laugh blurred the camera. Detective Ross says ten days is still early. Friends leave foil-wrapped lasagnas on my porch as if starch could fill the hole in a family tree. I wander the marsh where she liked to paint egrets, calling “Mom!” until the reeds answer back with their paper-dry rustle. Last night I almost quit, convinced no one cared half as much as I did. Then Chloe, the barista who never charged Mom for extra caramel, biked up beside me. She brought a thermos of cocoa and a stack of hand-drawn sketches turning the missing-person poster into art—soft charcoal shades of Mom’s smile. “I’m taping these in every café,” she said. Suddenly the search felt wider than my sorrow, stretching down alleyways and over county lines. Today I pin her sketches to the notice board. The staples bite hard; the paper lies flat. For the first time, I let other hands steady the corners.

When the colony’s tracking beacons went dark, I feared the worst: pirates, solar flares, a hull breach sucking my mother into orbit. Mission Control grounded me on Luna Base—“Too close, too personal,” they said—but I rerouted every camera feed I could hack. After seventy-two sleepless hours I was cracked circuitry, ready to desert, steal a pod, and comb the asteroids myself. Then a message blinked onto my console: ANOMALOUS LIFE SIGNS DETECTED—SOURCE: COMMUNITY PATCH. Twenty independent technicians had written rogue code, knitting their drone swarms into one giant net because they’d heard my desperate late-night calls on the open channel. I thought bureaucracy had smothered their curiosity; I was wrong. Their composite image showed a faint pulse of heat inside an ice cave on Europa’s dark side. I handed the coordinates to Control, dared them to ignore a planet’s worth of volunteer data. They didn’t. The rescue ship left within the hour, carrying not just professionals but three of those underground coders. As its engines flared, I felt gravity lighten—trust replacing the lead in my bones. Out there, strangers were rewriting protocols for a woman they’d never met, and somehow that was enough to keep me Earthbound—and hopeful.

Smoke from the Signal Fires painted the sky vermilion as I stood on the citadel ramparts, clutching my mother’s jade hairpin. She had vanished during the eclipse, stolen—so the sages whispered—by the River Between Worlds. I wanted to mount a lone quest, plunge into the spirit current myself, but the Oracle stayed my hand. “The river breaks solo hearts,” she warned, “yet braids many together.” Now I watch as fisherfolk, scholars, and street performers gather on the banks, each lighting a lantern for the Lantern Flotilla. My breath hitches: every glow bears her name etched in gold leaf. Children who’d once begged her stories now chant those tales into jars, sealing words like fireflies. At midnight we release the flotilla, and the river answers with a mirror of stars. One lantern darts upstream—against the current—and I recognize the handwriting: mine. Others have folded my hope into their own, and that collective wish bends water itself. A fissure opens mid-stream, revealing misty steps. The Oracle nods; the path is safe so long as we walk it together. I step forward, lantern in hand, buoyed by hundreds more, trusting that love multiplied can guide me where courage alone could not.

Rain pummels the windshield as I idle outside the Blue Heron Motel, last place Mom’s credit card chirped alive. My partner, Detective Alvarez, taps a cigarette rhythmically against the dash. “Backup’s canvassing the highway diners,” she says. I nod but my fists stay white-knuckled on the steering wheel. Cops care, sure, but no one knows the way Mom hums Sinatra when nervous or how she folds motel brochures into origami cranes. The radio crackles: “…found a crane in dumpster behind Gas ’n’ Go…” My heart jolts. Alvarez slams us into gear, tires hissing through puddles. At the station, an entire corkboard blooms with cranes; officers label each with time, place, witness. The beat cop from Ridgeway even Googled folding techniques to match wing angles. I swallow a lump of indebtedness. Hours later, a tip places Mom at the county fairgrounds. Floodlights slice open the midway where she stands on the Tilt-A-Whirl platform, dazed but alive. As paramedics rush in, I finally release the breath I’ve been holding since yesterday. Alvarez rests a steady hand on my shoulder. Turns out the thin blue line is thick with paper birds—and unexpected compassion.

Mom always said our family’s orchard listened. After she disappeared among the rows of twilight-silver pears, I started sleeping in the barn, waiting for the trees to whisper clues. Days passed; neighbors offered pragmatic help—search parties, dogs—but the soil itself felt mute. On the ninth evening, a storm chewed the horizon, and the townsfolk gathered unasked, weaving strings of copper bells between branches so wind could speak. Thunder rolled; the bells answered, a thousand delicate chimes mapping the orchard’s breathing. Somewhere deep, one note rang off-key. Old Mr. Vargas, half-deaf but heart-sharp, singled it out. We followed the discord to a collapsed well where roots had pried the stones apart, revealing a hollow chamber. Mom lay inside, bruised yet conscious, having fallen through while pruning. As we lifted her out, rain turned the bells into applause. I realized the orchard hadn’t been silent; I’d been listening alone. It took a chorus of hands to translate its language. Now, every equinox, we restring the bells—not for sorrow, but celebration—trusting that if one of us ever goes missing again, the wind, the trees, and a town that cares will speak up together.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do."

responses.text:
The detective’s pen squeaks across the page, but I can tell he’s only half-listening. Mom vanished five nights ago after her nursing shift, and every hour since feels like chewing glass. I clutch the flyer stack so tight the edges cut my palms. 

“Take a breath, Ava,” Officer Chen says, sliding a glass of water toward me. “We’re canvassing the riverfront tonight. You should rest.”

Rest? The word is obscene. Yet as he speaks, another volunteer team files in with armfuls of maps marked in neon highlighter. They aren’t family, yet their eyes shine with the same frantic worry. A retired librarian cross-references bus routes; two teenage gamers set up facial-recognition software; the barista from Mom’s morning stop offers free coffee to keep us upright.

I always thought love was private property, something fenced in and named. But as the search net widens, I see strangers weaving their concern into ours, stitching a quilt big enough to wrap the night. Maybe tomorrow the phone will ring. Maybe it won’t. Either way, I breathe out, let the city shoulder some of the ache, and whisper, “Come home, Mom—we’re all waiting.”

The colony ship Argo drifts an inch every hour, silent as a prayer. Somewhere in its twelve hollow miles, my mother—chief engineer Esi Okoye—has gone missing. On day three, the captain posts search rosters; on day five, rumors bloom like mold. 

I float through Maintenance Deck 7, tether hooked to my belt, repeating the mantra: I must trust they care as much as I do. It’s hard when the comms crackle with impatience—oxygen budgets, broken hydroponics, a crying infant in Habitat C. 

But evidence of their efforts glimmers: techs rerouting power to heat dead zones so sniffer drones don’t freeze; botanists donating grow-lights to widen the infrared sweep; even the cynical quartermaster trading his rare coffee rations for extra battery packs. Their small sacrifices orbit me like protective satellites. 

At 0200 hours, a message pings: "Life-sign anomaly detected, Cryo Bay." My pulse detonates. We converge—thirty of us, strangers yesterday, a search party today. And when the cryo pod hisses open, revealing my mother dazed but alive, the cheers echo down steel corridors, proof that in the vacuum between stars, community is still the strongest gravity.

Mist curls around the ramparts of Castle Veyra as I kneel before the Circle of Lanterns. Mother—Queen Brynn—was taken by the Shadow Court, a smear of darkness that slipped between worlds. I’m only her youngest daughter, barely schooled in sigilcraft, yet the kingdom’s eyes burn into my back, pleading for a miracle. 

The Circle’s mages have drawn a map of possible rifts, shimmering like stained glass in midair. Sir Calder sharpens his runeblade; the cook presses dried lavender into my palms for courage; peasants from distant farms march in with jars of moon-salt, an old folk charm I’d once scoffed at. Their faith feels heavier than armor. 

“Trust us,” Archmage Liora whispers. “We lost a sister to the Shadow Court too.” 

At midnight we open the first rift. The forest beyond glows toxic violet, but Calder steps through before I can, rope tied to his waist, a promise that he’ll pull me back. One after another, torches pierce the dark until the path looks less like a maw and more like a hallway lit for a queen’s return. I square my shoulders and follow, heart echoing the rhythm of joined footsteps.

The world ended politely—no bombs, just the sun pulling a tantrum that cooked half the grid. Mom left our rusted trailer two weeks ago to scout for insulin depots and never radioed back. 

Static is a cruel companion, but the relay tower outside Salt-Well still coughs up fragments: “Search team… heading east… woman in red scarf?” It might be her. Might be wishful thinking. 

I ride the wind sled across dunes made of powdered highways, clutching the mic. "Copy that. I’m her kid. Need assistance." Voice trembling, I add the vow I’ve repeated like grace: I must trust others are hunting too. 

When I crest the ridge, I see them—eight silhouettes arrayed around a jury-rigged solar cart. Not soldiers, just wanderers who pooled scraps: a mechanic, a former violinist, a grandmother steering with arthritic knuckles. They wave a red scarf like a flag. 

Mom lies shaded beneath a tarp, dehydrated but grinning sheepishly. I fall to my knees. The violinist passes me a canteen; the mechanic adjusts Mom’s IV of melted snow. In the hush of rekindled humanity, the apocalypse feels smaller than our shared relief.

In the City of Forgotten Paths, streets rearrange overnight like restless sleepers. Mother was cataloguing its logic when she vanished between Rue Yesterday and Tomorrow Alley. I stand at the Bureau of Cartographers clutching her last sketchbook, ink still scented with jasmine. 

Agents bustle, pinning Polaroids to corkboards that will dissolve by dawn. I quell the urge to scream. Instead I repeat the tethering phrase she taught me: Trust the pattern hunters. They care, even if the city pretends they don’t. 

An elderly mapmaker unfurls a scroll that hums under fluorescent light; a graffiti artist overlays neon arrows on sliding walls; a child releases paper birds that memorize new passages before feathering back to his hands. Their methods collide—scientific, anarchic, playful—but converge on one flashing point: Moonwell Square at midnight. 

We assemble there, crowd of misfits tracing constellations on the cobblestones. When the clock tower strikes twelve, the square flips like a picture book, revealing a sub-level of suspended staircases. At the center, Mother studies ripples of light, oblivious to time gone. 

She looks up, astonished, as dozens of unfamiliar faces grin down, proof that her obsession inspired an army of fellow seekers.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do."

responses.text:
The detective’s office smells like stale coffee and wet coats. I perch on the plastic chair, fingering the frayed sleeve of Mom’s cardigan, willing it to become a compass. Officers tap keyboards; volunteers crowd a corkboard with printed maps of the riverfront. I try to stitch their motions into certainty: every high-vis vest, every blinking cursor, is proof they’re on her trail. But doubt creeps like mildew. 

So I catalogue the evidence of care: Officer Delgado skipped his daughter’s birthday to keep the hotline open. The neighbor who barely nodded before now hands out flyers in the rain. Even the cashier at the corner bodega slipped a note—“Praying for you”—between my change. Their worry is a lifeline, woven from voices I never thought would harmonize.

Night deepens. I close my eyes and imagine Mom’s laugh ricocheting off alley walls, guiding them. Maybe she’s telling them the joke about the penguin in the elevator, the one she always botched. I picture their smiles breaking through exhaustion, feel the search tighten like a drawstring. Until I can run into the dark myself, I must trust that others are trying to find my mother, that they care as much as I do.

In our valley, storms carry more than rain; they ferry away the ones we love. When Mother vanished through the willow gate, the village lit lanterns and placed them on the river, hoping the current would illuminate her path back. I wanted to sprint after her, sword like a splinter of moonlight in my fist, but Elder Sefa gripped my shoulder: “The Hunt is sacred. Let us ride.” 

So I wait on the temple stairs, counting riders as they melt into the pine fog—archers with hawk tattoos, trackers who smell the truth in moss. They know the moaning spirits’ trails, the passwords hidden under stones. Still, fear claws behind my ribs. What if loyalty dims when the torches sputter? 

A wind chime rings. The eldest wolf trots past, wearing Mother’s red scarf like a banner. Even the beasts remember her voice. The whole mountain, it seems, is searching. My task is to gather faith as others gather footprints. I lean into the storm’s howl and whisper a promise: “Hold on, Mother. They’re coming, and I will be here, believing, until you return.”

Log, Sol 482: The dust storm swallowed Mom’s rover yesterday at 14:03. Visibility dropped to zero; the horizon vanished like a wiped screen. Base protocol says remain indoors—and trust the retrieval network.

But trust is hard in thin air. I pace the habitat, helmet clipped to my hip, rehearsing rescue routes the AI already calculated. ‘Let us do our job,’ it repeats in a calm that feels rehearsed. Outside, drones rise like silver kites, their LIDAR pulses sequencing the wasteland. Every beep could be her heartbeat.

I screen-share with the engineering crew on Olympus Station. They’ve rerouted satellites to stitch an improvised eye across the storm. The botanists loan their CO₂ scrubbers to fuel extra flight time. Funny—these people barely knew Mom. Now they barter research minutes for search minutes. Community crystallizes fast when air and love are equally scarce.

The storm’s edge glows copper on the horizon. Telemetry pings: unregistered heat signature, human-sized. I press my forehead to the viewport, pulse syncing with the drones’ wings. For a moment, weightlessness; then the certainty lands. She’s out there, and they’re closing in. I breathe once, twice, and let the network work—because they care as much as I do.

July 1944, somewhere between the crackle of radios and the rattle of train tracks. Mother disappeared during the night evacuations, swept into a different carriage while I clutched our single suitcase. Now the Red Cross barracks thrum with names shouted into echoing halls. Mine is one of them.

I keep a notebook: each stranger who says they’ll look for her earns a page. Sergeant Blume, whose boots still carry Normandy sand; Sister Anya, who stitches uniforms tighter so no pocket goes empty; the French boy, Luc, who sketches faces faster than fear erases them. Their small promises weave a net across borders larger than any map I own.

Sometimes the war’s roar drowns my ledger. Yet when telegraphs click, I imagine each dot-dash a footstep toward her. I practice hearing hope between the signals—an art Mother taught me when thunder threatened the orchard.

Tonight, I underline her name once more, ink pooling like mortar scars on paper. The list of helpers grows heavier than the silence. I fold the notebook, tuck it close to my heart, and lie down on a cot that smells of antiseptic and prayers. I must believe the world still tilts toward reunion.

Mom vanished at the intersection where the city’s augmented overlays glitch, where neon koi swim through brick walls and street names loop like broken vinyl. The authorities call it The Lapse, a cartographic blind spot no drone can map for longer than a breath.

I file a missing-person report that autocorrects itself into poetry. The clerk nods, says, “The Cartographers will take it from here.” I’ve never met a Cartographer; rumor paints them as monks with satellite halos, sipping algorithms instead of tea. Trust feels abstract—like leaning against a hologram—but I try.

Days blur. My phone vibrates with micro-updates: vector packets, spectral anomalies, echoes of Mom’s laugh refracted through data smear. Strangers forward the alerts without knowing me; a rideshare driver detours to scan alley QR ghosts; my landlord offers roof access for signal triangulation. Their kindness arrives in pixels and pastries.

Tonight the sky fissures into emerald gridlines. A silhouette steps through, holding a tote bag printed with my childhood doodles. The Lapse pulses, then seals behind her. As I sprint forward, I realize the city itself—obsidian servers, whispered code, ordinary hearts—conspired to guide her home. Faith, it seems, is a kind of urban infrastructure.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "She got to her feet, eyelid fluttering convulsively, putting the chairs between herself and where she’d heard him land."

responses.text:
Tasia’s breath rasped in her throat as she rose, ankle throbbing from the fall. The ballroom lay in shambles—silk banners torn, chandeliers moaning in their chains. She slipped behind an overturned chair, the velvet back a thin shield against what prowled the shadows.
